A hay cart passes you by, two children playing in the back. "Hey! Not fair, Isabelle!" The boy laughs and flails. His sister sits back down on a familiar looking chest. The one you found under a bridge, a little while ago.\n\nAs the children see you, they wave a friendly greeting, happily on their way to Sevenkeeps.
Wave back.

Somewhat out of place here, you find a beautiful cottage. There are nicely trimmed bushes, artistic flowerbeds, even a shell shaped fountain. Sadly, it is devastated by masses of the undead, and groaning and panting chokes the air.
Kill those appalling creatures.
Move up silently. Strike out of hiding.
With the undead dealt with, you are free to stroll through the beautiful gardens. Passing the estate, you see the main room adorned with lush rugs, a heavy chandelier and paintings on every wall.
Let's return to lady of the house.

Approaching the ruins of a slender elven tower, you see a group of men in Alluvyan colors shouting and pointing at something you cannot see.\n\nAs they spot you, they cry out: "These accursed ghosts keep attacking us! Help us fight them back and you can share the treasure we’ve found here!"
Attack the undead!
The ghosts must have had a reason to attack you.

A melodic voice interrupts you, whispering from the ruined tower.\n\nListening closely, you hear how an elven family hunted by Baron Meldec, centuries ago, sought refuge here. The whispers implore you to leave their resting place in peace, to drive off the men plundering their graves.
Attack the grave robbers.
Grab as much loot as you can and run.
Attack the undead.
You shake off the voice and order your company to hurry to the soldiers’ camp and grab their treasures while they fight the undead.\n\nYou hear angry shouts as you turn and flee, swearing revenge!
Fools! Keep watch over your treasures next time.

The soldiers thank you, but eye you warily as you approach their camp. A couple stand careful guard of the treasures they have pulled from the tower.\n\nWhen you demand your share, they only reluctantly part with a fraction of it.
Pleasure doing business with you.

Not far off the path lie dark ruins, crumbling walls reaching from the earth like twisted skeletal fingers. 

You step into the shadows, wondering what might await inside. As if to reply, a cold touch chills you to your bones.

When you look around, there is nothing but a dim stairwell down into the cellars that beckons to you.
Hello?!
Comb through the ruins above ground.
The cold materializes before you as a group of ghostly elven figures dressed in flowing, ornamental robes.\n\nThey sway back and forth, their mouths open in silent song.
Greet them.
Banish them before they cast some enchantment.
You must be Berenil’s ghost! IWe mean you no harm.

Searching the ruins, you conclude the castle was violently destroyed. There are claw marks on the walls and floor to suggest it was literally torn apart by its assailants.\n\nYou collect what you can find of use but suddenly notice the intensifying cold again.
Be prepared for a fight.
Wait what happens.
The ghosts withdraw a short distance, but silently cry out once more.
They are more afraid of us than we of them.

The tallest ghost floats forwards, extending her arms with her palms raised.\n\n"Listen, mortal! My name is Berenil. I was once leader of Dun Mael. Baron Meldec, our neighbor, was envious of the blessings Tiara bestowed upon us. He demanded I wed him. I tried to reason with him, offering Tiara’s blessing instead."
And then?

We were invited to his castle to enact our ritual dance, but Tiara’s blessing would not come. In his greed, Meldec made a pact with Nor, a renegade Guardian, to grant him the power to bind me to him forever.\n\nI resisted his sorcery, by Tiara’s grace, but he imprisoned us, swearing to sacrifice us to Nor to obtain our power. Blinded by hatred, he assumed some spell was at work.
Nor may have poisoned him with words. What then?

I knew my people would come for me. Much blood would be shed. I could not bear that burden, but nor could I let our souls be sacrificed. My sisters and I made a pact. We took each other’s lives before the Black Baron could.
You... you killed yourselves?!
It was our only choice. Had he sacrificed us, his powers would have become far greater. Either way, my people would have suffered his wrath.
I applaud your heroic sacrifice.
Tiara frowns on taking your own lives!
But... there are no elves in these hills anymore...
It is no different than dying in battle for the right cause. The ghost’s face becomes pained and sorrowful. "But a cruel twist of fate binds us here regardless."
What happened?

Our sacrifice was in vain. Meldec entered his pact with Nor promising the dark Guardian our souls on his own blood. With us dead, he feared Nor would take him.\n\nRather than face this, in panic he took his children to Nor’s shrine. His kin. His blood. He gave them to Nor to save himself.
Such depravity!
He tricked Nor, then? Interesting.
Indeed. But in denying ourselves as sacrifice, we doomed those innocents to death. We cannot rest until this foul deed has been avenged!
Does Meldec live too?

His pact left him trapped between life and death. Hidden from Hirin’s eyes he fell into insanity. No doubt, his sins weighed heavily on him.

Over time, he turned his troops to undeath and attacked Dun Mael, destroying it utterly. In return, our people raised the very forests around this place to obliterate it.

Ever since, he sits and broods in the shrine to his renegade Guardian. Go there. End this once and for all.
I will take care of it.
I will be interested to hear his side of things.
Think of all the knowledge he must have learned...
This is folly! He paid a great price for his power. So may you!
We shall see...

The ghostly figures begin to fade with a sigh on the wind. But Berenil stays for one moment longer, staring at you coldly.\n\n"We put all our hope in you, mortal. I pray to Tiara you will not fail us."
I will try my best.
Let's see.

You can see a swarm of undead and phantoms moving in the dark shadows of the keep.\n\nThe dark knight's hollow voice rings out: "So, what do you want, mortal?". He stands there motionlessly, awaiting your reply.
You must be Meldec. Prepare to meet your final fate!
Talk to Meldec.

The black baron laughs mirthlessly. "If you seek to gain the renegade god's secret knowledge, I can teach you the art of creating undead and ruling over them.\n\nWhat are you willing to give in return? Nor always expects a sacrifice."
Very well, give me your power and you shall receive my master's lore.
A small price to pay.

It starts and ends in blood. Nor will decide whose blood from those here shall be spilled.Then you shall get your reward. Know that there is more...much more to gain. Knowledge and power are the dark lord's gifts.
I hope it's worth it.

As the Black Baron falls, the ghosts of Berenil and her priestesses appear.

"You have done a great service to Tiara, and the world, by vanquishing this evil. Now we will finally know peace. May Tiara’s blessing be with you, always. Your noble deed shall resonate across all creation.

Take this accursed ground. With time, may your virtue cleanse it of its evil."
May Hirin bring you peace.
Approach the ghost.
Walk away quickly.
Walking quickly, you lose sight of him for a moment. Then, suddenly, he is standing in front of you.
What... Who are you? What do you want?
The name's Tum! Tum Barndell. I'm looking for our cow, Bessy.\n\nShe ran away when the bad people came. I have to bring her back home or my parents will be ever so angry with me.
She will be nothing but a bovine apparition by now!
How long have you been looking for that cow?
Who were the bad people?
We met that cow...
Ghostly tears form in the boy’s eyes.\n\n"I’m afraid the black coats will get to her before me. Will you help me catch her? I can’t go home without her!"
How would I hunt a ghost cow?
I will help you so you may find peace.
Where is your farm?
The boy shrugs.\n\n"Oh, it seems like forever that I've been running around these hills."
That sounds about right.
Bovine? No, her name's Bessy and she is the best milk cow we have.
I somehow doubt that.
The black coats. Baron Meldec’s men. Oh, me and my parents were right frightened when they came! They tried to take Bessy from us but she got loose and ran away!
Meldec? I have heard that name before...
Oh, thank thee kindly. My parents will be so happy when I tell them you’ll bring Bessy back!
Now, let's find her first.
I am sure you will find a way! You look quite clever, if I may say so. I bet you find her right quick!
If it will get you off my back, certainly.
I shall try and find her for you.
Not far! Just over yonder hills. Will you help me bring old Bessy home?
I will see what I can do.
A little ahead, you spot the shape of a ghostly cow grazing peacefully among some old ruins.
Approach slowly.
Shout at it.
Order her to you.
Bessy! Here, girl!
Trap the ghost with a ward.
The ghostly cow ignores you, trotting away and fading from view.
It's gone...
The ghost cow looks at you with big translucent eyes. \n\nIt seems to be waiting for something.
Now how do we get her to the child?

Suddenly, young Tum’s ghost appears next to you.

"Thank the kindly! I knew you would catch her. I can finally go home now!"

With that, the boy gives you one last wave and skips towards Bessy, then he and his cow fade before your eyes.
I am glad we did that.
You are called to the side of one of your companies one day because a group of ghosts in elven robes are blocking the path. They are beckoning to you with gaunt hands.
Better just back away from them.
Let's approach them.
I will try to banish them.
The gaunt figures swarm forward and quickly surround you, whispering of great shame that keeps them from leaving this world. Then cold hands touch you as the circle presses in.
What are you trying to tell us?!
With a glimmer of hope in their pale eyes, the ghosts ask you to seek out the Black Baron’s castle, to cleanse the evil within so they may rest in peace.
I will see what I can do.
Escorting your troops through the Dark Vale, you notice a group of black-clad undead approaching. They don’t appear intent on attack.
Do not attack yet. Let them speak.
Attack now, before they get closer.

The angry Baron cursed them for their insolence, decreeing they would never find rest nor respite until Berenil was brought before him. Since then they have roamed the realm to no avail.\n\nThey ask you to end their suffering if you can.
I will grant you this mercy.
I ban you from this world, ending your wandering.
If we find Berenil, they could be freed.
Their fate is not my concern.

While traveling, you hear a cheery but dissonant music, accompanied by the sound of voices singing slightly off pitch.\n\nIt’s coming from beyond a small copse. You think you can make out a glimmer of light there.
Ignore and press on.
Let's investigate.

As you round the copse, you are met by a strange sight:

Amid the crumbled walls of a ruined manor, you spy a long and richly laid table, platters of silver and goblets adorned with jewels. Dozens of ghosts sit around it, all singing raucously or playing various instruments. They are having a great time.

And as they see you, they beckon for you to join them in their merriment.
Sure. Why not?
I think I will simply observe.
The ghosts cry out: "Don’t just stand there! Come and join the party!"\n\nYou feel yourself inexorably drawn towards the ghosts.
I… Alright… Yes, I will.

Now you are closer to the table, you see the plates and goblets are real enough but the ghosts are using their own translucent cutlery and tableware.

The guests all look at you expectantly, raising their ghostly glasses.

"Well, stranger? What entertainment have you brought us?"
I've got a folktale you might enjoy.
I am a magician! Here are some magic fireworks!
This is ludicrous.
This party's over. Attack!
Grab some of the tableware and run!

The party applauds enthusiastically. You are soon surrounded by singing and dancing ghosts and all your minds are filled with music, laughter and wild merriment.

You are not sure what happens next but you awaken in the morning, lying on the damp ground with a terrible headache. Next to you is a half-buried silver plate. Digging it up, you find more of the tableware. The air echoes with music and laughter.

You take the treasure with you, confident it is a sign of gratitude.
A night to remember. Thank you, kind hosts!
The hosts’ ghostly faces all turn to frightening grimaces.\n\n"Spoilsport! Party pooper!" they cry, racing to attack you.
That escalated quickly.

Victorious, you look around you - but where there were richly lain tables before, there now are only crumbled ruins and grass.\n\nYou think you hear a faint echo of laughter as you make your way back to your path...
That was an exceedingly strange encounter.
Some women and children have gathered in front of the local tavern. One of the women is talking to a bored looking man, growing increasingly distressed with every word.
I'll listen in.

A heart warming smile brightens her face, and she wipes tears from the corners of her eyes.

"I'll not forget this! Thank you! You hear that, Sophie? They're going to save your daddy and bring him home! We must always remember them."

The girl nods absent mindedly.
We'll return when we can.

The woman turns towards you with a furrowed brow.\n\n"Husband, actually! Yesterday he and a few others made a bet. They wanted to see which of them was bravest by taking something from the old ruins. But none of them ever returned. I am so worried about my Benjamin. I swear to the Guardians, this place is cursed!"
We'll find your husband.

The ruins hint at a time of beauty and culture, but all their high arches and elegant pillars are long overgrown with ferns and moss.\n\nAll the same, you know magic when you feel it, and it is still at work here.
Let's investigate. But be careful!

In the quiet that falls after the battle, you hear sobbing coming from back towards the village. Scanning the landscape, you see the young girl, Sophie, hiding away from the ruins. When she sees you spot her, she runs away, wailing.\n\nOne of the men has dropped a glyph engraved goblet. As you pick it up, you feel the pull at your will, but you place it back on the statue before it takes hold and your mind comes to rest.
We should leave, before Sophie reaches the locals.

The young couple stare in wonder as you concoct the most beautiful drinks they have ever seen right in front of them.\n\n"Will you stay a while and drink with us?" the bride asks gleefully as you set her glass down on the table.
Very well. Tonight we drink.
The young couple thanks you for your generosity, and the village elders nod approvingly. They all insist on you staying for the feast, with a bard tuning up a lute to get the evening underway.
We'll stay a little longer then.

Come one, come all! The bard grins at the crowd. "Will it be a tale of joy for the happy couple? Or a story of fear, to rouse the blood and excite the spirits?"

"A happy tale!" the groom calls back.

"No, no!" His beloved taps him gently on the arm to the laughter of many. "Let's give ourselves more reason to drink!"
Let's have a scary story.
Let's have a happy story.

The bard clears her throat and sets down her lute, holding her hands up high.\n\n"On a dark summer's night, not unlike tonight, a nobleman threw a splendid party. He had thrown many such a party, where every guest was asked to perform for the others. Artful or silly, joyous or dramatic, each performance was cheered on by the crowd. Except one, at this celebration. A local baron, an evil man and a practitioner of the dark arts, used his performance to put a curse on the entire room! The laughter and cheering that had made the nobleman so much more popular than the baron would never cease. Some say, you can still hear it today, from the ruins of his manor. Some say, if you ever go there, you will foever be a guest to their merriment."
What a fascinating tale.

Further down the road, you see a familiar wagon overflowing with wares of all kinds. The wheel has been reattached now, but it looks as though the driver, with all his rotting teeth, has stopped for a break. He hasn't yet spotted you.
Well... let's see what happens this time.
Not this joker again. Let's find another way around.
You... must have me mistaken for someone else! he laughs. "I am but a humble merchant, trying to ply my trade..."
Enough! This is getting sad now.
The old man gasps and puts a hand to his wounded heart.\n\n"Oh, what must people think of old travelers on the road? Accusing them of being petty thieves..."
Stop. You aren't fooling anyone.

As you come up on the wagon and its 'merchant' rider, he lifts his head and gives you a wide, disgusting grin.\n\n"Hello, fellow travelers! My name is De..." As he recognizes you he falters. "Er, Deacon! My name is Deacon! I'm waiting here for escort! The nights are dangerous, and I fear bandits! Would you mind staying here tonight and travelling the road tomorrow together?"
We know it's you, Derrek. Stop with the games.
So that you can rob us blind in the night?
Derrek slumps and then shrugs, whistling his band of outlaws out of the bushes. They all give you an unimpressed look, keeping their hands on the hilts or grips of their various poorly made weapons.
Must we really do this again?
The band of robbers lies defeated before you, but Derrek vanishes in the midst of the fight. The wagon, though, is left behind, with plenty of items of worth for the taking.
Let's hope we never see him again.

You come upon a camp where most of the travelers are watching a heated debate between a woman and a large, tattooed man. When she sees you approach, the woman immediately halts the discussion, and her face lights up.\n\n"Good day! Are you perhaps interested in earning some coin? We lost our supplies, and need quite desperate help retrieving them."

She keeps up the friendly smile, but her eyes grow cold and hard.

"That's too bad. Safe travels."

Everyone in the camp keeps a careful eye on you as you walk away.
Let's hurry.

The woman indicates a dark, thick forest not far off.\n\n"We were just passing through when we were attacked. Wolves, I think. Loud and far too close for comfort. We had to run before we could get a good idea of just how many there were."
We'll head that way then.
Not far off your path, a wagon lies toppled over. Several barrels smelling of soured grapes are scattered and broken around it. Behind the crash, you can make out weak groans.
Investigate the noises.
Take what plunder you can.
Walk on. This doesn't concern us.

Behind the wagon, you find an old, frail merchant.\n\n"Thank you for stopping, strangers. My horses bolted, and I lost control of them. Could I trouble you with helping to repair the damage? And possibly catching my horses?"
All around the wagon lie people and horses, all dead. They look as though they died in a lot of pain, with dried blood encrusting their noses and ears.
Loot everything you can find.
Don't get close. Let's go.
We should burn the corpses.

Around the wagon lie several dead guards, shafts sticking from their chests. A wounded merchant sees you and weakly lifts a blood stained hand.

"Orcs... That way..."

Their arm falls limp as they give their last breath.
Follow the orcs' trail.
Loot whatever you can find.
Around the wagon, you find several dead guards, slain by orcish weapons.
Let's find those orcs.
Loot whatever the orcs didn't.

You start scavenging the wagon's remains, but an angry voice shouts out from amongst the wreckage.

"Robbers! Taking advantage of another's misfortune! This is a delivery for the king! You'll pay for this! Look! Guards!"

Indeed, as the merchant runs off, you see a crowd of riders approaching from that direction.
Quickly! Flee!
They don't stand a chance. Attack!
It's not what it looks like...!

As you continue on, someone calls out to you.

"Don't think I didn't see you there! What kind of people ignore someone else's plight?! Leave me to rot by the wayside, would you? I'm delivering wine to the king's steward! He will hear of this!"

Indeed, not far off, you see riders approaching under a great banner.

"Ah! See?! Here they come now! Riders! Riders! These scoundrels were going to rob me!"
It's time for us to go!
Draw your weapons! Engage the riders!
Excuse me?! We were doing no such thing!
As you continue on, you hear an elderly dwarven voice call out.\n\n"Please, kind strangers, don't leave me here. I can pay you for the effort!"
Move on!
Help lift the wagon!
Take his wares. He can't stop us.
When you set the bodies aflame, the air fills with an acrid, nauseating smoke.
Let's leave before we catch whatever killed them.
As flies buzz and the very air seems to rot, you take what little you can find on the dead.
Let's not stay any longer than we must.
You try to argue your innocence, but the merchant shouts over your protests and spurs the riders to engage you. Weapons drawn, they charge at your group.
To arms, troops!

Together, the wagon is righted. The old dwarf explains that he lost control of his horses. They are not far down the road, and your troops manage to corral them. The dwarf sets about reparing the wagon.\n\n"Thank you kindly, strangers. Please, take this. It shan't be said that this old man is ever ungrateful!"
Thank you. Safe travels.
There may be more to gain. Loot him.
The old dwarf cries out despairingly, begging for his life as your soldiers rifle through his things.
That's enough. Let's move on.
Leave no witness.
Following the orcs' tracks, you quickly catch up to them. They have stopped for the day, and are celebrating their successful raid. Drunken laughter ripples through the camp.
They'll never see me coming.
Strike them down!
Call out to them.
Elynn makes short work of the drunken guards, interrupting the celebration like a whirlwind tearing through their ranks. The orcs desperately call to arms, staggering forwards with an angry roar.
Charge now!
The orcs stagger around in surprise as you hail them. A big warrior at the center of the camp shouts: "Piss off! This is my loot!"
We shall see about that. Attack!
Alright. We'll leave you to it.
And we toast to your victory! No need for bloodshed.
These orcs were tougher than you expected.
Next time perhaps.
Finally! The orc roars with laughter. "Someone who knows I, Bonesplitter, am to be feared in these parts! Come then! Drink with us."
Our pleasure, great chief.
Approaching this bridge, you spot something underneath it. A simple, wooden chest - not locked, but nailed shut.
Let's crack it open.
Leave it be. Let's move on.
Inside, you find a bundle of clothes, some rations and a little gold. An unsealed letter falls to the ground as you rummage through the clothes.
Read the letter.
Take the coins and leave.

'Dear brother,

Let's meet tomorrow. I've saved enough money for us to travel to Sevenkeeps. I am yet to find a way to make a living there, but don't you worry. I will take care of us. I promise.

Love, Isabelle

P.S.: Try not to anger your stepmother too much tonight. I can't bear you getting hurt again.'
Take the coin. We need it.
Leave it be and move on.
Let's make their journey to Sevenkeeps easier.

You see two haggard and dirty children sitting on a boulder. The younger of the two seems to be in a lot of pain, and the older one is bandaging his foot with an old shirt. By her feet, you see a familiar looking small, wooden chest, that you once found under a bridge.
You shouldn't leave your possessions under bridges.

Rounding a bend, you come across a small wagon by the side of the road. It is packed with an assortment of wares: pots and pans, musical instruments, potions and trinkets stacked on high. As you approach, you hear muttering and cursing from behind the wagon.
Are you all right there?
Walk on by! We don't have time for this.

The merchant grins an even broader grin, showing yet more of the rotting holes.

"Crippling addiction, I'm afraid," he laughs. "Sweeties! I can't get enough of them. In fact..." He looks around and then puts his hand to his mouth and gives a sharp whistle. The bushes rustle, and a whole group of outlaws appears.

"My friends and I would love to know if you have any we can take right now!" Derrek gives you a coy smile.
A trap?! We will not go quietly! Attack!

As you trudge closer to the cart, Derrek puts a hand to his mouth and whistles sharply. The bushes all around you rustle, and a whole band of outlaws appears, laughing. Derrek pulls a sword from behind his back.\n\n"Your sweeties or your lives!" he cries. "What have you got for us today!"
A trap?! Attack!
Wait... Sweeties?!

That's right! Derrek exclaims proudly. "We'll let you walk if you hand over your sweetest meals! We've all got to eat, haven't we, my merry warriors!"\n\nThe bandits chortle, all now brandishing weapons at your troupe.
Fine. Here. Take some sweeties.
We don't have anything to give you.
Well then! The outlaws all ready themselves for a fight while Derrek shouts. "It looks like you offer your lives!"
So be it. Attack them!
This is ridiculous. I refuse to fight you over this.

Like excited children, Derrek and his band of outlaws all rush towards the rations you pass over to them, and immediately begin to squabble over who gets what. Not a single one of them pays any attention to you after that.
Let's just leave. We've wasted enough time here.

You slay most of the robbers, but during the fight Derrek seems to vanish. When it is all over, only the wagon stands quiet nearby. While your soldiers are rooting through it, one passes you a medallion they find amongst the wares: a collection of ornate symbols representing the Thieves' Guild.
I'll keep hold of this. Let's go.
Your soldiers are beaten by the robbers, and Derrek disappears away from the battle as if he was never there.
Damn it.

You enter a small town, where the homes are little more than hovels. Only one building stands out, a full three stories high with white washed walls. Without a doubt, this is the home of a noble family.

A notice is hung on the elegant fence.

'The lady will reward anyone brave enough to clear her home of Darkvale's undead. For more information, come inside.'
That could be quite a sum. Let's go inside.
This is no interest to us.

You find yourself in a spacious hallway, double doors leading left and right. A young boy in servant's clothes approaches you.

"Have you come to clear the house? You sure look capable. The Lady is offering a cassette of gold to anyone successful."

He indicates a large wooden box, ornamented with iron.
Agreeable. We'll do it.

You order your units to a halt as you see a translucent shape wandering about.\n\nIt appears to be the ghostly figure of a young boy in a wide-brimmed hat, searching for something and shouting with an inaudible voice.
You come across a few farm houses, strangely well preserved but empty of life. It seems they have been recently abandoned.
Investigate.
Stay away.

As you cautiously enter the village, there are echoes of voices crying out for help and the sound of fighting.\n\nAll of a sudden, the ground comes to life as skeletal hands dig their way up through the dirt!
Keep the undead away!
Revenge Hot As Coals
Follow The Tracks
You stop in your tracks as you come to a copse of trees. Grazing on the grass is a magnificent golden stag. It looks right at you, poised to flee.
Shoot it. Quickly!
Shots fly, but the stag is quicker, breaking away as your missiles pierce the ground uselessly.\n\nBefore it vanishes into the trees, you think you see the stag change shape.
What was that?
Too late, the majestic animal realizes the danger. It staggers to the ground before it can flee, mortally wounded by your attack.
This will yield valuable research.
The stag sniffs the air, then suddenly bolts before your trap is even sprung. You watch it run, but shake your head as you think you see it change its shape. Then it's gone.

The great stag looks at you with kind eyes and slowly bows its majestic head. You hear a sound like small bells jingling in the distance and smell a summer's breeze passing you by, filled with life and warmth.
We have been blessed.

Glancing up from your studies, you see a streak of golden light, shooting through the sky. Then another. Then another, until it seems the sky is alight with them! Where the lights hit the ground, explosions follow. Meteors! But so many?! This is unheard of, since the fall of the Hybernian Empire!\n\nWhatever these celestial signs may fortell, the meteors' Sky Iron is sure to be worth much to whoever can find it first.
I'll track where they landed.
This meteor has laid a castle to ruin, part of the walls and main tower destroyed by the impact. You can see something moving about in the rubble.
Let's take a look.

It is clear that this castle was lived in. Soldiers and peasants move about with grim faces, tending to the wounded and burying those killed in the disaster. It is devastation. Many just stare across the rubble, still in shock.
As you approach, you see a group of men in rugged cloth accompanied by various beasts digging through the rubble, no doubt seeking the same prize as you.
Elven Ruins
Forlorn Village
Amidst the smoldering ruins, the moving shapes take on strange forms that you cannot recognize. Whatever the meteor brought here, it is not of this world.
The impact into the stone walls has shattered much of the meteor to pieces and it takes a while to dig it out of the rubble. But finally, you have what you came for: Sky Iron!
Collect what you can!
You have missed this opportunity to collect the Sky Iron. No doubt it will have been claimed before you return.
Curses!
Let's do what we can to help them.
Get rid of them. The meteor belongs only to me.
Get the wounded healed.
They've suffered enough. Let's leave them in peace.

Your healers do all they can to ease the suffering of the wounded. The locals thank you for your kindness, insisting on giving you what little of value they can spare. Those able to help you commence the search for your prize.
Let's get to work.

You make your first priority helping the survivors and burying those who were killed. The locals are grateful for your kindness and offer to help you dig through the debris for your prize, despite their exhaustion.
You rest. We will manage alone.
Your help is what's due in return for ours.
As you approach the hole in the earth that the meteor's impact created, you can make out movement in the dark. Several figures are moving about in the dark hole.
Approach, but slowly.
You have missed your opportunity to claim this prize.
A pity!

A bloody battle with the dwarves ensues, but you remain victorious. As you finally enter the tunnel, led by the meteor's faint glow, you marvel at the beauty of the shining rock. The name Sky Iron does it a disservice.
Claim all you can!

Cautiously, your troops make their way down the hole. There, a band of dwarves are already working to mine the metal and their leader, face and clothes smeared with earth and soot, steps forwards.\n\n"I'm afraid you're too late, friends. This is our dig and you need to leave. No one gets to take the Sky Iron but Godwin Gorrasson, not while I live and breathe! "
Surely we can share these heavenly gift, kin?

Yngrid goes off for heated debate amongst the dwarves, passing around drinks, making loud and obnoxious jokes, smiling, laughing and making merry while the rest of you wait with decreasing patience. Eventually, she does return.\n\n"It's not going to be much," she admits. "But I managed to make them split the prize if we promise to keep it a secret."
That seems fair.
You approach the location where the meteor hit the ground and see that it opened up a submerged Allfire node, glowing with magical power.
Get closer.
You step closer, but are surprised by an angry roar! A group of creatures emerge from the node, surrounded by a magical glow.
Sevenkeeps
You have missed your chance to take hold of the fallen star.
Curses!

The creatures must have been disturbed by the fallen star but now you are free to salvage the massive black rock.\n\nIt seems the allfire node's activity depends on the rocks presence, though, as the meteor acts as a conductor to its flow. If you salvage the sky iron meteor, the node may dissipate.
Leave the sky iron and gain what might I can draw from the node.
Take the sky iron to the tower for refinement.
An eerie glow accompanied by a shrill ringing sound in your head greets you as you approach the glowing node.
Better leave quickly, this sounds dangerous.
Best stay back. Let me examine it.
Approach cautiously.

Borostor trudges towards the node, and the ringing heightens in your ears. Suddenly, the ground around erupts violently with a bright light and the black meteor is torn into a thousand shards that rip into your undead champion. Temporarily blinded, you turn to see Borostor removing a shard of black crystal from between his ribs.\n\n"Ouch," he says, flinging it to the ground with disdain.

As your troops approach, the ringing in your ears heightens, and the ground at your feet cracks open violently.\n\nYour soldiers are ripped by a thousand shards as the earth erupts all around them and the meteor splinters into pieces.
Look for remaining pieces to be salvaged.
There are some larger shards to be salvaged , but certainly not the amount of sky iron you might have hoped for.
Collect what you can.
Look for remaining pieces to be salvaged.
Perhaps I was seeing things.
The Golden Stag
When you catch up to the majestic animal, you nervously discover it has changed into a giant bear!
Shoot from afar, before it catches our scent!
Sneak closer to get a better shot.
Let me take the shot.
We should just leave it in peace.

As if it hears you, the animal lifts its head and stares at you with empathetic eyes. You are overwhelmed by a sense of love for creation, that moves you to your core. Blinking away tears, you want to reach out for the great beast. But it has already vanished from sight.
Alright. Enough now.
The creature flees before you can strike the mortal blow, vanishing into the bushes.
Again?
Damn this beast!
The great beast staggers and then collapses as the mortal blow is landed, dying as graciously and peacefully as it ever lived.
This will be a great research project!
People for miles around will know of this achievement!
How do you 'lose' supplies?
We have no time for this.
Sure. We'll help.
Lost Supplies
You hear the wolves before you see them. A whole pack has taken over the camp. Some are fighting over rations and meats. Some are resting or asleep. It is clear they haven't caught your scent yet.
We'll make short work of them.
You are slowly overwhelmed by their strength.
Curses!
Take what valuables you can.
What caused your animals to run?
Honestly? I have no idea. Stupid, skittish animals. Get scared by their own shadows sometimes.
Let's get the wagon upright then.
We will look for the horses.
Together, you quickly have the wagon back on its wheels, and you help the merchant load up the scattered wares.\n\n"Thank you!" the merchant groans. "Most kind. Take this, as a token of gratitude."
We'll be on our way then.
We will help round up the horses too.
You follow the horses' tracks to a small valley. Down below, you see them lying dead, with a number of decaying corpses quarreling over them.
Undead! Attack!

With the undead dealt with, you return to the merchant and wagon. The merchant laments the loss of his horses, but is grateful to have escaped himself, and packs up what he can to travel to the next village on foot.
Good luck on your journey.

You return to the wagon and warn the merchant of the nearby undead. He asks to travel with you to the next farm, just to be safe.\n\n"Take what you need from my wares. Better you have it than the undead!"
That's most gracious of you.
{amount}\n{delta:+-n}

Sifting through your materials, you notice a set of strangely marked bones. The carvings indicate some sort of notation system, but you cannot quite make sense of it. However, the bones emit a small magical aura.\n\nThe bones must have been taken from remains in one of the nearby ruins. Perhaps you can investigate them further.
{Value:+-c} from locations
{Value:+-c} for unit upkeep
{Value:+-c} from [mMight] distribution
[mMastery]
[mResearch]
Mastery

As you travel, lush, golden fields turn to a charred, bleak landscape. A burned out farmstead stands in the ashes like blackened bones.\n\nA middle-aged man, tan skin and sun bleached hair, leans on a dead tree, overlooking the damaged grounds, mumbling to himself.
Approach him and listen.
Walk away. He is busy.

You take time to wander the ruins, inspecting every corner. A rustling makes you turn around. Suddenly, you are face to face with a group of men, all with strangely glowing eyes and slack faces. Behind them is a statue, out of place as it is entirely untouched by time. If the men are cursed, that is likely the source.\n\nAs soon as your eyes meet those mens', they howl with inhuman voices, rushing forward to attack.
Destroy the statue!
Defend yourselves!
Celebration
An interesting story.

There once was a girl who lived all alone,
her parents were taken by spirits from home.
She walked into town to sell apples and pears,
Ignoring the people and all of their stares.

She skipped down the road, day after day,
'Til one day it changed to her utter dismay,
for a well had appeared where before there was none,
Beautiful, golden, hole swallowing the sun.

As she flipped just one coin into the deep well,
A secret she murmured, a wish she did tell.
'I wish that I weren't so completely alone,'
she said to the well, before skipping on home.

But when she got home, to her utter delight,
her parents she saw! What a glorious sight!
'Til the end of their days, they stayed all together,
And they lived quite happily, for ever and ever.

That depends. Derrek shrugs. "Do you have any sweeties for us? We'll take coin too - we really are just trying to get by."\n\nAfter a long pause for thought he adds, "And, err, this time it comes with a promise. You help us out now, and I promise you'll never see us again!"
We certainly won't. Kill these fools.

Derrek and his band of robbers all crowd around the rations you give him, quickly squabbling over who gets what. They immediately seem to forget that you even exist, walking back to their wagon to share their meal quite happily.
I never want to see any of you again.
Until next time, Derrek.

Derrek vanishes in the midst of the fight, but when the rest of the robbers have been dealt with, the wagon seems left untouched. While rifling through its contents for things of value, one of your soldiers finds an intricately designed token bearing the marks of the Thieves' Guild.
I suppose this might come in useful.

Trusting to Seshi's judgment, you engage Derrek in small talk. As he proudly tells you how he got into the sweetie robbing business, she moves over to the wagon, taking an obviously curious look at all the wares before going the long way around back to your side.

With some laborious effort, you convince the robbers to let you pass without conflict. When they are safely behind you, Seshi quietly hands you an intricately crafted token.

"This was in his pocket," she quietly reports. "A Thieves' Guild token. He is likely an informant."
Intriguing. Thank you, Seshi.

Derrek chuckles to himself as he catches the bag of coin you throw in his direction. He counts every coin before flashing you another rotten, toothy grin.\n\n"A pleasure doing business with you again."
Goodbye, Derrek!
While the robbers deal with your troops, Derrek runs off and disappears into the trees.
Curse this man and his sweeties!
Scry on the bones.
You attune yourself to the bones and trace their magical aura back to where they were found. After some deliberation you can locate the place - a ruin not far from your tower.
Search the surrounding sites.
Read up in the library.
I wonder what we will find there.

Rummaging through your books, you eventually find passages on orc and troll shamans using such bones as a way to store the power of summoned spirits. You cannot make out any active spirit bound to the bones you have found, but there may be a chance you can find out more wherever they were taken from.
Use them to narrow down the source location.
Use them for other research.
Bone Spirits
This overgrown ruin was once an outpost for a minor Highmark noble's house. It was destroyed during the War of Six Races, but nothing from that time remains.
There are no bones here.
{Value:+-c} from tower
Bone Spirits
You find very scuffed, but recent, tracks in the ruin. You may not be alone here.
Start searching for the bones.
Let's wait and ensure we're alone.
Finding no other occupants, you dig through the rubble until you find an old gravestone. Only once it has been completely exhumed do you realize that there is nothing here that will help you.
Unfortunate. Let's go.
Not long into your search, it is interrupted by a loud noise.\n\nLooking about, you see a large bear erupting from one of the broken towers, charging towards you quickly.
Grab your weapons!
Lying in wait, you hear a snuffling and scratching, and before long a giant bear emerges from one of the ruined towers. It does not seem to have caught your scent yet.
Leave it be. We'll return another time.
Bone Spirits

These ruins show obvious traces of ancient battlegrounds, with many skeletons and broken weapons littering the place. One of the towers is relatively intact, and by a crumbling wall there is a stairway that looks like it might lead to a cellar. A little further away, there is a small and nondescript earthen mound.
Search the tower.
Search the cellar.
Search the mound.
I'll find the bones quickly.
As you make your way closer to the earthen mound, you see rusted spears and pieces of armor carefully placed in the tall grass. Some small number of the battle's fallen soldiers were buried here.
Start digging!
Exhuming the grave will offend the spirits. Let's leave.

Apprehensively, your troops start digging into the mound. Soon, you find yet more skeletons, and all kinds of rusting and rotten armor.\n\nDigging deeper, an angry, moaning wail escapes from the earth, and a hoarde of ghostly figures quickly rises up around you, visibly angered.
Push them back!

Defeated, the spirits fade, letting you continue your work. Eventually, you find a red totem bag, filled with bones carved similarly to the ones you found in your tower. They will come in useful. But, as you pack up to leave, the angry moans of ghosts start to fill the whole ruin, swearing revenge on all defilers.
It's time for us to leave.

Searching the cellar reveals nothing but more signs of heated battles. Most of the skeletons here are of humans and orcs, with torn and faded banners harkening all the way back to the War of the Six Races so many years ago.\n\nSadly, though, there are no signs of any strangely marked bones.
Let's search elsewhere.

Wishing Well
You hear a high pitched clink-clink as the coin bounces off the stones and splashes into the water. A moment later, the rope stretches taut, as if a weight pulls down on it.
Haul the rope up.
You hear a splash as the coin hits the surface of the water with the sound of something bubbling in a swamp. Nothing else happens.
The coin you toss hits the well's roof and jumps out of sight.
Let's go. This isn't worth it.
On the end of the rope, you pull up a bucket with a nice amount of shimmering coins inside.
Thank you, Lady Luck.
The moment you touch the rope, it goes limp again, and as you pull it up, you see the end has frayed and rotted away.
Curse my luck.
Tinkered
Loaded with elemental magic
Grants elemental damage bonus per stack
Assault

Applies "Armorbreak"

You toss and turn in your bed, haunted by the strangest images. After hours spent struggling to sleep, you sit up, but you find yourself surrounded by an eerie, impenetrable fog. All around you, ethereal whispers float by. It is a dream! It must be!
Walk into the fog.
Try to wake up.
Something shifts beneath the earth, then bursts from it like some great worm. A tomb, ancient and resolute. You must go there.
And I will.
A cave in the distance is growing bigger and bigger, swallowing the entire world beneath your feet. You must visit this cave.
I will find the time.
Your mind is suddenly bombarded with a stream of thoughts that are not your own. Information comes and goes, leaving you feeling a little light headed, but empowered.
What can we learn in our dreams?

You close your eyes and will yourself to wake.\n\nA new sensation, comforting like the touch of a loved one, spreads through you. You dare to open your eyes, and you find yourself back in your bed. You feel as relaxed and rejuvenated as you ever have.
A strange but comforting dream.

You try with all your might to will yourself awake, but a tremor shakes the very world beneath your feet. You are dazed, winded, gasping for air!\n\nAnd then you awaken, feeling drained and clammy in your own sweat.
What a nightmare.

You stand there for a while, listening to the whispers. Hours turn into weeks before they etch themselves into words, familiar and logical.\n\nWhen you awaken the next morning, your mind is teeming with knowledge you thought lost or forgotten.
I shall write this all down at once!
Haul up the rope.

You are surprised to hear the coin land with a wooden thud. Glancing down into the well, you don't see any kind of bucket. Even pulling the rope up a little, there is nothing that could possibly explain the noise.
I need someone to explore this well.
Let's go. This isn't worth it.

You have someone carefully descend down on a fresher rope. With some effort, your stronger soldiers manage to drag them back onto solid ground, holding a small, wooden chest. Inside, you find a parchment full of scrawled notes.
This will help my research greatly.

Meldec? This must have been centuries ago...
I have no intention of running after a ghostly cow.
Oh. Of course. You have more important things to do! … I understand.\n\nThe boy is clearly crestfallen.
What a strange ghost...
Ghostly Prison
Castle Meldec
The dark figure looks up at you: "Of course, once you have tasted the power, there is really nothing else, is there? What will it be this time?"
Did you think I would squander Nor's secrets so readily? Fools! You have fed me enough power now to take you all!
I am not afraid of you, shadow! Face us!

The Baron's laughter echoes in the hills as he roams the lands again.\n\n"You set me free, you fool! I will destroy you and raise an army from your corpses! This prison of mine will crumble to dust and I shall spread death all across the Highmark!"
That did not go well...
The Ghost Cow

An inn greets you with the smell of grilled meat, and a simple tune played upon a fiddle.\n\nThere seems to be a wedding in progress - the whole village has joined in the festivities. Houses are adorned with garlands of flowers and everyone is dressed in bright colors.
Let's join the party.

Screams ring out as skeletons and decaying corpses burst from the local graves, moaning and chattering as they all line up next to each other and begin to move in stilted, awkward steps. The young couple run as far as their legs can carry them, and the alarm bells ring out! Some of the villagers shout as they collect torches and pitch forks.\n\n"Necromancer!" their leader yells. "Leave our village be, or we will drive you from it!"
Oh, relax. They're just here to dance.
We keep hearing stories about a wishing well...
Strange Dreams

Obviously, this is not the exact, world-eating cave of your dreams, but you certainly feel as if you are in the right place.

The hole in the earth has been hacked at, as though by a maniac with a pickaxe. More likely, it was not made by any humanoid.

You follow the large, rounded tunnel deep into the earth until it branches different ways. To the left, a rough path trodden by hundreds of feet. To the right, a glint of daylight.
The left tunnel must be what we are looking for.
It is only sensible to go right.
You trudge back towards the surface. As you climb out in this new space, you see all sorts of bones. A feeding ground, of some kind.
Maybe there are some valuables about.
Let's leave before whatever eats here returns.
You dig through the bones and dirt, filling your pockets with a small number of treasures. But behind you, noises begin to come from the cave.
It's time for us to leave.
A large cavern opens up. Before you lie hundreds of beetles. They are still. Dead? Or just sleeping?
Let's take what we can before they move.
We cannot risk our necks here. Out.
You move as carefully as you can, taking what you can. As you tug at what you think is an old wing though, it jerks back. To your horror, you realize this bug is very much alive.
To arms!
Strange Dreams
You almost miss the tomb, so weathered beyond recognition is its headstone. But it is here. Smaller than in your dream, but otherwise exactly the same.
Start digging!
You take your troops to a local tavern, becoming witness to a performance from a drunken dwarf. He bangs his mug on the table as he sings, keeping rhythm to his chant.
Listen in.

Fine metals and jewels we find while you sleep. 
Magic and stories and secrets they keep.
Burrow deep. Burrow, burrow deep.
Wealth and riches we find and we reap.
Burrow deep. Burrow, burrow deep.

Ruins of old we uncover below.
Inside the mountain where deep we will go.
The magic is older than all that we know.
Burrow deep. Burrow, burrow below.
Wealth and riches we find and we reap.
Burrow deep. Burrow, burrow deep.

Old ruins and glyphs we found in the mine.
For passage you need a magical sign.
To reach the riches down in their shrine.
Burrow deep. Burrow, burrow fine.
Wealth and riches we find and we reap.
Burrow deep. Burrow, burrow deep.
Stay for another verse.
Okay. We can go.
Fine. One more then.
Let's go before he starts again.
Those are some strange lyrics. Are they a legend?
XP
[research]+{Points}\n({OneTimePoints})[/]
{Value:+-c} in Storage
Halberdiers
Phalanx
Lights in the Night

It is not long past nightfall in this town that you see a small light bobbing up and down in the distance. It might be from a torch or latern if it weren't blue. Some of the people tell you such lights have been bothering them for weeks. Perhaps someone is trying to scare them?
Follow the light.
It could be a will-o-wisp. Best be careful.

The dwarf is far too drunk to give a satisfying answer.

"Aye! Mah... Mah famly found... Said ya need to... two... two key t'enter. T' pay off the guards. But I wasn' reliable, they said! Bunch of pricks. 't must be in da mountains... If only I noo..."

His head suddenly hits the table, and he snores loudly. You try to wake him, but he is out cold.
This might just be worth investigating.
You follow the will-o-wisp at ample distance. It leads you to a small pond that glitters enticingly. In the moonlight, you see the shadows of spiders hiding in the trees.

You follow the light, hoping to catch the culprit red handed. Despite your best efforts to catch it, you never seem to close the distance. Too late you realize you have followed a will-o-wisp into the darkness and it has led you right into a large sinkhole! You pull back quickly, but it is too late for some of your troops.
How foolish of us!
Strike now, before we lose them!
There is no need for us to endanger ourselves.
When the last spider falls, you search around and find some possessions of those unfortunate enough to have been lured to their death here.
Let's leave this place.
The will-o-wisp leads you to a mushroom circle that oozes some strange mucus. Likely poisonous. You carefully take a sample and have it brought to your tower. It might be useful in your research.
Time worth spent.

With ample distance to the light and sharp sense, you can pick out the large sink hole it is leading you towards. In the darkness, you can make out bones and the smell of rot. The wisps must have been the death of a number of animals and people.
Loot the corpses.
Let's not disturb the dead.
Your group carefully tugs some items free of the sinkhole, collecting it together before morning comes.
Let's go now.

Please, sir! I know you didn't like my Ben all that much, but someone has to go looking! You are the best in town! I'd go myself if it weren't for my Sophie here. I can't leave my little girl! What if something happens to me too?!

The man frowns, and spits on the floor.

"You're right, I didn't care much for him. He broke my nose last year! Why should I go looking for that pig?"
What's this about a lost pig?

They speak to you haltingly, with hollow voices.\n\nThey were once Baron Meldec’s soldiers. He once ruled these lands and was obsessed with a priestess of Tiara named Berenil. The soldiers were asked to take her prisoner, but after Berenil’s pleas they refused the order.
But why are you now undead?

Close
Are you... threatening us for sweets?!
This is just local drama. Let's leave.
The woman gives you directions to the ruin, then sheepishly offers you a meager coin purse.
If we come across this ruin, we'll look for them.
We'll report back when we can.
Her shoulders start shaking with silent sobs.\n\n"I... I don't have any more! Please! I beg you, bring my husband home!"
Fine! We'll do what we can.
Find someone else.
Benjamin? Are you here? Your wife sent us!

Further down the road, a couple of men are standing with their backs to you. One seems to hear your call, turning around slowly. His staring eyes glow, and his head is cocked to one side. The magic of this place must have overwhelmed him.\n\nHe twists and fights through different emotions, as though calling his name weakened the spell for a moment.
Benjamin! Wake up!
They are forsaken. Kill them all!
