Wishing Well
Out of the corner of your eye you catch a shimmer in the air. At first glance, you could have sworn this place was empty, but now you turn to see a wishing well.
Curious.

In the local tavern, you see a drunkard sitting alone. From time to time, he grabs at a passing patron, trying to tell them something in slurred words. Every time, he is sworn at or given a harsh look, and his words are always ignored.\n\n"I'm no dimwit!" he shouts suddenly. "I know what I heard. The tower wept!"
Tell me what you heard!

I wassa... in the woods. Huntin'. Then, I saw the ruins.

People say a lord lived their hundras of yees ago. His son loved another man, and he trapped them there, they says. He locked 'em in his highest tower, and they was never seen again!

I swear to Guardians, I though' it was a fairytale. But it's real! I saw the tower. I heard his cries for help! And I only turned away for a secon', then the ruin was gone!
A vanishing ruin? You need some sleep.
You should go. You're making people uncomfortable.
Interesting. We'll keep an eye out for ruins.

Fine! I'll go! The drunkard wobbles to his feet, throwing down some coins. "But mark my words, the place is cursed! And anyone who gets close will be cursed as well!"\n\nHe stumbles over a chair, almost falling before he makes it out the door. The tavern own nods to you thankfully.
We'll move on too.
Assault Skill
Explosive Slot
Grants Skill: [skill]{what}[/]

In a tavern, you overhear a conversation.\n\n"Old Danny told me he saw them spiders crowdin' in Southwatch. I hope they kill those monsters before they come 'ere. Imagine, wakin' up to your house being crushed underneath a spider as big as your barn!"
How much is killing those spiders worth to you?
This is a waste of time. Let's go.
We ain't got the money to pay for that! The militia already drained us dry with taxes! If ya do kill 'em, maybe the Southwatch militia will reward i'. That's what we all pay taxes for, isn' it?
See you around.
To Kill A Spider

The spiders must have been working diligently. You find large cocoons and nests everywhere. There is only a rustling of leaves before a large one suddenly lands in front of you, clicking its pincers threateningly. Above you, you only hear more such sounds.
Let's make this quick.
Maybe we can calm it.

It is not long before you come across another spider den, this one blanketing the surroundings in white sheets of thick silk. Spiders are crawling about the place, but there is still movement from one of the cocoons.\n\nSuddenly, a human hand breaks out of the white mass, desperately clasping for air.
Defend that person!
With the spiders lying dead at your feet, you finally have time to give proper search to the area.
Harvest the spiders for materials.
Search through the cocoons.
The spiders prove difficult to cut through, but you manage to harvest a good amount of material before your work draws to a close.
Well done, everyone.

You hack at the large cocoons and chunks of flesh and ooze spill free. The smell is horrendous, but everyone clenches their teeth and pushes through. The contents are mostly bones, but you find some usable materials in the wreckage too.
Good work, everyone.
You are still collecting what you can from the spiders' nest when the screaming stops. The spiders must have gotten the best of the fly in their webs.
Okay. Let's end those spiders now.

You are far from certain about using this magic in such a way, but the combination of spells you concoct is enough to make the beasts uncertain that you are easy prey. After a few warning jabs and clicks, the spiders skitter away, crawling back up into the trees and away.
Let's break open the cocoons.
You are looking across the brush for more useful gains when a scream tears through the trees. It's close. Someone else has been discovered by more of the spiders!
Quick, we have to save him.
The spiders make quick work of your soldiers, wrapping them up into cocoons before they take their final breath, keeping them fresh for another meal.
I hate spiders.
[charge]{Cooldown.Charges}[/] [mCharges]
[mMeleeAttackType]
[mMissileAttackType]
Attack Type: [type]{attackType}[/]
Chitin
Chunk of Meat
Animal Teeth
Bones
Throughout the fight, you hear muffled cries for help that seem to become more incessant when the spiders lie dead at your feet. The hand keeps thrashing at the cocoon, trying to pry it open.
Get this cocoon open!

Your soldiers use their sharpest blades to tear the cocoon open, and a young man collapses out, coughing up acide and mucus. He immediately tries to rub the viscious liquid off himself with leaves and branches, standing up shakily.

"Th-thank you! I was sure I was done for! Thank you! I won't forget what you've done here today!"

He scrambles at his pockets for a moment, and then presses a meager coin purse into your hands.
Keep your gold. We don't need it.
Thank you. This will do nicely.
Spiders crawl all about this den, which is like a white sheet of silk over the landscape, dotted with cocoons and webs. It is eerily quiet. There is no sign of the source of the screaming.
The spiders pose no real threat to your troops, and you harvest what you can from them for the militia.

Oh, bless you, kind soul! Thank you! I really will never forget this.\n\nWith that and some nervous waves, the young man makes his way back through the brush to go home, tenderly nursing his still stinging wounds.
Let's take what we can to the militia.
The young man nods nervously, then looks down at his ruined clothes again and without another word starts making his way away from the den, nursing his wounds tenderly.
Let's go to the militia.
Then let's just kill the spiders.
Let's search the cocoons too.
We should be on our way.

The inside of each cocoon reeks, but most contains only bones. The last that you pry open contains the half dissolved corpse of a young man, still fresh but eaten away by acid. He has a meager coin purse that you can salvage, but that is all.
Let's go to the militia then.
Spider Slayer

As you come across the remote village, you see local militia soldiers taking down defences from the outer houses and fields, carefully removing barbed fences and wooden spikes. One of them gives you a friendly wave and an impressed smile as you approach.\n\n"You must be the forces who ended the lives of those miserable spiders!" she calls.
That we are.
My idiot son returned a little while ago and told us of your work. Thank you, mage! It was a great kindness. He is recovering now, and we can remove the barricades now. Finally!
You're welcome! Take care.

As you walk towards this remote village, you see the local militia working on outer defenses. One is carefully setting up a barbed fence around a field, and another is setting wooden stakes into the ground. Another spots you as you approach - a stern looking woman.\n\n"Ho! Don't you know how dangerous these woods are? There are spiders everywhere!"
Not anymore. We killed them.
Of course! The militia woman organises a pouch of coins for you to take on your way. "Put it to good use! It is well earned."
Thank you. Take care now.

The closer militia soldiers all stop their work in surprise. The woman folds her arms and gives you an even sterner look.\n\n"Really? I don't suppose you saw my idiot son while you were out there did you? I think he went off to try and slay them on his own, the fool. I'd expect him to come back with you."
Sadly, he died in the attempt.
We didn't see anyone. Just spiders.

The woman's face turns to horror as you explain to her what happened in the woods. Her colleagues in the militia console her, and another presents you with a coin pouch when you show them the materials you took from the den.\n\n"Thank you for your help, mage," he says. "We will remove these defenses now the threat has passed."
We are sorry for your loss.

The woman looks at you suspiciously for a few moments before nodding. You present to her some of the materials collected from the spiders' dens as proof, but she remains grim-faced as she organises your reward.\n\n"He must have gotten lost somewhere," she mutters as she passes you a purse. "I'll send out a party to look for him. Thank you for your aid, mage."
All the best.

The Prince's Castle

You are traversing the grasslands. The fields and hills lie still and quiet before you, but as you look around, you blink. Suddenly, where there was certainly nothing before, the ruin of a long forgotten castle has appeared.\n\nFrom the highest tower, you hear loud sobbing and the occasional morose cry. Most of the entrances lie desolate before you.
Hello?! Do you need help?
Let's find a way in.
This seems like a cursed place. Let's leave.
As you turn to leave, an icy cold wind blows. The ruins vanish around you, leaving you in the grasslands once again.
How strange.
The sobbing continues, as if you have not been heard.
There must be some way inside.
Let's leave this creepy place.

You scout the area around the tower, finding two possible entrances.

There are some loose stone-slabs in the base wall. With a great feat of strength, you might be able to remove them.

There is also a window you could reach by climbing the vines that creep up the tower.
Try to break the stones.
Try to climb the vines.
Who needs strength when we have explosives?
The tools your troops have available to them aren't made for stonework, and make no dent in the wall.
Let me take a crack at it.
Let's try to climb the vines then.
Your troops take tools to the stones, slowly chipping away at it. As the debris is tossed away, a cold room is uncovered, containing a winding staircase leading up the tower.
Take the stairs up.

Lore takes a good look at the tower's base, mumbling to himself about materials, explosive radius and debris impact. He shoos you all clear, saying: "Just in case the tower falls down. Wouldn't want any of you to be crushed!"
Lore... Stand clear, everyone!

The explosion rocks the ground beneath you, flinging stone and dust into the air. Lore coughs and looks at the tower nervously.

"Well... that didn't go as bad as it could've. Hehe!"

As the dust settles, you see a hole in the wall that leads to some stairs. A cold wind brushes past you.
Let's make our way up.

Finding a good foothold on the crumbling stone proves difficult, and clasping onto the vines is exhausting. Eventually, you reach the lowest window, and inside find a winding staircase covered in decaying leaves.
Walk up the stairs.

Dirt and dust covers every single step of the stairs. The higher you climb, the colder it gets, and you reach the top with numb hands and feet. There is a door here, reinforced with rusted steel. Cobweb covered skulls have been piled up in front of it. Beyond, you hear the cries and sobs again, now much louder.
Hello?!

The sobbing suddenly stops. A gentle, male voice passes through the door.

"Who are you? Please tell me you're here to free us! You just need to open the door! But... be careful of my father. He's temparemental in his old age."

Just as those words are spoken, the pile of skulls emits a ghostly wail.

"You will not harm them!"
Break the door down.
Those skulls are an amplifier. Destroy them.
Fight! Fight the undead!

As soon as your troops break down the door, a ghostly wail rises up around you, and the dust twists and turns across the floor.

"You will not harm them! Get out. Get out!"

The skulls on the floor begin to emit a dull, pale light. Amplifiers, you realize too late! Making the spirits stronger.
Fight! Fight!

No sooner have you fought your way into the room do you become aware of the skeleton sat up in the large double bed, clasping the hand of another that lies quiet and dormant next to it. Both are dressed in withered noble's clothes, and other than a thick layer of dust, and cobwebs hanging in every corner, the room they inhabit looks well lived in.\n\n"You did it!" A gentle voice floats from the gap between the sitting skeleton's teeth. "Thank you! He's been driving me mad for years!"
Are you a prisoner here?

There is a long pause before the voice floats through the room again.\n\n"Kind of." He sounds unsure. "This is my father's keep. He hid us here. The people... they had problems with... us." The skeleton's head tilts with a loud click towards the skeleton whose hand it holds. "He only wanted to protect us, but the fool's vows trapped us here. When my love passed away, I stayed behind to stop my father causing chaos. Thankfully it is over now. It was going quite poorly!"

With your pockets full of the small treasures you find scattered across the room, you leave. The cold wind blows once more, and around you the ruin disappears into the breeze. You are left on the grasslands once more, quiet and still as they always were.
What a tale this will be.
Dwarf
Undead
Dwarven Resilience

A couple of young boys run past, excitedly talking.\n\n"I'm telling you, it's amazing! I saw a huge wolf! And a little man, able to balance, like, at least ten horses on his arms! It was amazing! I hope we go again when it's back in town!"
Is there a circus nearby?

... and I really, really don't know now! Please! Help me find them! I must see them again!\n\nThe speaker is very frustrated, waving a stack of papers around wildly. Onlookers are baffled, and only a few of them take a leaflet. One is jammed into your hands before you can protest. The page contains a rough sketch of a blonde haired, androgynous individual with a wry smile and a wink.
Why does this person look familiar?

You walk a little further and see the elf on the white horse trotting away in the opposite direction. He smiles and mock salutes you, then spurs his horse on.\n\nThat is when you remember the fleeing, elfin bride. They look strikingly similar!
Oh, so you want a fight? It's on.
You try to catch up to her, but she moves in a rabbit-like zigzag and vanishes from sight.
We better hurry off too, before her pursuer catches up.
Brimming with elemental magic
Tinkered
Artifact
Ingredient

[health]{amount}[/] [mHealth]
Deals [malus]6%[/] of maximum health as [dmg_physical][mPhysical][/] damage per stack of [malus]Bleeding[/] at the start of the units turn.

Still out of breath, the man looks you up and down.\n\n"Hard to believe after she left the stolen goods with you, isn't it? But since I got my property back, I will overlook it. This time." He turns to wobble off. "Don't let her fool you like she did me! She is a vicious beast."
Inspect Unit

Approaching the tomb, you can see undead gathering around the ghost of a woman like she is a queen. She floats towards you, the undead parting before her.\n\n"The Guardians preserve you, strangers. You have done me and my court a great service."
We have? How so?

You have brought justice to the grave robber who disturbed our rest. I summoned my court to search for the trespasser but they could not get to her in her village. Now we can rest in peace again. I will grant you a boon for your noble deed. What shall it be?

As you pass through a small town, you see a blond haired man being led away by guards. It seems the Sevenkeeps militia has caught up with the elf they were pursuing.

His face is unreadable and he walks with them without making a sound. It seems a little off, but before you can think too much about it, the lieutenant calls out to you.

"I remember you! We finally caught the overgrown fairy!"
Shouldn’t we get a big reward for helping?
This is a magical illusion.
He must be hiding nearby to cast an illusion spell.
The lieutenant barks a laugh.\n\n"I seem to remember paying you already." He raises one eyebrow. "That was already quite generous."

The guards stop short and take a closer look at their prisoner. The man flinches and breaks lose, fleeing the scene as a red haired human.

"I’m sorry" He shouts as he runs. "He paid well!"

The lieutenant throws down his helmet and shouts: "By the Guardians! He is as slippery as a fish!"
Better luck next time!
You catch a glimpse of blond hair between the buildings. The elf that passed you on the horse, some time ago now, quickly moves out of sight.
You said Sevenkeeps would pay generously. You did not.
Well, we are not greedy. Carry on.

The lieutenant’s face sours.

"If you should find him, Sevenkeeps will gladly – and generously – pay for his capture."

They salute you and spur their horses on, back towards Sevenkeeps.
The lieutenant salutes you, whistles and rides off with his troops following.\n\nIn that moment, you remember. The elf bore a striking resemblance to the fleeing bride you met before.
No, we haven't seen anyone.
You have a spider problem? We can handle that.
Tankards are raised to you in thanks.\n\n"Oh. Well, that would be great! Finally, a true hero! The Southwatch militia should pay you for your troubles!"
To your health.
Unit died
A trophy like this will bring me much fame.
Curse its magic! Don't lose it again!

When you return to the tomb, you are greeted by a wall of undead. They do not attack but they also will not let you pass.
Storm the undead lines!
Leave the tomb.

Hero
Slave
Summon
You are rummaging through the dirt when you hear the clicking of loud pincers all around you. Looking up, you see a group of large insects chittering away.
We already destroyed them.
Perhaps one of those roaming bandits that plague our region? The nobles ignore them! the woman replies. The villagers nod in agreement.
Someone in the village is responsible.
Then I suppose we must simply destroy them.
The villagers hurl abuse at the woman until she is driven from the village in tears.\n
She got off easy.
I sympathize with her plight but she was foolish.
Armor Slot

Your soldiers take the animal apart as best they can. As you watch, you hear a mighty roar. You can't see the roarer, but you know whatever made that sound is likely the monstrosity that killed this beast too.
It is too dangerous to fight. Let's go.

Finding what you can to cover the beast and hide the smell, you have your soldiers bind the beast for carrying. You are interrupted by a mighty roar, emanating from whichever monstrosity managed to slay a wolf of this size.
Let's go, before we are killed too.

Student's Haunt

Near one of the inns bordering the sprawling tracts of the Royal Academy's grounds, you find a heavily inebriated man in Academy student robes. He staggers towards you.\n\n"Spare a coin for… a… a innerlectual enndeavour? I... I'm examinning ssspiritss... if you catch my drifft?" he says, leaning heavily on you and reeking of cheap wine.
I don't deal with drunkards.
I am very fond of practical science. Here, have some coin.
Why should I?
Comonnow... I can give you summin in return, he mumbles, holding up a library pass. "Wanna trade?"
Give him some coin.

TRUE PATRONS!! he cries as he tries to embrace your soldiers. "Here, take it... I... I'm sick of those damn books anyway!" He pauses, burps loudly and stumbles forward. "Or maybbe I'm juss sick..."\n\nWith that, he vomits into a small alleyway.
A library card. How useful.
Books Of Lore

Your company makes its way through the bustling streets of the Highmark’s capital, marveling at the rich selection of wares offered by what must be hundreds of little stalls that line the streets to the Academy Gate.
Browse the books on offer in the shops.

As you make your way towards the Gate, you spot a group of elves being accosted by the City Watch and an angry man in scribe’s robes. Weapon’s have been drawn and the situation is about to come to boil.
Ignore the ruckus.
Help the guard!
Help the elves!

You watch as the elves and guards trade blows, but more sentries arrive from the walls.

The elfs’ leader lifts a glowing crystal and intones a few words, opening a shimmering, violet gate in mid-air before her. Surprised, the guards stop their advance just long enough for the small elven band to vanish through the gate, closing it behind them.

The whole affair lasts a mere minute.
I wonder what all that was about...

You all rush to support the guards as a fiery explosion and a wave of heat shakes the cobbled street.\n\nPanicked, the booksellers grab their wares and flee the scene. Through the chaos, you make out the guards strewn about like puppets on the ground. One of the elves holds up a glowing, purple crystal.
Try to stop the elves.
Rushing towards the elves, you see more guards approaching from the Gate. Before you, the elven leader pulls a glowing, purple crystal from her satchel.
What do you plan to do with that?

Finally reaching the Academy Gate, guards almost immediately block your passage.\n\n“The Gate and the Academy are closed to outsiders! By order of his magnificence, Magistrate Reinhardt of the Royal Academy.”
Why?

One squints suspiciously at your entourage: "Several magical tomes of great value have been stolen from the Academy's vaults. The Gate will remain closed to visitors. No one gets in without a pass."\n\nHe steps back and shrugs off any further questions.
We will have to find one then...
You push your way through the mass of people but, before you can reach the elves, they vanish into a shimmering gate that quickly closes behind them.
Too late!
Waiting for the streets to clear, you see City Watch healers rushing to the aid of the fallen guards as reinforcements close off the street.
Walk up to the Gate.

The brightly clad elf looks up and notices you. She hesitates for a second, glances over her shoulder at the guards and winks at you, stepping into a shimmering portal that opens up before her.\n\nHer people quickly follow her through and, within moments, the portal is closed again.
You order your troops behind a stone building close to the inner city walls. The elf shouts a command and her group vanishes into a shimmering gate that quickly closes behind them.

Dumbfounded, the surprised guards stare at the empty space where the elves just moments ago stood. Then, their captain shouts a few orders and the Watch begins to cordon off the street, pushing back the people waiting to get to the Gate.
Try to get to the Academy.

Hoping to access the library using the drunken student’s card, you make your way through the vast Academy with your troops, all marveling at the old buildings’ magnificent arches and colorful glass windows.

Created by the combined efforts of dwaves, elves and humans, the Royal Academy mirrors a time of harmony between races.

The road ends at another gateway.
Let's approach.

There are a number of City Watch guards and some apprentice mages turning back those trying to enter the library.\n\nA guard steps out from below the marble arch and says: “Stop right there, strangers. I have orders to take you in.”
I am sure that is a misunderstanding.
On whose authority?
Magistrate Reinhardt wants a word with you, the guard replies, roughly shepherding you all towards a side entry.
No need to be uncivil!
Unhand us at once, you lout!
Shut yer trap or I'll make you! the guard grumbles.
No need for trouble. We’ll go with you willingly.
Let go or lose your hands. We won’t be moved.
The guards quickly form a wall of weapons and shields in front of you.
There must be another way to resolve this!
You dispatch the guards quickly and the survivors take refuge inside the library.
I told you you would regret laying hands on us.

A man dressed in expensive robes hurries out of a nearby building, accompanied by a group of what look like warrior mages.

At the guards he barks: “Stop this foolishness at once!”

To you he gives a short nod and says: “I can see there was a misunderstanding. Allow me to apologize on behalf of the Royal Academy.”
Apology accepted. You are?
I will not be accosted like this. Name yourself!

Magistrate Reinhardt, Warden of the Royal Academy, at your service. May we have a word? Reinhardt looks pointedly at the drawn weapons. "I assure you, you have nothing to fear from me. All I want is a minute of your time."\n\nMotioning for his men to stay back, he adds: "I have a proposal that could be mutually beneficial."
I'm listening.

“I noticed your presence when our valuable tomes were so brazenly stolen. Now, while I am not much of a believer in fate, I doubt it was an accident that you have returned here now. You see, the thieves of our treasured works are still at large. We may need help finding them.”
Can the City Watch not help with that?
The Academy must be filled with mages qualified for that.

Reinhardt grimaces and says: “One would think with all the means at our disposal this would be a trivial task.

But the City Watch has no authority beyond Sevenkeeps. And the Academy is currently occupied keeping the council from tearing at each other’s throats! With the king sick, we dare not antagonize the nobles by sending search parties out into their fiefdoms.

“So,” he sighs, “I need a few able people with their wits about them to find the thieves and bring the books back without creating a diplomatic crisis. In return, I am authorized to offer you free access to our library’s treasures.”
How about a little advance?
Why pick us?
Hunting elves does not sit well with me.
The man gives a corteous laugh.\n\n"Surely, you understand this is not a negotiation?"
So what's the offer then?
He gives a slight smile and replies: "I have been watching you for a while and I am impressed by your endeavors. And I’m sure you will find a friend in Sevenkeeps quite useful in the future."
A friend is useful but won’t solve all problems.

He barely raises an eyebrow at your tone and responds calmly.\n\n"These elves were renegades - neither of Finon Mir nor of the Morhir that have allied with us. I can only surmise they have given up all loyalty to their kin and the Highmark. I don’t expect them to share your qualms."
Maybe. What would we gain by this?

Reinhardt nods and moves on.

“We have managed to scry the thieves’ portal’s exit point. You best start there with your hunt. For that, I can offer you free access to the works present in our library, to study at will.

Or perhaps you want a more practical reward? An item maybe? Or some rare ingredients?”
The books must be quite valuable to you?

Folding his hands into his robe sleeves, he nods.

"They are. But, more importantly, this is a matter of principle. We cannot have just any scoundrel steal our books. The library must be protected at all costs!

But... I’m sure you will find the reward worth your while. I'll leave word that you shall be allowed to visit my offices if you return with the books."
When, not if.

Entering the Royal Academy again, you are quickly led through a succession of hallways into a small office that smells of beeswax and wet ink.

Sitting at a large, wooden table, Magistrate Reinhardt looks up and nods away the guards.

"I take it you have found my books?"
As requested.
Unfortunately they have been lost...
I demand answers first.
Perplexed by your tone, Reinhardt’s eyebrows shoot up.\n\n“If I can answer your questions, I certainly will,” he replies, irritation begins to creep into his voice.
The elves said someone put a spell on them.

The magistrate becomes serious.\n\n“Really?” he asks doubtfully. “I would have expected more from you. It seems I was wrong in my judgment – quite… unfortunate. Can you tell me what happened to them?”

Reinhardt takes them with reverence, examining them for a moment.\n\n"Excellent!" he exclaims. "I knew you were the people for the job. This will go a long way to keep you in the Academy's - and the Sevenkeeps Council's - good graces, I can assure you."
That is good to know.

Reinhardt gives you an expectant look as he carefully puts the books down.

“You have earned your reward.” He signs and seals a slip of paper, handing it to you. “This will ensure the Academy pays its dues. And let me reiterate my personal gratitude – it is good to have someone who can be trusted with such matters.”

With that, a gentle hand points you to the door.
Not so fast. I have questions.
The pleasure was all mine, Magistrate.

The guards lead you to the bursar’s office to hand over your slip. Squinting at it, the bursar looks up at you and down at the paper again.\n\n“That all seems to be in order. You shall be allowed to study in our library then. What should your further compensation be?”
A magical item from your vaults.
I need rare ingredients.
The elves destroyed them.
The elves teleported them away.
“A spell you say?” He looks surprised. “I had no idea…”\n\nHe shuffles almost imperceptibly in his chair.
That does not sound convincing. We will keep the books.
Well, it certainly bears further investigation.

Is that so?” he replies with a glint of steel in his voice now. “I’m afraid I must insist on taking them from you now. I am sure you would not want the collective might of the Royal Academy crashing down on top of you?”
#Books Of Lore ALL.5e0d1365-ec5b-4440-a7b7-be1489fdbbd3;You'll have to catch us first! Run!
#Books Of Lore ALL.62103b8d-ef16-47e4-acdb-3e24e8340a6e;Reinhardt gives you a sharper look.\n\nYou are joking, yes? Don't take me for a fool! I will give you one last chance to hand them over to me."
Of course. Just a bad joke. Here they are.
I think I will keep them a bit longer.
Reinhardt’s eyes bore into you.\n\n“Hand over the books and get out and I might ignore your insolence,” he says. “But do not expect to be welcomed here again.”
You escape the city, but this episode will not have earned you any friends.
At least we get to keep the books.
You are driven back and barred from the library forever.
...Damn it.
The City Watch guards are quickly alerted to your flight, catching up to pepper you with arrows.
Damn it.
An elderly librarian in stiff robes stops you from entering.\n\n"Magistrate Reinhardt said to let you in when you have retrieved the tomes. Until then, the library remains closed to you."
We will come back with the books.
I don't have any coin with me.
This unit is ethereal and can move through obstacles.
{DamageTypes.PhysicalResistance:+-pc} [mPhysical] Resistance {postfix}
Can Fail
Mysterious Key
Where is a key, there is a lock
Giant Pumpkin Patch
As you try once again to get through the Academy Gate, the City watch stops you.\n\n“Members only!” they remind you. “You won’t get in without a pass.”
Let's find one, then.
“You are absolutely right!” Reinhardt nods. “I will personally ensure that this is followed up on diligently. Now… the books?”
I want this cleared up before I hand them over.
Here. Take them.
They mentioned you by name.
Everyone! Make a run for it!

A lone rider on a shaggy pony approaches and you can hear the clang of iron boots mounting the stairs to your tower.\n\n"Greetings, mage. My name is Kelgrun Windhammer. I am Windholme's emissary to the Sevenkeeps Dwarf hold. May I have a word?"
Of course.
Go away!

The dwarf lifts his worn cloak to reveal fine clothes and gleaming armor. He must be someone of importance.

He looks around your hall before dropping a pile of rusting weapons onto a nearby table with a loud clatter.

“Do you know what this is?”
Some junk cluttering up my home?
Low quality ironwork?
Whatever it is, I am not buying.

The dwarf laughs mirthlessly.

"Ha! These… these are legendary Adamantinum weapons, crafted by the famed dwarven smiths of Sevenkeeps. They are made to last centuries and never dull their edge!"

He pauses a moment, as if waiting for a reaction."These weapons were forged a fortnight ago. And now look at them! Nothing but junk!" He spits and knocks them from the table angrily. The brittle metal shatters into pieces on the floor.

"This is a curse!” Kelgrun foams, his face red with anger. “A powerful one, cast by no mere witch or wizard. This… this comes from the magistrate and his cronies!"
Magistrate? Magistrate Reinhardt you mean?

That treacherous scheming gullyworm! the dwarf spits. "He blames us. Us! He claims we tried to trick the Academy and the king's army by delivering impure weapons. The insult! Now he wants us thrown off the council and all our artificers expelled!"
That seems too convenient.
I already suspect Reinhardt of instigating the elven purge in Sevenkeeps.
And rightly so. Who needs dwarves anyway?
What?! The dwarf positively screams at you, then collects himself and mutters: "I… I can see I have been misled about you and your position. I have nothing more to say to you."
Good riddance.

You see where this is going? He and his cronies are trying to break up our people's alliance. It has stood since the War of Six Races! And he is playing into the hands of those Granite Dwarf fanatics, who maintain we should not trust humans.

He calms down a bit, fidgeting with his heavy silver bracers.

"I cannot turn to any mage in the Academy. They either work with Reinhardt or fear him. And the Circle won't move against him either. This is why I have come to you for help."
So what is it you need help with?
I think Reinhardt is doing the right thing.

The dwarf looks at you as if weighing you up.\n\n"Standing up to the magistrate is no simple feat. But if you could prove his foul play in this affair, the dwarves – and all of Sevenkeeps – will surely be grateful.”
He has the Royal Academy behind him. It’s madness!

The dwarf snorts derisively.

"I thought you braver than that but I was apparently mistaken. I can't say I blame you for it, of course. The magistrate's reach is long indeed.

 Well, if you change your mind, come to the Dwarven Gates in Sevenkeeps and meet me there."
Good luck!
I do have a bone to pick with the magistrate.

Excellent! the dwarf exclaims, beaming. "We think someone tampered with the Adamantinum in our mines - a magical curse perhaps? The miners have been reporting disturbances as well."

He drops a few scrolls on your table.

"I will let my people know that you are working for our cause. I look forward to hearing what you will find!"
We will be in touch.
The dwarf looks taken aback, but shrugs and turns away again.\n\n"This will not be the end of it!” he shouts over his shoulder. “You will find me quite persistent!"
Whatever!

The very same.

I found it odd that the dwarven artificers would be so vehemently against a simple investigation and sent a small dispatch to parley with the guild master. My messengers were refused entry and a skirmish ensued.

Now, the dwarves have closed down the tunnels, blocking access to all travelers. We thus find ourselves unable to confirm the accusations leveled against them and unable to commence with a fair trial.

I was hoping you could act as a go-between, seeing as you have served the Academy in the past. Sevenkeeps would be in your debt, of course.”
#KIngmaker Humans.d9e11384-7a8f-439a-8e6d-c539da9081a8;I have no interest in helping.
#KIngmaker Humans.a5a96f03-0cc7-44c7-a628-e7b34a61af5b;It would be good to prevent a civil war.
#Dwarf City Entrance.3dbb92f8-77dc-41f6-98c6-85f27d397bfd;Dwarven Gate
#Dwarf City Entrance.fc7ddb93-b080-4298-8706-2a65e5a93b78;The guards on the other side of the iron gate seem to be expecting you, quickly ushering you inside.
#KIngmaker Humans.1dbf61e2-acde-4443-b914-1230f2e96784;You receive a letter from Magistrate Reinhardt, Ward of the Highmark’s Royal Academy. When you touch it, a magical mouth appears and intones:

Greetings,

I apologize for the intrusion and will get directly to the matter at hand.

We have recently had an unfortunate incident with the dwarven artificers of our esteemed academy. There is evidence that their kin, who usually forge weapons for our brave soldiers, have been criminally negligent. The artificers have disputed the evidence and walked out of the council in anger.

You have helped us in the past. Perhaps you might again?”
No wonder. Dwarves are easily angered.
So there is evidence? Not just speculation?

“Indeed. I fear a very specific motive to risk sabotaging our army’s supplies: The Granite Dwarf movement is gaining traction again in the dwarven realms. The weakening of our nation’s army could be the result of their machinations.”

We have irrefutable evidence that the Adamantinum weapons the smiths delivered have been tampered with - made worthless. The artificers of course deny they are responsible, citing some corruption of the base metal.\n\nI fear there may be another motive: There are reports of the Granite Dwarf movement gaining strength again in the dwarven realms. The sabotage of our nation's army could be the result of their machinations.

You carefully remove the collar, and think about what to do with the wolf. But a mighty roar interrupts you. Whatever made that sound most likely killed this wolf too. A dangerous creature, if it could manage this.
Let's go, or we'll be next.

Again, the boy scowls, and just like that, the bag vanishes from out of his hand.

"Fine!" he snaps. "I must have misjudged you. See you never, spoilsport!"

He runs behind one of the shrine's walls, but when you get there, you find the space completely empty. The boy has vanished, and none of your troops can find any trace of his presence.
How bizzare.

Your scouts reported this camp to be empty, which makes the hot coals in the firepit suspicious.\n\nNo sooner has the thought crossed your mind do brigands appear all around you, adorned in fake bushes and bundles of dried grass. Your scouts are mortified. Under their bluster and camouflage, the bandits seem desperate, gaunt and hungry.
If you want a fight, we'll give you one.
We don’t want trouble. Have some gold.
The brigands are surprised at your reaction, but grab the coin and return to their camp. One of them turns back to you, mouthing a thank you.
They must have fallen on hard times.
With the brigands dead, the camp is truly abandoned. You take some coin and rifle through their belongings. There are no valuables, but there is a letter in the tent.
Read the letter.
Well, this was a waste of time.

The letter dates back about a week.

'My love,

Some men came by earlier this week and left this coin for you. They said you'd know what it means, and to meet them in Sevenkeeps?

Kisses, M.

P.S. Please return soon. I'm not sure the baby will wait to be born much longer.'
I wonder what is in Sevenkeeps.

Your scouts find a camp on the grasslands, abandoned in a hurry. There is no trace of who it once belonged to, but you find a large chest half hidden under burlap sacks. It is richly decorated. And locked.
Locks are easy to pick.
Try to get it open.
In just a few moments, the chest is open. You take coins and various other items from inside.
Worth it! Let's go.
A few of your troops attempt to pick the lock by various means, but it does not give. The chest remains closed, and is far too big to carry with you.
Well, we tried. Let's go.
Nailed to a tree, you find a colorful notice.\n\n'Visit Zacharias' Menagerie of Beasts and Oddities! Brighten your future with a reading from Madame Fortuna! May your luck bring only clover!'
It may be nice to visit a circus.
They give you a nod and pull the elf away. For a moment it looks like the elf’s hair is red, not blond, but they round a corner and disappear before you can take a proper look.

The lieutenant eyes you for a moment before chuckling: "I like your boldness. My soldiers could learn from you."\n\nHe throws another purse your way, nods and pulls the elf away. You could swear, just for a second, the elf’s hair is red, not blond. Before you can mention it, they have disappeared from sight.

The lieutenant nods and holds out a coin purse.

"You are right of course," they say as they pull the guard away. "Here. You’ve earned this."

Your attention is barely on the pouch they give you, as for a moment you are distracted by the color of the elf’s hair. For a moment it looks… red. They disappear before you get a proper look.
Discreetly follow the elf.
Your prisoner just vanished between those buildings.
Pay us double and we will catch him for you.
He disappears in the secluded alley, gone before you can catch him.\n\nUpon a barrel, some coins are arranged to spell out two letters – C U.
No doubt we will meet again.

The lieutenant affixes you with a stern gaze and steps closer.\n\n"I told you before, Sevenkeeps will pay for his capture but we will not… Ah! Who am I kidding?" He takes a deep breath. "Fine. Catch him and bring him to us. You’ll receive the coins and something of your choosing from our armory. Or the laboratory, if you so prefer."
That sounds like a deal. We are off then.
Use Item

You overwhelm the guards, leaving the man defenseless.

"N-no! Please! I… I was just…" He raises his shaking hands, dropping the package in the process. He nods to it and slowly backs away. "Please let me go! You can keep that!"

You pick up the goods before returning your attention to him.

He lets out a string of vile curses: "If I ever see that bitch again, I’ll kill her! Never let any woman fool you! Evil witches!"

He stomps off angrily.

When he is gone, you take a look inside the package. Jewelry, coins, cups and chalices. Cutlery and candelabras. You take everything of value and leave the junk behind.
Let's take it as a sign of good luck.

He runs – or rather waddles – away. Once he is out of sight, you take a look inside the bag to find jewelry, coins, cups and chalices. Cutlery and candelabras too.\n\nYou take everything of value and leave the junk behind.
Let's take it as a sign of good luck.

He rips the package from you.

"Finally! The bitch was trying to pull off a marriage fraud. Never trust women! They’re all evil witches!" He huffs and takes some coins from the package. "A token of my thanks."

He hands them to you before turning and waddling away.
May she be caught swiftly.
Run off, you coward.
The guards make short work of your troops.
What a horrible display of wealth.

Summon Wolf Pack
You can drop the act. I know those tattoos.
Praise the Light
What reward did you have in mind?

She gives a disbelieving laugh.\n\n"We've got nothing but our clothes to our names now. The money lies with our cargo, you see? As soon as our wares are safe, I can pay you. Gold, potion ingredients... Whatever suits your fancy, you'll be compensated."
That sounds reasonable. Where to?

By the time you reach the camp, you've heard no hint of the wolves. The entire pack is fast asleep between ripped tents and ruined supplies, taking slow and steady breaths with the occasional kick of the back leg.
Ambush the wolves, quietly.
A small portion of the group leads you closer to their abandoned camp, but then stops.\n\n"We'll wait here," the woman says. "Be wary. The wolves might still be there."
Tread lightly, everyone.

The band of thieves arrives a little later, looking impressed as they scan the battlefield.\n\n"Good job. I don't think we could have managed this. Well, a deal is a deal! Will you take money or ingredients?"
Coin it is. Pleasure doing business with you.
Rally

The boy thinks, then shuffles off. You hear muffled voices, then he returns with an older woman. She takes out a silver key and unlocks the cassette and hands you some of the gold.\n\n"Return to us as soon as you can. But be quick. The Lady is not very patient."
We'll get to it.
You knock on the door, once again greeted by the young boy.\n\n"Have you cleared the undead away?"
We made short work of them.
The boy scurries away, no doubt to inform the lady of the house, and you hear a cheer from the top most rooms. Soon after, he returns with your promised gold.
Our work here is done.
They may have belonged to a queen once
Beautiful emeralds in a golden fixture
Burning
Light Javelin

We must return with higher numbers.

Magic User
Fire Beetle

You come across a man in simple clothes, sitting on the ground wearing nothing but a small bag. The side of his head is bleeding from a recent beating. His eye is swollen shut.\n\n"Spare some change for a poor soul?"
We some coins. Please take them.
Ignore him, we have to move on.
What happened to you?
He takes the money with a thankful nod.\n\n"Guardians protect you. Take good care on your journey. And heed my warning - don't go toe to toe with the militia. They are little more than bandits."
May the Guardians watch over you.
Did they do this to you?
Let me heal you.

He shakes his head and spits.\n\n"The militia. They just wanted someone to knock around, and I was the closest punching bag. After nearly beating me to death, they took my money too. Called it taxes."
Take these coins. You shouldn't go hungry.
Let me heal you.
Sorry. We have no coins.

He sharply sucks some air between his teeth as you approach. He relaxes more as his wounds close.

"Thank you. Guardians protect your kindness, and may Lady Luck bring you clover."

He gets up carefully, testing his balance, and gingerly walks off with a last wave.

He nods his head again, then stops himself with a painful wince.\n\n"They said I didn't pay enough taxes last month, so they had to make an example of me. I swear, I've never been late to pay, nor did I skimp on it. They just came past and decided it was time to knock someone around."
Heal his wounds.
Take good care of youself. Try to stay away from them.
Ah, I didn't expect any. May Lady Luck smile upon you more than she does me.
May the Guardians watch over you.

He takes the money with a thankful nod. 

"May the Guardians protect you and may lady luck bring you clover."

He carefully starts ripping off slim strips of his shirt to bandage his head.
Continue on your way.
May the Guardians look after you.

The distressed outcry of villagers can be heard coming from the main square. You follow the sounds and find the Rushwater Downs militia in the process of putting several people up on the pillory. An already shackled woman curses and screams.\n\n"This is insulting! We did nothing wrong!"
What did these people do?
The commanding officer does not even look at you.\n\n"Disloyalty, disobedience and disrespect. If you don't care to join them, you should be on your way quickly. Let me do my work."
This bullying stops here. Get them down.
Your empty threats don't frighten us.
Having dealt with you, the guards leave the village, likely to harass the next.
They will be sorry for this.

The villagers are horrified as you slay the militia. Parents usher their children inside and others move as far away as they can.\n\n"P-p-please, don't harm us! We can pay you for your service but please, leave."
We only wished to help. We'll be on our way.
We'll leave if you show a little more gratitude.

Zacharias is at the back of his wagon, behind a folding curtain. He seems to be trying on everything in his wardrobe.\n\n"Ah, it's you! I gather my letter found you well? Have you managed what I asked?"
I have them here, exactly as you asked.
Pray tell, why do you need all this?

A few moments later, he appears in a dazzling sequine suit.

"Marvellous!" He grins. "To the prop makers then!"

He leads you to another wagon, where all sorts of props clutter the entry. He asks a woman to take the bundle off your hands, then turns back to you.

"As promised, your reward. And do make sure to watch the show! It will be magical."
Good luck with it, I suppose.

A pair of purple pants are thrown out of the booth. A pink fur shawl follows suit.

"I thought of something wonderful indeed. If keeping a large beast is too dangerous - why not make my own creature?

I'll create something new, a costume so to speak, and the people will never be the wiser. They just come for the excitement."
I see. Well, we'll return with your costume parts soon.
A notice hangs on Zacharias' door.\n\n'Out, being splendid.'
I guess I'll come back later then.
Alchemy

You had almost forgotten about your encounter with the Rushwater Downs militia, but are gently reminded when a troop of them block your path and point their weapons at you.\n\n"You caused us quite some trouble, undermining our authority with the Rushwater folks. I think an apology is due."
What do you want?
You're common thieves and we'll treat you as such.

Magic Damage

[mWhite]
Oh, we'll see about that.
I will have revenge.

Earth Barrier
Light Cavalry

You hear some disgruntled dwarves talk as they pass you.

"...haven't had any Adamantinum again this week. It's like something ate it all away."

"What are you talkin' about? Monsters?"

"Nah. It must've been those bloody Granite Dwarves. They need Adamantinum as much as we do. We should go after them."

They pass before you have the chance to ask for more information.
So the Granite Dwarves are stealing all the Adamantinum...
Shake Off

You hear a cry for help echoing through the village. A dwarf runs up the street, gesturing wildly behind him. It seems he is being ignored.

"Help! Trolls! We need help! Please! Anyone?"

By the villagers' reactions, you gather he must be one of Norgate's Granite Dwarves.
Take a deep breath. Tell us what happened.
Serves you right.

The dwarf wipes blood out of his eyes, running from a cut on his brow.

"I... There... In Norgate. Trolls from Regan Gor. Please... Help my village. Kill the trolls!"

Completely exhausted, he faints at your feet.
We should help. Hurry!
Empty his pockets before we go.
Scholar

{Value:+-c} from units
Gatherer
Potent Water
Stunned
Mentalmagic
Ignore him. We need to be on our way.
The trolls tear through the village, trampling all in their way without care and throwing boulders at anyone trying to flee. It is a massacre that costs you dearly.
We will rebuild.

After defeating the grey skinned giants, you take a careful look around. A few houses were flattened, but a large portion of the village is intact. There are some casualties, but slowly the dwarves are coming out of hiding to retrieve their fallen. One, heavily leaning on a walking stick, approaches you.

"You came too late. We lost good people, and a chunk of our resources and reserves. But... you helped, despite our differences. Thank you."

The final words are added very quietly, as if not meant to be heard. He drops something on the ground and hobbles away.
You're welcome, I suppose.
Rooms
Test Room
We should keep our ears open.

While wandering the streets of Windholme, you hear a sudden crash. As you turn, you see two dwarves fighting, cursing each other. One of them is in the process of brushing barrel splinters off his chest.

"You bastard! Kept it all for yourself! Stop lying al...!" Interrupted by a punch.
"I ain't no liar! All the mines are empty! What I found might as well have been dust!"

The fight turns more violent, and bystanders now start to intervene.
So uncivilized...

While travelling the Windwall Mountains, you find a weathered, enscribed stone.\n\n'The Granite Dwarves are exiled for crimes against the dwarven race, and cruelty against others on a large scale. They may never return to this realm, and are refused help and kindness. May Niethalf show their barbarous souls no mercy.'
Mana Stash
Threshold Limit:
It sounds like we should avoid these Granite Dwarves.
There is no way the Granite Dwarves did this alone.
Not enough skill to craft this!

A little off your way, there are traces of a rockslide. It could be possible there are people buried under it. Or treasures.
Let's take a look.
Continue on our way.
There is nothing of interest under the loose tangle of stone, snow and ice.
Curse our luck.

Mine a [unittag]mineable[/] location on the worldmap to gather ore.
After some rooting around, you find a handfull of coins scattered between the debris.
Thank Niethalf for his gifts.
You dig through the debris and find some mining equipment. It is all rather old and broken and there is nothing else hidden in the rockslide.
What a waste of our time.
The slide must have emptied a nearby mine...
You rummage through the debris but hear a deep rumble. The mountain shakes beneath you and it quickly becomes difficult to stay upright.
Run, or we will be crushed!
Ahead you see the remains of a rockslide.
Maybe something is buried beneath.
Let's ignore it.

Under the icy rocks, you come across the frozen body of a dwarf. He is still clutching a piece of rope that might have belonged to a wagon once, or a mule maybe. He was probably a miner that lost his way.\n\nYou uncover his mangled body. There are some pearls in his beard and a coin pouch wedged between his belt and thick furs.
Take the valuables.
Let's give him a proper burial.
We'll take them, but let's bury him properly.
There are traces of a rockslide a little out of your way.
See what's buried beneath.
Ignore it and move on.
After some digging, you find a small amount of Sky Iron in the fallen stone. It is not much, but the mineral is rather rare in the Windwall Mountains.
This is a lucky find.
As you trudge along, there is a shift behind you and you watch a landslide crash down on the path.
Maybe something was uncovered in the rubble.
The landslide seems to have upheaved an old grave. There are multiple dwarven bones buried in the debris.
Collect the bones.
Don't disturb the dead. Let's move on.
A meager reward.
Try to dig deeper!
As quickly as it began, the shaking stops again. Sadly, digging through the rubble, you find nothing but pebbles and sleat.
Just moments later you come upon a large and heavy coin pouch. Enough reward for your troubles. The mountain grumbles on though, louder than ever before.
What a waste of time...
Run now, or we will be crushed!
Praise the Guardians for rewarding our efforts.
The grumbling gets ever louder and a heavy shake throws you off balance. A sudden avalanche crashes down, loosened by the quake, sweeping some of your soldiers away.
Flee to safety!
Some way off you hear the telltale signs of a rockslide. A little while later, you come across it.
Let's investigate.
Ignore it. Let's go.
To your surprise, you see a hand sticking from the sleet and rocks. The fingers move only slightly, but whoever is buried is definitely still alive.
Enemies will emerge from here!
Start digging!
The risk is too high. Let's go.
If we move slowly, we can avoid another slide.

As you work to uncover the body, there is a rumble. The sky suddenly grows dark as another rock slide comes crashing down.

Cold, slushy ice and stones pummel you and your troops, making the rescue near impossible. You barely recover your troops and half a dozen hurt and frozen dwarves.

"Th-th-thank y-you," they chatter.

Once their wounds are tended, they each give you a bit of their coin as thanks.
You're lucky we got here in time.
Your kind gifts will be used wisely.

You manage to uncover six dwarves. They are cold and hurt but alive.

"Th-th-thank y-you."

It takes some time to wrap them up and nurse their wounds. Most aren't serious, but there are some broken bones and nasty cuts. They each give you a bit of coin in gratitude.
You are lucky we were here. Take good care now.
Your kind gifts will be used wisely. Good bye.
Stack Movement Points
Stack Power

Hulking trolls block the mountain path above the village. The largest one mumbles something in a deep and angry but grating voice, throwing a rock down the mountain side. He then limps away and you see his leg is swollen. Infected, probably.
Bring them down!
Move on! You cannot stay here.

Slowly blinking, the trolls look you over. The largest of them decides it is his duty to answer.

"Rest here. Move later. You, I eat now."

With that, his large hand descends on you, threatening to take a handful of soldiers and throw them into his stinking gullet.
To arms!
Oh, we taste awful! We're riddled with parasites.
How about we give you food?
He thinks for a moment before nodding, proud that he has produced an idea.\n\n"So, I won't eat you. Bring us meats, then we move on. But you bring lots."

He thinks for a moment before his face turns angry.

"You lie. I know! You lie!"

With that, the trolls charge furiously.
We bring only death!
Alright. We will bring you meats.
Defend yourselves!
With the trolls thrashing about, an avalanche is loosed and the village at the bottom of the mountain is destroyed.
Curses! Guardians, watch over them.

The descending hand now sinks to your side, palm open as if expectant. You have some meat thrown into it, which the troll accepts with a pleased sigh. He barely chews on it before swallowing it down.\n\n"Need much more. Then we leave."

While traveling Draycott's cold landscapes, you encounter a dwarven militia troop.\n\n"Halt a moment, if you please! We're looking for a lost supply delivery group! Have you encountered roughly ten dwarves with a wagon?"
We have seen no such group.
We are in a hurry! We have no time for this!

The dwarf sighs, and the icicles in his hair and beard clink.\n\n"They were supposed to bring supplies to our Adamantinum mines, but never made it. If you come across them, we'll reimburse you for bringing them home."
We'll keep our eyes open.
I'm afraid we have no time.

His expression darkens at your words.\n\n"Soon, it will be your problem. They were supposed to bring equipment to our Adamantinum mines. Need I remind you it's an important component for many magical artifacts? And there is not much left." He takes a deep breath and wipes his face. "If you should encounter them, bring them home. We will reimburse you for your troubles, of course."
You're right, of course. We'll keep our wits sharp.
We really don't have time. Good day.
You find traces of an avalanche that could have buried the lost supply group.
Dig through the drifts. We must find them.

After trudging through the snow for what feels like hours, you hear cries for help. Following the sound, you see a wagon, barely hanging from a cliff edge. Six dwarves are fighting off some snow leopards. They are quickly forced to retreat, only for the beasts to trap them under an overhang.
That must be the supply group! Defend them!
Don't get too close. We can't risk our own troops.
You troops clear away much of the avalanche before it becomes evident the dwarves were not buried. But you do find tracks that suggest they at least passed through.
They're not far ahead of us!

You watch the wild cats pick the dwarves off one by one. They feast on their prey and fight over the pieces, then drag the rest of their meal to a nearby cave. Blood colors their trail in the otherwise calm, white landscape.
Your units fall prey to the snow leopards, together with the dwarves you have tried to save. A sudden shudder goes through the mountain, burying the carcasses and wagon underneath a blanked of white.
May Hirin watch over the souls of our fallen.
Once you have dealt with the threat, the dwarves fall to the ground exhausted.\n\n"We were close to completely spent. Thank you!"
We were asked to bring you home.

A heavy silence falls on the group. They move to the cliff edge, near their wagon, and look into the pit below.\n\n"May Niethalf watch over you, brothers. We shall not forget you." For a minute, they pray silently before turning back. "We lost four of our brothers today. But your courage saved six. We shall never forget that."
Niethalf will protect the fallen.

Their faces darken and they stare at you in silence. Since you do not budge, their expressions only twist into fury.\n\n"So you are thieves without honor, is that it? We will not go down without an honorable fight!"
Let's see how honorable it will be to die here.
It was a joke! You should see your faces!
Their faces do not lighten.\n\n"A bad joke in a bad time. Get going. We don't need your help."
It was in poor taste. Apologies.
It feels as though the hammer of Niethalf himself comes down on your troops. The village will not be happy to hear of your attempt to rob and kill their mining suppliers.
Let's try to avoid them in the future.
Your soldiers salvage what they can from the wagon and the corpses. The dwarves did not carry much of interest to you.
Let's see what the wagon holds.
We should let the town know they will not return.
Perhaps we can still claim the promised reward?
Arsonists
Throw Torch
Catalysts
[bonus]Doubles[/] the amount of potions gained through alchemy but [malus]lowers all Essences by 1.[/]
Poison Tooth
Ration
[bonus]Triples[/] the amount of potions gained through alchemy.
Consumable
Consumables
Select Target
Fine. But this is the last you'll get.
We don't have any more, but we'll get you some.
You already agreed to move!

This meat goes to the others, who gulp it down in much the same manner. The largest troll scratches his head as if thinking about asking for more. After a moment he decides against it.

"You keep promise. We leave."

Without another word, the lumbering creatures march off into the mountains.
Finally, some peace and quiet.
The troll thinks, grumbling for a moment while picking his nose.\n\n"Need more meat. Am hungry!" he finally says, his hand reaching out expectantly again.
Then go to Regan Gor! Lots of meats there.
With that, the troll lets out an annoyed grunt and gives up. He kicks a large boulder off the mountain and stomps away like an angry child, leaving his companions to follow behind him.
Hopefully that's that.
Fine. Last bit!
We've run out, but we'll get some more.
We will continue on!

With the trolls dealt with, a silence spreads over the snow covered mountains again.\n\nYour return to the village is celebrated. The dwarves have saved some mead and generously give it to you in way of thanks.
Have you found our brethren yet? They have still not returned.\n\nA little crowd has gathered, watching you with hopeful eyes.
Not yet. Hopefully soon.

You can hear cheers and laughter before you reach the village, as family and friends await the suppliers' return. They are immediately taken into care, their wounds bandaged and their bellies filled. You are rewarded with coin, and a feast.\n\n"Our gratitude, grand mage. May Niethalf watch over your journey and give you strength. In those blasted mountains, you will need every bit of it."
Thank you. May he watch over you as well.

All are silent and still at that. After a long minute, life returns to them. Some walk off, hanging their heads and crying.\n\n"Thank you for looking anyway. We will arrange to have their bodies retrieved. Here. The promised reward."
Let's rebury them, to rest their souls
You take the bones unbroken by the avalanche and stow them away for later use.
Let us continue our journey.
We should leave quickly.
The bones you have collected are suddenly tugged away by an invisible force. Ghosts appear all around you! They don’t look best pleased with the handling of their remains.
To arms!
The undead forces overwhelm you.
We shall not lose hope.
We should not disturb the dead.
With the undead slain, the world falls quiet and a light snow begins to fall.
Collect the remains before they are snowed under again.
We've done enough here.

The ghosts watch you with slack faces. A moan goes through their ranks like the wind and they nod.\n\nUnder their careful, wordless supervision you take the time to uncover every bone and take them to a small alcove in the mountain wall. There you stack them, with care, placing the heads on top of the pile.
Close the alcove with a large stone.
We wish to bury you properly! We mean no harm.
Now it is time to destroy them!
After a heavy stone is rolled into place, the ghosts float into their final resting place. One remains a moment to point to a snowed over bump in the ground. You uncover a tightly packed coin purse.
At least they rewarded us.
May Niethalf watch over your rest.
You take the closest bones but many are quickly lost under a cold, snowy blanket.
We have what we need.
Retreat, before more ghosts come.
We found them dead.
Be careful. They were attacked by snow leopards.
We are sorry for your loss.

As you wander the Windwall Mountains, a sudden avalanche crashes down next to you. It barely passes your troops, ripping stones into the deep and uncovering a cave entrance. From within, you can hear a hungry and dangerous growl.
Snow leopards! Defend yourselves!
Hide behind those boulders!

A small pack of snow leopards jump forth from the cave and takes off into the mountains. They must have been trapped in there for some time. \n\nWith them gone, you take a moment to inspect the cave they sprang from. Among the chewed remains of at least two dwarves, you find some coins and riches. What a sad fate to be trapped with hungry snow leopards.
We better leave, or we'll meet the same fate.
Let's give them a proper burial.
The leopards makes quick work of all your troops.
At least it was a swift death.
We will send out reinforcements at once.
It does not take long to collect and prepare the remains.
May they find peace now.
Melee Damage Reduction
Missile Damage Reduction
Spell Damage Reduction

Stone Skin
Reconnaissance Expert
Holy Weapons
Miner
Physical Resistance
Wind Walking
Iss that... real gold? He takes a hearty bite into the coin and winces in pain.
So what now?
You march up to the iron gate leading to the dwarven tunnels. No guards stand on the outside, but on the other side you see well armored dwarves watching you closely.
In the name of Sevenkeeps, I demand entrance!
We are here to conduct peace talks.
The dwarves laugh at you from behind their iron gates.\n\n"Go away, before we make you, fool!"
Storm the gate.
Do not back down.
Having broken through the gate, you hear the sound of a horn echo through the tunnels. It seems the dwarves sent scouts back into the mines and they are mobilizing against you!
Wait for them to approach! Lower your weapons.
Prepare the defenses!

A voice rings out in the dark. "A truce! Let us end this bloodshed!"

You see a silver-haired dwarf in the robes of an artificer walking towards you, arms raised and palms open.

"I am Master Maednir. What is it you want here?"
We merely wish to talk.
Take him hostage.
The old dwarf's eyes meet you with a steely glance. He raises himself slightly.\n\n"Well, what do you want? State your case and make it quick."

The old dwarf shrugs and defiantly replies: "Threaten me all you want. It won't help you find the truth. I have been willing to reason with you but, if this continues, you leave me no choice but to fight!"
Please, we will follow you.
Last chance!” the dwarves call. “Clear the gates or suffer the consequences!
Stand your ground.
Magistrate Reinhardt is plotting against you.

There is a pause and you hear urgent murmurs from behind the gate. Then a voice rings out: "Why should we trust you? The magistrate might have sent you as yet another foul trick. They poisoned our guild master, you know?"
Believe me, I have no sympathy for the magistrate.
Peace can only be built on trust, no?
I will not repeat myself. Open the gate. Now!
Very well! a gruff voice replies. "We will open the gate - but no tricks, or my warriors will take you down!"

You are led down dark passages until you reach a small room, its walls adorned with intricate carvings. A silver-haired dwarf in the robes of an artificer stands behind a dais.\n\n"Greetings. I am Master Maednir. What is it you wish to discuss?"
Greetings, honorable master.
We must talk to a guild master.
You are easily fooled. Kill them!
Magistrate Reinhardt accuses you of foul play.
We came to warn you. The magistrate plots your downfall.
We wish to mediate this divide peacefully.
Your emissary tried to recruit me. I was not convinced.
I will be the one asking the questions here.

The dwarf's face clouds over with anger.\n\n"The Magistrate accused us of knowingly selling tarnished weapons. He has sullied our reputation and used his lies as an excuse to banish us from the city. We have suffered a grave injustice and now you come to my doorstep with this?! I will not be insulted in my own hall!"
I apologize. So you think the Magistrate wronged you?
I will take you to the Magistrate now.
Then lets get to the bottom of this, shall we?

The dwarf nods slowly.

"Yes. I fell for his deceit when he accused the elves of stealing the Academy's books and poisoning our guild master.

But now I see that the Magistrate has been plotting to rid himself of all competition within the Council. The tarnished adamantinum was just a happy accident he has used to sow further discord."
So he isn't behind the weapons breaking?

The weapons were forged by the best craftsmen in Windholme - as usual. Of late, we have discovered that something is affecting the metal. It has become tarnished, turning brittle and weak after a while. We have no explanation yet for the root cause. \n\nBut for once, the Academy bears no blame. We told Master Reinhardt about it but he accused us of deceiving the Council. We had no choice but to leave before he turned the whole city against us.
So Master Reinhardt knew and used me?
He has tried to trick me into persuing you.
Do you have any proof for your words?
You still sold the useless weapons. That is negligence!
Bring it on!
Tell me your tale then. Not that I believe you.
Then tell me truth about the adamantinum weapons.

I have had enough of this! I won't stand here and suffer any more insults! the old dwarf roars angrily. \n\nBefore you can react, he steps up to the stone wall behind him and melts into it. All around you, you hear the clatter of iron-shod boots.
To arms!

I have a letter… His voice trails off and you can hear a horn sounding from the corridor leading to the chamber.

"We are under attack!” he shouts after a moment. “Argh! The magistrate and his forces have entered our tunnels. You have betrayed us!"

The dwarf runs to the stone wall and seems to melt into it, disappearing.
No! We have nothing to do with this!
No! The magistrate has deceived us as well!

You leave the chamber and come upon a great hall, where Maednir and his dwarves are already facing a small army of the City Watch. You can spot Magistrate Reinhardt behind the lines.\n\n"Ah." He nods. "I see you have come in time for the finale. Thank you for showing us the way in and keeping the dwarves occupied. Now, if you just help us settle this affair, the greatest library in all Fiara will be at your disposal. And I’m sure the Sevenkeeps Council will show their gratitude as well."
Side with the dwarves.
Side with Reinhardt.

Your sacrifice was not in vain.\n\nYou bought the dwarves time to rally, allowing them to fight back against the magistrate’s forces. Reinhardt himself, however, escapes to Sevenkeeps and the gates to the dwarven realm remains locked as the Council finds itself at an impasse.

Magistrate Reinhardt lies dead at your feet but the dwarves catch one of his apprentices, who testifies to his plans to take over the Academy and rule the Council. He even wanted to bewitch the young king so he could control the child and rule in his stead.\n\nYour bravery has not only saved the dwarves, but all of Sevenkeeps from the magistrate’s rule, preventing the Highmark from sinking into civil war. The dwarves are generous and grateful.
Now there shall be peace again.

You are overrun by the defending dwarves, who pour onto the field of battle to drive Reinhardt and his forces back too.\n\nThe magistrate is furious, berating you for your weakness. Sevenkeeps settles into an uneasy truce as the dwarves keep the gates to their realm locked.

Your attack overwhelms Maednir and his forces. Magistrate Reinhardt's men chase the remaining dwarves deep into their tunnels.\n\nReinhardt congratulates you on your victory and the Royal Academy’s library opens its doors to you. You have become a hero to the humans of Sevenkeeps.
Finally a proper reward for my troubles.

Fully heals all mortal units in targeted stack.

Passing through a busy town, you hear talk of moles in the area going rogue.

"They're multiplying like their lives depend on it!"

"That's exactly what it is! They got left behind when the mine was closed, so they've had to adapt! I feel sorry for the poor things. Left to fend for themselves all alone down there..."
We should be mindful of those moles.

This was once a keep of some kind. Now, the walls are crumbling, and only holes in the great hall's masonry tell of the beams that once held several floors aloft.\n\nIn the courtyard, there is a lone well. Strangely, the flowering vines that cover all the walls seem to keep distance to it.
Investigate the main hall.
Take a closer look at the well.

The process of rebuilding your master’s tower is now underway and your attention turns to his grimoire.\n\nIt looks like pages were hastily torn from the tome, though whether by your master or someone else is unclear. On the binding, you also find a spidery pattern of barely legible words, right where some of those pages would have been.
Take a closer look.

Squinting at the tiny script, you realize it forms instructions. They seem to point somewhere a bit further away from the tower.\n\nSurely, this was meant for you to find. Perhaps some of the grimoire’s missing pages are hidden at the locations the instructions point to.
Investigate the places
Having beaten the beasts back, you approach the grimoire’s missing pages’ hiding place, marked by a strange shimmer in the air. Lights dance and swirl all around, leaving you strangely light-headed.

Even from afar you can clearly make out the New Purity's white banners. They are marching on a village. Lytra's hand instinctively reaches for her weapon as she stands in her saddle to get a better view.\n\n"They will round up everyone in that village, young or old. They will torture each and every one of them until they find someone with magic to... 'cleanse'. We must stop them. I can't stand idly by and watch them torture innocents!"
The what? Why would they want me?

A shadow washes over her face and she shifts uncomfortably.\n\n"I... I served the Purity myself. My father sent me to them, telling me they were servants of Aonir, concerned with the fate of the common people, dedicated to the Light. With each passing day, I realized their ways are far from righteous. I cannot bear to witness that. They must be stopped."
And how do you intend to do this?
What do they want with me?

She glances towards your tower and suppresses a shudder.\n\n"They claim practising magic is usurping the Guardians' power. An affront to the Allfather Aonir that leads him and his Guardians to abandon us. They see it as their duty to cleanse anyone practicing magic from their impure desires. Few survive this ordeal."
So how do we stop them?
First I want to know your connection to the Purity.
I am willing to face them and defend you against their crusade, if you grant me your troops. Let me prove my worth to you.
I have no use for you. I can defend myself.
Be my guest.

Her expression freezes for a moment, then she takes a stiff bow and begins to mount her war horse.

"I pray you are right, mage. May Aonir's light bless you."

She rides away without a glance back.
I don't trust her.
Room Crafting Cost Modifier: {RoomCraftingCostModifier:+-pi}
Human Barracks
Blackwood Forest
Broken Weapon
Wheat
The Purity will not prevail!
Approach with care!

As Lytra predicted, the Purity followers are already busy rounding up villagers in the market square. One of their leaders preaches about Aonir and how he will not return as long as Eo remains tainted by the practice of magic. The villagers listen in fear, crying and begging for mercy.
Storm the village.
Let's try to talk to their leader.
The New Purity is stronger than you expected.

The townsfolk flee into their homes during the fight and only reemerge when it has died down.

"Thank you for defending us. We don't have any arcanists here, just a wise woman. The Purity would have killed her, though she never harmed a soul. Let us thank you with this humble gift."

You are handed a pouch filled with fragrant herbs and other ingredients.
We shall rain vengeance on these fanatics!
Thank you. I hope you will be safe now.

All eyes turn on you. The leader's face shifts from surprise to burning hatred.

"You wield your blasphemous magic openly, sorcerer! You will be cleansed! Neither word nor coin will lead us astray from the path of righteousness!"

He signals his troops to attack.
So much for diplomacy.
