Lytra approaches you with a sorrowful expression. She bows stiffly, waiting for your eyes to meet before posing her request.

"When I led the Purity into the Misty Coast, we caught a shaman of the Stonebuilder orc clan. I have had word he is still alive - imprisoned in one of the Purity's strongholds. I have to save him, if I can."

You can see it pains her to be responsible for the shaman's fate. Not everyone would think of an orc this way.
Do what you must.
What do the Purity hope to gain from him?
What do you care for an orc?

The Purity has taken refuge in an old watchtower. An orc is being held in a kennel at the front of the tower, guarded by a few soldiers. He looks weak and exhausted, his skin blistered from multiple brands.\n\n"That is the shaman," Lytra says. "To think I led these soldiers in our assault on the clan's village..."
I am uncertain. The tribe did supposedly posses knowledge of an old, orcish artifact. Zarach's Banner, I think it was called. Maybe they want that, for some reason.
All the more reason to stop them.
I doubt they have the banner, but still worth investigating.
I care that the shaman and his village suffer because of me. I must right the wrong I contributed to. Please, let me absolve myself of this.
Make it quick.
Fish Trap
Grants faster and 10% cheaper [bonus][iroom:c] room crafting[/] when inside your [mDomain].
We could set fire to the tower and block the doors.

Lytra rides towards the guarded tower and hails the white-clad soldiers, bellowing orders. They looked confused but open the prisoner's cage. With an air of authority wrapped around her like a cloak, Lytra leads the prisoner away. None of the soldiers dare stop her.\n\nQuickly returning to you, she reports: "News of my desertion hasn't reached them yet. They think I am delivering the prisoner to the Westguard. Quickly now, let's be away before they realize their folly."
That went... very well!
The orc seems to recognize his savior. Shaking from exhaustion, he looks at Lytra with a mixture of disgust and anger.\n\n"I know you. You are with the whitecloaks. Why help me now?"
She saved your life. A little gratitude would be good.
She wants to repent for what she did.

Lytra carefully steps forward.

"I wronged you. I know that. But I no longer follow the Purity and want to fix my past mistakes. I am truly sorry for the harm I caused you and your clan."

The shaman remains silent for a while before replying: "Zarach teaches that the fire of our actions burns away guilt. If you wish for that, come to my village soon. You must see something."
We will be there.
No matter how many enemies fall, the tower seems to contain yet more.
We lost today, but we will win tomorrow.
Lytra shakes her head sharply.\n\n"They'd deserve it, but we cannot stoop to their level. No. We fight them honorably, or not at all!"
Then you may call the charge!
Then we should gather more troops.

The orcish village is a scene of desolation. Many dwellings have been destroyed. Everywhere are large mounds of ash and charcoal. Pyres, erected and already burned out. Amid it all, the shaman stands as part of a small group, many of them wounded and scarred, most staring at you in fear and hatred.\n\n"Here," the shaman says harshly, sweeping an arm across the scene. "This is what happened when I was caught by you and the whitecloaks. Your father's soldiers slaughtered my clan without mercy. Your regret will bring none of them back."
My father would never do something like this!
My father's men? But...why?

The shaman keeps his face stoic. "You know in your heart I speak the truth. Your father has always hated us, coveted our lands. He used the Purity to weaken the village so that he could strike. Our dead are witness to his cruelty!"\n\nLytra trembles. "You don't know he ordered this slaughter. I am sorry for your loss, really, but there is no proof here he was involved. I will get to the bottom of this, mark my word. Whoever it was shall be punished."

The shaman laughs bitterly: "Child, your father has always hated us and coveted our lands. He used the Purity to weaken our clan then struck when he saw the chance. Greed drove him to this."

Lytra trembles. In a low voice, she replies: "He has lied to me my whole life. He used me to further his ambitions and gave me to the Purity as a pawn in his schemes."

She holds her hand to her heart. "I swear he will pay for this. Justice will be served!"
I am sorry for your losses.
Let them mourn their dead.

Lytra stands before you, her face determined and her voice steely.\n\n"I have thought about what the shaman said. I know in my heart he spoke the truth. My father deceived me all my life, abusing me to further his own ambition. Whatever his goals are, he and the Purity must be stopped once and for all. I must leave for the Westguard and put an end to my father's reign."
You want to wage war on the Westguard?
She nods grimly.\n\n"Yes. I think... it is the only way. My father cannot be allowed to continue his rule. We must march against the Westguard and the New Purity's strongholds."
Are you sure? He is still your father.
War should be our last resort.

Rengar Storme has agreed to meet on neutral ground - an old inn near the Westguard's borders. He has certainly brought a respectable force with him. There are guards outside, at the ready, and more waiting nearby.

He sits at a table in the middle of the room, his sword lying in front of him. His dark look speaks of both irritation and disappointment. Lytra's shoulders sag slightly at the sight of the man in plate armor.

"I thought I taught you better, Lytra. Stand straight and speak fast. Why have you betrayed me?"
It is you who lied and betrayed my trust!
I am not here to quarrel.
Lucky
This unit is lucky and increases the chance of its stack to find more items

New Purity adherents swarm out from behind trees and boulders, blocking your path.

"Halt! Lytra Storme, you are under arrest for heresy and treason against the Order!"

Lytra glares at the assembled soldiers. You think you spot one of the shaman's guards from the tower among them.
You dare show your faces again?
Your troops are bested by the New Purity.
I will get them next time.
I spared you. This is how you thank me?

The soldiers shift uncomfortably. Many of them look ill equipped - perhaps peasants who fell for promises of light work and good pay.\n\n"But... we have to catch someone. If we return empty handed, our heads will roll. We're just following orders."
Take some gold. Leave the Purity and go home.
That is your problem, not mine.

The young man who spoke takes the money with trembling hands. The others look relieved and the band quickly disperses.\n\n"Like me, they were just pawns in this," Lytra says, her voice thick with bitterness and regret.
At least they will return home alive.

The battle is over quickly, dead soldiers lining the path. Many of them were little more than peasants in armor. They died for someone else's cause and there will be many bereft families in the local villages.
There was no glory in this.

Rengar stands and walks to the front door, resetting his armored gloves and helmet. Without so much as a glance back he says: "Farewell then. I will see you on the field of battle."\n\nLytra stands still for a moment, very straight and very pale. With a sigh, holds her weapon tight and follows him. "Let's end this," she says tonelessly.
I am sorry it had to come to this.
The enemy forces make short work of your troops.
Rengar will pay for this.

Tears run down lytra's cheeks as she surveys the aftermath of the battle.\n\n"I know it was the right thing to do." She starts cleaning the blood from her shield to distract herself. "Yet all I feel is sadness and pain. May Aonir guide him to the true light."
I am sorry for your loss.
Don't shed a tear for this villain.
Lytra will want to do this herself.
The shaman requested that Lytra see this too.
Lytra must be here to talk to her father.
Forwards! Ignore the lights!
I will cast a protective ward around the expedition.
Your ward bolsters the minds and protects the eyes of your whole company, allowing you to press on to your objective without delay.

Your troops push forward. Despite your instructions, many start to stumble and their formation quickly loses cohesion.\n\nTo make matters worse, when you are finally through you find that some of your followers have not emerged with you. They have vanished, without a trace.
No matter. Push on!
The goal is near now.

You are confronted by a dark, gaping hole. When you throw down a torch, you catch a glint of light in the depths – a reflection of metal, you think. You send someone down attached to a thick rope and some time later they return with a small box.\n\nInside lies one of the missing grimoire pages, weathered but in one piece.
My master's secrets finally in my hands!
I apologize on this dwarf's behalf. I'll pay for the damages.

The dwarf is brought before you wearing a leather apron, goggles and a dusting of soot. The innkeeper comes by too, a lanky human with a receding hairline and a singed eyebrow. Both talk at the same time.

"I told him my experiment is unstable and not to enter my room! How should I know he has a cleaning fetish?"

"I never agreed to him using my inn as a laboratory for his crazy experiments! My life's work is ruined!"
What were you working on, Stonebreaker?
Sorry he caused trouble. He'll work in my tower from now on.

Both look at you in surprise. The dwarf regains his composure first, nodding to you and then to the innkeeper.

"Beyond generous, great mage. Of course, I shall repay you for your patronage in kind. Lore Grimm, at your service."

The tavern owner agrees with far less enthusiasm, mumbling a response.

The dwarf clears his throat and straightens his shoulders.\n\n"My name is Lore Grimm. I am working on controlled explosives - something more precise than simple black powder. But this imbecile ruined my experiment! Now I have to start collecting materials again. And build a new laboratory."

The tavern owner rolls his eyes.

"I will await reimbursement then. I'll come by again to collect."

Meanwhile, the dwarf's face brightens at the idea. His mouth works wordlessly for a moment, so stunned is he by your offer.
You can work in mine.
That's very dangerous for an inn.
How far along are your experiments?
I hope you bring forth useful inventions.
Move your experiments into my laboratory.
Tell me why the inn exploded.

I only need a couple more tries. I'm sure of it. The explosives I’m making are already much more refined and contained. I just need to find a way to make them more manageable. I was in the tavern so I could venture out to find materials. They weren't available at home.
Finish your work in my laboratory.
You can use my materials.
The innkeeper whose livelyhood Lore's experiments destroyed comes to you again, asking for recompense.\n\n"My tavern burned to cinders. I need to build myself a new life. Will you help?"
This isn't my fault, or my problem.
I cannot now, but come back and I will pay you.
I hope this can help you.
The man looks satisfied with the money you give him, taking it eagerly.\n\n"You really are kind. Thank you. I will build close by and, if a thirst bothers you, you can always come to me."
All the best with your business.
I'll come by and visit.
The man stares at you grimly for a moment before grumbling: "I do hope you intend to keep that promise."
Don't doubt it.
Out of my sight before I change my mind!

The man's face goes pale then turns to red. He screams at the top of his lungs.\n\n"Guardians, curse you! Hirin will never take you to the river beyond! Your soul will rot in the darkest places, next to Nor and Zarach! I curse you, mage! I curse you!"
Oh no. Whatever will I do?
Take some dignity as you go.

Once more, the innkeeper stands before you. This time, he has brought others.\n\n"Great mage, let me introduce my family. My wife, Mara. My daughters, Samantha and Diana. My son, Silas. We're living in a neighbor's shed at the moment. Please, we need some money to build a home. Will you help this time?"
Sorry for keeping you waiting. Here is some gold.
I cannot pay you. Is there anything else I can do?
Oh, enough of this. Guards!
He firmly shakes his head.\n\n"I will come by one more time. Next time, I must either have gold or Lore Grimm. I will not leave this tower without one or the other."
Thank you for your patience.
You aren't in the position to give demands.
Your guards escort the family outside. You hear the innkeeper's outraged cries and his wife and children whining.
How bothersome.
They better not come back.
A familiar voice shouts out: "Lore Grimm! Your master hasn't paid your debt! It is on you to do so!"\n\nThe disgruntled innkeeper moves towards you, leading a rather brutal looking group behind.
Be reasonable! Here, I have your money.
How about you take another taste of my explosives?
We should leave.

The man rips the coins from you as if he doesn't trust you or your word. He counts it all out before he nods.

"Fine. The debt is paid."

He waves the others to follow him and turns away.
At least he won't bother us again.
I hope to visit your tavern soon!

Killing farmers and bandits doesn't feel right but somehow you know that they would not have given up. Lore even speaks a small prayer for each of them.\n\n"I'm sorry it had to come to this. But I'm also thankful you stood behind me. Beyond words. I'll work hard on my experiments, I promise."
You are overwhelmed in short time. At the very least, the innkeeper doesn't have reason to keep bothering you.
Guardians, guide the souls of the dead.
How did it come to this?
I'm sure you will, Lore.
Remember these deaths the next time you work.
It seems the innkeeper and his militia have caught up with you.\n\n"We will not stop hunting Lore Grimm, until either his blood flows or ours!"
Well in that case...
You fools! We will never let you catch us!

After a night of research, Lore comes to your study, bleary eyed but with a huge smile.\n\n"I think I've done it. I found a way to improve my bombs! The solution seems to be adding dried shrooms to my mixture. If you provide the ingredients, I can build a prototype at once!"
Let's not waste time.
Shrooms? Really?

The dwarf emerges from the laboratory visibly disappointed.

"I must have miscalculated, but we are on the right path. If we can kill some Firebugs, I can study their anatomy. They can produce fire on command and this could improve my work too."

With a shy grin he adds: "I only need a couple!"
That shouldn't be a problem.
Fine, I suppose.

You are witness to the tedious process of adding and mixing more powders and liquids extracted from the firebugs for the bomb. \n\nLore measures everything, noting every step down to the positioning of his fingers. Finally, he reaches for a bottle and tries to pour its contents over the bowl, only to find it empty. He scowls at the blue, bulbous glass with great disappointment.
What now?

Once past the dead beasts, you can clearly see the place is aglow with magic. The ground shudders with a deep, resonant hum. Surely this must be where your master has left one of the grimoire’s missing pages.\n\nIn the center of this magical nexus, you think you can see it, floating in the air. Is it safe to take it?
March forth without fear!
Is there some way to reach the page without entering?

When you push into the vortex, the swirling light immediately blooms to blind and shock you. It shrinks and then explodes in a shimmering wave. Behind you, armor and weapons clatter to the floor. Their bearers?\n\nNo longer there.
They...they just vanished?
But with the vortex dissipated, having taken its toll on your company, the spell page floats listlessly and harmlessly to the ground.
I hope the page was worth it!

You channel your power through your soldiers, so that when they step into the vortex, its magic does not affect them.\n\nYou hear a shrill but muffled sound and the vortex vanishes. Before you, the page floats harmlessly to the ground.
We have it! I am eager to see what it says.

The lone warrior you send forth is cautious to enter the swirling vortex. For a moment, both seem to flicker, as the humming changes to a high-pitched scream from within.\n\nWith a shrill, the light finally vanishes and your champion, though tired and hurt, clutches the spell page tightly.
Your band tries to reach the page with a long pole, but the swirling lights shake and rattle it, making the task virtually impossible.\n\nThis will not help you retrieve the page.
We must enter the aura.
Borostor
You need this more than I do. Keep your money.
Is this really all your husband is worth?
Let's search for the magic source.
Some rewards locked due to low reputation.
Lyraine is a peaceful and wealthy town, profiting from Goldenfields grains and fruits. Most people here are friendly and open and there is always a reason to celebrate something.
The Dancing Rat

The distant noise of singing slowly filters through your mind. It is muffled and far away, but seems to be moving closer with steady speed.\n\nNot long later, the singing comes to a crescendo at your door, and the song is replaced by a knock.
Enter, whoever you are.
I am working! Do not disturb me.
If I ignore you, will you...

The door opens. A female dwarf steps inside with a bright grin on her face and a mug in her hand.
You are perplexed, for they are a rare sight, especially outside of their homes.

"Good day, master mage! Please, do carry on. I don't wish to disturb you!

Alright, that was a lie, I do. My name is Yngrid. I have found a magical artifact that could interest you!"

With her free hand, she draws a piece of paper from her belt and triumphantly slaps it on the table before you.
This is just a piece of paper.
What am I looking at, Yngrid?
I have little time for games.

Without missing a beat, Yngrid pokes her index finger at the crude drawing on the paper.

"This, my dear mage, is a key! It draws the owner to a specific place, wanting nothing more to be reunited with its lock.

I owned this key, for some time, and I felt its draw. But, alas, someone stole it. I was robbed in a tavern.

This is where you come in! I want to retrieve the artifact and find out what it unlocks. It whispered of old and powerful magic. I have a sneaking suspicion it might be Shaper made."
Shaper made? Do you have any other information?
Intriguing! I hope you find it again.
This is a waste of my time. Leave at once.
Yngrid grabs the paper from the table and mocks you with a deep bow before turning on her heel and leaving without another word.
Good riddance.
She was rather grating.

Her expression darkens and she shakes her head.

"Sadly, I lost track of the bastard who stole the key. He'll probably be in a tavern, but I need to find out which.

So, how about it, mage? Want to work together to uncover this secret?"

Yngrid offers her hand for you to shake. As you take it, she laughs and grins wildly.\n\n"I knew you'd see reason! Thank you. I can return the favor. I might not look it, but I know how to swing an axe, so call on me if you need a hearty fighter! Now, if you'll excuse me, my Whiskey is waiting for me."
Your... Whiskey?
Yes. You convinced me.
Shield
Melee Weapon
Heavy Armor
Light Armor
Melee Weapon Slot
I understand. You meant no harm. We shall spare you.

The woman's sobbing continues. "Thank you kindly for your mercy! Here, take the gold from that accursed treasure, as thanks for sparing my life."\n\nYou accept but the other villagers eye you suspiciously.
Be gone. The matter is resolved.
Then I shall set off and deal with the 'unnatural'.

The door bursts open, startling you. With a loud voice, Yngrid announces: "Good news, master mage! I found the ass! My mount, Whiskey, sniffed him out. He is hiding in a tavern. We should hurry, before he leaves."
What are you waiting for?
I have other things to attend to first.

The tavern is barely more than four walls held together by the smell of rancid beer. Most patrons are hidden under wide brimmed hoods or armed to the teeth.\n\nOne table holds the whole room's attention. Someone is watching the man opposite them mix three cups, a pile of gold and a leather pouch next to them. When the mixing stops, the whole room leans closer. The player's hand hovers over the cups, stopping atop the left one. The dealer's eye twitches. The player grins savagely as they lift the cup, but there is nothing underneath. They scream angrily, throwing the cup across the room and stomping off to the audience's cheer.
That's my contact. I guess we need to play for the information.
I have no time for games. I need information.
He won't talk without persuasion. Someone restrain him.

He nods and resets the game, covering up the walnut and smoothly shuffling the cups.

"Which will it be? Choose wisely and the artifact will be yours."

Yngrid watches the dealer just like the player before her, slowly moving her hands over the cups one after the other. The dealer's eye twitches as she reaches the right cup.

He blanches a little, raising both hands defensively.

"Hold on, now. There is no need for violence. You see, all these people here are my patrons. This is my tavern. And you know how unruly people get when no one is there to pour the beer."

All around you, chairs scrape against the floor, and weapons scrape against sheaths.

So impatient. The man clicks his tongue and shakes his head. "You'll need to play for that information."

He shows you a single walnut, places a cup over it and two more to its sides. He shuffles them, then looks at you slyly.

"Well?"
I take the left one!
Hah, it must be the middle one.
I'll play you for the axe and the information!
It's under the right one, I know it.
This is too much. But I’ll be back with more.
Lodges
Stacks
Lodges
Inspect
Buy

The informant chuckles and drags the gold towards him. As he sees Yngrid approaching, he points her to a walnut on the table.\n\n"Come, young lady, sit! Do you want to play a game? For only a bit of coin I will wager this pouch, which holds an artifact of magnificent value. What do you say?"
Absolutely! We'll play.
This is ridiculous. Tell her what she wants to know, now.
A fight you want, a fight you'll get.
It seems we misunderstood each other. Let's play.
This is ridiculous. Tell us what we want to know, now.
Stepping inside the tavern, you realize you have no idea what to look for without Yngrid.
I will return with her.
I suppose we'll return with the money then.
The fight is over before anyone can say: "By the mighty Allfather!" Your troops are struck down without mercy.

After defeating the tarvern fighters, you return to the owner, who is crouching behind his table.

"P-please! I have information! You want Garam, right? The one who stole from Yngrid? He only stayed for one quick drink and rations. He was as white as a sheet, kept looking around. I thought he might be being hunted!"

He quickly draws a crude map on a piece of parchment.
Never pick a fight in a tavern.
Hirin, guide them through the river.
Next time, you know to tell us sooner.
We'll take the artifact and those rations, please.

The informant greets you.

"Welcome back, friends. Have you collected your money?"

He has just won another game, the player retreating from the table like a beaten dog.
Let's play already.
We're not quite ready yet.

His eyes never leave Yngrid as he mixes the cups again. With a wide gesture, he invites her to choose one and leans back confidently. You catch his face twitching again, barely visible, as she moves over the left cup. Yngrid fixates him with an intent stare and thinks aloud.\n\n"Your eye twitching is just a ruse. You use it to lull players into a false sense of security. So, the correct cup is..."

He raises the cup, but there is no walnut underneath. Yngrid quickly grabs the other two and a walnut rolls away.\n\n"You know I don't cheat, young lady! That hurts my feelings. Another round, hmm? Maybe that'll prove my honor."
Fine. I'll get it this time.
Of course you are cheating!
Ah, ah! Careful. My patrons don't like people accusing their bartender.
Then they can fight me for it.
Fine. Let's get this over with.
...the left one.
...the middle one.
...the right one.

Yngrid lifts the cup, and he is genuinely surprised as she reveals the walnut. She immediately motions for the pouch in front of him, smirking, and he laughs loudly.

"You got me. A clever young lady, I'll admit. The artifact is yours.

As for the information you seek - Garam was the one who stole from you. He was here, bought some rations, and wandered off." He quickly draws a crude map on a piece of parchment. "That's all I know."
We'll set out. Good game!
Much appreciated. We'll leave you to it.
He squints at her, but lifts the cup to reveal an empty space. Yngrid looks at him, perplexed.\n\n"No... That can't be! Let me play again!"
Yngrid! Please stop gambling with my money!
I have had it with you and your tricks.
Thanks, you old bastard. Another game when I return?
The man gives Yngrid a fond laugh.\n\n"You've lost in here so many times, I don't doubt I can beat you again. I hardly believe you saw through it this time! Took you long enough."
Please don't gamble away all my money, Yngrid.
Yngrid will want to help you find Garam.
She will guide us to the key.

Following single file tracks, you hear screaming, howling and wailing. As you move closer, you see orcish slavers around a pit trap, looking down in amusement as slaves quail at their warg guards.

In the pit is a lone man, trying tirelessly to climb the steep walls. He never makes it more than half way, and they are already slippery with blood from his raw hands and knees. A never ending stream of maddened pleas erupt from his mouth.

"Let me out! Let me ouuuuut! I need to go! I have to! I have to!"
We'll take him off your hands!
Kill the slavers!
One of the orcs snorts at you.\n\n"You think you can handle this cracked nut? Take him, if you can pay for him."

The man laughs and looks at her fondly.\n\n"You've left more than enough money on the table, Yngrid. You're looking for Garam. He was here, bought some rations and left again." He quickly draws a crude map on a piece of parchment. "That's all I know."
Thank you for the help.
Then we are off as well.
{DamageBonus:+-c} Damage

A magical calling envelops you. Only half aware, you lead your troops right into the pit trap.\n\nGaram, hands bloody, sees his chance and climbs over you to escape. By the time you are free of your stupor, it is too late to escape the pit, and the orcs devastate your forces.
I am sorry for leading you to your death. I will make sure it was not in vain.
Convince them to let us take him.
Aye, we will come back for more.
A few of your orcish troops negotiate the release of the prisoner. The slavers tell them he has been screaming for two solid days, then move on.
Then we take him by force.
Here you go.

The slaver looks perplexed, but laughs heartily.

"You must be mad yourself. Fine then. Take him and go."

Yngrid stares hard at Garam, swallowing hard. For a moment, you see a glint of insanity in her eyes too, staring at the strange object that hangs around Garam's neck on a thin, leather cord.

The orc who addressed you moves closer now, folding his arms in front of his chest. A thin smile bares his tusks as he looks at Yngrid, then you.\n\n"Fine, smart ass. Half the price. But you get to take him out the pit yourself."
Deal.
You ask too much for a delirious prisoner.
What are you waiting for, Yngrid?
Let's do this quickly.
Let's get him out of there.
Necromancer

A dust cloud overtakes you as a heavy wind rushes over the land. As it settles, you see stocky figures in the distance, drawing closer. Whiskey shifts his weight nervously, then plants his feet into the ground and makes a growling noise. Yngrid groans and whispers a curse under her breath.

"Brace yourselves, everyone."

A group of dwarves comes up to you, all of them heavily armored.

"Halt! Yngrid Firemead, I demand you come with me! I will not let my wife be killed on an fool's errand!"
What is the meaning of this?
Ignore him. Let's go.

Yngrid takes a long swig from a flask and rolls her eyes. Her declared husband speaks up again.

"We were to be married this year, as was arranged at our births. But Yngrid decided to run off, leaving nothing but a letter behind saying, 'Seeking adventure! Good luck!"

The dwarf fumes, but Yngrid barely contains a mischievous smile.

"I've told you for years, Thoradin. Years! I'm not interested in marriage. I don't want to be bound to hearth and home."
My name is Elynn. I am a Shaikan of the Seltris Banner. I offer my services to you if you are willing to trade me yours in return!
That's a rare offer.
I want nothing to do with your ilk, I have enough warriors as is.

I was accompanying my sisters to the Snakepass, to complete my warrior's rites. We were attacked by some undead armored beings and I was knocked unconscious in the battle. When I awoke, they were all gone. I cannot return home without at least trying to find my sisters but I cannot fight those abominations alone. Will you help me?
I have a few questions first...

From her pouch, Elynn retrieves a carefully folded piece of thick, yellowish paper.

"I have tried to find out more about the Hollow Guards. Tahar used an artifact to fight them and their masters. The Might of the Giants it is called, a great hammer forged by the giant Utrur and repaired by the Circle mage Isgrimm himself. With it, I may be able to face them and free my sisters.

But these scribbles here make no sense to me. They are written in some magical script. I need you to decipher them so I can find my sisters."
You could ask Isgrimm himself.

The dwarf steps forward, putting a heavy hand on her shoulder.

"You were promised to me! You know what it means to our culture, your family. You know why we make these sacrifices."

"Don't touch me, Thoradin! You are sacrificing nothing, and I am more than a child-bearer! I've told you a hundred times, I'm not responsible for my parents' promises. I will. Not. Be trapped!"
There are too many. We should go.
Yngrid has duties here that she is sworn to fulfil.
Lay a finger on my soldier and we will destroy you.
Yngrid's choice seems clear to me.
Yngrid has duties here that she is sworn to fulfil.

Thoradin looks at Yngrid in disbelief.

"Are these the people you surround yourself with? Savages who dishonor promises?"

Yngrid looks up at him, challenging him with burning eyes.

“My parents’ promises, Thoradin. Not theirs. And not mine either.”

Her betrothed turns red as beets and small veins shake on his temple. With an expression of pure disgust, he slaps her squarely in the face.

Thoradin's face turns ashen, and then red as hot coal.\n\n"You think you can bind her to you with honor?! You hold none! She was promised to me! I can't choose another. There are none to choose! This will be the end of our families, our... legacy!"
Then let's fight for it. Winner takes all.
Fine. A fight it is then.
Try this again, and you'll regret it. Good bye.

When only Thoradin remains, Yngrid grabs him by the collar and pulls him close. Whiskey growls again, baring his teeth at the dwarf.

"Go home, Thoradin. Tell my parents I won't forgive them for sending you after me. And tell yours I'm sorry they have you for a son."

She pushes him away and watches him run for the Windwall Mountains, petting Whiskey.

"Come on, Whiskey. We have to find Garam."
Let's hope they don't push the point.
He deserved worse. Let's go.
Thoradin is victorious over Yngrid, spitting on her as he leaves her crumpled in the dirt.
May Niethalf himself strike him down.
[bonus]Is built[/]
[malus]Is Not built[/]
Gate

The shocked screams of a woman draw your attention towards the pastures where she is kneeling, crying over a herd of brutally slain and gutted sheep. Other villagers come running from their houses, faces mixed with pity, compassion, and appal.\n\n"These wounds, those are not wolves'. What in Aonir's name is killing our livestock?"
Elynn Seltris
That is both dangerous and stupid.

Lore snorts and walks to the door.

"I won't tolerate words of belittlement from someone inept in alchemy. Good day."

The innkeeper follows him, pestering Lore for reimbursements until they fade from earshot.
That was a waste of time.
May we take a look at them?

You find a storage silo crawling with large bugs. They must have already devoured half of the grain, for there is not much left inside.\n\nThose must be the creatures that tore into Lyrains livestock.
No time to waste! Kill them!
Burn it all down.
After your fight you see tracks leading all over the surrounding fields, suggesting some bugs fled to the next silo.
Hurry! We can't let them multiply!
You hear the crack of chitin plates and high pitched screeching as the flames consume the bugs with the grain and silo itself.
Onto the next beasts.
The animals have made it to another field, feasting on crops and smaller creatures.
We have to return with stronger forces.
You will die just like the others!
Heroic Victory
You win without losses.
Close Defeat
The enemy has the edge.
Pyrrhic Victory
You will suffer great losses.
Close Victory
You will lose some units.
Decisive Victory
You might lose some units.
Decisive Defeat
The enemy will completely destroy you.

A shudder runs through his whole body. You wait, nervous. Suddenly, with a groan, his eyes stop glowing and he falls to his knees.

"Ugh. My head... What...?!"

As he looks around, his eyes fall on one of the statues in the ruin's center. He quickly scrambles away from it in fear.
Ah! That's the source. Destroy it!
Now is our chance to kill them.

You charge forwards and strike the statue. It tips and falls from its pedestal, shattering to the ground. At the same moment the cursed men collapse. One of them drops a goblet that rolls away - it looks like it would have fit quite nicely into the statue's hand.
We need to return whatever you took from the ruin.
With shaking hands, he brings forth a stone goblet with glyphs etched on the rim. He gingerly places it in the statue's hand. For a moment, nothing happens, and Benjamin gives you a panicked look.
Wait for it!
The only thing you find is a half decayed book, almost completely covered in moss and mostly illegible. But it definitely is old.
A good find.
Give them a moment.

Slain insects clutter the ground, providing you with some insight over their physique. After burning their bodies, you inform the people of Lyraine that you defeated the threat and soon enough, word of your work spreads through the Highmark.
That went well.
Word of your deeds travels throughout Goldenfields. People spread tales of your brave soldiers and cunning plan to destroy the bugs.
The people seem to like us.
Walking Corpses
Treasure Stash
Zombie Curse
Killed mortal units turn into [unit][isquadsize:c]Walking Corpses[/] after battle, when they suffered enough damage from a unit with this ability.
Aria
Distilled Aria
Black Ash
Black Wood

You meticulously transcribe the text Elynn gave you on the Might of the Giants.\n\nIt seems like it was buried with Tahar, as it was never seen again after his death. Visiting his grave should be your next step.
Once more, Thoradin and his men catch up to you.\n\n"I won't let you get away, Yngrid! You are coming with me!"
Oh, enough of this!
Can we buy Yngrid's freedom?
Guardians be damned! Run!

When only Thoradin remains, Yngrid grabs him by the collar and throws him in the direction of the Whindwall Mountains. He staggers to stay upright, fleeing as she shouts after him and Whiskey growls.\n\n"Go home, Thoradin! Tell my parents I won't forgive them for sending you after me! Tell yours I'm sorry they have you as a son!"
Let's hope they don't push the issue.
He deserved worse. Let's go.
Thoradin does not stop beating Yngrid even as she lies in defeat, spitting on her when the fighting is done.
At least the score is settled now.
May Neithalf himself strike him down.

Yngrid shoots you a confused scowl, but Thoradin's anger vanishes. He laughs at first, then realizes you mean what you say.\n\nWhat could you possibly pay that is worth a wife to me? It would have to be a treasure beyond all coin!"
I rather just fight for my freedom.
Entangle

Yngrid guides you towards the mountains. For a while, it looks as though she's following the wrong tracks, but then you notice arches overhead, spreading across the deep canyon you now walking. The stone is artfully carved into hidden glyphs, ornaments and statues.\n\nYou find Garam lying in front of a giant stone plate at the end of the way. His necklace is now firmly lodged into a slit in the end of the plate, and two large, imposing statues with spears sit on either side of it, watching Garam with lifeless eyes.
Restrain him!

Yngrid steps forward to investigate the door again.

"I feel like I should be able to understand this!"

She gives a frustrated chuckle, going over the glyphs carefully again and again.
We shall come back once more...
Is he alright?
This is a shaper ruin. We should inspect it closer.
This is too much. We'll be back with more.

Yngrid's companion and mount, Whiskey, has been acting strange for the past hour. Suddenly he stops and furiously scratches at some earth. Yngrid steps off and looks at the ground.

"What have you found, boy? What is it?"

Whiskey uncovers the vein of some ore.
Good boy, Whiskey!
That is exactly what we needed.
A convenient find.
Whiskey stops walking, and starts chewing on some plants. Yngrid takes a closer look at them.\n\n"He must have a stomach ache. This is a healing plant."
Will he recover quickly?
You do give him some strange snacks.

The large mole that follows Yngrid around at every waking moment nudges a peculiar stone with one of his large, shovel paws. Upon closer inspection, Yngrid gives him a treat.\n\n"Did my boy find some copper? Hmm? Are you a good boy? Yes you are. Yes you are!"
This is a very odd relationship.
A good find. Good boy, Whiskey.
Come on. Let's continue our journey.
Might of the Giants
King of the Hill
A large Westguard army is assembled here, their flags flying in the wind.\n\n"They fly my family's crest," Lytra tells you. "This is my father's banner guard. It will not be an easy fight."
Enter the battle!
Glistening white Purity banners flutter over the camp. Their forces are already moving into formation to defend against you - they must have seen your approach early on.
Yngrid slowly moves closer to the man. He doesn't even twitch as she kicks him against the shin.\n
Heal the poor bastard.

After hours of research and translation, you finally decipher the glyphs. You know now, the stone plate is the door to a temple. Its magic is depleted. The statues need energy to activate the opening mechanism.
Be prepared for possible danger.
Let me talk to them. This might end without bloodshed.
Lay a trap.
Lytra should really be here for this.
With your nod, she approaches the soldiers alone. Her words don't carry back to you, but the fanatics' body language reveals everything. They will not be swayed.
Enough of this. Attack!
Lytra firmly shakes her head.\n\n"Theirs is the way of lies and deceit. I will not partake in it. We will meet them in honorable battle."
Perhaps we can parlay?
To arms!
These forces were far stronger than you anticipated.
We shall rain vengeance on them.
The pain of killing her former comrades is etched into Lytra's face, leaving deep lines that age her far beyond her years. When the fighting ends, she prays for the fallen.
Aonir, watch over them.

With your nod, Lytra approaches the soldiers alone. You watch as she shakes hands with the commander and after some discussion returns to you with a relieved smile.\n\n"I know their commander. Batir was one of my teachers. He saw reason in my words and he is willing to surrender if we promise to let them go unharmed."
Let them go freely
No mercy. We will not let them leave without punishment.
Lytra's gaze darkens, but she salutes stifly.\n\n"As you wish. But I am afraid that means we will have to fight them."
So be it.
With the battle won, you have the banners pulled to the ground.
We have done well.
Daze
Slugger
Attacks have a chance to daze enemies
Ragehammers
Yngrid would wish to discover the key's secret with you.
I shall return with her.
This must be a door, but I see no handle.
I must inspect those statues. They almost feel alive.
Even when his wounds are healed, Garam does not awaken. He must be deeply exhaused from his long journey and hardship. You certainly won't be able to question him any time soon.
Let me look at this plate.
These statues are beautiful, even if old.

The statues and the door look weathered and smoothed by endless years of wind and rain, but tiny glyphs twist and intertwine around everything you see. You don't recognize most of them, but you might decipher them with time. Over it all, the hum of magic pulses from behind the plates like a heartbeat.
Make a rubbing of the glyphs. I'll study them.
This magic must be what drew Garam here. Curious.
Lesser Glyph: Firewielder
Lesser Glyph: Graverobber
Lesser Glyph: Seer
Lesser Glyph: Healthy
Greater Glyph: Seer
Greater Glyph: Graverobber
Greater Glyph: Firewielder
Corrupted Glyph: Firewielder
Cleanse Ally
Corrupted Glyph: Seer
Raid Tomb
Corrupted Glyph: Graverobber
Pure Glyph: Firewielder
Pure Glyph: Seer
Pure Glyph: Graverobber
Pure Glyph: Healthy
Lesser Glyph: Bowman
Artifact of the Bowman
Lesser Glyph: Cutthroat
Let's make haste.

Tahar's remains are housed in a mausoleum, covered in snow overlooking a mountain valley.\n\nPillars of strangely shimmering, white stone support a semicircular roof. A raised sarcophagus lies within, made of the same material. A plaque set at its base tells of Tahar's deeds. Strong metal bands lock the lid tightly shut. The closer you get, the more they seem to constrict. A magical measure to keep the corpse safe from looters, no doubt.
Read the plaque.

Elynn calls on you, her expression one of grim conviction.\n\n"I have tracked down the creatures that took my sisters. The time to strike is now! Allow me to lead your troops into battle against the Hollow Guards!"
Go with my blessings.

So did I, Elynn says. "Hokan has been harassing my people for years, but I didn't think he had Hollow Guards at his side. He must have found some of the remains of the Purity's servants and conjured new unlife into them.\n\nIt doesn't matter. If he has my sisters, it is even more important that we free them. If he uses their blood in his designs, then destroys us with their help, my shame will be doubly so."
Prepare a direct assault.

Some of your followers have stopped by a tavern to rest, so before they move on, you head in to get an idea for local news. To your surprise, a small band of Shaikan mercenaries are sitting, drinking and eating.\n\nPerhaps they know something of Hokan's plans, or have seen something of the Hollow Guards empowered by Elynn's sisters essence.
You there! Tell me what you know!

I must make an offering to Hirin to ensure my sisters' guidance to the beyond, Elynn states bluntly. "There is a shrine a few days march from here. I wish to go."\n\nFor a trained mercenary, she definitely does not think much of the chain of command...
Put your sisters to rest with my blessings.

Good day. My name is Philo Heath. I have come because a strange dream haunts me. When the darkest hour of night falls, I see a book and a tower, much like yours. It is suddenly ripped apart by a shadow. And, sometimes, I awaken in strange places, not knowing how I got there.\n\nI can't explain it. Can you... make it stop? Can you help me?

After a hard day's walk, Philo suddenly stops in his tracks. He stares intently at a ruin not far away.\n\n"This... that is the tower from my dreams. Look. There is a dark spot at the top, almost like it burned."
Maybe we can finally find out more.

The tome that Philo has given you, or rather that Mathu'Gar gave you, turns out to be both diary and study journal. The owner, Horrucs, tried to control the demon's power by imprisoning it in the boy's body.

Philo's soul must have resisted, repressing the dark invader. A soulstone was used in the ritual - it might just be what is necessary to reverse it as well. But it could also cost one of their lives.

The book also mentions a general of the New Purity of Light in charge of those special stones.
I should find them.

Having collected all you need for the ritual to separate Philo and Mathu’Gar, the excitement in both is visible. The body shifts from human boy to waving shadows in mere moments as both fight to stay on the surface of consciousness, reverting just as quickly.

"Please, help me, master! He is getting stronger! I can feel it! I promise myself to your cause! I..."

"Don't listen to the youngling's whining! Which of us can grant you infinite power?!"
Stay strong, Philo. We will get through this.
We will be a force to be reckoned with, Mathu'Gar!
Philo Heath
Greater Glyph: Bowman

Pure Glyph: Bowman

Tome of the Owl
Pure Glyph: Pathfinder
Pure Glyph: Vampire
We will return once I have collected more magical energy.

As magical energy flows through the statues, a jolt brings them to life. Slowly, they turn outwards and put their spears into the ground. A blue light travels from their bodies, into the spears and, finally, into the stone. Groaning and grinding loudly, the door opens, swinging inwards to reveal a beautifully overgrown temple stead.

The pulsing magic you feel in this place draws you in, beckoning you to enter.
Search for the source.
Tread carefully. There could be traps everywhere.

Without hesitation, Yngrid steps inside. She walks through the temple as if she has been here multiple times, avoiding everything she could trip over. She stops by an altar and reaches for something atop it.

As Yngrid touches the intricate axe, she sighs in relief. Her hands grab the shaft firmly and she raises it with a victorious cry.

"This is what called to me. It is beautiful!"
And very valuable. You did well leading us here, Yngrid.

You lean over the sarcophagus, but are surprised to see it empty but for the huge hammer bearing strange markings. Why would someone take Tahar's corpse but not his weapon? Or was he buried away from the public eye, to ensure his peace would not be disturbed.\n\nPerhaps an investigation for another time.

'Here lies Corporal Tahar.
He fought against the Purity of Light's corruption,
defending Nortander against their supplantation and hatred.
He shall forever live on in our memories.'
Nortander's hero? He must have been a great warrior.
The hammer is ours.
An acidic concoction should do the trick.

You carefully drip some acid on the bands, corroding them as the chemicals eat into the metal.\n\nSoon, you can break the brittle chains and push the heavy lid aside. It hits the ground with a resounding crash, echoing across the mountainside.
I love science. Let's look inside.

Rengar Storme's forces have been vanquished and he met his end at his own daughter's hand.

You watch Lytra for any sign of regret as she kneels before his grave, setting down a handful of white flowers. She glances over her shoulder at you.

"All is well. I hope he will find peace with Aonir now. And I am finally free of the burden of my guilt." Her armor creaks as she stands up and raises a hand in salute. "You have stood by me all the way. In turn, I shall stand by you on whatever path you walk. This, I solemnly swear!"
I'm glad to have you by my side, Lytra.
Before she falls, Lytra releases the prisoner. When the fighting is done, you find him watching over her collapsed body.\n\n"I recognize her. She was with the white ones. Why did she help me?"
She wants to repent for what she did.

The shaman thinks for a moment.

"Regret is weakness in the eyes of Zarach. But she may wash away the transgression with blood, so the spirits will not haunt her for it.

I must return home. I have been gone far too long. Come to my village. There is something I must show you. Bring stormdaughter with you."
We will come.
Your victory is spoiled by the grevious wound Lytra has suffered at her father's hand.
This will not stop us.

Lytra fights until the last of them are slain. Only then, with the adrenaline fading, does she start to struggle. There is a deep gash across her stomach, pouring blood.

"At... At least they have been d-dealt with."

With a sigh, she collapses, closing her eyes.
We will get you back.
Lore's Baby
Lore's Baby
Throw the bomb at an enemy
Lore's Baby
Lore's Final Final Baby
Enkindled
I can thin their numbers before the fight.

The small camp you approach has been heavily fortified, but they must not be expecting an attack, as the gate stands open. Through it you see a Hollow Guard keeping silent vigil over the camp.\n\nBut, to your concern, it is not the symbol of the Purity of Light, or its ‘New Purity’ offshoot, that you see, but the banners of Hokan Ashir fluttering gently in the breeze.
I thought your sisters were taken by the New Purity?
When the fighting is done, your soldiers throw the unconscious outpost commander down at your feet with a look of contempt.
Your troops fall to Hokan's organized defenses.
We need better fighters when we return.
Wake him up.

The first patrol doesn't see Elynn until it is too late. She fells all of them with a flurry of her two blades. The second have more of a chance to react, but she still cuts some of them down too before they begin to fight back. The moment the alarm sounds, Elynn races back towards you.
She needs our help! Attack!

Rudely awoken by a hard slap to the face, the commander looks around startled. After a moment of startled panic, he begins to laugh.\n\n"That was a mistake." He breathes through his injuries. "Hokan Ashir won't forgive even the smallest slight."
Tell me where my sisters are or I swear I will end you!
We're looking for the Shaikan you captured in the Snakepass.

The question makes the commander hysterical.

"You are far too late to save them. They serve a greater purpose now. Hail Hokan Ashir!"

He dislodges something in his mouth and bites down hard. Sulfur and acid fill the air as he chokes and smoke and foam come oozing from his mouth.
Damn.
Shaikan
This unit is a Shaikan and has:
Agile
Nimble
Effortless Defense
Evasive Moves
Landing
Drunk

At first, the Shaikan seem hesitant to speak to you, but they watch your party closely the whole evening. A little later, one comes up with a drink in hand.\n\n"We don't think you're a real threat," she tells you. "But whatever you want to know... we're mercenaries, not spies. It'll come with a price."
Will this suffice?

The Shaikan stop what they are doing to look at cross at you. A couple go for their weapons, just as finely crafted as Elynn's, but one stands up with a kitchen knife, spinning that into a reverse grip threateningly.\n\n"Make another demand and see what happens, mage. I suggest you leave, while you still have legs to leave with."
I... suppose we'll go then.
It cannot hurt to ask.

The commander's eyes light up as he looks at Elynn and the Hollow Guard. He cackles, growing in confidence.\n\n"You are nothing more than bastardized experiments by some long dead mage. Your sisters are gone. Their bodies and blood will serve in Hokan's craft. As will their souls when they grant unlife to Hokan's creations. They are gone, away from here, spread across the west to further Hokan's interests."
How do we save them?
You... killed them?
You recognize the stench of death before you come up on the camp where Hokan's troops seem to be digging a mass grave, two Hollow Guards standing motionless nearby as they work.
Burrow to target hex within {range} and [skill]Guard[/] afterwards.
Modified Crossbow
This unit's crossbow won't need to reload anymore.
Demolisher
Cluster Bomb
Mathu'Gar
The demon has taken over control:
Philo Heath
Take Control / Contain Demon
Either take over control with Mathu’Gar or contain him with Philo
Rift Walk
Teleports you to target position
Crystal
Your tower suddenly fills with the scent of roses. Confused you try to get to the bottom of this.\nThe smell leads you right to Lore's laboratory.

It seems I've used up all my Black Ash. Inconvenient - I need it to finish off the mixture. It's really hard to come by too. Alchemists create it by grinding down Black Wood, or it can be taken off stronger demons.

He gives you a sidelong glance.

"Would you...?"
My patience is thinning.
I'll send out troops immediately.
Lore furrows his brow as his face scrunches up.\n\n"You shouldn't hurry an alchemist! If I add one wrong ingredient, the whole tower could go up in smoke! I'm just being careful!"
Sorry. I'll find this Black Ash then.
The camp's guard have been doubled since you were here last. An attack won't be easy.
Time to face them.
We're not ready. We'll return later.

Elynn steps closer to the lifeless hull. Her eyes are wide, unblinking, and tears run down her face. "I... I hear you, Willow."

She inspects the armored form closely, then with a determined look plunges her hand into its chest and rips out a glowing crystal, pulsating with energy. Elynn stares in wonder for a moment before touching it to her forehead and whispering. Over the next few seconds, the glow deepens from the soulstone and dissipates.

"Find peace in the next life, sister," Elynn says softly. She stands up, sheathes her blades and looks to you. "If they cannot be rescued, they can still be set free. I will not let them be imprisoned in cages to serve this monster."
We will make sure of it.
You gave Elynn your word. She should be the one to lead your troops in the rescue.
I will allow her to do the honor.
I will talk to them.
The Shaikan leader weighs up the gold you throw at her, pocketing it away when she decides it enough and motioning for you to tell your story.
We are seeking Hollow Guards belonging to Hokan Ashir.

Elynn approaches their table very cautiously, bowing at the waist. The Shaikan take special note of this.

"I know I approach as one who has not completed her rites," she says, "but I need your help."

"Why are you even here if you have not completed your rites?" the leader asks her sharply. "You should be in Shaikur! Where it is safe!"
We are trying to find my sisters.
Elynn drives one of her blades into his neck before anyone can blink. Eyes wide, he collapses to the floor.\n\n"A life for a life," Elynn says coldly. "It must be so."
Next time, wait for my order.
My sisters! Let me get to them!
Hokan's forces have clearly been warned of your arrival. They stand ready with a small collection of undead to bolster their ranks, and of course two Hollow Guard ready and waiting too.

Elynn walks through the carnage of the battle to remove the Hollow Guards' soulstones. She prays over each of them and releases their essence back into the fabric of the world, watching them disappear solemnly.\n\n"Goodbye, Nevena, fairest of them all. Farewell, Abitha. I will miss your laughter."

Elynn runs straight at the Hollow Guards, but Hokan's forces throw themselves between her and her goal. They are met with a quick and violent end, but Elynn is badly hurt too, forced to cut her way back to an escape.
Help her!
Your people fight hard, but they are eventually slain.
Their sacrifices won't be in vain.
Hirin guide them on.
You take all the time you need to make sure the soulstones are removed from the Hollow Guards' chests when the fighting is done.
Elynn must not know I kept these.

From a distance you see Hokan's troops entangled with a pack of griffons. They are throwing roped nets at one, trying to drive stakes into the ground to hold the animal. The others circle and dive at the company, including a Hollow Guard that struggles to defend itself.
Let's wait to see who wins.
Protect the griffon from harm.

Hokan's troops barely have time to work out why a protective shield falls over the griffon. In their panic, their stakes fail and the beast's wings beat the netting away. A wild headbutt sends one of the troops crashing to the floor before the griffon joins its brethren in the sky. Soon, Hokan's troops lie dead or run screaming, and the griffons start trying to peck the Hollow Guard to destruction.

A loud outcry shakes the tower's walls. Lore comes running soon after.

"I did it! I improved my bomb! I'll need to work on the formula some more, but I am now, finally, making progress!"

As quickly as he arrived, he vanishes back into his laboratory, leaving a large ball on your desk.
Great! And thank you for... this?

My last experiment was a huge success, yet I know I can do better. 
An old friend of mine owns a brewery in the Stoneblades. If you could bring me some Forgebrew, or maybe craft it yourself if you are so inclined, that should do the trick!

He pats his sooty hands on his belly.

"That and... some lunch? I am quite famished."
If that's all it takes, gladly.

Lore is hunched over a mountain of diagrams, instructions, reports and letters as you enter your study. Seeing you, he gives you a conspiratorial smile.\n\n"I found it. The last ingredient, the final missing piece. Right here! If we can get our hands on a piece of Corrupted Adamantinum, I can finish the bomb!"
You said the same thing about the Aria...
Lore? Are you alright?

He drops the small orb onto a stone in a metal crate and slams the lid shut. A loud pang marks the explosion and the crate is suddenly deformed by shrapnel. Lore lifts the lid and the stone is almost completely ground to dust. He laughs triumphantly.\n\n"You made this possible! The most precise, trustworthy bomb of all time! Worthy of an entry in Eo’s history books!"
Brilliant alchemy! Congratulations!
I'm no babysitter. Go play elsewhere.
Mathu'Gar
Enables swapping between Philo and Mathu'Gar
Tickbugs
The battle won, you turn your attention to the mangled Hollow Guard. Its chest already caved in, it does not take long to reach the soulstone.
Free the soul.

After ensuring she will not be disturbed, Elynn kindles a fire in the offering bowl.

One by one, she feeds mementos of her sisters to the flame. She watches the fire die down in perfect silence. Some of the ashes, she sets into a small, crystal vial, sealing it and putting it around her neck as a pendant.

"Thank you," she says. "My sisters have finally found rest. I shall no longer carry shame and they shall ever be close to my heart. As promised, I will continue my service to you."
I am glad for you.
Keep the soul.

With both parties destroyed, Elynn goes straight to the mangled Hollow Guard and tears the soulstone out of it, immediately becoming more gentle and less angry. Once again, she touches the stone to her forehead.\n\n"I will miss you, Hazel. Hirin guide you."
Molebeast
Alchemy
Necromancy
Artifice
Sharp Weapons
Prowl
Philo drops to one knee and draws a thin blade from his belt.\n\n"I promise to make myself useful. Take me in and you have an ear in every room. A knife on every foe's throat."
Well, that's intriguing.
This isn't funny. Be off with you!

You wander the old, familiar rooms of the tower, lost in memories of your time here as an apprentice.\n\nThe place was clearly searched through before the goblins ransacked it. Your master's crafting room has been depleted, most of the other chambers ravaged. Whoever did this left no stone unturned.
Go to the library.

Buried beneath a toppled bookcase in your master's gutted library, you find his old grimoire.\n\nReverently, you open the heavy tome. Many of its beautifully illustrated pages have been torn out, but you still see bits and pieces of your master’s illegible script. He was always secretive about his arcane research, often writing in code.
Try to decipher the grimoire.
Build Elynn's Lodge
Strange. Stay here for now. I must make some observations.
I don't give out my services for free.

A large crack splits one side of the tower open, baring the interior to weather and wind. Parchment notes, splinters and rubble litter the ground. Dark matter is smeared everywhere, as though a shadow tried to rip the tower apart from the inside.
We should investigate inside.
I have been here before. We should visit the top floor.
Collect as many notes as you can find.
The rough weather has already made most papers unreadable, but some information is still salvageable.

The interior is in fairly good shape. A few small creatures have evidently explored the tower, but aside from that, it is the recognizable living quarters of a mage.\n\nBut the higher you climb, the messier everything gets. It is as though a shock wave pushed everything to the walls, toppled shelves and destroyed vials. At the top most room, you halt in the doorway. The floor is covered in dried blood. What you can only assume was once a human body lies flattened in the room's center. Everything is covered in sulfur and coal dust. A dark, leather bound book lies almost hidden under some debris.
This is a mage's tower. We'll find more inside.
This was the epicenter. Perhaps the book is still intact.

A shadow darts forward with astonishing speed, grabbing the book suddenly. Philo turns to you, his eyes glowing like white hot coals, his body draped in darkness. A toothy grin almost splits his face in half.\n\n"Finally we meet, mage. It was about time the boy gave me some space."
Who are you? Or rather, what are you?

The figure moves closer with surprising fluidity and grace. 

"I am Mathu'Gar, demon lord of a world beyond your reality. The fool who is spread across this room summoned me, thinking I would grant him power. His death was swift. But you... You are a mage of real power. You will free me of this weak body and I shall serve you for that."

Mathu'Gar holds the tome out for you to take, awaiting your response with the casual grace of a noble.
Philo, what ever this is, you can fight it!
Enticing. I'll see what I can find in the book.
I do not deal with demons. Wake up, Philo!

The offer recedes and the grin vanishes. Philo shakes his head, holding the tome tightly. The shadow around him retreats once more and he groans painfully. When Philo can focus again, he is even paler than before.\n\n"I remember now." He looks at the body. "He was a mage. He lured me here with a spell and used me to summon a demon. But... something went wrong. I... I can feel it inside me. Oh, Guardians, please! Help me find a way to get rid of it!"
Don't worry. I'll find a way with the tome.
Fascinating! I need some time to research this.
Invest

Strange sounds wake you one night. Outside your door, you find Philo on the other side of the hallway, mumbling to himself. In the dark of the tower, it's almost as though a shadow clings to him like a cloak.\n\nYou are about to call out to him when he startles and looks around confused. He must have been sleepwalking.
Another strange dream, perhaps?

You are in your laboratory, mixing and weighing ingredients, when Philo wanders by. For a moment, you swear his eyes are glowing but he passes by. A few moments later he comes back, looking confused.\n\n"Did you call me?" he asks. "I found myself by the door, but cannot remember why. I swear someone called me, though. They beckoned me to step closer."
Not me, I'm afraid.

Philo kneads his shirt and nods.

"I guess it was another dream then. I wish I knew what triggers them. It is quite alarming to wake up without knowing how you got somewhere."

He gives you a corteous nod and wanders off again.
What might the cause be?
The fight over, you can finally leave the cave, and your purses are a little heavier after you rifle through the troll's possessions.
A fruitful adventure.
The last standing remains of what must have been a dwarven building jut out from the mountain. Someone has vandalized its wall in dwarven script.
What's written there?
No time to waste. Press on.
'What do you call a female elf?'\n\nThree answers are carved beneath the question, almost begging to be spoken aloud.
'A female elf'
'A Shelf'
'A woman'
You speak your answer and are disappointed when the stone remains silent and stoic.

When you speak your answer, you hear a mischievous chuckle on the wind. Someone was pleased you played their game. Turning away, you see a shelf has appeared from nowhere. There is a pouch on top of it, overflowing with gold.
Very amusing. A mage, or jester, at work.
A terrible prank. Let's move on.

You find the ruins of a dwarven keep, built into the mountain. Most of it has been destroyed by time and rock slides, but some parts of it are still accessible.\n\nYou find a large banquet hall littered with pebbles and bones but it is not quiet. Beneath one of the long tables, you definitely hear snoring.
Something is lodged in the ceiling beams.
Those are mole snores. We best retreat.
Hello? Is anyone here?

The snoring stops and something sniffs and shifts, then bumps against the bottom of the table and crawls out.\n\nA family of moles has made itself a home here and it seems they did not enjoy being disturbed.
Charge them!
The moles tear through your troops in defence of their new home.
Consume Corpse
Consume an adjacent corpse and restore {heal}.
I should cook them. That would show them.
Killing the moles poses no problems for your able troops. Soon, you are looking around the room again.
It has been ransacked already. Let's leave.
You feel a tugging from one of the ceiling beams. You order your people away from the rubble and debris, stretching out with your magic to pluck a leather pouch from a small nook.
A worthy detour in the end.
Maybe my magic can find something still.
Since you last visited, the mole family seems to have increased in number.
Kill the beasts once and for all.
No way are we entering that place again.
After a long day's walk, you find a ruin where you can rest for the night. It is partially covered by loose rocks, but otherwise seems sheltered from the elements.
Let's take a look inside.
Let's move on.

Upon entering, you find a fire already burning, a dwarf stirring a pot. He looks at you, then at the pot and finally at a stuffed, toy animal sat on the floor next to him.

"I didn't know you invited guests, Rupi! I don't think I cooked enough for all of you but I'm willing to share a meal."

He waves you over with an apologetic grin. His gaze never meets you directly. He seems to stare at a point right above your head with unblinking eyes.
What are you doing here?
He's talking to a toy. We should move on.
We can't just take from you. We shall share too.
Have some coin as thanks.
You quickly free the dwarf of his head, then ruffle through his belongings. Not much to be had, but it will bring some comfort to your travels.
This was worth our while.

Well, cooking my dinner. This is my home, after all! Right, Rupi? Mine, Jesmin's, and Lowen's and Brok's. And Pattsi's!\n\nHe leans over to pet the stuffed animal's head, mumbling some more under his breath. Something about him makes your troops uneasy.
We should leave before the others find us then.
Well then, we will share what we have too!
It smells delicious. May we pay for some?
He thanks you graciously for the coin, handing bowls to everyone.\n\n"I will let my brothers know I have met some fine people. Thank you!"
And thank you too. Take care!
You will never get the chance. Kill him!

The cave entrance is very well hidden. If the dwarf hadn't told you about it, it would have been easily missed.\n\nInside, there are mining carts and equipment around a large vein of gold. Some of it has already been loaded into crates, and can be taken easily. It seems the dwarf that offered you stew wasn't mad but merely strange.
A promise of gold
Let's go before the miners come back!
Let's push our luck!
Soon, another crate has been emptied of gold.
Now it is really time to go.
We can still get more!
You are unloading another crate when a shout rings out.\n\n"Oi, you! Who the bloody hell are you?! Hands off!"
Time's up!
As you fight, you see a dwarf flee and disappear for help.
Let's go, before more come!
Your troops soon fall to the dwarves you were stealing from.
A terrible misjudgement.

The walls are blackened, and charcoal crumbles under your feet. Your troops search every nook and cranny, but find nothing of worth. One does find a message, roughly carved into the stone mantle over the long dead fireplace.\n\n'They rest in the dark now. Let them rot.'
That's omninous. We should leave.
In the dark... Investigate the well.

A foul smell wafts up from the deep darkness of the well.

You have your soldiers lower down a lamp. Weapons, and oh so many bones, cover the ground.

Suddenly, a pale, blue light ignites in the depths. You stagger back as a hissing whisper comes from the well with a clear message.

"Revenge!"
Fight!
We don't know how many there are! Run!

The ghosts fade, and for a moment you think it over. Then, the well shudders, and crumbles! Bones rise up in a flood, spilling over the courtyard in a macabre fountain!\n\nThey bring with them trinkets, and golden baubles that roll at your feet.
Oh. Well, at least they left their thanks.
Throw Hammer
Griffons
Levitate Tower
Levitate your tower and move it slowly to a new location. Requires a lot of energy and your tower stops emitting your [mDomain].
Adjust Camera Height
Adjust Target Y
Adjust Target X
Zoom
Rotate
Take Screenshot
Toggle Photo Mode
Toggle UI
Bait them with some meat then we can strike out of hiding!

Some farmers cross your path, armed with flaills and scythes and led by a few hunters. They stop and wave at you.\n\n"Will you join the wolf hunt? We've lost a number of our flocks over the last few months. Now it's finally time for payback! We don't have much, but we can offer provisions!"
We have more important things to do.
You already have professional help.

Oh, yes! These good hunters offered their help too.

The leader of the hunters shoos the farmers away, closing in on you.

"Don't get involved. This is our little business, you get my meaning?"
There are plenty of wolves for all of us.
You will tell us all the truth.
Fine. We have more important things to do, anyway.
They snarl as they readjust their crossbow.\n\n"We'll see who hunts what."
How charming.

Their eyes go wide and glassy as you cast your spell.

"We stole the livestock and blamed the wolves. Now the farmers pay us to hunt the wolves too. It's the perfect scam."

The farmers look shocked. The hunters are already reading their weapons as their leader regains their senses.

"Curse your vile magic! Take them out!"
You'll find we're not as easy to kill.
The farmers gather their things, but leave you with a reward.\n\n"That was rather unexpected. Thank you for uncovering the truth."
All in a day's work.
Despite your warning, it seems you are no tougher to kill than lambs and chickens.
Save yourselves!
The hunting leader gives you a stern warning once you have dealt with the wolves.\n\n"From now on, stay out of our business."
As long as the farmers are happy.
This is why you leave the work to the professionals, the hunting leader gloats. "Stay out of this."
Some people just aren't wolf hunters.
Drowsy
Distracted
Drunk Lullaby
Drunk Lullaby
The bugs devour the bait with unexpected speed, offering the perfect opportunity for your troops to strike them down without much of a fight.
Marvellous. Onto the next.

Domain Range {AdditionalInfluenceRange:+-c}

Ghouls of the earth! Be gone!

On your travels, you are perturbed to come across a man, slumped dead by a tree. His clothes are simple - probably those of a farmer or small merchant - and a little torn. It looks like some wild animals have started to pick at the flesh of his legs, but he seems to have all of his belongings, and you see no wounds. Just a trail of blood leading up to where he fell, and dried blood running from his eyes, ears and nose.
Take his valuables. He doesn't need them now.
Search for any signs of what happened to him.
Let's give him a more dignified end.
Where the blood trail starts, you find an unfinished book on plants and their uses. Perhaps the author made a grave tasting error, or was hunting for an antidote to stop whatever was killing him.
You prepare a proper burial. As you finish paying over his grave, the wind whisperes through the trees. It almost sounds like gratitude.
I will study his notes.
Let's continue on.
Making your way through the land, you come upon a severed human foot. Traces of blood mark the ground, all the way into the undergrowth. In the distance, you hear pained groans.
Follow the trail, maybe someone is in trouble.
Let's move on. We should avoid whatever... this is.

Following the trail, you find a woman hidden in the shrubbery. Her skirt is soaked in blood, and torn to form a miserable bandage over the stump of her knee. She is pale, and shaking like a leaf.\n\nBehind her, a small group of the Undead emerges through the trees, searching for their escaped prey.
I send you to death once more.
Kill them!

With loud thuds and cracks, the corpses tumble to the ground, once again lifeless.

The woman tries to crawl towards you, too drained to show any care.

"T-thank... you. I..."

She collapses with a wretching groan.
Patch her up! Hurry!
We cannot save her. Take what you can find.

The ruin seems deserted, but you doubt your master would have left such a priceless asset unguarded. The crystal must be here somewhere...

The walls at the base of the ruined tower bear strange markings and your minions also spot a trapdoor covered by rubble only a stone's throw from the walls.

Now able to move your tower across the land of Fiara, you can seek out a more powerful Allfire source and connect with it through your tower.\n\nYou can only imagine what magical growth it will allow you to explore. If the Circle does not intervene first.

These enemies were no doubt here to secure the Allfire source. They all bear the marks of the Circle. \n\nYou know they have warned you against this course. A fight with their own mages will bring trouble your way.

The Allfire calls to you, whispering of unfathomable power that could be at your disposal. Now that your tower is near, you can finally unlock this node’s full potential.

But, suddenly, an image flashes before your eyes: a flaming circle in the sky.

"Stay away from the Allfire!" A voice – a multitude of voices – sears across your mind. "It’s secrets are not for the uninitiated. We have warned you already and will not do so again!"
The Allfire
Dream Treasure
Allfire
