Debris
Aonir's Blessing
I will scare them away with magic.
We'll take some ingredients, thanks.
What if we take both? Kill them!
As the wolves pounce on your troops, the band that led you to the camp bursts in. They don't stop to help your soldiers, making a dash for the supplies and disappearing into the trees.
Curse them and their greed!
You dispatch of the group with relative ease. While you are looking through their possessions, you find a thieves guild token too, which you pocket, just in case..
Perhaps I should have known this would happen.
The group kills your troops with fervor, taking back their own supplies and looting your soldiers' pockets too, before disappearing into the trees.
I will not forget this.

The wolves are taken by surprise when your beasts charge into the camp. The alpha tries to rally them, barking and howling as chaos ensues, but there is simply too much panic. The wolves sprint away, their tails between their legs, yelping as they disappear into the woods.
Let the thieves know the coast is clear.
Tell the travelers the coast is clear.
Use our own animals to scare them off.

Your spells wake the wolves, and for a little while they seem uncertain of what is going on. Some prowl around and some cower, or raise their hackles and bark. But an animalistic instinct slowly takes over and with time they skulk away, growling and whining.
Inform the thieves their camp is clear.
Inform the travelers their camp is clear.
Back From the Grave
Undying
Will revive <nobr>[turns]{UnitModifiers.SelfRevive.AmountOfTurns} [mTurns][/]</nobr> after dying

He finally turns to you, eyes hollow and hopeless.

"I did. Had to. 't was ridden with pests and I couldn't stand it no more. But the fire got out of hand and destroyed my home too.

If you come across those bugs, do an old man a favor and kill them. Bloody insects have grown too large for any reasonable man to fight them..."

They kept coming. Eating my grains, trampling my livestock. Giant bugs, large as my house.

If you ever come across those beasts, please do an old man a favor and kill them. I tried. Took up arms and threw all I had at it. Almost cost me my life. Those chitin bellies are just too thick...

Oh, Aonir, Guardians, show those monsters your wrath. He continues his prayers, almost as if he has already forgotten your presence.
We will see what we can do.
Within mere minutes, your soldiers are reduced to insect feed.
These pests are more dangerous than I thought.

With the surprisingly large bugs killed, you see a familiar figure running closer with a crude club. He stops a little distance away, but you recognize him as the old man who prayed over his destroyed lands.\n\n"Y-you did it! By the Guardians, you killed them! I was ready t' beat 'em myself, or die trying. Thank you, master mage. I am in your debt. All of Fiara will know about your honorable deed!"
We will keep an eye open.

The mage's tower is slanting, its windows are missing and the gardens are overgrown. Its compound is made up of a number of low buildings in a dismal state - peaceful, but also oddly quiet. No birdsong. No small animals rustling in the weeds. The tower's door stands open and you see stairs leading up and down. One of the closer buildings, probably for servants, is missing its door entirely.
Search the servants' quarters.
Look for an alchemy lab.
Look for the mage's quarters.

It looks like those who lived here left in a hurry. There are rusted pots and pans in a tiny kitchen, chests filled with moth-eaten clothes. In one corner, a single skeleton lies with an unsettling hole in the back of its skull, scratches all over the bone.
You easily find the lab. It looks like most of the tools and materials are still here, but some of the glass has been smashed, tables are overtuned and cabinets broken. Even... chewed upon.

The chamber's windows are all broken. The wind has carried in seeds that sprout from moldy bed sheets. In a small box on the nightstand, you find a book, a diary of sorts. Most of it is unreadable, but the writing on the last few pages is big and shaky. An unmistakable warning.

'One of them is inside my head! I can feel it chewing, making a little cave there. It stings! It sings. Sings to me. Orders me around. I will end it. I am so sorry. Gather them. Gather... Gather... It is hungry.'

Hidden in a hole cut into the pages lies a small, gleaming key.
Leave this place for now.
Let's speak to the dead.
Look around more thoroughly.
Let's leave.

The skeleton twitches as it begins to animate, then twists its skull to look at those surrounding it.

"Aaaaaargh!" the ghost bound to the bones screams. "It's eating my head! I can hear it! It's talking to me! It's eating, it's... Get it out, get it out!"

Until you let the spell dissipate, the rest is garbled nonsense.
Let's leave the servant house.

You find a note stuck behind one of the crumbling chests. It is a list of purchases someone was tasked to make: More eggs of 'those bugs from the west', alchemical ingredients. The writer also noted that the 'old master is behaving increasingly weird'.
Let's go.
What was the mage researching?
Look around.
Leave the laboratory.

From the scattered notes and left over substances, you guess the mage was interested in changing living things. Making them bigger, fiercer, combining them. Some of the ingredients hint at strengthening psychic powers.
Look around for other clues.
Leave the laboratory.

You find glasses containing shiny, round eggs in viscous fluid. Next to them, scraps of paper with scrawled images of all kinds of bugs. Big and small, incubating inside human bodies, larvae of parasitic wasps. Finally, you see a bug with a crown, or some kind of halo.
He lost his mind. Let's go.
Ominous. Let's leave.

You exit through the main hall, where your torches' lights gleam on huge, glass jars, full of dead bugs of all sizes, preserved in a clear liquid. As you move past them, you hear a commotion from outside. \nThen, one of the bugs squirms in its jar and emits a high pitched screeching. It echos the screams from outside. Your troops are under attack!
Stand your ground!

The bugs have dug up the rich earth and created a hive in the golden fields, hidden under carefully arranged haystacks and bushes. But the bugs crawling everywhere make it clear there must be an entire warren of them under your feet. It is not long before you are seen, and a beating, angry buzz breaks out all around you.
I'll collapse their tunnels.
We'll make a stand here!

After a valiant effort, your lines are overrun. Your troops try to disengage and flee, but you wonder. How could the bugs have grown to such numbers with no help?\n\nAs you flee, you glimps a single person standing on the other side of the bugs' writhing mass. They stagger, lurch and disappear, arms flailing wildly.
Something's not right...

The battlefield is a mess of broken carapaces and wounded soldiers, but you have to wonder. How many more are there? Why are there so many without help?\n\nYour soldiers report they saw a single person, probably human, watching from a distance and then running away jerkily, like a puppet on strings.
What is going on here?
Every [bonus]{when}[/] round(s) [statuseffect]{what}[/] will be applied to all units on [bonus]{positions}[/] random position(s).
[bonus]{amount}x {unit}[/]

With troops in need of rest, you head for a nearby village. Instead of the warmth of a tavern's taproom and some cool ale, you are greeted with a glint of axes, pitchforks and snarling dogs.\n\n"Stay away, thieves! We will... Oh! You are not them. Sorry about that."
Trouble with bandits?
We'll take our leave if we're not welcome.
The villagers call after you, voices thick with desperation.\n\n"No, wait! We need help!"
With bandits, I assume?
The militia will help you. Good bye.

Bandits, aye. The Baron of Goldenfields sent out tax collectors twice already. Or so we thought. Until the third ones came with his official sigil. That's when we realized some bastards had tricked us. They looked so real, we didn't even think about it.

But now we cannot pay the Baron! Without his protection, that only means more trouble coming.

If you will, hunt down those mongrels. Bring them to justice before more fall prey to their schemes. We, and the Baron, would hold you in high regards for such an act of kindness.
We will make sure they pay you back.

The white smoke of a campfire betrays the location of a small, human group. They are laughing, drinking and feasting on what looks to be grilled boar. From the villagers' description, these could be the bandits that stole the Baron's taxes.
I don't care. We will take our leave.
This won't take long. Attack!
Move silently. Listen in on their talks.
Overview Map\n
Faction Promotions
Upgrade
Poison their drinks.
Even though you jumped them from hiding, these bandits know how to defend themselves. Within a few moments, the fight goes dramatically in their favor.
Guardians help them.

Rummaging through their belongings, you find well forged letters and noble clothes, sowen haphazardly, but believeable enough at first glance.\n\nIn a small, pumpkin sized chest, you hear the light but sharp ringing of coins from within.
Inform the villagers we have their gold.

Too busy celebrating their success, they don't notice you sneaking poison into their ale barrel.

The first starts vomiting after a few minutes. Soon, more lie on the ground, holding their stomachs and cursing the villagers for 'giving them sour ale'.

Their deaths are noisy and gruesome, their suffering dragging on for about an hour.
Turn their camp upside down.

Seshi presses her body low to the ground and approaches without a sound. She sneaks close enough to understand the conversation of two people idly counting coins and drinking in celebration.\n\n"One mocked how gullable the villagers are," she reports back to you. "The other asked if twice might be cruel and dangerous. He feels as though their leader - Tirmon - is being too reckless."
Let's punish them for their recklessness.
We'll wait for nightfall and steal the money back.
Take the gold. The villagers need never know.

A group of six villagers return with your runner, clutching weapons and pulling a mule with them. They put two heavy crates down, filled with bottles of ale, mead and wine.\n\n"Thank you so much. The Baron will hear of this. Please, accept these as a token of our gratitude."
Travel safely, now.

Shaded by the night, you carefully enter their camp and search for the coin casset. You find it in the arms of a rather drunken man with broad shoulders and a wiry beard.\n\nYou deftly pry the casset free, giving the command to retreat before anyone else can notice you.
Inform the villagers we have their gold.
Take the gold. The villagers need never know.

The sound of disgruntled villagers has drawn you closer. Richly dressed guards of the Cornbaron of Goldenfields himself are busy searching houses. One of them is nailing a notice onto a tree in the market square.

'Signet ring stolen
If the culprit comes forth, the sentence shall be seven lashes on the bare back
Should the ring not be returned by the third fall of the sun, the sentence shall be death
Reward for capturing the one responsible - Payment by the Baron upon presenting the ring'
We should seek out this ring.

The camp you come upon is quite well hidden, the tents either under shrubbery or covered with well placed branches.\n\nTwo men are playing dice, using an old tree stump as a table. One of them occasionally toys with a large ring, setting it down to pick up his dice. The Baron's signet ring, no doubt.
Take them down without mercy!
Shall we play for that ring, bandits?

The signet ring lies tightly held in the commander's fist. It doesn't take much effort to break his fingers and free the silver band.\n\nReturning it to the Baron means not only a reward, but greater standing with the Baron's villages and guards in Goldenfields.
Shouts of pain and death are the last things your troops are able to utter as they are being picked apart by knifes, daggers, swords and arrows.
May the Guardians watch over them.
Let the Baron know.

Upon your call, more people emerge from the tents with weapons drawn. But the man with the ring laughs loudly, and sets up three cups. With a wide gesture that everyone can see, he puts the ring under the middle cup, waves you closer and then shuffles them.

"You are either bold or stupid to announce yourself and walk in here. If it's the former, I like it. Play for the ring, you say? If you win, you can have it. If you lose, we will tear you apart, piece by little piece."

His smiling features betray nothing. There is no telling which cup the ring is under. Hopefully Lady Luck is watching over you.
Your fire wreaks havok upon the thieves. The smell of grilled meat and burning hair fills the forest, and the screams of the wounded echo long and loud through the trees.
Finish them off!
The left cup.
The middle one.
The right one.

Smugly, he lifts the cup to reveal nothing. He waves his other hand in front of you, producing the ring from thin air.

"Let this be a lesson to you. Never play a game of chance with a charlatan."

He signals his units to attack. Within the bat of an eyelid, you are surrounded.
Conjure a fire to smoke them out.
We will come back with more force.

Slowly, vines sprout from the ground, covering everything closely and then pulling tight. The tents are crushed, restricting everyone inside them. The two men playing dice together are bound and pressed against the stump between them.\n\nSurprised outcries and groans of pain fill the small stretch of forest.
Take the ring and go, before they free themselves.
My revenge will burn you all.

A small group of farmers and hunters come up to your troops, whispering among each other nervously. Eventually, an elderly human man steps forward and doffs his cap respectfully.

"Please. We're looking for someone to take care of a problem. We've lost many of our sheep, and quite a few dogs, to wolf attacks. This never happened before. Well, not so often. We got a little gold scraped together, if that helps!"

A hunter scoffs and mutters: "Makes no sense at all."

Well, honestly, we've had wolves sneak into the villages before. In bad winters. But never like this, I swear! Seem real hungry and fierce, these wolves. And they even skulk around during the day! Never seen anything like it. Some are hurt too, but not by dogs, I reckon. Looked real weird, those wounds.\n\nThe man swallows nervously. "Will you help us?"
What happened, farmer?
What do you mean, hunter?
Let me talk to the hunter.

It's not natural, the hunter mumbles. "Not at all. Shouldn't be down in the valleys this time of year. Shouldn't be so keen on sheep when there are dogs and people in the fields."\n\nHe squints at you. "Only thing I can think of is something drove them out their usual hunting grounds. Something big."
We'll take care of this.
Let me talk to the farmer.
We'll take care of this.

Arriving at the village, people are quick to show you pastures and barns that the wolves have struck. It is easy to follow their tracks to an overhang, where a pack of wolves is dozing away the day. There are dozens of them, all shaggy and lean. Some are injured, but it would still be quite a fight to take them all down.
Let's try to calm them.
We can probably scare them off.
Unfortunately, we must protect the people.
We should come back later.

First, the animals growl and posture, but soft elvish words do calm them. They lie down, licking their wounds. They even allow your elven troops to inspect the long gash in one wolf's pelt. They come back with a tiny sliver of chitin.\n\n"Bugs must have driven them from their hunting grounds," the soldier says. "There are old tracks we could follow."

Guttural screams, brandishing of tusks and a bit of chest bashing has the leading pair of wolves lying in front of your orcish troops, showing their deference. They will probably move on and leave this place to you, but something must have driven them from their usual hunting grounds to come here.\n\nOne of your scouts spots older tracks coming down from the hills.

You are forced to flee, but perhaps not all is lost. Once you have reassembled what remains of your forces, your scouts report they have found older tracks leading down from the hills. Something up there must have driven the wolves down.
We should recover first.

This cave was once a wolves’ den, but huge bugs with shining carapaces now skitter across the opening, through tunnels and over the hills. Piles of moldy greens and grain and gnawed bones litter the place.
We must destroy them.
We should come back later.

When you have crushed the last bugs, you find a human corpse among the debris and remains. As one of your soldiers pokes it with a weapon, the body suddenly bucks and flails. You watch a single bug, the size of a fist, come crawling out of its mouth. You have it squashed immediately, but you cannot shake the feeling that something here is very wrong.
We need to find out more.
Overwhelmed, your remaining troops are soon running. The bugs will continue to disturb this land's natural order.
Those bugs are too tough.

You slay the wolves. The villagers will be safe now. But where did the pack come from? Your scouts quickly find older tracks leading down from the hills. Something must have driven them down, closer to the settlements.

You thought you were following a trail of multiple footprints, but you only come upon a drunkard, trying to find his way home.\n\nHe has laid himself to rest in a trampled field, sleeping noisily where the ground is muddy. Bandits might have passed through too, but there is no way to discern their tracks from the drinker's.
Keep looking.
He is begging to be robbed.

This trail leads to a serene place. A tree trunk lies to one side, carved to form a comfortable bench watching over the surrounding rolling hills and lush, golden fields.\n\nSomeone has dug a shallow firepit, and you can see the small bones of a hare.
Let's keep looking.
Just as you are about to walk away, you notice a shimmer in the sunlight by your feet.\n\nSomeone had dropped a silver coin of sorts.
We could find use for this in Sevenkeeps.

It is not long before the Baron's guards arrive, equipped with horses and spears.\n\n"The Baron graciously thanks you for removing this threat, and returning his signet ring. He would like to reward you with this."
Extend our thanks to the Baron.
Base: {Value:c}
I might know what left those marks.

The villagers clear a way for you as the woman wipes her hands on the grass.

You can see tracks in the ground that lead away from the village, and the occasional blotch of red blood.

"We have never seen such tracks before. What if these monsters come back for more? Oh, Guardians, help us! What if we are next?!"

The gashes in the sheeps' bellies show clean edges, telling of something frighteningly sharp. It looks like large pincers have torn into them, but the Highmark is not home to giant bugs, leaving you puzzled.

"If those beasts come back, we will be helpless. They might kill us next!"

Panic ensues in the village.
We will find and destroy this thing.
We will deal with this!
{CombatModifiers.MeleeAttackType.MeleeDamageReduction:+-pc} Melee Damage Reduction
{CombatModifiers.MeleeAttackType.MeleeDamageBonus: +- c} Melee Damage

{CombatModifiers.MeleeAttackType.MeleeDamageModifier:+-pc} Melee Damage

{CombatModifiers.SpellAttackType.SpellDamageModifier:+-pc} Spell Damage
Allfire
In Dire Need

When you enter the market, you find most stalls empty, and only a handful of people clusted around the well. There, a man in white robes is submerging a fish in a bucket. After only a few moments, the splashing stops, and the fish floats belly up.\n\n"It is as I thought. The water is poisoned. Alas, my cupboards are empty - I am unable to help."
Your well is poisoned? How did this happen?

The people start explaining their desperate attempts to stop a pest.

"We thought those large insects were gone, but just recently they reemerged. They eat our crops, kill our animals. We had no choice but to stop them, so we turned to poison. Unfortunately, it seems to have soaked into the grounds and reached our wells. Whoever drinks from them gets sick.

We don't have the resources to heal so many. A lot already drank from the water."
I can offer you healing potions.
How can we cleanse the waters?

The villagers and their healer take the offering with reverence.\n\n"Humble thanks, master mage. These will provide temporary relief, but it is sorely needed. We need to cleans the waters too though, lest more become sick. Would you be able to get us some healing herbs? I can provide directions as to where you can find them."
We will bring you what you need.
I'm sorry. We have no time for this.
We understand. You have already helped us greatly. We shall send some of our bravest. Hopefully they can return swiftly. Many thanks, master mage.
Fare well. Good health to you all.
Please, take this Lenya.

The village begins to cheer as the healer takes your offering with many thankful nods.\n\n"You are sent by the Guardians themselves! Our gratitude, master mage. You saved this small community from extinction."
Good health to you all.

If we had more healing herbs, we could eliminate the poison. I can provide directions, if you are willing to bring us some? I know multiple sources, but we only need a little. You can keep the rest as compensation for your work.
We will get what you need.
We already have Lenya you can use.

A messenger comes up to you, huffing but offering a quick salute.

"Please, I have a message from Baron Halvier, master of the city of Lyraine and liege of Goldenfields. A caravan carrying much needed supplies to the palace has been stopped and plundered by bandits. If you would take care of them, and secure the stolen goods, my lord would reward you handsomely."

He bows, and then waits for an answer.
Tell us where to find them.
We don't have time for this.
You find the camp exactly where you were told it would be. There is little movement among the tents and huts. It seems likely your army has not been spotted.
Rush them!
Watch a while.

Your troops begin their approach, rushing towards the camp when suddenly a huge orc steps out from one of the tents, shaking an empty sack. He looks up, sees your army coming down the hillside and bellows loudly. Dozens of orcs quickly appear, ready to meet your attack. This is not a simple bandit camp.

Your scouts sneak closer to the campsite, but you hardly need their reports as you quickly spot the burly figures moving among the tents. Orcs are kicking through stacks of goods, rummaging through tents and sniffing at empty casks. It is no bandit camp.
We are already committed. Fight!
Let me handle this.
Raiders! Charge!
Let me talk to them. Maybe they'll join us.

Galtrak approaches the band's leader and you bear witness to a grunted exchange. After a few words in their language, the orcs split into two parties. Some walk away with angry growls, but others follow Galtrak as he returns to you with a toothy smile.\n\n"They say everyone was dead when they arrived. Since they didn't get the chance to loot much, they'd rather join us than be stranded here."

You quickly find that nearly everything in the camp that could be eaten has at least been chewed upon. Even the wooden tent poles look like something tried to bite into them. Chitinous carapaces crunch under foot, as if armies of bugs had died here. Or... molted?
So be it. Now, let's look at that camp.
We don't need them. Let's focus on the camp.
Send a message to the Baron explaining this. Our work is done.
The Orcs drive you off, hollering and waving their arms, praising Zarach for the fight.

You pick through what is left of the goods you were sent here to collect. Everything not made of metal is gone or spoiled. Very little of use remains. Even the bandit corpses have been chewed on, as if by wild animals. Their wounds don't match orcish weapons.\n\nFlies hover above the camp and chitinous carapaces crunch underfoot. Bugs are everywhere.
Let's send message to Lyraine.
Regroup elsewhere.
Alluvyan Square
Some units locked due to low reputation.
Alluvyan
City of Lyraine
The village is still largely empty, many inhabitants still sick. The healer walks between the houses, comforting where he can and easing the pain as much as possible.
We need to get the healer those herbs.
We brought some Lenya to help the sick.

In the wake of Goldenfields' giant bug outbreak, many a charlatan and fake witch has sprouted up, selling potions and charms to the innocent and naive, 'protecting them from the threat'.

One such fraud, Madame Myriel, has time and again avoided the Baron's attempts to unmask her lies and now he has turned to you for your help in doing so.

Today, she plans to prove the effectiveness of her charms to a town. It is the perfect opportunity to uncover the truth.
What is she planning, I wonder?

You arrive in town just as Madame Myriel is setting up in the market. It is full of people, all crowding around two large wagons. One is covered in fabrics. The other looks more like a circus wagon, big, bright and colorful.

It is from the door of the latter that an opulent woman walks, her silver curls artfully arranged and her lavish clothes glittering with beads and crystals.

"Gather close, young and old! I have many a charm to sell!"
Investigate the wagons.

Many of you have heard of the beasts roaming our lands! Myriel starts. She has climbed a crate and is looking over the villagers. "Awful things. But fear not, for I have brought you hand-crafted charms! These are sure to frighten off any large bugs. Guaranteed! Don't believe me? Believe your eyes!"\n\nWith a flourish she tears the fabric from the wagon, revealing a cage with a giant bug inside. She holds a charm up to the creature and it flees in the opposite direction, almost tangling its legs in the process.
I can see the strings controlling its legs!
Interesting. Perhaps she is legitimate?

A group of guards - no more than thugs with chipped and rusting weapons really - stops anyone from coming close.\n\n"No one is to near Madam Myriel's wagons! If you want to see the show, stand over there!"
Then we will force our way through. Attack!
Oh, we're here for added security.
Will this convince you to spill her secrets?
You really think we're that stupid?! Step away. This is your last warning.

Finally! Move over there then. We need more people around the second wagon!\n\nYou take position by the wagon covered in fabrics. As Madame Myriel begins to talk, you see two people vanish underneath them, careful not to be seen by the townsfolk. A moment later, you hear a very slight 'click'.
While the town panics at the outburst of violence, Madame Myriel is ushered into her wagon. They take off while the guards dismantle your band.
She will not get far.

The guard captain, if he can be called that, pretends not to pay attention as he subtly accepts the offered coin. With that he has his soldiers usher others away and leans in close.\n\n“She is a charlatan, alright, offering useless trinkets for coin. If someone here were to pay attention to the underside of that wagon, they might find a surprise. Now, off with you, before we’re caught.”

People here are very wary of your troops, but they relax when they see your colors and banners.\n\n"It's just... The baron's soldiers stationed nearby." An elderly man tries to explain. "They turned real funny. Suddenly plundering our granaries and fields. More than they could ever eat! And then they took it all with 'em when they left! We're 'fraid you were more of the same. But then... Well, if you could maybe help us get back the grain? Taxes be comin', an' the baron won't be pleased when we've got nothin' to give."
Where did these soldiers go?
I'm no errand runner.

Your band dutifully follows their directions. You stumble across a small group of soldiers much sooner than you thought you would. They don't seem very soldierly, though. They may wear the Baron's colors, but they stumble about confused, and several of them keep scratching at their faces, leaving bloody streaks.
They seem disorganized. Attack!
Watch them a little longer.

Among the soldiers, your scouts make out bugs swarming. Insects of all sizes, from tiny specks to the size of a child's head. One of the soldiers suddenly screams and tries to run, but is held back by their comrades.\n\nThen they see you, and become agressive. Somehow, they manage some semblance of a fighting formation.
I guess we'll have to fight.
You hardly believe it, but when the Baron's soldiers wildly attack, your troops falter.
Save yourselves! Run!

While your soldiers take care of the last stumbling fighters, one of them breaks away and flees. He moves jerkily, like a child's puppet, but seems to follow a straight line away from the battlefield.
There must be more. Follow him!
The Traitor Army

The lone soldier has been running without pause for hours, but eventually comes to a camp where the Baron's banners flap haphazardly in the wind. It seems more orderly than the group you fought before, but your scouts also spy a few troops stumbling about aimlessly.
Try to talk to them first.

Your troops catch one of the aimlessly wandering soldiers and question them. They cannot get any straight answer. The soldier mumbles, and then yells. Finally they just begin screaming: "It's inside my head! My head! I hear it moving and scratching... GET IT OUT!"\n\nHis screeching alerts the camp.
Damn it. Attack!

When the fight ends, only the leader still stands, eyes glazed over and looking far past your soldiers. When he is struck down, he lies still for a moment before beginning to twitch and convulse. Then, to everyone's horror, an insect bursts from his left eye, buzzing its blood-spattered wings.\n\nOne of your lieutenants swats at the creature and then tramples it underfoot until it no longer moves.
Burn it all.
The Wolf Problem
The Wolf Problem
A Well-Deserved Feast

Messengers from the baron and local guilds come to you accompanied by trumpeters, drummers and petal throwers.

"Hear ye, hear ye!" a crier reads from a scroll. "For Goldenfields' heroes, the Baron Halvier of Lyraine has made ready a great feast and a day and night of merriment! Please, good people, come to the Inn of the First Crossroads! Dance, eat and drink until the sun rises again!"

They hand over official invitations and directions to the inn. It seems the people of Lyraine want to show their gratitude after you have solved so many problems.
Let's head to the inn!
A Well-Deserved Feast

The feast is all that was promised and more. Mead, wine and food are plenty. Musicians play for your company, people dance and everyone toasts to your health.\n\nMuch later, in the dead of night, when the candles have burned low and many are getting ready to sleep, a scream rouses you all. Another scream comes, followed by the loud clicking of mandibles. The inn is under attack!
Prepare to fight!
Quickly! I will protect you with magic!
A spell seals the civilians - tavern workers, musicians - behind a shimmering barrier away from the battle. They seem grateful, but you have invested quite some power to protect them.
Now we fight.

Wading through dozens of bug cadavers, you all come back to sobriety. You are all dour. Your celebrations were poorly timed - as it has been for months, Goldenfields is still infested with bugs.\n\nThe inn is completely ruined, but you are given gold in thanks for your aid and in compensation, the feast in your honor being so rudely interrupted.
We need to find out more.
Pleasure doing business with you.

The townsfolk are certainly taken by your accusation, looking cautiously at Madame Myriel to prove her innocence.

"How unjust!" she cries. "Can you not see it moving? Can you not hear its unnerving calls?"

Right at that moment, the bug makes a noise that sounds like a mixture of rasping and screeching.
Show us the cage! Now!
They're definitely hiding something then.
This is a trick! Show us what is beneath the cage.

Myriel blanches at the townsfolk start to murmur and then call out for more proof.

For a moment it looks like she might run, but then she gives in to the angry shouts of the people and pulls the fabric beneath the cage up. Everyone sees two men in the small space, holding sticks and strings in place to move the bug from below.

The Baron's guards arrive in the afternoon to take Myriel into custody. The townsfolk are outraged, and thank you for helping them keep their well earned coin.
All in a day's work. Fare well!

The sudden onset of violence has the townsfolk reeling but you fight through, victorious. Madame Myriel begs for her life, pulling back the fabrics of the first wagon to reveal a motionless bug in a cage.

"Please! Don't kill me! It was a fluke! A scheme! I found a dead bug and saw an opportunity! Here!" She shows you a secret compartment underneath the cage. "My soldiers use sticks and strings to move the bug from here. It was just meant to be a harmless prank!"

The baron's guards come to take the charlatan away a little later, and the townsfolk praise you for revealing the truth.
The baron will take it from here. Fare well.
Have it your way. Kill them!
Fine. I can wait.
When you catch up to Madame Myriel and her band of outlaws, she barks at them to drive you off while she takes cover in the bushes.
Turn yourself in now and no one will get hurt!
A fight you want, a fight you get!
The outlaws beat your soldiers back and Myriel escapes once again.
I will hunt her down.
The underlings take one look at your much better weapons before exchanging a quick look and throwing down their own.\n\n"Oh, come on!" Myriel complains. "I... Urgh. Fine. I give up!"
Call the baron's guards.
In the fight's aftermath, Myriel quickly pleads for her life, falling onto her knees and begging.\n\n"Have mercy, please! It was just a jest! A harmless prank!"
Let's inform the baron.
Day {dayNr} Week {weekNr}
Everyone will be affected by [factionpromotion]{what}[/]

While active, all your units completely regenerate each turn on the strategic map.
Increases the range of your [mDomain] emitted by your Tower and Lodges by [bonus]1[/].
A Welcome Respite
Well of Life
Of sheep and wolves

You come across a remote village, where bees spread the smell of honey and a constant buzzing fills the air. \n\nSuddenly you hear children screaming. They come running past you in a panic, closely followed by a pack of large wolves.
Defend them and kill those wolves!
There is a magical essence coming from the wolves.
Those are not wolves. Their movements don't follow natural patterns.
Come, children! We can hide in the trees over there!
Your troops scream as they are ripped apart.
My soldiers will be avenged.

You start to kill the wolves one by one, but more come out of the houses. Without warning, one of the children flings themselves between you and the animal that you are currently fighting.

"Noooo! Not my mama! Stop!" The child sniffles and tears run down their chubby cheeks. "Our parents went and chopped some trees a couple days ago. That night, all adults were turned into wolves. But they are still good! I swear!"

You look around and see all the other children crying, clinging to the giant canines.
Are you saying your parents were cursed?

The girl nods, smearing snot all over the wolf and her face in the process.\n\n"Mama said the elves here guard the healing herbs too jealously. But we need them to stay healthy. Our parents went out to collect some, and when they came back they looked like... like..."
Can you show us where they went?
We'll help. Bring us all the coins you can find.

The children run off, searching the houses for coins as if it was a game. The wolves follow them, growling occasionally in your direction but never attacking.

Shortly afterwards, the children pile up their findings on a tablecloth before you. It is a quite a big sum. Probably all they have.

"Will you turn them back now?"
Of course. Show us where your parents went.
I need to fetch a magical book first. Good bye.

You are brought to a very small and clear pond. The water shimmers turquoise, and you can see Lenya growing around it in small patches. It is true, the plant is fiercely protected, as it is difficult to grow and increasingly rare, particularly in the Highmark. As such, it is no surprise to see a handful of elves step out from behind nearby trees.\n\n"Have you come back for more, you greedy hairless apes?"
You did this to the villagers? Will you undo it?

We will undo it if they promise never to come here again in their lifetime. Elen's Grace needs more time to grow than you have. We warned the humans of this weeks ago and they didn't listen! We told them there would be consequences!\n\nSome of the wolves snarl and growl. Others whimper.
You’ll die for the curse you have spoken!
A warm wave of golden light rolls out from the fallen elves. You feel something like a pressure lifting.\n\nBehind you, the wolves turn back into humans, and the children hug their parents tightly.
Let this be a warning to leave the Lenya alone.
Let's go before the remember we took their gold.
The villagers approach you warily, keeping distance between them, their children and your troops.\n\n"Thank you for your help, master mage. We will never touch it again, that is for sure."
Good. We shall take our leave now.
There is not even time for your soldiers to retreat before the elves tear into them.
I will show them the same mercy.
If you can’t be reasonable, neither can we.
Then the Lenya harvesting ends now. Yes?

After what seems like debate, the wolves go quiet.

"It is agreed then. Should they return, their fate will be worse."

The elves speak a few words and the villagers return to their original form. On seeing their parents, the children cry and give them joyous hugs. The adults quickly step back from the pond and the blue leaves growing around it.
Let’s get going, before they remember the gold.
This should be warning enough. We will be gone now.

The children follow you, but the wolves are faster. Within moments, they are between you and the children. To your surprise, the children laugh, and some even hop onto the wolves' backs. The large canines growl at you, baring sharp teeth.\n\n"Are you here to rid our parents of the curse?" one of the children asks. Tears build up in her eyes as she afixes you with a desperate stare.
Are you talking about the wolves?

Almost as if to answer your unasked question, the wolves position themselves in front of the children in a protective manner.\n\n"Are you here to rid our parents of the curse?" one of the children asks. Tears build up in her eyes as she afixes you with a desperate stare.
Are you talking about the wolves?
You find the children standing on the wolves' backs, trying to pick apples and cherries from the trees in the village.\n\n"Hey! You came back! Can you lift the curse from our parents now?"
Sorry children, not yet. We will come back.
Yes, indeed. Show us where your parents went before the curse.
Wolves have been pestering Alluvyan's villages for some time now. The people have begun offering rewards to anyone who can prove they have killed some of the beasts.
Sacrifice your own mortal unit, turning it into a [mUnit][unit]Skeleton Warrior[/] and completely heal all other units of its stack.
Aonir's Blessing
Primordial Forest
Summon Primordial Being
Choking Fumes
Warped Reality
Darkness
Light
Entangled
Strong Winds
Bane of the Unnatural
Soul Maelstorm
Haunted
Lightning
Volcanic Activity
We do have wolf fur. Maybe the villagers are easily deceived.
That sounds like a task for us. Let's see if we can find these wolves.
Another time perhaps. We move on.

You present your furs to the villagers, spinning a tale of how you bested the rabid animals.\n\n"We thank you, grand mage. At last, we can rest in peace again. Those animals killed too many of our livestock already."
Rest up and gather your strength. We will leave you to it now.
Immolation
Snipers
Tiara's Touch
Focus Leak
Great Life Stealing
{CombatModifiers.Armor:+-c} [iarmor:c] Armor {postfix}
You have an adventure here.
Death Bolts
Returning to the village, its people are still in shock after the last wolf attack. Apparently some of their best horses were killed.\n\n"Someone really should put an end to those beasts!"
Worry not. The beasts are gone! We have their fur as proof.
We should hurry and kill these wolves.
You are celebrated as a hero and rewarded in gold for your help.\n\n"We can finally rest without fear. Your noble act shall be remembered."
May the Guardians keep your village safe.

A very angry mob of townsfolk appears suddenly before you.\n\n"You lied to us! The wolves still come every night, killing our animals and endangering our children! If you don't take care of this now, we'll take our money back!"
You can have your money back. Over our dead bodies.
I see now we wronged you. We will kill the beasts right away.
The money may be yours, but the City of Alluvyan will not be happy to hear of these deaths.
There is no time to retreat. The villagers tear your troops apart with more ferver than you thought possible.\n\nThey take back their money and stomp off.
This did not go well.
We better move.
This fur will provide proof that you killed the wolves.
Onwards.
{MeleeAttackType.MeleeArmorBonus:+-c} [iarmor:c] Armor against [mMeleeAttackType] attacks {postfix}

Grants the wearer additional Life
Lesser Glyph: Mountain Goat
Grants Mountaineer
Greater Glyph: Healthy
Greater Glyph: Mountain Goat
Firewielder

You are passing an elven camp that has seen better days when a couple of words are carried to you by the wind.\n\n"... Summer's Harp... Humankind will keep destroying... save Elen's Grace... kill them if we must..."
Sorry for intruding. What was that about Elen’s Grace?

The elves ignore you at first, but after some consideration, one stands and speaks to you.\n\n"Elen's Grace is what we call Lenya. We were talking about how the humans are killing off the last of the reserves. They must be stopped, or it will all be destroyed. But we are not enough to stop them alone. Our numbers are dwindling and the humans keep growing."

You find human gatherers kneeling over a handful of Lenya plants. They are carefully cutting them and layering their harvest into woven baskets.\n\nNot a single leaf is left behind. The ground looks barren were once a lush field must have been.
Join us in destroying the elves that would end your harvest!
Stop the harvest or you will taste your own blood.
Can we help?
Stop the harvest by any means necessary. Our people have already taken back the Summer's Harp, but even this was not enough to dissuade them, it seems.
Worry not. We will put an end to the harvest.
What is the Summer's Harp?

It was a gift, from Finon Mir to the people of Alluvyan after the War of the Six Races. It was meant to represent peace and respect between us, and blessed the harvests of the lands.\n\nBut if the humans cannot be trusted to tend to Elen's Grace with care, they do not deserve such a gift.
We have heard enough of your delusions. Your lives end here.
We will do whatever it takes to stop the harvest.

The elves show no mercy, cutting through your soldiers with coldhearted precision. The last thing you hear is them calling to each other.\n\n"If we can prevail against these, the harvest can be stopped! We attack at dusk!"
These elves are up to no good.

Close to a small Lenya field, you find a group of human gatherers all unarmed and slain in cold blood. You find elven arrows, and other signs that it was the otherwise gentle race. You are still undecided on whether to bury the bodies when soldiers ride up to you.\n\n"Stop right there, scoundrels! Do not try to run!"

After casting aside the elves, you hear footsteps. A group of human soldiers approaches, congratulating you.\n\n"Those fanatics were completely mad. You have probably saved a lot of lives, killing those long ears. Thank you."
It is good to be of service. We must be off now.
It was elves that killed these people, not us.

The guards find the same signs as you. cursing the elves.\n\n"Those tree humping, bark sniffing...! Are you here to put an end to their fanatical actions? We would reward you for killing them once and for all."
Deal. We will put an end to them.
You find the group of elves gathered around a tiny fire. They are still in the process of tending to their wounded, and cleaning their weapons of a past battle's blood.
Now you die!
We need to gather more forces before we can attack.

The elves relinquish every last drop of hope you have, slicing through your units without batting an eye.\n\n"Is this all you have to offer? And your puny race was once celebrated. You deserve worse than what we give you."
After removing the elves, the humans stay true to their word.\n\n"We have not much to offer in gold, but you should have this."
We are glad to be of service, but now we must leave.
My vengeance will burn hot.
The city of Lyraine, trading hub of the [gold]Goldenfields[/], controlled by the ruthless Corn Baron.
Two armies clashed here not long ago. Explore for magical artifacts.
The farmers look up from their work, fear twisting their faces into masks of horror. Soon, they are up and gone, their harvest forgotten and trampled underfoot.
The elves have moved closer to the humans, no doubt to see if you would actually put an end to their harvests.\n\nInstead they see your betrayal, readying their own weapons.
Take only what has already been harvested.
Explore this site for research and knowledge.
Explore this site for treasure.
An alchemist calls this house their home. You can buy all kinds of potions and ingredients here.
Explore this site to increase your mana reserve.
[bonus]Harvestable[/] location.
[bonus]Mineable[/] location.
[unexplored]Unexplored[/] location.
Ribcage
[tooltip_hint]Cannot be used when engaged.[/]
I demand half up front.
Let the packs loose to chase them away.

The elves come forth from the bushes. They must have followed to ensure you were true to your word.\n\n"They will not be gone forever. But you did save what little remains of Elen's Grace. We are grateful."
Then show it. How grateful are you exactly?
We will let you tend to the plants now.
The elves shake their heads with disappointed sighs.\n\n"You have already taken the harvested plants, what more do you expect from us? Be gone, before we change our minds about you."
You heard them. We are leaving.
I don't like your tone. Apologize, or draw your weapons.
The elves did not have much on them, but you find a few coins to take.
You should not have tested us.

The elves strike quick and hard, and your soldiers are forced to retreat further and further away before they fall to elven weapons.\n\nOne of the elves puts up a magical barrier, shielding the Lenya from any approaching dangers as they turn to tend the plants.
May Hirin abandon these cursed fanatics.

You did not expect the soldiers that suddenly came to the farmers' aid out of the nearby forest. You are dealt with quickly and the farmers return to their work, taking the last of the Lenya and moving away.
We have failed.

You soon have slain all the farmers. The elves come out of nearby hiding places. They must have followed to ensure you'd stay true to your word.\n\n"Elen will be proud to call you one of her children. Take this, as our sign of her blessing."
It feels good to work in Elen's favor.

The harvesters look suspicious at first, but then their demeanor changes and you understand. They are scared of the elves.\n\n"We are simple farmers. Only a few of us are able to fight! But if you plan to kill them, we will stand with you!"
Onwards! We will make short work of them!
This will be your demise!
The elves are soon dealt with, and the farmers gladly reward you with some of their harvest.\n\n"To a mage ike yourself, those should provide useful."
Useful indeed. Thank you for the offering.
Why do you harvest such a meager patch of leaves?

The farmers look up at you, hints of a day's work clear in their faces.\n\n"Harvests have been sparse. We need to make money to pay our taxes and put food in our families' bellies. Believe us, we do not like this one bit - the elves are already angry with us. But we have nothing else left."
I can pay you. Will this suffice?
I understand. Let's see if we can come up with the funds you need.
Then we have no choice but to kill you.

The people could not believe their eyes as you pay them out.

"This is plenty! Thank you!"

After the humans have left, the elves come out of hiding. They probably followed to assure you would stay true to your word.

"They will not be gone forever. But you did save what little remains of Elen's grace. We are grateful."
Then show it. How grateful are you exactly?
Thank you for giving us the chance We will leave now.

You find the elven encampment where druids are completing the ritual required to wake more treants from their slumber. Your arrival is not unnoticed, and guards soon swarm you.
You will create no more monsters!
Flee while you can! We were sent to destroy you!

Your warning is met with sceptical looks. Though weapons are drawn, you are not attacked.\n\n"You bring a warning instead of the final blow. Does this mean you stand with us, to protect Elen's Grace?"
Yes, we have come to help.

As your troops fall to the guards' brutal blows, new threats rise. The elves fall back and the elementals spread to all corners of Alluvyan. \n\n"May these guardians protect the forest and kill what destroys Elen's Grace! Retreat, everyone! Our deed is done."

You end the elves' lives before new monsters can arise. You bring proof of your fight to the village, and the people hand over their prized glyph.\n\n"Alluvyan is safe from roaming monsters and murdering elves once again. Our thanks."
This glyph will be a valuable asset during our coming endeavors.
They leave the monsters to fight for them? May the Guardians protect us from their wrath.
Enough of your shenanigans! You will die here!

The priestess, clad in ceremonial robes, takes back the fabric and smooths its worn edges between her fingers.\n\n"This was entrusted to us after the War of the Six Races," she explains. "A prophecy said that, as long as we hold it, Zarach’s Banner shall never again be seen flying in the Highmark."
Zarach's Banner. This is a piece of it then?

A loud scream draws your attention to a group of orcs pinning a merchant to his cart.

"Filth!" their leader screams, shaking the finely dressed man. "Liar!"

As the orc draws a nasty looking blade, the merchant whimpers: "I swear! I thought it was real – please! Don’t kill me!"

The orc throws a piece of red cloth onto the sobbing man, spitting on its crude embroidery.
What is going on here, merchant?
Why are you shaking this poor soul half to death?
What did the human do to deserve such treatment?

They are trying to kill me! Please! the man screeches. An orc kicks him over and pins him down with his foot.

"I wanted to sell them a... priceless artifact!" The merchant wheezes. 

"A fake!" the orc leader bellows. "You dared fake the Banner of Zarach!"
That was stupid. But perhaps an honest mistake?
Leave the man be or face us!
The orc turns on your fighters and draws his weapon, licking a crooked tusk.\n\n"Then you will pay for his crimes against Zarach with your blood, fools."
The orc growls.\n\n"How we deal with him is up to us! Walk away, unless you wish to share his fate."
No need for that. We will go.
Well, my soldiers *are* itching for a fight.

The merchant gets up slowly, brushing the dust from his clothes.

"Thank you," he says. "I swear, I thought it was real. I picked it up on the old battlefields, near the Gate of Kings. I heard the orcs were searching for Zarach’s Banner and… well, it looked like it…"

He picks up the red cloth and stares at it.

"Might be worth trying elsewhere," he mumbles. "Maybe not with orcs though."
We saved your life. That must be worth some coin.
The hapless merchant’s end is wordless screaming.
Orc justice is merciless.
None of your concern, the orc leader growls. "This worm disrespected Zarach and will pay the price."\n\n"Please!" The man on the ground whimpers. "Help me! I swear, I didn’t mean to trick anyone!"
He's not worth it. Look at how pathetic he is.
Don't you dare lay a finger on him!

He tried to peddle us a piece of the holy Banner of Zarach, lost to the Clans since the War of the Six Races! He sullied Zarach’s name! Insulted us! He shall die a painful death for it!\n\nThe orc spits: "We’ll slit him open and stuff his bowels with his fake flag!"
He should get a proper trial.
How do you know the banner is not real?

It is some time since you heard any dispute over Alluvyan's Lenya fields. Recently though, humans have begun harvesting again, and there have been whispers of the elves wanting to take more aggressive action.

On the outskirts of a village, you see large creatures of bark and leaves rising from the nearby forest, elven rangers between them.

"We tried to talk, but we were lenient for too long! Elen's wrath will wash this village clean!"
The elves are beyond reason! We must help those villagers!
They are right. We will stand with the elves.
Retreat. We are not equipped to withstand a force like this!

You splinter the treants, shielding the villagers from the attack as best you can. The few elven rangers who remain flee, leaving the giant creatures behind. In the end you save the village from being trampled, and the locals thank you with gifts aplenty.\n\n"There aren't many left, but we fear the elves will return with more monsters! Please, grand mage, will you make sure they never return?"
You can do nothing but watch helplessly as people flood from their houses, fleeing the destruction as the village is crushed in the treants' wake.

You join the rangers, defending them as the treants stomp the village into the ground. Once the humans have fled, silence falls on the grasslands before you.\n\n"You've done a great deed today. We must save as much of Elen's Grace as we can, and you have helped in that. We found these in the humans' possession. May they bring you luck."
We will return with help for those folk.
There is nothing more to be done here.
The giant forest guardians destroy everything in their wake, leaving no house standing and no human unharmed.
What a brutal display of power.
Worry not. We will find them and eliminate the danger.
My soldiers have done enough.
Please! If you save us from this looming threat, we will give you an artifact we found in an elven encampment!
A fine piece of artistry. We will do our best.
Have you no shame asking for more after all we have done? We are leaving.
May Elen smile upon you.
No! You must leave, or they will send more troops!
Then we shall wake the last guardians! Make your way to the marked trees and bring it our blessing. Speak these sacred words! Hurry!
We will fly like the wind.

The elves watch you stoically for a moment before calling the retreat. Their leader throws a pouch on a stump, already turning away.

"Though you will not stand for what is right, you have our thanks. May Elen watch over you and yours."

They are gone before you have the time to reply.
May she do the same to you.

You find a marked tree that the elves spoke of. The old guardian is slumbering in the midst of mushooms and protective glyphs. You remove the glyphs, speak the incantation of waking and watch the creature rise to its task. It will bring chaos to the greedy Alluvyan humans.
One last treant is sleeping. We should find it quickly.
The elves catch up to you soon after you raise the last treant.\n\n"You have fulfilled our request well. Those that defile and pollute the lands will be punished, and we thank you for it."
May you find peace now.
Grimoire Page: Lytra Storme
What you thought to be the right path quickly turns out to be pilgrims. They greet you and continue on their way, murmuring prayers to Tiara and Hirin.
That was frustrating.
Hunter or Prey

Travelling through Southwatch has been difficult lately, with a rise in spider attacks. You are often forced to bypass large webs, or duck beneath sticky white strands. On one journey, you take refuge in a village to rest up, when a boy approaches you with a thin coin purse.\n\n"My pa went to kill the spiders that keep attacking us from the cave and never came back. Will you look for him? I saved some money. I can pay you!"
Keep the coins. We will return your father.
Commendable. We shall look for him.
We have more important things to do. Fare well and good luck.
The brave ilttle boy tries his best not to make a face, but his eyes well up dangerously. He quickly bows to you, then runs off.
A good lad. We should see what we can do.
The boy salutes to you, puffing out his chest before dashing off again.
Let's see if his father is still alive.
You find the cave the boy told you about, covered in webs and likely crawling with spiders. A rusty sword at the entrance is the only indication someone was here.
Hunter or Prey
Kill every spider you see.
Burn it all down.
Trick the spiders out by pulling on the right strings.
Place three poisoned chunks of meat in the webs.
The boy doesn't need to know they likely killed his father. Let's leave.
It is a mere day after leaving the village behind you that you hear of its destruction. Spiders came down and crushed the buildings, wounding some villagers as they went.
I hope the boy is alright.

You catch up with the shaman in red and his wyvern, only to realize he has assembled a host of followers where he has landed.\n\nThere have been reports of orcs pillaging the area. Here, they have brought forth their considerable stolen wealth to the shaman.

The shaman steps forward, beholding you with burning eyes.

"The time has come for us to rise against the Iron Lord! He has grown weak! Accepting humans in his armies! Content with a few scraps of land at the very edge of Fiara!"

He laughs maniacally and shouts: "When I hold Zarach’s Banner, the Clans will follow me as their true leader! The Iron Lord’s rule will crumble! But who are you to even deserve such knowledge?"
The Iron Lord has been around for centuries!
The Iron Lord has sent me to stop you.
Let's see you try.

My followers will search these lands until the pieces are once again gathered. Then, the Iron Lord’s armies will flock to skin him alive at my command and I will rule the Clans as Zarach wills it!

He looks at you, a wild and toothy grin spreading across his face.

"But you will not live to see it."
A giant orc in full iron plate mail steps forward.\n\n"I am Therik of the Iron Storm," he bellows. "We seek a fugitive: The Red Shaman."

He has dared challenge the Iron Lord’s rule, he replies, anger creeping into his voice. "He claims to have received visions from Zarach, telling him to retrieve the Banner and lead the Clans in rebellion!

His folly has cost many young warriors their lives, dying needlessly in foreign lands. I will crush the traitorous worm if I find him!

But finding him in these strange lands has been… difficult," he adds with frustration. "We have orders not to provoke a war. We move slowly, hiding under the cover of night like cowards!"
We may be able to locate him.
The orc looks at you with distrust.\n\n"And what is it you want with him?"
We want to end his crusade before more blood is spilled.

Bah! he growls. "You people are all alike. Greed rules your minds.

But the Shaman must die, one way or another. So, here is my offer: Kill the worm and return to me with proof. I shall reward you for it."

He looks at you, sizing you up.
We have a deal
You return to the Iron Storm camp, the shaman's staff in your hands and place it before their leader, Therik.
I promised you, I would get him.

With the spiders gone, you find a man nestled inside a crack in the cave. The spiders have clearly been trying to get at him - the nearby wall is scratched and crumbling. As you approach, he squeezes out, revealing an unexpectedly large frame. He shivers, brushing webs away.\n\n"Th-thank you. I thought I would be strong enough to deal with them but…"
Let this be a warning. Don't try such foolish undertakings again.

The flames eat through the webs. Soon you hear the loud cracking of chitin and screeches as the heat draws every drop of liquid from the spiders' bodies. But between the crackling fire and their screams, you hear something else too. The desperate cries of a man being grilled alive.
Get him out of there!
Your troops are qucikly tangled up and devoured by the ever hungry spiders.
A truly gruesome death.

As predicted, the spiders empty from the cave at a well placed tug. While they search for their prey, your troops sneak in. The boy's father is pressed into a small crevice, hiding out of the creatures' reach.

You coax him out, talking him through where to place his feet as to not alarm the spiders. Soon, you are back outside, and far enough away to be safe.

"I don't know how to thank you. I will tell everyone who will listen of your bravery today."
Be careful in the future. Our deed is done.

The bait is strategically placed around the entrance. After a heavy tug on a thick strand of webs, spiders come crawling out, devouring the meat in seconds. They disappear again, and you wait. For some time, nothing happens. Then, the spiders slow. Eventually, they stop moving completely. Unsure, you wait another moment. A broad shouldered man emerges from the cave, carefully avoiding the spiders.\n\n"You saved me! Oh, by the Guardians, I will sing your bravery to the sky! Thank you!"
Go home to your son. We'll take our leave.
This man's task ends with his sacrifice. We're leaving.

You storm the cave and find the boy's father on the ground. He is a large man. Your troops suffer their own wounds dragging him to safety, but you escape with your lives. The spiders cannot claim the same.\n\nOnce out of harm's way, the man thanks you, still in shock from the recent events.
Your wounds will heal. Go home to your son.
We are not ready for this. We will be back.
While travelling through Southwatch's sunny grasslands, you hear a faint cry coming from within the web covered woods.
We should investigate those noises.
We should hurry, or we'll be the next meal.
You advance into the webs, and soon find multiple cocoons hanging from the trees. One is twitching and emitting a muffled noise. By its shape and size, you guess the contents to be humanoid.
We will cut you out. Stay still!
Stop moving. I can feel spiders stirring.

The shell is thicker than you anticipated, but a man soon topples out with an ooze that burns your nostrils. His clothes are in a sorry state, and you can hear faint sizzling from his skin and the ground where he landed.

"Thank you! If I had stayed in there any longer, I think the acids would have dissolved me to the bone. I..."

The sudden hiss of spiders around you drowns out his last words.

You free a man from the cocoon with small, well placed incisions, careful not to disturb the surrounding webs. His clothes have been dissolved by the harsh acids inside the cocoon, and his skin is red and covered in blisters.\n\n"What an awful experience. You saved my live. I have nothing on me to thank you, but do come visit my shop. I have plenty of interesting things for mages such as you."
We will gladly visit.
Everyone, run!

You run until the scrawny man calls for you to stop. \n\n"I am a scholar, not an athlete! I... think we have gone far enough. Thank you for saving my live. I don't have anything on me, but my shop has much to offer. Do come and visit some time."
We will.
The man runs at the sight of more spiders, but within moments he is caught, together with your troops. All prey for their sharp pincers.
I failed them all today.

During your fight, you find the man very poorly hidden behind a tree, watching with wide eyes.

Once you have defeated the spiders, he comes forth shaking.

"That was quite enough for me! I'm not carrying anything on me, but I would gladly serve you in my shop! Please, do come visit anytime."
Of course, we will stop by.

Spiders rose all around and it took almost all out of the Southwatch resources to beat them back. Now that their numbers have been decimated, a new threat arises. \n\nUndead have found a way from the Darkvale valley into Southwatch's peaceful grasslands. Many a village has requested help, but the local militia is already spread thin. Anyone brave enough to defend the lands would do a great deed for Southwatch.
The undead must be dealt with.
Despite your best efforts, the undead prevail, spreading further into Southwatch.
I will not accept this foul invasion.

While passing through an urban area, you are stopped by concerned citizen.\n\n"Every month, an Underhall merchant brings us ores, metals and such in exchange for supplies. His last arrival is overdue and we fear the worst. If you could ensure his safety, you can take a share of whatever he carries. We will pay him."
We shall look for him immediately.
A frail skeletal creature lies on the ground, its head smashed in with a large piece of ore. Around it the ground is trampled, and occasionally you see small blood spatters and bones in the dirt.
The merchant must have passed through here.

The constant demon attacks on the main roads are making it difficult to travel, and trade in and out of Southwatch has suffered significantly.\n\nConnach is calling all capable fighters to find the demons' origin and destroy them once and for all.
Killing the demons would improve our standing with Southwatch significantly.

You see an angry crowd pushing and shoving an orc who tries to stagger away from them. His hands are bound and his face bloody. He is thrown to the ground and crawls away as the crowd shouts furiously.\n\n"Crawl away, you savage!" one of them screeches as they kick the orc.
Stop this at once! Leave the orc be!
Let the crowd rage.

You order your soldiers to disperse the crowd and cut the orc's bonds. He rubs his wrists and eyes you warily.\n\n"Thank you. They thought I was a raider but I am a mere wanderer, trying to reach my kin in the Misty Coast."
Try to stay out of trouble.

The orc tries to get up but the crowd kicks him down again. Stones begin to fly in the orc's direction. It does not take long for the orc's body and spirit to give up.\n\n"Pah. Those cursed creatures do not belong in our lands. If they cannot keep to the Howling Steppes and Iron Fields, they should all suffer the consequences!"
He should not have come here.

Your troops’ movements are obstructed by what seems to be a funeral procession.

Oddly, the body being carried is also bound. Before the coffin is closed, a priest throws in a bundle of herbs, then drives a wooden stake into the corpse’s chest!

"It’s ‘cause of the undead we’ve had coming down from Norimar," a woman explains. "It’d be terrible if Auntie Ada joined their ranks, so we asked the priest to make sure she stays dead."
You are right to be cautious.
I think your aunt deserves to voice her opinion.

With a quick incantation, Ada’s corpse starts flailing about, breaking the thin wood of the casket. People panic and run, the priest gathering up his robes and squeaking like a mouse. The corpse rolls around, hissing and spitting, but is impaired by the priest’s wards.\n\nShe would not have been much use anyway, but her remains will serve a greater purpose.
Fun and educational. But mostly fun.
Army of the Dead

A man driving a wagon at frantic speed passes by. He does not even stop for a moment, but waves and screams: "The undead! The undead are coming!"\n\nIndeed, the first skeletons and dried cadavers already make their way through the underbrush towards your convoy.

When the last skeleton has been destroyed, the man who warned you comes crawling back out from a bush he was hiding in during the fight.\n\n"That's just one of them bands roaming about." He shakes. "There's lots more. The folks in Audale would surely love for someone to put them back underground. Us too."
Audale can do their own work.
The last thing you hear is the dying gasps of the man who warned you.\n\n"And these... were just the vanguard..."
That is not encouraging.
Army of the Dead
The first band of undead shambles towards you, gnashing foul teeth and dragging rusty swords.
These waves of undead must be coming from somewhere! Who could be behind their appearance?
This should be the last band of undead. For now.
Turn them into the regular dead again!
We will return it as swift as the wind.

A priestess approaches you, her face showing anguish.\n\n"I implore you, help us! I tend to a shrine of Tiara. A few days back, an orc band plundered the shrine and took a tapestry of great importance. We need this returned, else all of the Highmark is in danger!"

Picking through broken weapons and orc belongings, you spot a faded, embroidered cloth. It’s a bit worse for wear, having seen at least one battle.\n\nOne of the orcs gurgles in a death rattle, reaching for the cloth and muttering: "The banner… Zarach… banner."
Let's return this to the shrine.
You have your troops comb the battlefield but none find the missing tapestry. It seems you have killed the wrong party of orcs.
We must get this right.

A notice tells you that Highmark's annual mead festival is drawing near.

'Bring forth your best creations! The winner will provide the king himself for the year to come!

Winner of last year's contest: Meadnight Tavern in Southwatch'
Their mead is supposed to taste divine.

The streets are bustling with people preparing their carts, selling their wares or walking briskly about. You find a large, two-story building with a sign reading 'Meadnight Tavern' in golden letters. Everything about it looks polished to perfection.

Inside, it is no less perfect. Soon enough, the owner comes to the counter.

"A taste of liquid sunshine for the weary soldiers?"
Give us a sample! You do make it sound tempting.

He fills the last of a large stoppered bottle into small clay jugs and hands them out. It tastes divine. The owner clearly knows this, giving you a proud wink before unstoppering a new bottle.

Instead of the sweet smell of honey, acrid vinegar wafts from it. The owner blanches, then turns as dark as beetroot.

"No! You wench! Vixen! How dare you ruin...!" His face displays pure horror as he opens more bottles. The sour smell spreads further and he falls into despair.
Such a shame, it tasted lovely. What happened?
Wench? Are you saying someone sabotaged your mead?

Ah! Southwatch and Rushwater Downs fight for the title every year. The others aren't even worth tasting! Last year, the competition kind of got out of hand. Mead was spilled on both sides. It seems it wasn't forgotten. The bloody witch decided to strike out early!\n\nWill you help me make her taste her own medicine? Salt her reserves. I'll greatly reward you once I've collected at the festival.
We're not getting in the middle of this. Thank you for the mead.
Your revenge will be dealt swiftly, rest assured.
Nor's Grip
Enemies killed by this unit will not trigger effects on death and won't be able to revive.

The brewer in Southwatch described his Rushwater Downs rival as a 'witch-led dump'. It comes as a surprise then to find a very well cared for tavern. The sign above the door shows a mermaid sitting in a large tankard, the letters below reading 'The Meadmaid'.
Salt in the Wound
We will sneak into the storeroom at night and salt their reserves.
We could play both parties and talk this one out of some money as well.
I think a warning is in order.
You are greeted by a young woman when you enter the tavern, whose embroidered dress mirrors her sunny demeanor.\n\n"Welcome to the Meadmaid. What will it be? Some stew? Rooms?"
Southwatch sends their regards... in form of salt.
The Meadnight Tavern is out for revenge. You ought to be careful.

A sinister smile splits her lips. \n\n"That old mule had it coming. Last year, he stole my mead and declared it was his at the festival. He won with my creation! So, this year I struck back. Since you came all this way to warn me, here's a deal! If you protect my mead until the festival, I can reward you with a glyph that's been in my family for generations. I'm sure you have better use for it than me."
Even after slaying the demons you can already see more coming forth. Nonetheless, people are thankful for your help.
Keep your eyes open. We must find their source.
To your dismay, more demons appear on the horizon. This time though, you are certain you see where they come from.
There must be some way to stop them for good. Follow them.

You find a ritual site where someone has opened a portal. Glyphs are smeared in blood on the ground, and you see footprints all over the area where many demons have passed through.\n\nEven after looking for the better part of an hour, you find no more tracks. Whoever opened the portal must have closed it shortly before you arrived.
This is not over. Keep your eyes peeled.
Start Research
Summonification of a wispification that magicifies an elementarian ornamenterly for unexpectedly usagication.
Come nightfall, you find your way to the storage room. You add salt to bottle after bottle of the mead stacked on its shelves, then silently retreat, taking care not to leave any trace of your visit.
Maybe we should see how it goes at the festival.
The man grumbles under his breath, and you catch some words before you leave.\n\n"... find another way then."
That could be trouble. Maybe we should visit the Rushwater Downs tavern.
That sounds fair. We'll do it.
We won't be dragged into this. Good luck with the contest.
Annual Mead festival

Like every year, the festival is grand. People from far and wide arrive to advertise their products, or compete in the contest.\n\nYou post guards around the Meadmaid's stall, and don't have to wait too long before you spy a group of delinquents starting a fight far too close for comfort. Their motions are too deliberate to be coincidence. Finally, one bumps into your troops, landing a heavy punch.

When you reach Highmarch, the festivities are in full swing. Mead is being handed out at every corner, and vendors sell delicate pastries, sharp cheeses and meat pies to go with the drinks. Soon, the official contest begins. You see the innkeep from Southwatch waving to you.

During the sampling, a tense silence settles on the crowd, until a stout man with a booming voice finally announces a slurred result.

"Dis years winner 's... The Meadnight Tav'n innn Southwatch!"
Time to collect our reward.
That is enough! Now you will suffer the consequences!

After being thoroughly celebrated, you find the innkeeper back at his stall. He greets you with reddened cheeks and a big smile.\n\n"You stood true to your word and so I shall stay true to mine! Your reward as promised!"
Much obliged.
Take this money and back off.
Caught off guard by your response, the thugs withdraw back into the masses and you are left alone for the rest of the day.
The mead is spilled with the blood of your troops. There goes your opportunity to gain some favorable reputation.
If I ever see those bastards again...

Out of the corner of your eye you see the stall and mead being smashed to pieces. The Meadmaid's young innkeep storms forth and cries for the guards, but they are too late.\n\nYou can feel her glaring at your back as you retreat.
This did not go as planned.
Keep an eye out, just in case.

As the contest finally commences, you watch with anticipation. During the sampling, a tense silence settles on the crowd, until a stout man with a booming voice finally announces a slurred result.\n\n"Dis years winner 's... The Meadmaid Tav'n innn Rushwater Downs!"
Time to collect our reward.
You find the young woman at her stall, flushed with excitement. \n\n"What a thrill! This was perfect! The glyph, as promised. As well as some mead to celebrate!"
Much obliged.
Notifications
Notifications
{what} joins
{what} revived
{what} built
{what} destroyed
{what} built
{what} crafted
Tower upgraded
Enchanted unit can traverse any terrain.
Fly on the wings of love through the cloud filled air, but behold of ze germans.

Your continued aid to Southwatch hasn't gone unnoticed. One day, the citizens of Connach approach you with an offer.\n\n"You have done us many favors. In return, we wish you to have a magic scroll, found in Southwatch many years ago. It is kept safe, in a small village. We have arranged for you to pick it up without questioning."
Thank you. We will go there.
{what} canceled, couldn't afford upkeep!
{what} quit, couldn't afford upkeep!
{what} milestone completed

When you reach the village, you are greeted by blood soaked grounds and many dead. Body parts lie strewn between guts and dirt, and the massacre stinks to the high heavens.\n\nOne house's door bursts open, and a demon steps out with a scroll in hand. Its grimace shows sharp rows of teeth.
No Active Research
Could Cast A Spell
Alerts
Demons
Low funds
[malus]Not enough gold[/]
Low Mana
[malus]Not enough mana[/]
Alerts

Strange smells guide you to a village where people are currently standing in line to enter a mansion. Each is holding a plate, bowl or pot in hand, and you see many freshly baked goods, cooked stews and more. But each meal has a different disturbing ingredient. You see pinecones and grasshoppers, snakes and many things you cannot even guess.
What is the meaning of all this?

A man with nothing in hand leans over to you and quietly explains.\n\n"The Lord is seeking a new cook, see? He is... rather eccentric about his food. He wants someone who can surprise his taste buds every day. But the pay he offers in return is just so much! If only I had some jelly meat, then I could participate!"
What would I get if I brought you some?
Well, good luck then. We must be off.

The man's eyes twinkle. He was waiting for exactly this question.\n\n"If the Lord takes me on, I'll pay you plenty, and then some. I have a magical item. A glyph! Just bring me some jelly meat and it's yours!"
It shall be done.
How did you come by a magical artifact?
You returned! Did you bring me the jelly meat?
Here you are. About our reward.
Not yet, but it won’t take much longer.
You are a mage after my own taste! I'm sure to get the job with this!\n\nHe hands over the promised reward and dashes off to cook.
A curious fellow.

I found it actually. I was on my way to trade with the dwarves when I stumbled across a ruin. Or rather... the last standing stones of one. I found it underneath the wreckage. I promise it'll be yours. If you bring me jelly meat.
We must go then. Those jellies won't hunt themselves.
I don't believe that. Give me your stolen goods or suffer the consequences.

The man's face shifts from smug to shocked as he realizes you mean what you say. He tries to stutter an excuse before handing you something small. A glyph.\n\n"You are not as righteous as I thought. I'll make sure all of Rushwater knows your greed and distrust."
Do as you wish. We are leaving.
Wait a moment! How about a trade? You bring me some jelly meat, I'll reward you with gold, and this glyph I have! That sounds like a good deal, right?
Where did you get this from?
It does. We'll look for some jelly meat then.
We are not errand runners. Find someone else.
{amount} units can level up!
Empty Room available
Tower is targeted
Lodges can be build
Enemies close
Would some coin hasten your departure?

The officer turns to you with a shocked, dark glint in his eyes.\n\n"You're obviously either dumb or deaf, so I'll let that slide. Leave now though, otherwise my soldiers will show you the sharp edge of a sword."
