The officer turns and eyes the offered purse. Smiling slightly, he takes the coin and waves his units away, leaving without another word.

The villagers quickly help each other down from the pillory.

"Many thanks, grand mage. That was a true act of kindness. We cannot repay you in gold, but at least let us give you something in return."
How much do you want to leave these people be?
Fine, we will leave. But this will not be forgotten.
Leaving the village behind, you cannot shake the feeling these people will talk about this for a long time to come. You doubt it will be in your favor.
What does it matter? Continue on.
Thank you. May the Guardians watch over you.
Reputation with {what} changed to {reputation}
The villagers come running at your approach, crying for help.\n\n"The river has stopped! We cannot fish or water our crops! Can your magic bring the water back to us? We need it so much!"

You quickly discover why the river is suddenly so low. A large cluster of jellies has clogged its narrowest point, and the water flows over the banks instead.\n\nUpon futher inspection, you realize the jellies are clinging to what must be an adult of their species.
We will look for a solution.
I have no reason to help you.
Slice them all up.
Their remains are washed further upstream, but at least the water is running freely. Within hours, the fish should return too.\n\nIn the guts of one, you find a shimmering reward for your troubles.
I can drive them upstream.
Try to disperse them with food.
We will have to think of another way. Retreat for now.
If we raise the water's acidity, they should flee.
After throwing the bait, you realize you will need far more to get the jellies moving. Nevertheless, you have a feeling that with enough food, it can be done.
It will only take a few more. The villagers will be thankful.

Seshi carefully joins the jellies' dance, expertly mimicing their flowing movements. Then she takes lead of the patterns, using it to lead them further upstream. To your surprise, the jellies follow her away!
That was... marvellous.

As you expertly change the water's chemistry, the jellies rush and tumble over each other to move themselves. Soon, the water is flowing feely again. It will only take a few hours for fish to return too. The village is saved.
They will be glad of our help.
That should fix the villagers' problems.
We cannot spare enough food for this. We must kill them.
This can't be the best way. We will return another time.

As you near the bridge you spot a young man cowering at its foot.
You soon notice he is in distress, his robes torn and blood gushing from a wound to his arm. He is white as snow and shaking.

"D-Demons are coming! Prepare... I saw them! They are coming from the Tuscari Sea! Barely escaped with my life..."
Looming Danger
Draw
An ill omen. Prepare yourselves.
Sevenkeeps
The moment the page is taken from out of the small chest, it disintegrates, leaving behind only specks of light and dust.\n\nAn illusion! All your effort, wasted.
Perhaps we will have more luck in the next place.
This feels like a trap my master would set.
I see. We will leave you to it then.

In a narrow street, you hear distressed voices. Villagers stand in a circle there, crying over some who lie dead. A woman notices you and waves you over, tears streaking down her face.\n\n"My wife and I were closing the bakery when the militia came about. They demanded bread, but we hadn't any left. When they started destroying our shop, these people came to help us. The militia killed them without remorse. Something is wrong with them. They've never been so irrational, so brutal before!"
They've caused enough trouble. Time to finish this.
Sorry for your loss. We'll let you mourn.

She quickly stands in your way.

"Wait! Will you make sure the militia is dealt with? This man was my friend! He did nothing to deserve an end like this! I beg you, destroy those heartless monsters."

With her jaw clenched in anger, she offers you her full purse.
We daren't interfere. I'm sorry.
It will be done.

You walk the grounds of the militia's barracks. Many soldiers are training in combat, others seeing to their gear's condition. Not knowing which group attacked the village, you approach the captain's quarters, only to find them guarded by two elves.\n\n"No one enters without permission. The captain is praying."

A huge orc with fearsome scars and just one eye approaches your army.\n\n"I challenge you to battle!" he bellows, brandishing his axe. "We shall flay the flesh from your skin and drink your blood for the glory of Zarach!"
You and what army?
Orc Warband
I decline the challenge. Find someone else to battle.

You pass by a lone cart, a woman sobbing next to it as she cradles her dead partner’s head.\n\n"Orcs! A huge band of marauders!" she cries. "After they overran the militia, they just hunted us all down. We never stood a chance!"
His death shall be avenged.

You approach the orc war band. Most of them are young, their tusks gleaming, faces yet to be scarred. A one-eyed orc in red face paint yells and gestures, telling them to slay the weaklings and whipping them into a frenzy.\n\nWhen your army forms rank and marches towards them, the leader orc steps behind the lines and raises his weapon.
Give them a fight they'll remember!

The last of the young orc lies dead at your feet.\n\nThe old leader stands away from the battle, surveying the carnage. He raises his weapon, lets it fall to the ground and nods at you once. Without another word, he turns and rides off east.
I wonder why he did that.

Three humans carrying large backpacks and strange implements wave for you to stop for a moment.

"Well met!" the first one greets you. "We are... independent contractors for spelunking and... treasure retrieval. We work mostly with the deceased. Problem is, the dead have become restless these days."

"We can't do our jobs like this!" a short one with glasses protests. "I ain't afraid of no ghost, but an army of them? You can't get a decent day's work in without being drained of all life by one of them!"

"We will compensate you!" a tall one chimes in, shouldering his enormous backpack.
Where are those ghosts?

The stench of decay is strong on the air as you close in on the marching undead.\n\n"There, you see? Undead as far as the eye goes!" the tallest of the three strange men says. He shivers visibly. "Someone has really got to take them down."

The spelunking band moves in, quickly marking promising spots. One of them comes up to you with a cloth-wrapped bundle and opens it before your eyes.\n\n"These should show our appreciation." he says. His grin shows a gold tooth. "Much obliged."

A delegation of Audale’s dignitaries approach you. One steps forward, bowing and smiling while a servant holds his umbrella.

“Good mage, we humbly ask that you lend us your strength. Armies of undead have come down from the north-east and ravage the countryside. We can only deal with so many, for our forces are stretched thin.

Help us and you shall receive an artifact from our treasury in return!”
We will take on the undead!
Gather round! I will bless us.
Your scouts tell you of a mass of undead that have left a trail of destruction behind them. Many have joined their shambling lines, their sheer number seemingly ever growing.
The magic you channel into the ground seeps into bones and rotting flesh of the wandering undead.
Now! Take them down!
A bright light encases your units, granting them strength and vigor for the upcoming battle.
Victory once more.
Finally the last enemy goes down and a tired, fierce cry of victory rises over your ranks. Audale - and all of Gillyshire - is thankful for your contribution to their safety.
You’ll have to deal with this alone.

The delegate is lost for words, opening and closing his mouth like a fish on dry land.

"This is most... unfortunate," he finally says. "But... as you wish. We will find another solution. Or... or leave the peasants to be killed. Thank you for your time."

The entourage turn to leave and citizens nearby murmur darkly.
I'm sure Audale will be fine.
An apology, like I said! You cost us quite a sum. If you're willing to pay said large sum, I might talk my soldiers into letting you go. If you aren't... Well, I think we can arrange a swift death.
Fine. Take the money.
Oh, your death will be anything but swift.
Outrun them!
You will regret this.
Hand over the scroll. We can part without a fight.
In its last breath, the demon mutters something, then cackles maniacally.\n\n"Good luck!"
What ever that meant, it cannot be good.
Outrun them!

You are about to charge when the faces of the militia contort and darken. Their limbs stretch and warp until there is nothing human left of them. Suddenly, your soldiers stand face to face with demons.
I knew something was wrong! Attack!
As your troops run, you take a last look back. The militia deforms and darkens. Within moment, there are demons stood there, laughing at your retreating troops.
Hurry, before they catch us!
Demonic Militia
I will have revenge.
The demon unfurls the scroll, taking a long look at the content before tossing it to the ground.\n\n"Like I said, I already had my fun. You can have it. If you let me take some of your energy."
The demon leaves your company slain in the carnage of the village, taking the scroll as it flees.\n\nThis might have been your only chance to read it.
Let that be my problem.
So be it then.
We’ve seen their true form. They are demons.
The crowd gasps in shock.\n\n"That's why they've become so barborous! Will you destroy these monsters? They've already done too much damage. We would be forever grateful!"
The exterior of the militia's barracks looks normal, but you know there are demons hiding inside. The training grounds are empty now, but you see shadows moving in the windows.
Kill every demon you find.
Ambush them at the doors.
We have his permission.
Will coin open any doors?
Set some traps before the doors.
You'll let us pass right now!
The guards raise their weapons suspiciously, gesturing to the exit.\n\n"The captain is a she. You will not enter her quarters."
The guards share a quick glance before grabbing the coins.\n\n"The captain will have our heads if we let you in this way, but there's a window in the back."
That will suffice.
Fine!
Take this mead for a job well done.
We're to replace you on the door.
On your way around the house, you spot an open window. A heavy curtain hangs before it, and only muffled noise filters through.
We'll wander for a while then.

Inside, you find a woman drawing glyphs on the walls in blood. Her other hand clutches a small effigy of Nor. At your entrance, she turns in surprise and her face grows furious.

"What?! Oh, you will not disturb this sacred ritual unscathed!"

She mumbles something, and the door bursts open. Strong hands grab your troops. Suddenly you are surrounded! The humans you passed on your way here deform into Demons in front of you.
You offered your troops up to house demons?! Attack them!
This is our way in.
The guards grin and toast to your health. They're quickly too drunk to do their job. One even starts to nod off.
Now we can enter.
The guards are too confused to see Nuvian wave a hand at them. Then, their eyes soften and they nod thankfully. Nuvian keeps waving as they walk away, then turns to you and grins.\n\n"Taken care of!"
You're quite good at that, aren't you?
The guards blanch as Philo's eyes turn black. His voice was much lower than you have come to expect from him. When the guards have stepped away, his innocent face turns to you.\n\n"What?"
Nothing. I just thought I saw... Never mind.
Your plan works well, and your troops are able to do some damage before a real battle ensues.
We still need to regroup!
Ritual ended and effigy destroyed, you know that demons will soon stop coming to the Highmark.
We're all safe from their devilry now.
Grants "[locationpromotion]{what}[/]" for {battles} Battle(s)
Grants "[locationpromotion]{what}[/]" until the end of the week

Miners keep shooting looks at your troops. Finally, one of them is brave enough to come over.\n\n"I hope I'm not bothering you, but our village needs some soldiers. You see, Granite Dwarves have seized one of our mines. If you help us remove them, we could give you some of the loose ores."
A generous deal. It will be done.
The mine is a gaping maw in the side of the mountain. From within, you hear hammering, and the distant talk of dwarves distorted by echoes.
Ready your weapons. They won't go without a fight.

You are about to lead your soldiers inside when the talking turns suddenly to screaming. The dwarves swarm out of the mine, fleeing a group of snow leopards. They must have found their way in and decided the mine would be their new home.

Confusion turns to desperation before he falls to his knees in front of you.\n\n"Please! We have our differences, I know, but we are kin aren't we? Save your kindred! Save my village and you'll be plentifully rewarded!"
You really must be desperate. Fine. We'll help.
We won't help scum like you. Get lost.

You find a local griffon trainer - possibly the last there is, since griffons have become quite rare. You hope to buy mounts for your forces, but those you see are either hurt or at the brink of death... Large claw marks have ripped through the grounds of the entire pasture.

A dwarf, in the middle of looking after a young griffon, looks up at your approach.

"No griffons left, I fear. The blasted wyvern made sure of that."
A wyvern attacked your griffon?

Aye! And 'em orcs from gods know where. Must have come over and tore right through my stock. I didn't even have time to call for help.

His hand jerks to wipe at his face, barely conceiling his tears.

"If you feel like killing them, I might be swayed to give you my last remaining animal."
You have yourself a deal.

The dwarf is true to his word. Upon showing him the slain beast, he brings forth his last griffon.\n\n"I was able to save some eggs. It will take some time, but I might just be able continue my passion. In a few years, that is. The babes have to hatch first. Thank you, grand mage."
May the Guardians protect the next generation.
Griffon

Each year, the dwarves of Silver Drift Hollow, Draycott, Coldmark and Windholme meet with the conclave near Stoneblade Peak. There, they assess who may work which Adamantinum mines for the coming year. This year, you have been invited to attend the discussions, but the ambassadors for Silver Drift Hollow arrive late, and rather disheveled.\n\n"Those darn Granite Dwarves attacked us on our way. Took all our Adamantinum! Someone ought to teach them a lesson!"
Move towards the Gate.

Strolling past vellum makers and bookbinders, your way leads past a bookseller’s stand. There are all kinds of work on sale – maps, mundane stories, magical theorems! Such a wealth of knowledge in such a small space.\n\nBut, as you gaze on the titles to find something worth your attention, you are disturbed by a commotion at the Academy Gate itself.
What is it?
Slay those leopards!
Let them eat the dwarves!

To everyone's surprise, the dwarves beat back the snow leopards. Soon, the beasts are fleeing over the mountains. Once your troops are in earshot, the miners make sure you know how little they think of you.\n\n"Didn't have it in you to fight such vicious beasts, did ya? Those weapons are just decoration, then? You call yourselves soldiers. You should be ashamed! No real dwarf would ever work under you!"
We were just saving ourselves to fight you.
This mine doesn't belong to you. Walk away.
And let you have all the riches? Don't think so! Fight for it, or bugger off, scum.
Your intervention makes an impression on the dwarves, and they thank you roughly for your help.\n\n"That was not even half bad for barbarians."
In return, leave us this mine and move on.
Or you can take these crystals and leave.
Then we fight.

Their greedy expressions betray their boastful attitude and you come to an accord. The Granite Dwarves are quickly gone, and you collect your promised reward. Your soldiers scour the mine for loose ores, and soon return with a full bag.
This was rewarding indeed.
Be smart. We're the stronger force here.
Don't get ahead of yourselves. You're next.

They are torn between cursing your insolence and weighing the threat you pose. In the end, they don't push their luck.\n\nWhile the Granite Dwarves pack up their things, your units scour the mine for loose ores - the promised reward - and soon return with a full bag.
This was easier than expected.
If you want riches, what about this coin?
We do have a little Adamantinum to spare.
You've insulted us for the last time, swine! You can keep your dirty money, but we'll take your lives!
So be it.
The dwarves reluctantly take the crystals and pack up. Your troops scour the mine for the promised reward of loose ores, and soon return with a full bag.
Finally this is dealt with.
Once the Granite Dwarves are dealt with, your troops scour the mine for lose ores, as it was the promised reward, and are soon returning with a full bag.\n
Our work is done here.
Where did you encounter them? We'll sort it.
How did you escape?
Some of the ambassadors shuffle and shift nervously.\n\n"We, uh, gave them the Adamantinum. That was enough for them to let us pass, mostly unharmed."
Then we'll retrieve it. Where did this happen?
I thought you said they took it.

Their faces flush a shameful red. The ambassadors stutter a short response, but the conclave is onto them now. The Draycott emissaries raise their voices first.

"Lies will get you nowhere! Tell us what happened! Why have you brought no contribution?!"

Finally, the facade crumbles, and the ambassadors confess. Their harvests have been scant, and they kept what little they could mine for themselves. They are shunned for their dishonesty and asked to pay a fine. You are thanked for your sharp wits.
You search every pocket and all the Granite Dwarves' belongings, but cannot find the missing Adamantinum.
It wasn't an utterly wasted effort.
Goblin Brawlers
Goblin Archers
Javelin Throwers
Drummers
Warg Riders
War Troll
Brutes
Ravagers
Orc Shamans
Goblin
Slave Driver
Drum Heal
Brutal
Slaveable
Slaver
Deal up to {MissingHealthDamageBonus.MaxDamage:+-c} Damage based on missing health {postfix}
Berserk
Grants [unitpromotion]{what}[/]
Coming back to the noble house, you see the sign still up on the door, offering a reward to those who destroy Darkvale's undead.
We must do that before we go in again.
Subdue
Inferno
Target random enemies within {aoe} around the user [bonus]{AmountOfHits}[/] times and deal {damage} damage on every hit.
Good day.
Battle Cry
Battle Cry
Battle Cry
Cluster Bomb
Inferno
Blessing
Legend
Stack
Location
Adventure
Monster Spawner
Dangerous endeavors

A crowd clusters around a young man in front of the local tavern. He looks like he has seen a horrid fight, all torn and bruised. He is telling a tale, feeding his dog meaty treats.

"Stay away from the caves. Those blasted snow leopards charged right at me! Of course, I was scared out of my mind, but Sam here jumped in. I dragged myself away while my lil' boy fought them off like it was nothing. You are a hero, Sam! You hear? A hero!"

The dog is not 'little', but definitely delighted with his snacks, and certainly a hero.
To Sam!
Let's hope we don't encounter such beasts.
What a bunch of nonsense.
Toggle Legend
They wouldn't come all the way out here.
Let the beasts loose!
Bury the snow leopards in an avalanche!
Where are the other four of you?
No problem. Now hand over your riches.
The idea was sound, but larger rocks fall with the explosion. The leopards are scared off or buried, but the dwarves and your own troops sustain some damage too.
At least we saved the dwarves.

The leopards measure themselves against your beasts as their prowl forward, but decide it is not worth their while. They growl at you all and trot off into a nearby cave, tails furiously twitching behind them.
Alright. Reign them in.

The Granite Dwarves look you over quickly, then offer you a deal.

"We want no trouble. Just the metals. If you help us, we'll give you half in return."

The miners give you pleading looks.

"Please, we need all the Adamantinum! Otherwise our forges will lie dormant. We will pay you to rid us of these thieves!"
Armored
Piercing Attacks
Hornets
Wargs
Bloodthirsty
Electro Ball
Small Jellys
Big Jellys
Tailwind
Discharge
Iron Beak
Plaguesplosion
Demon

Crossing a particularly tricky mountain route, you hear distressed voices. Behind a steep curve, you find a group of miners held hostage by Granite Dwarves.\n\n"Last chance! What will it be? The Adamantinum or your lives?"
Hold it right there, thieves!
This is not our concern. Continue on.
Bigger Problems

Small boulders tumble down into the village at steady intervals. The dwarves are cramming together what food and provisions they can muster, packing it all into a large bundle.

"Some trolls have moved into the mountains above the village," they tell you at your inquiry. "They keep threatening to set off an avalanche and bury us all if we don’t bring food! Our reserves are low now – soon we won’t be able to pay.

Can you help us?"
We'll deal with them.
Sadly, we are busy. Good luck!
We have some nice, uhm, juices! Here!
They gleefully take the flasks without thinking. Only after downing the contents do they realize the liquids are poisonous. It is a slow-acting poison, though, and, with a roar, the trolls attack.
Attack while they're weak!
This should suffice, shouldn't it?
If we heal you, will you move on?
The troll eyes you all with suspicion.\n\n"You can make ouch go away? Yes. If you can, we move. If not, we eat you."
We'll see about that!
Hold still. It will take a moment.

Your healers work at the wound until the angry red swelling subsides. The trolls watch with fascination. Once the troll’s leg is healed, they all get up.

"You keep promise. We leave."

Without another word, the lumbering creatures march off into the mountains.
Well, that was easy.

The trolls haven’t moved since you last came to visit.

"Meats or death?"

The largest holds out a hand, as if expecting a treat, and gives you a menacing look.
If we heal you, will you move on?
Meats. Here you are.
Soon. We need to find a few more pieces.

The Trolls share the offered meats with many a growl. When their bellies are full, they slowly get up.

"You keep promise - we leave."

Without another word, the lumbering creatures march off into the mountains.
Now that’s taken care of, let’s return to the village.
{what} depleted
Horned Beast
Aether Beast
Wyvern

The last thing you expect, passing a small camp of Granite Dwarves, is that the otherwise hostile and unfriendly folk would approach you.\n\n"We need help," they tell you. "Beasts have taken up shelter in a mine. We need them gone. Do it and you’ll receive Adamantinum in return."
We will never help the likes of you.
Show us where to go.
Sly grins and chuckles spread through the crowd.\n\n"If you won't do it, we can't let you pass. These mountains are our home. We can't have you desecrate them."
Fine! We'll kill your beasts. Where is it?

A low grumble comes from deep within the tunnels, reverberating off the walls.\n\nThe Granite Dwarves' promised Adamantinum sounds tempting but, whatever this monster is, it went deep into the mountain to hide and the sound suggests something large and dangerous.
Unexpected request
Let's find out.
Wendigo
Core Dwellers
Arachnoid Abomination
Broodfather
Infest Corpses

Even sheltered from the wind, the tunnels are cold and slippery with ice. The main path quickly forks in different directions and with so many echos, it is impossible to discern the direction of the growling.\n\nYou are faced with a decision: One path leads to a pool of sorts. The second is halfway filled with rubble and stone. The last looks barren, except for a warm, red glow.
Let's try to cross the pool.
The monster could have caused the collapse.
The glow could be a fire.
You find yourself in a maze of sorts. The glow is emanating from a hole high in the steep wall but various ways trace back and forth towards it, crossing and winding across the whole cave.
In the low temperatures, the pool has frozen over, but there are cracks in the surface where stalactites have fallen.

Where the ceiling has caved in you can climb up to another cave. There, the growling becomes almost deafening. The steady rhythm tells of deep sleep and soon you catch the outline of a wyvern in the darkness. It must have crashed through the ceiling and may possibly be hurt.\n\nAs you all climb up, you can already see dark shapes moving a little further into the darkness. Whatever they are, you should hurry and decide what to do.
Where did you find such a precious metal?

The dwarves seem less comfortable to discuss that.\n\n"It may have been… disregarded by some miners. We found it. Saved it, if you will. Now. What about the monsters? Will you kill ‘em? We don’t have all day – answer quick!"
Fine. We'll kill the beasts for you.
You don't deserve help. Fix it yourselves.
A loud groan goes up. One dwarf rolls his eyes.\n\n"Yes, it’s tarnished! But you can still use it, can't you? Do we have a deal or not?"
Are you trying to give us tainted Adamantinum?
We'll do it, but you better give us lots.
We won't help you.
This does not look safe. Back.
I am light-footed enough to find a safe path.
Send the undead forward first. Don't step where they fall.
Coldsnap
Medusa Warriors
Medusae
Onwards. Carefully.
The ice cracks under your troops’ feet and the first falls through the ice in moments. They are left almost scorched by the biting chill.
Hurry to the other side!

Elynn slowly and carefully pads forward, testing every step before signaling for the rest of you to follow. Safely on the other side, you continue down the tunnel.\n\nThe growling gets louder as you come to a large cave. Among the mining equipment there is a fiery light, emitting out of a group of golems' cores. With the sound of grinding stone, they turn in your direction.

You leave the mine with the ‘monsters’ dealt with. The Granite Dwarves are still hiding close by, awaiting your return.

"The noises stopped," they say expectantly. "Is it done?"

Upon your nod, a rough cheer spreads among them: "Finally! Then this is yours now."
Hold on! This is tainted!
Next time, you deal with the problem yourselves.
A mischievous smile spreads across their leader's lips.\n\n"We never promised pure Adamantinum. Enjoy your reward!"
You betrayed the wrong people.
This won't be forgotton.
The dwarves push your soldiers back. Some don't watch their step, falling into the deep ravines. Others fall to the vicious dwarves' axes.\n\n"Next time, ask better questions. Hahaha!"
May Niethalf show you no mercy.
It will be impossible to get through. Let's go back.
Easy! Me and Whiskey will handle this!
Let's attempt the maze.
After trying every possible way you find, you always come back to the landing far below the red glow. There doesn't seem to be a way up.
We must try a different way then.

The way is confusing and illogical but you trust to Yngrid and Whiskey’s senses and eventually find yourselves on a high ledge. The growl is louder here – and the glow almost too bright to look at. You follow both a few steps closer until you see golems with glowing, burning hearts aimlessly wandering the cave.\n\nOne of them has seen you.
Calm, beast. Let's get you outside.
Healing it will help it escape.

The shadows – iron beaks – become insessently noisy as you approach, waking the wyvern from its slumber.

It is wary as you try to free it, keeping a sharp eye on every movement and trying to free itself from the heavier boulders. When it can move its wings again, they spread and stretch across the cavern.

With a loud screech it is gone, the flock of iron beaks racing after their symbiotic partner quickly.
That should suffice.

The moving shadows – iron beaks – quickly break out into chorus and wake the wyvern, which snarls as your healers approach to fix the deep cuts in its flesh and your soldiers remove the boulders from it wings. Slowly, the wyvern stops fighting, simply watching you all closely.\n\nWhen the tissue is healed and it is free, it stands and carefully spreads it wings, dropping something from its large claw. Then it and the iron beaks are all gone, racing up into the hole that leads back to the open world.
Problem solved.
A few bits of enchanted stone glint in the sun, but otherwise you find only sleet and pebbles.
Better than nothing.
Movementpoints restored
stack healed

Some humans approach you, their banner that of Sevenkeeps.\n\n"Greetings, great mage. One of our expeditions was searching for a pass to Regan Gor and never returned. If you encounter them, would you please let us know?"
We'll keep our eyes open.
You find some tracks to suggest the expedition passed this way. It is already snowed over, but you see faint signs of a struggle.
This looks like a fight. We best find them quickly.

It takes you a while to track the expedition further, not helped by the heavy snow.\n\nTo make things worse, it seems snow leopards have picked up their scent too and a pack of them are sniffing a boulder smeared with blood.
Here! Blood! We can use it to track them!
Kill them before they find the expedition!
I will cover our own scent so they don't attack.
We can't mess with snow leopards.
The expedition’s tracks lead closer to Norgate. Following it on, you find a foot print far too large to be human.
They're being chased by trolls! Hurry!

The tracks end at a cave. And a sprawled out troll, very much dead. The smell of decaying flesh is sickening.

From within, you hear whimpering and pained grunts. A pair of fiery red eyes flashes in the darkness. Then another and another. Demons step from the shadows, hands and faces sticky with dried blood and meat.

"Dessert has finally arrived." One of them grins at you.
No! Just your death!

When the sounds of battle subside, a small group of humans slowly step from the cave. The Sevenkeeps expedition. As they see the slain demons, a rather disheveled sigh of relief goes up.

"You are a sight for sore eyes," they tell you. "Bless the Guardians for sending you! Just in time. Thank you! Thank you a hundred fold!"

Not long later, another search party passes. You make sure the explorers are escorted home safely and the reward is plentiful in return.
Stay safe, now.
You had your warning, scoundrels. Time to pay.
Half the Adamantinum, you say?

Your troops hold the miners at weapon point, and the Granite Dwarves pack the Adamantinum into their own pockets, leaving half for you.

"As promised! Maybe Niethalf will show you some kindness too, for helping us."

They are quickly gone, leaving the miners at your mercy.
The miners keep their word, thanking you manyfold for your help. You get the feeling that word of your deeds will travel.
Have a safe journey.
The Granite Dwarves flee with the wares, leaving the miners to their fate.
We underestimated them this time.
Pack up the Adamantinum.
Silence them. Quickly.
Icicle Cannon
Fire Golem
Icy Touch
Petrifying Gaze
Plaguebeetles

Upon passing a dark crevasse, you hear strange noises coming from within. Howling, whimpering and scratching, distorted by many echoes. You have never heard such sounds before. There is no telling what beast they might come from.
Let's see what we find.
We best hurry. Whatever it is might be hungry.

A steep path leads into the darkness, and your troops have to maneuver carefully through sharp rocks. The strange noises stop for a moment, as if listening to the descent, before returning even more urgent and wild.\n\nAt the bottom, you find some dwarves, all tied up and half buried under their cart and debris. Their exhausted screams sound hoarse, and the cart stretches the sound beyond recognition.
Free those poor souls.
Check their pockets, then we'll leave.

The wreckage is quickly shoveled aside, and the dwarves take count of their many wounds.\n\n"Bless you. This could have been our end. We were intercepted by Granite Dwarves on our way to deliver goods. They took our wares and threw us down here to die. We were lucky it was just broken bones and bruises."
Let's get you healed up.
What were you transporting?
We’ll give the bastards a taste of their own medicine.
I feel like a reward is in order.

Not long later, you find the Granite Dwarves sitting in a small camp, relishing their victory. They obviously don't fear being caught, and their guard is down. On one side of their camp, a small hand cart is filled with crates and sacks. It must be the miners' stolen goods.

As their wounds are being healed, one of the dwarves speaks up, venom thick in his voice.\n\n"If you should find them, kill them. They've been ignored far too long. And we'd reward you when our lost goods are retrieved. What say you?"
Let's find them.
These are your desputes. We'll take our leave.
We had some newly forged glyphs from Windholme, some ores and metals. I tell you this. If you find those bastards and retrieve our goods, we'll give you some of them as a reward.
Don't worry. We'll find them.
We want no part in this. Farewell.
Aye. The Granite Dwarves took everything, so you shall be rewarded upon delivering our wares to Coldmark. We'll make sure they pay you plentiful.
Let's find your wares then.
Pah! So ungrateful.
You won't cause trouble again, miscreants!
The cart can be sabotaged into rolling away.
With a grand gesture Lore expertly creates a small avalanche that crashes through the camp without destroying the cart. Surprised and wounded, fighting the Granite Dwarves will be much easier now.
Bring them down!

A well placed shot is enough to dislodge a bolt from the cart's wheels. Before the Granite Dwarves know it, it is sliding away towards you, and they curse and swear while your troops catch it and run before they can be caught.
Let's get away before we look inside.

You find the miners where you left them and they deliver on their word. Rummaging through one of the crates, they offer you a small pouch.\n\n"This was newly forged in Windholme. It's yours! As thanks."
Very useful. Thank you!
Manufacture an avalanche to bury the camp.
Opening a cleverly fitted slot in the cart, you uncover some gold and a glyph. A fine solution for hiding the real valuables in transport.
The miners will be pleased everything is in order.
The miners won't mind us taking our reward now.
Take everything. They'll never be the wiser.
You deliver the cart, telling the dwarves you already took the glyph. They clearly disapprove, but stay silent on the matter.\n\n"We're grateful you returned the rest. Safe travels."
To you as well.
The cart contains some copper, and a few potions, but no glyphs.
Let's return what we can.
We should just keep this and go.
They'll be in a hidden compartment.
This is a misunderstanding! Have back what we took!
Halt, thieves!\n\nThe miners your robbed are coming after you, and have brought help.
Draw your weapons!
We can't face them!
They eye you suspicously.\n\n"Fine then. Hand over the glyph and we will leave you be. But let this be a warning not to cross us in the future."
Of course. I am deeply sorry.
Gullible fools! We will never return it!

You've messed with the wrong dwarves, mage!\n\nYou suddenly find yourselves surrounded by Granite Dwarves - the same ones that stole the hand cart from the miners. Or rather, the same ones you stole the cart back from.
Brace yourselves!
You might have won the battle, but word of your deeds may travel quickly. The dwarves will not look so kindly on that.
At least we can keep the goods.
Breathe Fire

The whole village is clustered around its governor, who is currently finishing speaking.

"I urge everyone to stay vigilant! The moles are a very real threat! No one should leave for the mines without the means to defend themselves!"

The governer notices you and waves you over as the villagers slowly disperse to share their concerns with others.
What's this all about? Moles gone rogue?

The elderly dwarf nods regretfully.\n\n"Indeed. Something must have disturbed those in our largest Adamantinum mine. We haven't had such a panic in centuries. At this speed, they'll undermine all our villages soon, and potentially kill us in the process! We need someone to cull their numbers, before it comes to that."
You can count on us.

A large gap opens into a vast tunnel system. From deep within, you already hear the omnipresent drips of moisture, but you hear growling and cackling too.\n\nThe dwarves believe their mole problem originates here.

Two dwarves are arguing in front of a shop, one of them throwing a lump of silvery ore into a basket.

"Tainted! Tainted like the rest! Not worth smithing glyphs from!"

"I'm sorry," the other mumbles. "But... the Windholme alchemist, he says he's working on a method to cleanse the corruption. Maybe if you go to him..."
That is interesting information.
An alchemist appears from a back room, accompanied by a timid apprentice.\n\n"Oh, good people," the alchemist beams. "Welcome! What can I do for you?"
We hear you can cleanse Adamantinum?
We'll retrieve some Black Ash.

Indeed! Garroshim is the name.

I'm working on a new method to purge tainted Adamantinum of its impurities. If you're interested, I'd ask you to bring me a much needed ingredient. I'd be in your debt - I'd cleanse your Adamantinum without extra charge.

I need Black Ash, very rare. Its purest form is often found with demons.
It happens I have some Black Ash.

The assistant comes rushing out when he sees you near the workshop.\n\nHe crashes past a few crates but keeps his balance and blurts out: "Do you have Black Ash and Adamantinum? If so, we can take it to the laboratory and... do the alchemy thing."
I do.
It seems I came here in vain.
The assistant nods and scratches his head.\n\n"How much?" he asks. "I will need Black Ash and Adamantinum in a one to one ratio to do it."
One unit of Adamantinum.

When you show him the Black Ash, Garroshim grins broadly.\n\n"Very good!" he says. "We can make our purifying reagent now! I'll happily do it for free, as long as you keep supplying Black Ash. I'd ask that you take some of the tincture to a mine that has been struggling though. The taint is only now setting in, but it would rekindle hope for all artificers in Windholme if we can stop it quickly."
We can visit the mine.
Two units of Adamantinum.
Three units of Adamantinum.
Five units of Adamantinum.

When you enter the workshop, Garroshim greets you with a grin. When he sees your grim look though, he swallows nervously and stops his work. You explain what happened in the mine and he shakes his head.

"Now, now. I've heard they've been unlucky, but I assure you..."

The back door crashes open and his assistant stumbles in, swearing loudly. "Boss, I don't know where to stack all the tainted Adamantinum," he says. "The last batch of pure ore is taking up all the..."

He sees you and your soldiers and stops for a moment. "Niethalf's rotten molars."
What exactly is going on here?
Tell me what you did or I will destroy you.
You are a traitor to all dwarves!
Speak or I will rip the knowledge from you.

Well... Garroshim grins sheepishly, wiping away sweat. "If you'd been left a mine that's not on any map, you'd probably want to drive prices up too! When all it takes is a little Black Ash?"\n\nHe quickly pulls a lever behind his desk, disappearing down a hatch that closes with the clicks of well-forged locks.
Follow him!

Garroshim flinches, then frowns.

"It's just business!" he says. "If you inherited a mine no one else knew about, you'd do the same! It's genius entrepreneurial spirit! Now, one last gift for you..."

He pulls a lever behind his desk and disappears through a trap door, spikes punching through the floorboards below your soldiers.
Get that ingenious bastard!

Garroshim laughs.

"Traitor?! Maybe Niethalf himself inspired my uncle to give me his hidden mine, and inspired me to create the corrupting reagent! He certainly doesn't seem to have helped you find the truth, has he? No one will stop me now!"

He pulls a lever behind his desk, and disappears through a trapdoor.
Follow that traitor!

Philo is now shrouded in a dark aura and his voice has dropped several octaves. He has become unrecognizable, oozing danger and superiority.

Garroshim's eyes go wide and he gulps as words are pushed from his mouth. "Inherited... mine. Fouled the... ore from... others. Pretended to purify. Exchanged... instead! Good... money..."

He shakes his head, breaking free from the fear, and quickly pulls a lever behind his desk, disappearing down a trap door.
Stubborn dwarf. Follow him!
Be on your way.
The tunnel collapses behind Garroshim but his assistant is left behind. He awkwardly offers you some folded parchment.\n\n"That's where you'll find him. That's the mine. Can I go?"

The mine is in disrepair. Most of the workers don’t move from the barracks when you come through, coughing and staring at you darkly.

"You want us to do what with this?" the foreman asks, studying the phial of elixir the alchemist gave you.

"I tell you, we won't be working that mine, no matter what weird mixtures you want us to take down to the ore. We are tired and many of us are sick. I can't find a full team to work a shift even if I tried! Unless... you'd be able to help us?"
We have gold. You can buy medicine with it.

The map leads you to a hidden valley where rubble disguises a mine entrance. Inside, dwarves are readying themselves for a fight. Most of them are miners, not soldiers, but are strapping on armor all the same.
We will tear through them.
I will spare you. Where is your leader?

With the resistance broken and the alchemist lying dead, your troops celebrate.\n\nThis mine will support the Adimantinum trade. Hopefully, other mines will soon be cleansed too, once the tinctures spread on the ore lose their potency.
Well done, everyone!

A dwarven smith and merchant sadly excuses himself when your fighters are resting outside his workshop and looking over his wares.\n\n"I cannot offer you anything of worth," he explains. "The last mine that produced halfway decent Adamantinum has stopped delivering. It seems the curse has struck them now, too."
Is that the mine we tried to help?

Garroshim looks up as he passes something to his assistant.

"Oh, I'm sorry," he says. "Without the Black Ash I'm afraid there's nothing I can do."

His assistant crashes to the floor with a pained howl, dropping what Gorrashim gave him. "And I'm very busy!" Gorrashim adds. He shoos you from his workshop and rushes to his assistant's aid.
Nothing we can do, it seems.
The mine is busy again. The ore is still of poor quality, but the workers seem hopeful.
We'll let them work.

When your troops come near, the workers start yelling expletives and hurling chunks of dull, gray ore at you.\n\n"Niethalf's balls!" one screams. "You poisoned the mine! It's all gone dark and brittle!"
Calm down!
We have spare food to help your workers back to their feet.
I have some healers. They’ll tend to your workers.
Then we will come back later. Maybe.
We have enough potions to heal some workers.
Why would I poison the Adamantinum?!

You calm down! The veins at the foreman’s temples bulge. "You acted like you cared then made everything worse! Don’t tell me to calm down!"\n\nHe hefts his pick axe and throws it at one of your fighters. Suddenly, everyone is embroiled in the brawl.
This is bad.

When your troops inspect the mine and the ore, it is obvious the Adamantinum has degraded far more quickly recently. One of the remaining workers swears it began when you brought the elixir from the alchemist.
You tell us! the foreman shouts. "All we know is it all got worse when you brought that potion. It’s no coincidence!"
One of them steps forward, nervously tugging at his beard.\n\n"Why should we lay down our weapons?"
Because I said so.
He poisoned sacred Adamantinum and tricked all of Windholme! Neithalf weeps!
He deprives artificers of Adamantinum! Our sacred art is dying!
Several of the dwarves exchange guilty glances. Slowly they drop their pick-axes and make a hasty exit past you, thanking you for letting them go.
Some of the dwarves hesitate and slowly let their weapons fall.\n\n"We… we would fight by an artificer’s side!" one of them says. "May Niethalf see this and forgive us. If you will take us."
Let's start exploring.

You emerge into a semicircular cave. White bones lie in clusters between mining carts and other equipment. You can see the large claw marks of moles, where dwarves have used them to drag carts and ores from one place to another. A deep growl and tearing sound comes from one of the smaller tunnels leading away.
There are some salvageable ores here that we can take.
Whatever this is, we must kill it swiftly.
Let’s return with more muscle later.
The mine has long been abandoned, but your dwarven soldiers find the valuable deposits that were left behind under the rubble.
Now let's slay this beast!

Your path ends abruptly, falling down into a cavern with ridged walls and protruding sharp stones. A giant bear is feasting on a mole at the bottom of the pit, ripping chunks off and speckling the ground with blood and meat.
Charge that beast!
I have some concoctions that can penetrate its pelt.
Hide our scent with fur, then prepare an ambush!
The bear did not sense the danger fast enough, sustaining some serious wounds.
Roll a minecart down there. That will wound it.
Now bring it down!
The bear is defeated, and quickly disposed of.
Hopefully the moles will return now.

Grand mage, a moment of your time?

You almost miss where the voice comes from, for the dwarf it belongs too is sat between two large boulders. You recognize them as grave markers.

"Our situation is quite dire. Undead have come up from Norimar, besieging our watch towers and attacking our villages. Can you help defeat these dark forces?"
Your people won't stay unprotected.
We have a lot to do. Ask your local authority.
All along the watchtower

You've grown accustomed to dwarven shouts when in audible range of watch towers, so the foreboding silence leaves you feeling uneasy. No warm firelight flickers from the tower's top. Instead, you see the dark shapes of the fallen at its base.
Start inside the tower. Search for survivors, and anything useful.
Walk the perimeter and look for tracks.
Give them a proper dwarven burial.

Your dwarven troops collect the bodies and take them to an alcove nearby, laying them to rest in proper fashion, and giving a prayer to Niethalf on their behalf. As no one knows their names, you have 'Guardians of the Coldmark' enscribed on the boulder that is used to seal the grave. As it is rolled into place, you hear a whispered 'Thank you,' on the wind.
Now, investigate the tower.
Now, look for tracks.

You begin the long climb up the tower when a familiar sound stops you. Suddenly, a shower of bolts rains down and your troops are forced back to the ground, closely followed by a whole band of the undead.

With the undead dealt with, you have the tower searched and come into posession of some minor trinkets and helpful items. Beyond the structure, you pick up the trail, certainly heading for the next watchtower. Some undead must have pressed on.
No snow has yet fallen, so the tracks left by the undead are clear. They lead towards another watchtower.
In Health and Sickness
We can catch them if we leave now.
Let's investigate the tower first.
We can sill catch them in time if we hurry.
Select Target
Any Ore
Any Plant

An eerie quiet falls on the tower. It looks almost serene against the stark, white snow.

You are preparing to leave when a unit of mole riders meets you at the tower.

"We saw the fight from afar, but it seems you were closer. By the looks of it, right on time! Thank you. Please take this as reimbursement."
Skeletons and specters are besieging the second tower. The air is full of wails and screeches, drowning out the dwarven cries for help from within.
Away with you! Walk away at once!
Send our own undead in first and ambush them!
We gladly did so. Fare well now.

Only a few villagers are out and about. The rest are bed ridden with a strange illness. Healers in leather masks walk the steets, burning incense to purify the air. You are soon surrounded by the desperate folk, begging for your help.\n\n"The Guardians are angry with us. Two weeks ago, they poisoned our water, rendering most of us weak with fever and bile. We have tried all we can to cleanse the spring, but we are still getting sick. We beg you, please, find the source!"
Show us the spring.

You are brought to a small stream. The water flows by the main street, and ends in a cavernous opening at the foot of a hill. A set of deep grooves has been worked into the earth by the passing of many feet, none of which look humanoid.\n\nYou enter the cave as carefully as possible. It utterly stinks of rot, and on the cave's floor, you see a large beast with a black shell, sitting in the water.
Its body is poisoning the water. Kill it!
Kill it elsewhere, to protect the water from more damage.
We must properly prepare before we engage.
Drag and drop an item on here or\nhover over an item and use the \nsell hotkey to sell an item.
Toggle additional information On/Off.
Rooms
Hiring
Cancel
Sell

Slowly but surely, your command begins to take hold. As the undead feel the urge to heed your words, they shuffle away from the tower in confusion, leaving their fallen lying destroyed at the tower's feet.
Leave us be, spirits!
The undead falter and stop, looking forward with empty eyes. For a heartbeat, no one moves. Then, the undead turn to the side, leaving the tower and your company behind.
Continue on.
There is much confusion as more undead soldiers join the fight, but it only takes a moment for the besiegers to recognize you as a threat. Soon enough, they turn on you.
Now we will end them!
Harvest them. We can use those remains.
I need to make some preparations. We will return.

With some coaxing, you bring the beast outside, towards the border to the Snake Pass. The creature soon vanishes down the mountain, into its natural habitat.\n\nYour success is met in the village with tears of joy and celebrations, many applauding you even as you pass through to report the good news.
All the best! I hope you recover quickly.
You return to the village successful, and are met with many shouts of celebration.\n\n"Niethalf favors you! Thank you, grand mage! You have saved many lives!"
Fare well! May you recover swiftly.

Noises of battle draw you closer, and you see a village in turmoil. Plague beetles have overrun homes, feeding on moles and cattle. Dwarves run around frantically, finding weapons sharp enough to pierce the beasts' hard plates, or waving torches in the hopes of distracting them.
Help them! Attack!
We can't help them. Gather more forces.

The villagers are very grateful for your swift help, handing you some of their finest bottles as thanks.\n\n"We appreciate your help, great mage, but may we yet ask for more? Sadly, the beetles killed many of our beasts of burden. We have a mole breeder in Silver Drift Hollow, but can't afford to send away our remaining fighters now. We'll compensate you for your work, of course."
We've done more than enough. Good day.
A few moles would compliment my forces too. I accept.
A small hut is pressed tightly against the mountain wall. Not far away there is a large cave, which a dwarf now walks out of. He mumbles something angrily, kicking a nearby bucket.
Are you the breeder? Your Coldmark clients sent us.

You explain the situation, and the breeder beams.\n\n"That is wonderful news! I mean... not for them, but with all the moles running rampant here, I am close to shutting down my shop! Anyone can just pick a mole off the mountains now, but mine are well trained! People forget that. I'll make the delivery right away! And, if you'd like moles for your army here... I suppose I can gift you one. As thanks. I'll just have to charge the village more! Haha!"
We'll gladly take some. Thank you.
We have no need for beasts. Good luck!
Tower
{Value:+-c} from free unit upkeep
You come across a muddy road close to the fields. The grass here is trampled, and someone has carelessly tried to cover tracks that lead towards a cluster of trees.
This looks promising.

A flickering light inside the mountain beckons you closer. If the light would not have guided you, you would never have found the slim entrance into the vast tunnel system below. This must be a side entrance to the grand mine. A quiet tangle of voices can be heard, discussing urgently about something.
Who goes there? This mine is supposed to be closed off!

Quiet falls, then you hear an owl hoot, and a sharp clang of metal against metal.

"Idiot! There are no owls here! Quick, before they come any closer!"

A scuffle unfolds. Pressing on, you find a group of dwarves in the process of breaking open a door in the stone face. It must be a storage cave, where Adamantinum and mining equipment is kept.
Cease now, and you may yet live.
Granite Dwarves! Attack!
The dwarves look at the avatar at your side before blanching.\n\n"Is that... Are you..." They fall to their knees, quivering and praying. "Oh mighty Niethalf, you have returned to us! Praise be you!"

Before the dwarves' leader can speak, you have cast a spell that seals the door shut, pushing those trying to get through it away violently. The leader turns to you, chewing his lip with vitriol.\n\n"Fine," he grunts. "I don't have the patience to deal with you, so I suppose we have to make a deal with you instead."
Wise choice.
True to their word, the dwarves unhappily split the metals you find in the stash between your group and theirs, then leave without another word.
They're lucky I chose tact.
The door stays closed until we come to an arrangement.
It's good that it stayed secure. Let's go.
Let's see what's inside.
After the battle, your attention turns to the locked door.

Your soldiers break the doors down. As expected, you find a small cornucopia of metals and supplies inside. You take what you can and head for the exit, but behind you hear voices shouting, "Hey! Thieves!"\nThis must be the returned miners, and they will not be happy about this.
Just as you are leaving, a group of miners approaches. You explain the situation to them and they are grateful for your handling, sending you away with far heavier pockets.
With a final glimpse, you see the Granite Dwarves breaking open the door and quickly carrying crate after crate out and away.
They will get what they deserve soon enough...
With two fights already behind you, it is unwise to stay much longer.
This looks like they killed each other. Let's go.
Onwards, we have a lot to do.
Purity Archers
Purity Goliath
Purity Soldier
New Purity
Hollowed Guard
Magehunter
Blessed by Aonir

A group of miners approaches, a dwarf with a fiery beard introducing himself.\n\n"Radgan. I manage one of the mines. We hoped you could aid us, grand mage. Something has taken shelter in our mine. It needs to be killed. We need your help, as we can't harvest any more Adamantinum with this beast in the way."
We will look into it.

You meet Radgan, the miner that approached you for help right outside the entrance.\n\n"Thank you for rushing to our aid, grand mage. We have heard strange noises from within, but I could not tell you what beast has taken shelter in there." He shakes himself. "I get shivers thinking about it."
Can you describe what you heard?
You find yourself in a cave where the walls curve up to form a dome. Crystals glitter on the ceiling, drawing the eyes and catching every light, reflecting it back in beautiful rainbows.
After a few corners, you hear voices. Following them, they slowly become more distinct, until you hear Radgan talking to his miners. You must have led your troops in a circle.
Let's try this again.
Try to climb up and collect some riches.
Continue on. No distractions.
I've had enough. Let's leave.
They are just stalagtites. Pretty, but worthless.
A muffled noise stops you in your tracks. A mole's sniffing snout turns the corner, coming closer with steady huffs.
Make no sound and we should be alright.
Retreat at once!

Yngrid presses herself against the wall, waving everyone to follow her example. The moles pass by, not but a hand's width away. No one dares even breathe until they have moved on, when relief washes over you all.
Walk on.
Silence falls when the moles are dealt with. You strain to hear anything in the darkness, forced to pick another tunnel to follow.
Over here.
There is much cursing, as the walls are slick and climbers just slide back down. In the end, reaching the crystals proves impossible.
Let's continue then.

With a loud roar, the ground gives way beneath you. You slip and slide down into a pit of rubble, moss and bones. When your daze passes, you see a slim crack leading out of the mine. But between you and your freedom, a pack of griffons awaits.\n\nThey must have fallen into the cave just like you, or entered through the crack when they were young and small, never to be able to escape again. Truly a pitiful fate.
Kill the beasts!
Sacrifice the weakest so the rest can flee!
Abruptly, the ground before you falls away into a black pit. You can see the other side, but you cannot find a way of crossing without risk.
We will have to find another way.
We can fly across, as long as we're quick.
Let's try to jump.
Despite your best efforts, you almost lose some soldiers to the sharp stones beneath you. Nursing injuries, you are forced to retreat from the mine.
Against all odds, you all manage to cross the ravine.
The Guardians are smiling on us. Forward!
You find a dead end. There is no other way than to turn back.
This is worse than a maze.
We will try again when we've healed.
When you finally return to the entrance, the miners welcome you with ale and mead.\n\n"You have done us a fine favor. A toast is in order! And a reward, of course."
At least this is over now.
Dwarven script decorates the wall, and arrows point down different tunnels. Just from looking at them, there is no way to discern what leads where without knowing them.
We're looking for the main shaft. This way.
We can only guess then.
Without warning, the tunnel opens up, and you find yourself back where you started.
Let's try again then!
I have had enough of this! We'll return another time.
Without warning, a large claw comes around the corner, followed closely by a pack of moles.
Kill the beasts!
They are blind! Don't move, and they will pass.
They are fleeing, not attacking. We have nothing to fear.

You see a rather young dwarf pacing in front of a cave. His clothes suggest he might be a black smith's apprentice. He is shocked when he sees you, but his expression quickly changes to one of wide eyed revelation.\n\n"You are the grand mage commander, yes?! I am lucky to meet you here! I found this old mine, you see? I was trying to get some gold, but lost my father's fur in the process. He doesn't know I... borrowed it. Could you retrieve it for me? I'll craft you any glyph of your choosing in return."
A bold request. We'll retrieve it.

At last, after maneuvering through the darkness for some time, you come to a cave that glitters with gold deposits. The fur is draped over a mine cart, completely intact. You can see why it would be sorely missed. It is well worn, of rich quality and decorated with many trinkets.

When you hand it back to the young dwarf, he almost leaps with joy.

"Oh, you did it! Thank you! I shall honor my promise! Tell me, which glyph shall it be?!"
Do you have the fur?
Not yet. We'll go back into the cave.
Silenced
Purge Heretics
Perhaps we can heal the sickness.
You have your healers make rounds, visiting the sick and easing their ailments. They are grateful, but the sickness clearly needs to be dealt with at the source.
We can do little else for now. Take care.
Where is the spring?
Gone with the Wind

During your stay in one of the Coldmark's villages, you find yourself surrounded by a group of concerned dwarves.\n\n"Grand Mage! Please, a word! Granite Dwarves have taken our Griffons in the dead of night. We need them for our trade, and our daily lives! Can you help us get them back? We know where they are hiding!"
Show us where to go.

They lead you to the mountain top, where a small hut and meager pasture have been built between the flat, stone walls. Deep grooves cut through the sleet and ice, and many a feather lies discarded on the ground.
Those grooves look like wheels. Let’s follow them.

Grand mage, you have done so much already, but something has awoken in the mountains! Our scouts tell us of a monster of giant proportions, spewing ice and a biting cold that could freeze the very soul. We ask, one last time. Will you help us? The reward will be in proportion to the threat - quite to your liking.
Audale
Connach
Bastion
Orgash
Let me see where the griffons were stolen from.
A heavy wagon scored the ground. You didn't hear this?
We can track the griffons using the feathers.
The wheel tracks lead away from the village, towards a small camp. Granite Dwarves are loading griffons with tools and gear, readying themselves to take flight.

As the dwarves begin to discuss among themselves how obvious the event must have been, the griffon rearer caves.\n\n"It was me, alright?! I sold them a few animals in exchange for a secret mine, but it didn't have any of the promised Adamantinum! Just corrupted ore, and a few speckles of gold. But, while I was gone, they took all the griffons! If... if you help me get them back, I'll give you some of our stock! Sound fair?"
Can you tell us anything else? How many were there?

Your beasts tug in a different direction than the wagon wheel tracks suggest. The griffon rearer questions them on this quite impatiently.\n\n"It's quite obvious they came this way. You should follow the tracks! Before the Granite Dwarves disappear with our griffons!"
You're right. They must have caught a different scent.
You seem oddly irritated about this. What's the matter?
Halt! You will not get away with this!

The griffon rearer is put in shackles, awaiting punishment for his betrayal. Once the other villagers have wrangled the griffons back, they stand true to his word, giving some of the beasts into your care.\n\n"Your help won't be forgotten, wise mage!"
The Granite Dwarves manage to wrangle the griffons and flee, flying away on the wind.
You've got some nerve. They better be your best beasts.
You sold the griffon rearer an empty mine!

The Granite Dwarves halt in their tracks, but after recovering from the shock of your appearance, stride towards you with confidence and humor.\n\n"Oh! We promised a Adamantinum mine, but never a pure or good one. This was a fair deal!"
You leave us with no choice. Attack!
Dealings with Granite Dwarves? Disgusting. We're leaving.
May the Guardians curse those damned Granite Dwarves.
We thank you for the Griffons. Good day.
The Inner Most Secret

During your visit, you are invited to a dinner with Silver Drift Hollow’s mining collective.

"We wanted to thank you properly for all you have done. You opened many a door and cleared out threats of all kinds and sizes. Now we want to propose a deal.

Clear out the mines we’ve marked on this map and in return you will gain access to our largest Adamantinum reserve. It is yet untouched and should be in pristine condition. You can take your share for all your hard work."
We will go to the mine right away.
Scare the griffons into throwing their riders!
Your beasts charge forwards and the griffons panic, taking to the air and throwing off the Granite Dwarves. They come down in a cursing, jumbled mess.
This is our chance! Attack!
You sold the griffon rearer an empty mine!
We will deal with this monster.

When the golem lies still, a griffon rider from Coldmark City approaches you with the promised reward.\n\n"The Coldmark thanks you deeply. These are just a few tokens of our gratitude, but know that you are always welcome in our city, as long as your actions stay true. May Niethalf bless you and your followers with his gifts, and guide your battles."
Thank you. We will remember these words and gifts.
Invest additional [mMana] and convert it into [mXp] for target unit.
Create the illusion of gold to pay your troops with, lowering total unit gold upkeep.
Turn your own mortal unit permanently into a [mUnit][unit]Walking Corpse[/] - a strong, resilient minion that doesn't require upkeep.
Invest [mGold] into increasing your standing with target city.
Teleport a stack from anywhere inside your [mDomain] to anywhere else inside your [mDomain].
Draw [unexplored]souls[/] from target city's population. The higher your reputation, the better quality the souls are.
Levy
Levy a weak [mUnit] [unit]regional unit[/] on target [unexplored]Urban Hex[/]. Lose some reputation with the regional authority.
Turn target non-hero unit permanently into a Wendigo.
Steal [mGold] form target city and lose reputation in the process. The higher the reputation, the more gold you'll receive.
City
Reveal the nearest unknown location of your choosing. If there are none, the spell fails.
Levy some troops from target city but lose some reputation in the process. The higher your reputation, the more and stronger units you'll control.
All your units will instantly gain a level.
Cast on a city or other location with a shop, to immediately refill all their stock.
Spend additional [mMana] to increase reputation with target city.
Cast on a location being mined to reset the exploitation counter, making it last longer.
Reveal all nature and plant locations in a large area around a nature hex.
Reveal all locations in a large area around an urban hex or city.
Revive any of your fallen heroes in your tower.
Recover all the glyphs invested into target unit. The glyphs will return to your inventory and the unit's slot will become empty.
Reveal the nearest metal deposit of your choice. If there are none, the spell fails.
True Teleport
Teleport target stack to any seen location, without restrictions.
Plague
Apply Plague to all units in target stack that lasts until the end of their next battle.
Confuse
Confuse all units in target stack, that aren't immune to mind effects, until the end of their next batttle.
Lift Spirits
Lift the spirits of all units in target own stack. The effect lasts until the end of their next battle.
Fatigue
Fatigue all mortal units in target stack until the end of their next battle.
This is a busy mine. Cart tracks lead up and down, left and right, away into dark tunnels. Someone has carved a crude map on one of the walls, and dwarvern script show which tunnel leads where.
We'll return when we have time.
We have to do something else first.
How did you lose it?

Well, uhm... People say a monster lurks inside these tunnels. I heard a scratching. It might have been nothing but... I ran. Like a coward. Please! My father will have my head if I don't return with his fur!
Wait here. We'll retrieve it.
We need to prepare. I'll return later.
Left to a gold deposit. The fur is probably there.
It says there is something interesting to the right.
Let's try left first.
The right tunnel looks promising.
Let's return later with a larger force.
The ever twisting, turning tunnels lead you in a circle. You find yourselves right back where you started.
Let's try again.
Enough of this. We'll return another time.
Turning a corner, you find yourselves face to face with a bear and its cubs. Judging by their size, they must have spent all their lives inside the mine, probably feasting on moles and stray miners.
Kill the beasts before they kill us.
If we back away, they'll leave us be.
A few pieces of meat may occupy their attention.
As torch light falls on a crack in the wall, you see something set deep inside it glittering. It beckons you to come closer.
It might be valuable. Try to squeeze through.
We came for the fur. Continue on.
Enough of these winding tunnels! We need to leave!
You retrieve a few crystals, though many are set too deep inside the wall.
This will have to suffice. Onwards.
Nimble hands pull a few bottles from the crack. Someone must have hidden their stash here.
An interesting find. Onwards.

The refreshing sound of water hitting stone leads you to a small cave containing a waterfall. It pools into a shallow pond, before draining through small gaps in the rock. One trickle follows a deep groove in the floor, leading further into the mine.
Retreat! Out of the mine!
Blind them with fire!
The roaring fire blinds, scares and wounds the animals.
Now we have them!
This is a dead end. Go back.
Follow the water.
No matter how much your units try, the crack is simply too narrow and the prize too far inside.
A shame. Let's return to the tunnels.
Cancel
This Spell is already active.
Your tower is already flying.
There are no such locations detectable.
Slaver
Enchant a unit and give it the ability to enslave others.
Great Exploitation
Crafting Overdrive
Magic Wasteland
Cell Division
Once finished, duplicates this unit.
Cell Division
Cell Division

You come across the first vandalised place of worship you have seen on your journey through the mountains. A stone statue of Tiara, her dress poised perfectly with her dancing feet, has been smeared with foul vegetables. Other parts of the small shrine have collapsed entirely. Four dwarves are cleaning up the mess, praying to her fervently for forgiveness.
How peculiar.
What happened here?

We are unsure ourselves. We have come here for years, and never seen anything like this. Tiara is important to us, so we are greatly pained. I fear it was an act of rebellion, of the Granite Dwarves. Windholme declined to help them fight some troll from Norgate.
We'll keep our eyes open for the culprits.
You catch a group of Granite Dwarves as they start to tear down a shrine to Hirin. They have already painted the Guardian's face red, and broken some of the offering bowls.
You find another vandalized shrine. This time, someone has knocked a statue of Hirin from its pedestal, urinated on it, and replaced it with one of Niethalf.
Ashes
Black Ash
Fur
Ingredient
I'm sure the locals would like an end to this.
You will not get away with this.
Niethalf should be the one worshipped here.
The Guardians are all equal. You might anger them thus.
The Granite Dwarves scoff at that.\n\n"Oh yeah? How devoted are you to Niethalf? If you cared, you'd destroy the other shrines on his behalf. He is the only true Guardian worthy of worship!"
A few of the dwarves' expressions change to discomfort. Some even glance at the high mountain peaks and the sky above. They might not be entirely convinced, but you rattled their resolution.
Having dealt with your soldiers, the Granite Dwarves retreat back into the mountains, leaving nothing but destruction in their wake.
Hopefully, we can save the next shrine.
You might have defeated us, but our brothers will not rest until Niethalf watches over us all.\n\nWith a rasping breath, the last of the Granite Dwarves collapses, the life leaving his eyes.
Not if we stop them.
We'll begin when this one is toppled.
The other Guardians will surely strike us with their wrath.

The dwarves are taken aback by your troops' enthusiasm for tearing the shrine down. But they soon join in, smeaking paint and carving stone to their hearts' content.\n\n"If you really continue our work at other shrines, we'd consider rewarding your efforts."
We will prove our devotion.
Ectoplasm
Eggs
Remains
Chunk of Meat
Empty Vial
Heavy Pelt
Obsidian Husk
Stardust
Heat Stone
Mysterious Schematics
Cursed Candle
Infused Bark
Locket
Talisman
Ritual Dagger
The Iron Mask
Lightbringer's Prayerbook
Pristine Claw
Monster Heart
Whispering Gemstone
Twisted Horn
Ether Distillate
Crystalline Splinter
Eternal Flame
Belongings of the Deceased
Living Skull
Tiara's Revelations
Giant's Tooth
Phantom Warriors
It has happened before. Have you heard of the Bloodburn?
Pathetic! Strike them all down!

This leaves them speechless. Some return to the shrine, frantically trying to return it to its former state. Others simply drop their tools.

"This is not over! We won't be stopped! We'll continue spreading the right beliefs!"

With that, they are gone. A passing group of pilgrims, having seen the whole exchange, nods their thanks to you.
Onto stopping the others.
The next shrine you find is already under attack. Some villagers from nearby are trying to dissuade the Granite Dwarves to stop, so far without success.
Your lives are forfeit now!
Stop this madness! Niethalf is furious at this desecration!
Let us help!
You order the tearing down, burning and breaking of the entire shrine. The villagers don't dare speak against you, but you can feel their hateful glances.
The Granite Dwarves turn to you with visible confusion.\n\n"What's that supposed to mean?"
It means he sent us to punish you.
The Bloodburn has befallen your brothers! You must repent!
You see the panic set in. In a few moments, statues start being put back in place. When the're gone, the villagers commend you for your wits and quick thinking.
Only one shrine left.
The villagers thank you plentifully for your help.\n\n"May the Guardians forgive their deluded actions and reward yours in return."
One shrine left to save.
Onwards. We have one more to destroy!
The shrine still stands - no vandals have reached it yet. Aonir's indescriptive face looks down onto a stone plate, with all seven Guardians depicted in various poses and action.
Should he come, we will be ready.
Destroy this place.
Jelly Creeper
Jelly Critter
Bandages

Not long later, some villagers come by with offerings.\n\n"Master mage, we don't know what you told the Granite Dwarves, but there have been no attacks since you intervened. These are for you. May the Guardians watch over you all."

You have only just begun when a group of Granite Dwarves steps out of hiding.\n\n"We have kept an eye on you. You held up your promise. It is good to know that Niethalf still holds respect in some hearts. Take this, as a blessing."
May Niethalf bless you too.
Within the hour, the Granite Dwarves come to destroy once more. They seem determined to leave nothing standing.
I am glad it has worked. Thank you!
Defend our position!
Word of your actions travels fast. With the saved shrines, your reputation in Windholme drastically rises.
Maybe we should return to the city.
Reincarnation
Chant of Unlife
Wild Magic
Behind closed doors
I must make this worth the cost.
Try to stop me! I do not fear your wrath!
Examine the signs.
But this is what they are most afraid of.
Back
Custom Mage
Alchemist
Necromancer
Artificer
Wandering the outskirts of Windholme, a low whistle draws your attention to a hooded figure. They wave you closer, and then vanish into a small hut.
We should take a look.
I have no interest dealing with shady activity.
Confused

Undying Curse

You enter, and a stout dwarf stands in a corner. He throws back his hood and reveals dark leather armor. A Granite Dwarf.\n\n"I bet you've heard about the Adamantinum shortage. If you need some, I can supply it, but I need Heatstones and Heavy Pelts in exchange."
Guards! A Granite Dwarf!
Is that it? We'll return as soon as we can.
We have both right here. Show us the Adamantinum.

The dwarf steps into the shadows and is suddenly gone from sight. When the guards enter, the extra light reveals a hatch through which he must have fled. No matter how thorough the guards search, the dwarf does not appear. The guards remain thankful though.

He places the gleaming metal on a crate, taking your offering.

"Pleasure doing business with you."

Only on your way out of the hut do you recognize the betrayal. You have been given corrupted Adamantinum.
One less rat on the streets.
So? How about it? Some Heavy Pelts and Heatstones in exchange for Adamantinum?
Sure, we got both.
We've decided to rat you out instead. Guards!
Curses.
Guards have been posted in front of this inconspicuous cave. They eye passing travelers with distrust but wave you through as soon as you tell them why you have come.
You finally catch up with the Granite Dwarves and their stolen war balloon. Now you only need to reclaim it.
Bring them down!
Flee, before they spot us!
Give us the balloon! You no longer need it!

When you bring the good news to Windholme, you are celebrated as a hero. The dwarves drink to your health and reward you promptly for the return of the stolen war balloon. \n\nThroughout the night, your name is shared in fantastical stories of how you had to take down a dragon-sized demon to reclaim it.
That does make for a far better story.

For a heartbeat, nothing happens. You repeat the command, this time with more force.\n\nA few minutes later, the balloon lands and the dwarves depart with glossy eyes, walking off into the icy landscape.
Inform Windholme right away.
We shall keep the balloon as our reward.

Ever more monster sightings have been reported in this part of Windholme. The dwarves are full of concern.\n\n"It all started when they tried to open another mine. The monsters must have been inside. The city guards are already spread too thin to fight them all. Your help would be greatly appreciated."
The dangers of mining
We'll see what we can do.

When the noise of the fighting settles again, dwarves step out of the mine. They must have hid in there from the golem.\n\n"Y-you saved us! Thank you, master mage!" They assure you that word of your deeds will find Windholme quickly.
Let's journey on.

With a scent of warm summer rain, an apparition appears before you of a robed female with flowing red hair and mesmerizing eyes. With a mock bow she greets you: "So you are the new mage everyone is all flustered about? I am Ianna the Singer. A pleasure to finally meet you"\n
What an unexpectedly warm welcome.
Craft {Amount} Potions!
Craft {Amount} Undead!
