Thunderstorm
Unit has an additional free attack.
Heals affecting this unit are multiplied by {Health.BattleHealRateMultiplier:c}.
Replaces [bonus]{replace}[/] with [bonus]{with}[/].

Late at night, a frantic rattling at the door wakes you up. From your window, you see a hooded figure nervously eyeing the path leading up to your tower.\n\nSpotting you, they frantically wave and shout: "Quick, open up, in the name of our master! They are after me!"

I am Jonath. I studied the art of necromancy with our late master, the man says proudly. "Here is proof of my work with him!"\n\nHe hands you a number of densely scribbled pages. Their topics center on facilitating the creation of undead, marked in numerous places by your master’s hand.

I am Folrian Ironbend. I studied to become an Earthmaster with our late master, he says proudly. "Here is proof of my work with him!"\n\nHe hands you a number of densely scribbled pages. They revolve around working with various ores and metals and are marked several times by your master’s hand.

I am Nalkis of Connach. I studied the alchemical crafts with our late master, the man says proudly. "Here is proof of my work with him!"\n\nHe hands you a number of densely filled pages that seem to center on extracting various essences to concoct poisons. Your master’s hand is scribbled all over them.
Stolen Pages

Following your master’s description of his spell, you need to find a crystal large enough and imbue it with powerful magic. Only then a less strenuous, even permanent, levitation of your tower can be achieved.\n\nIf you can aquire one, a black meteor shard from the Magnet Stones might be a usable transmitter. The problem is, an enchantment placed there by the Guardian, Hirin, means no living being has been able to retrieve one as of yet.
The Crystal

With your help, your troops can carry the stone away from the ritual circle. \n\nPossessing it will enable you to create the conduit of power sketched out by your master and do what he could not: conquer the Allfire. You are eager to begin the process.
Build the Crystal Chamber
Build the [bonus]Necromancer's Crypt[/] room in your tower
Heals any visiting unit for 50% of their maximum life.
Ruined Farmhouse
Only a few blackened walls remain of this farm, long overgrown by weeds and brambles.\n\nA heavy air of loss hangs over the place.
There is nothing for the child to return for here.
Make way, spirits!
The apparitions shrink away from your magic, fear in their eyes.
... I wasn't expecting that to be so easy.

In horse whispers they tell you of an elven priestess of Tiara they once served, Berenil by name. She was sent on a diplomatic mission to Baron Meldec, once cruel ruler of this place.\n\nMeldec betrayed and imprisoned Berenil and her acolytes while her servants fled in fear. When Berenil died at the evil baron’s hands, their shame at having abandoned her knew no bounds. They are damned to wander the lands until they have been redeemed.
So how may you find peace?
Back, you devils!
The sound of sobbing floats on the wind as the ghosts’ pained visages fade away.
I hope we saw the last of them.
You again? Leave us be!
I see I will not be rid of you. Let's talk then.
I can draw the unlife out of them before we attack.
The soldiers’ remains lie scattered, but you hear an echo of someone praising your name as their voices are carried away.
May Hirin guide them.

A golden ray of light momentarily breaks through the dense, black mist and a glimmer of hope steals into the desolation of Meldec’s abode.\n\nHe rises slowly, extending a claw-like hand. A host of the undead slowly emerge from the black fog billowing around you.
Forward!
The Black Baron nods mockingly\n\n"The pact is sealed. You shall receive what was promised. Greater gifts can be gained with more sacrifices!"
I will return with more offerings.
Nothing is rotten or decaying. There are a few useful ingredients and food for fresh rations lying on tables. You cannot sense any illusion or magic at work yet this is clearly no ordinary place.
Collect what you can and move out.
Rest here for a while.
Do not tarry. This must be some sort of trap.
The company makes camp and falls into a deep and troubled slumber, plagued by nightmares.
Leave while you can.
The company quickly gathers what it can and takes its leave of the strange village.
Let’s hope there is no more to this...

The black towers of this evil place loom large and dark clouds billow around them. Try as you might, you cannot penetrate the suffocating mists. It is as though the building itself does not want you to approach.\n\nBut you hear faint song in elvish sung by many voices. "Find us in our prison", the voices call out to you.
Investigate the source of the song.
Open the door.
Broodmother
This unit is not affected by any changes to [mWillpower].
You amplify the acolytes’ magic as best you can, strengthening their spells with what little energy you can spare.

With your help, the acolytes’ magic is far more powerful than their leader dreamed of. The hum resonates with the power you throw at the crypt, as if tendrils are creeping forth towards you expetantly.
The Circle's forces have spotted you from afar and are prepared for battle.\n\n"Stay away or we will end you!" their leader shouts from one of the tower’s windows.
We do not fear you! Attack!

You search through every room of the Circle’s tower until you find your master’s research spread out on a table. As promised, he has written about a way to channel a much larger amount of Allfire using your tower as a focus.\n\nScanning the text, you barely understand half of it. But the potential is evident: This method would have brought him far closer to mastering the Allfire and rival the Circle mages. No wonder they wanted him stopped – they feared he would become their equal!
I must study this further! No matter what the Circle thinks.
A great achievement!
I recall someone boasting about having such a stone.
White Immunity
Nature's Vengeance
Nature's Vengeance
Only a little more!
We are almost done! I can feel it!
The Crypt of the Revenants
Only when the fight is done do you see the acolytes are already dead.\n\nA scuttling and groaning announces more undead. Soon the place is filled again. For now, you have no choice but to flee.
Curses! We have to seal the crypt again!
The low hum of magic grows louder and louder as more undead escape the crypt. For now, you are left with no choice but to flee.
Bring a Hero to level 15 and finish their story.
Be revered by {Count} Cities
Triumph over {Amount} Circle mage
I will strengthen the seals to assure it stays closed.
The glyphs, I can replace them.
Turn Animal
Corrupted Elder
Turned
This unit is turned until the controlling unit is killed.
Hellhound
Rise From Ashes
Revive From Ashes
Will revive <nobr>[turns]{UnitModifiers.SelfRevive.AmountOfTurns} [mTurns][/]</nobr> after dying.
All units in targeted stack magically restore some [ihealth:c] health at the start of the next day.
Phase
Teleports to a hex in range
As you leave, you think about the apprentice the villagers kept speaking of. Perhaps you can find them – they may be able to shed some light on your master’s fate.
I will see if I can find out more.
Survey the area for any pursuers.
You scan the darkness but you cannot make anything or anyone following the hooded figure out. They hammer against your door again.\n\n"Come on! Hurry! They cannot be far away now!"
Open the door.
Who are you and who is after you?

They are clearly in panic now, crying out: "I am your master's last apprentice! The Circle are after me and what I know of his secrets. Open up, in the Guardians’ names!"\n\nThey hold up a robe, stitched with your master's sigil. Their fear seems real enough and you recognize the robe. It is similar to the one you wore in your time as his pupil.
Very well. Come in.

After quickly sliding through the doorway and locking the door behind him, a man slumps against the wall and breathes: "I pray they have not spotted my trail, or we may all be lost."

Slowly catching his breath, he pulls down his hood. He is older than you thought, his beard already graying.

"Apologies, where are my manners?" he mumbles. "I know who you are – our master spoke very highly of you. But, no doubt, you wonder who I am."
Indeed.

I must say, it is quite the tale. He takes a seat at the small table near the tower entrance. "Do you want me to tell you everything, or just what has happened to our master’s research after the Circle came for him?"
I have time - tell me everything.
Skip to the end, if you please.

As you no doubt know, our master’s obsession has always been to control the flow of the Allfire. It is something long thought lost with the Shapers but, a few years ago, he made a breakthrough!\n\nHe managed to split the Allfire’s flow with a magical prism, allowing him to harvest part of its might and begin real research into its mastery. It was a slow and dangerous process but he did succeed. I have his treatise on the subject!
Interesting. Tell me more.

Having begun to master the Allfire, he grew more ambitious. He devised a much larger prism that could be mounted onto his tower to channel far more of the Allfire into a special chamber, where it could be siphoned off directly!\n\nIngenious, I must say. Nothing like that has ever been attempted!
But there is no such chamber here...

Because he never had the chance to build it!

An emissary of the Circle came and attempted to warn him off but he did not heed the threat! He was too close to another breakthrough to stop. So, the Circle came back with an ultimatum.

Knowing full well they would intervene, he handed me the pages of his research for safekeeping and sent me away. I was still in sight of the tower when they arrived...
What then?

The man looks crestfallen as he haltingly replies: "I ran, I am ashamed to admit.

My master did tell me to go, for his research was more important than his life, he said. But still, I panicked and ran. Not out of duty but out of fear. I traded with the local villagers to hide me in their cart and carry me away from here."

The man looks at you a little forlornly: "I never saw our master again. But now... now I have failed him twice!"
How so?

When I heard someone was rebuilding the tower… my curiosity got the better of me, I suppose. I hid in a goblin village not far from here. But the Circle was watching for me and ambushed me, demanding I hand over our master’s plans.\n\nHe begins to sob as he says: "I… I feared for my life! I gave them the plans our master died to protect!"
Where was this?

A day’s journey from here. Not far away is a tower the Circle’s forces have long used as a base. I am certain that is where they took the pages with our master’s most valuable research.

I… I managed to gather some of our master’s former servants but our forces are not sufficient to take on the Circle’s minions.

I implore you, please help me protect our master’s legacy. I swear, I will not fail him again. I will even offer you my services if you help me retake his research. Please. Together, we may best the Circle’s forces! Our master’s work must be preserved!
I agree, for our master's sake.
This research is invaluable. I must have it.
Expedition Site

Exploring the sunken remains of your master’s research site you notice that much of the equipment is missing. There are some high quality ingredients well preserved in glass jars, but that's it.\n\nOut of the corner of your eye, there is a movement in the shadows of an overgrown plant. As you turn, something hisses and slithers away.
Medusae? After them!
Crypt of the Revenants

You are making your way across the Tuscari Sea when one of the murky shadows deep under the water moves. Bringing your company to a halt, you prepare to call to them to arms, or flee in the face of some horrible sea creature.\n\nHowever, as a form with the head and torso of a man, with a long and scaly, shimmering tail floats up out of the darkness until he breaks the surface of the water and washes water away from his eyes, you falter.
A... A merperson?!
Another merperson!

Oh, aye? the merman laughs. "It's no' often ah spick to people who've sin mih before!"

You take the time to describe your experience meeting the mermaid of Three Lakes and the merman laughs again.

"Those lo' are so paranoid! We got no problem wit yoos. Bu' then, I spose, there's no' a lo' of yous aboot here. Wha are yoo hir?! Yur no midoosa, that's fur damn sure."

Aye, the merman replies with a healthy dose of caution. "We live deep down a' the bo'em of the wa'er. It's no' oftem ah see people hir. Midoosa! Every deh! Hoomans, no' so much. Wha' are yoo doin' hir?"
We're seeking Hirin's Hourglass.
We're just exploring, really.

Well bih cehful! Thees are dangrous wa'ers. The midooseh think they tehmed all the jellees bu', well... theh hafen'. An thehr are deadlieh things oot thehr. All the best.\n\nWith a curt nod, the merman runs his fingers through his long hair and dives back under the water, quickly disappearing into the depths.
They probably know these waters well. Take care.

You relay the tales your scouts told you of Hirin's Hourglass. At first, it is obvious that the merman is completely oblivious to all of it - you are not entirely certain he even knows who Hirin is. But at the mention of a ship lost at sea around a certain time, his eyes light up.\n\n"Ah, aye, ah know it. Aye, aye! I was a wee lad then! It was off tuh the sooth, but 'twas a long time agoh. It could've drifted since then! Good luck findin' it. Soonds like wih wan' nothin' to doo wit i'."
Thank you! We will take a look.
Let us revisit my deeds.

You have finally been initiated into the Circle of Mages.\n\nNot every member welcomes you with open arms. Some even resent your success. But none can deny your actions have earned you a place among them.
They are too strong. Run!

On arriving in the Tuscari Sea, you take a moment to attune to the world around you. There is a lot of magic in this place, old and strong magic. You sift through it, pondering Hirin's Hourglass.\n\nNot sure of what it is or the purpose it serves, you cannot be certain of its presence, but you do think you feel a tug somewhere in the swirling vortexes of the Allfire. It must be here somewhere.
We must keep searching!

Doubt is beginning to creep back into your mind that everything you have heard about Hirin's Hourglass may just be rumor. Then, by little more than chance, you come across the bow of an ancient ship jutting out of the water.\n\nYou have not seen any other shipwrecks. Maybe, just maybe, this is it.

Your apparition does not feel the chilling bite or building pressure underneath the water. You may simply float down into the darkness, unblinking as the story of a ship half destroyed by wind and waves comes to life before your eyes.\n\nAnd in a chest lying miraculously undamaged in a crevice between the two broken halves of the ship, you find it. Glistening and glittering sands inside a strong, metal hourglass casing. Simple to behold, though it emits a tremendous magical power.
This is it. Hirin's Hourglass!
I will dive down and take a look.

You are beginning to doubt the merman's friendly directions. Perhaps too much time has passed and any hint of the Hourglass's true location has been eroded away.\n\nBut there! A shape that cannot possibly be stone or plantlife. Indeed, it is the bow of a ship, broken and drowned just below the water's surface. The merman said there are not many people here. How likely is it that this is the very same ship the Hourglass was lost from?

Following the creature you happen upon a swarm of jellies. Amid them a medusa stands tall, glaring at you with malice. A faint magical aura emits from her and her arms are raised, ready to unleash a spell.\n\n"What is it you seek, stranger?! These are not your lands."
Then we will make them so.
Your mind games won't work on me. Who are you?

You charged at her. You killed her, you were certain. But now, you blink and… suddenly everything looks untouched. It was all some mental trap sprung when you followed her!\n\n"I will ask you one last time, what..." Her sentence goes unfinished as she sees the flute fastened at your side. "This instrument... I recognize it."
My master conducted research here. Did you know him?
We can keep going! Forwards!
A Portal into the Unknown
Trudging along the muddy shores of the Tuscari Sea, you meet a sole fisherman furiously lasting out at one looks like over-sized frogspawn.\n\n"Blasted creatures! Take this!"
What are you doing?

Goo oozes out to coat the ground and fill the water as you squash as many of the eggs as you can. The fisherman is taking great pleasure in the display of violence, watching you with a grin.

"Thank you. That is the revenge my poor kitty deserves. You hear me?! No jelly eats my kitty without getting killed!"

He sounds at the water. A ripple goes through it and you hear distant plashing.
These are jelly eggs. Hungry, awful beasts. They ate my cat! I want all the revenge I can get on them. There are far too many anyways!
Help the man! Destroy those eggs!
We better not aggravate the beasts. Let's leave.
Phantom Spiders
Bronze Wyvern
Basilisk
Storm Wyvern
Charged Spit
Recharge Necessary
[skill]Recharge[/] is required to use the ranged attack again.
Recharge your water reserves
Recharge
Needs recharging
Thunderblast
Spire of the Circle
Used by Circle mages to expand their [mDomain] and summon creatures.
Lasts for {Turns} day(s)

Your master and I were close. He promised to help me reopen the portal Shâr sealed, so I can return home to the islands.\n\nIn turn, I promised him an army to keep him safe from the clutches of the Circle.

You find yourself before a large stone arch. It is overgrown with moss and algae, filling every tear and crevice in the uneven surface. The glyphs and symbols carved into it mark it as a portal, but where to you cannot discern.\n\nIt takes no great wisdom to see the portal is old and has been inactive for a while. Yet, you still feel a faint magic emanating from it.
Maybe I can unlock it with the right ingredients?

The medusa looks you over and a sudden recognition flashes over her face. Her features soften ever so slightly as her hands drop back down.\n\n"You are them, yes? The mage’s apprentice? I recognize the flute you carry. That means the Circle got to him after all..."
You knew my master?
It belonged to my master. Did you know him?
It is a bridge between Fiara and what you know as the Unknown Islands. Unfortunately its power was cut off and I cannot return home.

Her features turn dark. You can see barely restrained anger bubbling up under the surface of her eyes.

"Shâr is a monster. He used the portal to gather my kind and enslave them. He has even gifted them to the other Circle members, as if we were simply cattle."

She spits out in disgust.

She takes a deep breath, as to steel herself.

"Your master was not just researching this portal, but also the Allfire and how to tame it. We spoke of it at length. He was very curious about my magic as well and… but I get sidetracked.

Shâr and the others never liked people knowing much about the Allfire. An army would have been the least to prepare against them."
What portal?
Who is Shâr?
Why would my master need your army?
I could be the one to fulfill that promise.
Let's not waste any time.

With a fluid motion the medusa bows and the jellies around her mimic the movement.

"Then we may help each other. My sister and I took your master’s things to safety. Unfortunately, she was recently attacked by a wyvern. If we can find this beast, we can surely discover how to open the portal within your master’s reports.

Once this is done, the army I promised your master shall be yours to command."

Indeed, there was a rumor of a necromancer some time ago who called forth a group of shadow-creatures from the Magnet Stones to retrieve one of the floating crystal shards for him.\n\nIt could be worth seeking him out to learn the process.
Find him!
Reflections off the obsidian cast strange, wavering shadows across the floor. As soon as you approach, the shadows begin to move and take form, swarming towards you.
Flee!

When you close in on the necromancer’s last known location, you find only a ritual site and his rigid corpse lying nearby.\n\nIn the middle of the ritual circle, you see a black stone floating silently in the air.
Could it really be that simple?

The necromancer’s corpse dealt with too, you are finally able to approach the stone. Its black, obsidian surface emanates a soft light, which slowly grows and wanes.\n\nBehind you, your troops await your command.
Grab the stone.
I shall have the earth itself bring us the stone.
Cast a ward around your troops.

When they touch the stone, your servant’s eyes glaze over and they suddenly seem to forget their intention.\n\nThe effect ripples outwards, affecting the rest of your company too. All of them blink in confusion, utterly incapable of making a move. At the same time, a black light engulfs them and some begin to lose substance.
Follow my voice away from here!

As a member of your company touches the stone, their eyes glaze over for a moment and they stop their work, as though forgetting what they were supposed to be doing.\n\nYou focus on your wards, pushing back against the stone’s magical effect to renew your troops’ purpose.
Continue!
Nature's Endurance
I have a bad feeling about this...
They are still too strong!
Away before we are caught!
This unit is mind-controlled until the controlling unit is killed.
Assassinate
This unit deals {UnitModifiers.FlankingSpecificModifiers[0].FlankingCombatModifiers.DamageBonus:+-c} Damage on a Flanking attack.
Fight Once More
[bonus]Revives[/] dead allies within {aoe} around this unit.
Language
Choose the game text language
Reset
Apply
On
Off
Settings

Load
Save
Savegames
New Savegame
An inspection concludes that there are multiple methods that could unlock it. Without your master’s reports, finding the right ritual will prove difficult but not impossible.
Infused Bark, Ectoplasm and a Prayers Book should do the trick.

Lodged between some stones, fern tufts and small vegetation you find a slim leather scroll case decorated with beautiful symbols.\n\nThe patterns are the same as the ones in your master’s tower. It must be one of his reports.
We found one!
The Master's Reports
These symbols. The satchel is enchanted.

You reach for the leather strap but the casing jerks away. Puzzled and bemused, you watch as it dances around in order to escape your grasp.\n\nWithout warning, the satchel starts beating your units, then flies from reach at unfathomable speed!
Enough is enough!

Your quick observation lets you dispel the magic your master used to keep it from dangerous hands.\n\nNostalgia strikes at you and you remember how you learned this spell yourself the first time you snooped through his library. It is almost as though he wanted you, and only you, to find this.

Your scouts have finally found the wyvern’s nest. It is located a little higher up on the shore and a beautiful blue wyvern sits atop on guard. The color must be some kind of mutation, possibly caused by the portal’s magic.\n\nScanning the area, the beast sees your troops, who quickly duck away and hide where they can.
This seemingly endless pool will clad you your troops in shadow, helping them in battle.
Numbs the thoughts of those under your spell and whispers mad secrets into the minds of those who oppose you.
Abort
Abort\n\nAbort attack
Deal {damage} damage or summon an [bonus]Earth Barrier[/] on each position in a line [aoe]{rangeValue} <nobr>[aoe][iaoeline:c][/]</nobr> Tiles[/] in front of the user.
Cancel Spell
Crafting Slots
Unit Hiring Slots
Ore Slot
Shaper Secret
Let's see what he was working on...
I need more magical essence to break this curse.

The satchel only contains a quarter of a page, edges torn as if the paper was ripped apart. It is crinkled for good measure.\n\nFlattening it out, you make out: 'Learning about the portal… A dagger rubbed in the ashes of fallen warriors should provide a good base...'
Interesting indeed. Onwards.

The nest is overflowing with all kinds of ingredients, scrolls and pouches. One of them is colored off white and round. The wyvern probably mistook it for one of its eggs, the reason why it attacked in the first place.

You collect what you can and take a moment to scan over the report you find.

'… warm the ritual blade over a small flame until… should be enough to cut through the fabric of time and space.'

Searching the Tuscari Sea proves fruitful. You uncover yet another stash of ingredients and reports.\n\n"… many attempts have yielded nothing. The conclusion must be that a ritual of light is not enough to unlock the portal. The bark from it is still stuck to my fingers, as if I glued them there."
So bark is not one of the ingredients I need.
That’s it! With this information I can reopen the portal.
We’ll have to return when I figure this out.
A Cursed Candle, Ashes and a Ritual Dagger will do.
Bandages, a Living Skull and a Locket are what I need.
I should have another look at the reports.

You prepare the ritual, combining the ingredients and infusing each with magic. Your spell weaves around the portal and you can feel its power spark to life.\n\nSuddenly the ground beneath your feet trembles and the magic dissolves, leaving a faint stench of burnt hair and coals in your mouth.
That didn't work. I will have to try again.

The ritual takes hold. You feel a strong surge pull you towards the portal. Loud cracking, like thunder, and flashes fill the area around it and magic starts swirling into life at its center.\n\nWith a final pulse, the portal manifests beneath the stone arch. The strange smells of a jungle waft through it.
It seems the restoration was successful.

A medusa emerges from the water and approaches the portal. She has many wounds. She passes through the portal and disappears.

Later she returns, followed by more of her kind.

"We are ready to fight, master mage. At your command."
I am looking forward to be working with you.
The first report reads: 'Learning about the portal... A dagger rubbed in the ashes of fallen warriors should provide a good base... '
What did the second say again?
I know what to do now.
The second report says: '… warm the ritual blade over a small flame until… should be enough to cut through the fabric of time and space.'
What did the first report say?

The medusa has pointed you to the location where she found her sister after the attack. Partly submerged, you find papers and ingredients scattered about. A trail of broken bottles, parchments and more lead away, possibly pointing you in the direction of the wyvern’s nest.
Onwards. We must find the rest!
Prepare to take this beast down!
Some of you need to distract it.
Wait. Once the animal flies away for food, then strike!
A small group breaks away and starts making as much noise as they can. They splash in the waters and shout and the wyvern quickly swoops down to chase away the threat.
Within the hour, the wyvern takes flight, probably to find food, leaving the nest unattended. It is undeniably a stroke of luck, but you take it nonetheless.
Now! To the nest!
It takes hours for the wyvern to finally leave. Your troops are exhausted from the seemingly endless wait.
The young king and his Council praise your deeds. You have brought an end to the conflict tearing Sevenkeeps apart and your fame in the city has increased mightily.
I am glad this is all settled.

The Seat of Kings – a legendary site from the age of the Hybernian Empire. This is where the kings of the Highmark are traditionally crowned. It is said that the Guardians themselves bless their reign here.\n\nNo one is allowed to enter without permission of the king. You will need to be held in the highest regard by Sevenkeeps to gain entrance and only the king, personally, can grant you access.

The building is dominated by a giant throne, said once to belong to the self-proclaimed descendant of Aonir, King Chlerus. The ancient walls of the throne room radiate with magic.

Though its design and actual purpose elude you, the presence of strong enchantments is unmistakable.

The young king of the Highmark, in all his regalia and surrounded by the Sevenkeeps Council, await you inside. The way to him is lined with the king’s guards, in all their splendor.
We will return one day.
Enter the throne room.
Seat of Kings
Phalanx
This unit protects adjacent allies by increasing their defenses in battle.
Affects only [bonus]{who}[/] units.
Does not affect [malus]{who}[/] units.
Build the [bonus]Glyph Smithy[/] room in your tower.
Goblin Leader
Congratulations!
By mastering your magic you have attained the title of
Your power has increased and your tower has become bigger.
Domain Radius {amount:+-c}

Tower Rooms {amount:+-c}
This unit regenerates up to {Amount:c} Health per day.
Draw

You come across a small band of orc travelers bundled up against the salty wind, carrying their lives on their backs and struggling to push a cart full of stone chunks. As they pass, one of them catches your eye, glances at her companion, who has a child sitting on his shoulders, and then looks at the state of their sorry group.

“Are you sure this will be enough?” she asks.

“It must be,” the companion replies. “If we promise the Stoneheavers we will do our share… Toraq has taken in many with less.”
Where are you going?

Many of the orcs blanch at your sudden question, as if they hadn't even noticed you were nearby. The child on the orc's shoulders beams happily, flashing the rounded points of sharp fangs in your direction.

"We are going to Orgash!" they tell you without thinking.

"Enough, Garash!" one of his parents says hurriedly. That is not for them to know!"

The orcs quicken their pace and change their direction, not in anger but seemingly in fear.
We better keep a look out for this place.
It is as if the trees close up around you, swallowing your fallen and any hope of finding this place again.
Domain Radius {amount}
Apprentices {current}/{max}
Tower Rooms {amount}
Stop Bleeding

Be an Alchemist, a master of bottled elements.
Brew potions and concoctions to support your soldiers in combat, summon magical creatures and control nature itself.

[adventure_main]PLAYSTYLE[/]
You prefer lots of options in combat to overcome the odds with clever use of your resources.

Be a Necromancer, an artist of life in death.
Harvest souls from the bodies of the fallen to create your horde and flood the lands with your servants.

[adventure_main]PLAYSTYLE[/]
You prefer big armies but will happily sacrifice individual units.

Be an Artificer, a creator of magical items.
Craft glyphs and artifacts to provide your troops with a multitude of different upgrades and wrest secrets from the earth itself.

[adventure_main]PLAYSTYLE[/]
You prefer quality over quantity and like to buff up individual units.

You see the banners of the Stormes - wardens of the Westguard - fluttering in the breeze from some way off. It is only when they are a little closer that you see not everyone in the group is a Westguard soldier. As they move north, they are pushing orc prisoners along with them.

Slowly coming up behind you, you hear the sound of many marching feet. When a voice cries out, you take a moment to look.\n\nA band of soldiers from the Westguard are dragging some orc prisoners north. They will be upon you shortly.

Your company is breaking camp after a short rest when a scout returns in an enthusiastic hurry to give his report.\n\n"There are soldiers nearby bearing the Stormes' standard - from the Westguard! They are taking orcish prisoners north!"
Perhaps I can talk the soldiers into sense.
Wait. Not all of these orcs will be raiders.
This has nothing to do with us. Move on.
Let's go. This is not our fight.
We should not get involved. Let's go.
We should try to free the prisoners.
Ignore them. It is not smart to pick this fight.

There were many times my father and my commanders in the Purity told me we were defending the Westguard, and all of the Highmark, then gave the order to burn an orc settlement to the ground, Lytra tells you with a touch of spite.\n\n"Just like us, some of these orcs may well have never wielded a weapon in their life, let alone against the Westguard."

Lytra spurs her horse to meet the soldiers before they reach you in force. It is quite obvious that she is trying everything she can to make them see they cannot follow their orders blindly, but whether out of fear or steadfast belief, they will not listen.\n\nAs Lytra rides back to you, despondent, the soldiers order the prisoners away at a quicker pace, away from you and the Storme of questionable loyalty to the Westguard.
Perhaps next time, Lytra.

It is obvious that the soldiers recognize Lytra as the Lady of Stormwatch Faste. One even bends the knee.\n\nLytra engages them in a long discussion, quite openly in front of the orc prisoners. Those who understand her nod along enthusiastically and after some time, the soldiers' minds are changed. They set about releasing the orcs from their bonds before continuing their long march north.
Well worked, Lytra!
Of course you have some numbers to fight the Westguard soldiers if you must, but the right spell may also free the prisoners without the Stormes, or anyone else, learning of your involvement.
We have the advantage. Attack!
I can unlock the bonds from here!
I will be more prepared next time.

The moment the orcs realize they are free, chaos ensues.\n\nSome choose to fight, taking the soldiers by surprise long enough for the rest to run. The fight turns into a brawl that leaves many on both sides greviously wounded or dead. The orcs that escape all turn and flee southwards, back into the stretches of the Misty Coast.
My work here is done.

The orcs get to work freeing themselves from their bonds while you focus your efforts on their guard.\n\nWhen they are free, some of the leaner, more ragged members of the group offer you their service in return for steady pay.
You are most welcome in my ranks.
There is no need. Go home with your families.
Perhaps I can handle this differently if it happens again.

Bold and resolute as they have always been in the Westguard, these soldiers prove too strong for your troops, pushing back your attack with no doubt that they can also stop the prisoners from escaping.

The local theater group has fallen violently ill overnight! The medics are at a loss – no one knows what ails them.\n\n"We hope that Lenya will at least give them some comfort," one tells you. "Do you have any to spare?"
I am sure my healers can help them.
I might be able to fashion an antidote.
No, but I can get you some.
I am glad we could help.
Please, take these tufts.
That would be quite wonderful! Please, come find us at the infirmary once you have it.
We will hurry.
It takes some time, but the Lenya is able to drive the sickness out. After a few hours, the troupe feels much better! The medics give you their thanks and word of your good deed quickly spreads.
It seems that resolves this issue.

The medics take the offered lenya and begin preparing tonics and tinctures to alleviate the troupe’s pains.

It takes some time, but after a few hours the thespians start to improve and you are thanked graciously for your help.

"You name will be in everyone’s mouth and they will celebrate your presence."
You find the infirmary, where the medics have erected a few tents to isolate the sick, just in case their malady is contagious.
We will return at a later time.
We have brought the medicine.
I think I can help after all.
My healers will support you.

With some observation, you conclude the group has been poisoned. It is nothing fatal – with some bed rest, none of them will suffer any long-lasting effects.\n\nAfter a few hours in your care, their condition finally starts to improve. You are certain that, the next morning, all of them will be as good as new.
That was easy. I wonder who did it...

Between a few trees, you see the theater group you helped heal not but a few days ago. They have cornered a single elf – even from a far you can see the situation could derail any minute now.\n\nWhen the elf speaks, one of the artists suddenly jumps at her and they both go to the ground.
What is happening here?
Halt your bickering!

The two of them slowly and abashedly get back to their feet while someone else tells you what is going on.

"This elf is the one who poisioned us! She wasn’t happy with how we portrayed her race in our latest piece so she joined us for a meal and poisoned us!"

"You made us act like headless chickens! Insulted our intelligence and portrayed us as nothing more than cattle! I was teaching you a lesson!"
No righteous person demeans another for their race.
I see. Then good luck discussing this.
Poisoning seems a bit drastic.

The elf takes up position close to you as the theater group sneers.\n\n"Oh, what do you know? They’ve done enough over the years to warrant our anger. Stealing our lenya, driving us from the woods… It’s about time someone stood up to them!"
Find your manners, or I’ll lose mine.

The troupe bands together with your soldiers and the elf takes a few steps back.\n\n"We have endured years of pain, false accusations and death at human hands. Not one of you can tell me you wouldn’t have done worse things to protect your people and culture."
You are right. The elf should be punished.
You acted out and will be punished for it.
The elf is right. You got what you deserved.

Some of the troupe go to speak up but, eyeing your seasoned soldiers, decide against it. Instead, they turn their backs and trot off with a few uttered and muttered curses.\n\n"Thank you, magus." The elf’s voice sounds unsure. "May I join your company, as thanks for your help."
Indeed you can. Join me.
Your coin is worth more to me.
She nods and brings forth a pouch. \n\n"May Elen guide you forward."
The troupe sneer and chuckle as they circle the elf. She barely as much as blinks as she is restrained.\n\n"What will we do with her?"
Take her to the militia. Prison will do her good.
She should pay for her freedom.
Kill her for all I care.

The elf is brought before the law. The troupe may have hoped for more immediate revenge but seem satisfied with your solution.\n\n"Ours was a fortunate crossing of paths, mage. We will carry this deed of yours into the world as song and play."

She swears in elvish before emptying her pockets. The troupe greedily take their share and happily ignore her, obviously satisfied with the outcome.\n\nThey hand you your own share before waving goodbye.

As you turn to leave, the elf utters a sharp cry in her own language. Too late, you feel the tendrils of a curse take hold.\n\nShe is resolute up until the moment she dies. The troupe run away more afraid than satisfied, no doubt also feeling the curse’s effects.
This did not go as I expected...

You hear the sounds of fighting from a little way off and hurriedly send a scout to find the cause of the commotion. She returns a few moments later, breathing heavily.

"It is soldiers from the Westguard, great mage!" she reports. "They are engaged with a smaller force of orcs. It looks like they are guerrilla fighters of some kind."

Intervening in the fight could raise your standing, either with the Westguard or the local fighters. Likely not without aggravating the other party though.
Attack the Westguard soldiers! Attack!
Attack the orcs! Charge!
This is not our fight. We should stay clear.
Let's carry on. This is not our fight.

Another skirmish has broken out between the local orcs and the Stormes' troops from the Westguard. You are close enough to help either party, though you are certain there will be consequences either way if you do.

With you distracting the bulk of the local orc force, the soldiers from the Westguard are able to rally and cut down the rest.

The captain comes to you afterwards, offering a decent reward in gold for your aid.

"There was a bounty on those brutes - they have been harrassing our forces for weeks. The Stormes will be told that you have helped us here today. Thank you!"
Glad to be of service to the Westguard.
The local orcs, desperate and fierce in the defence of their home, manage a phirric victory against both you and the Westguard forces.
We underestimated them.
Despite your best efforts to help the orcs, the Westguard troops are simply too well trained and too disciplined, in the end destroying both parties.
We were no match for them. This time.
We are glad to have helped.

Your surprise attack against the soldiers of the Westguard gives the orcs the time they need to run for cover. When the fighting is done, they stand waiting for you.\n\n"Thank you for your aid today, mage of the noble fight. Please take these as a token of our thanks, and know that your actions will become stories in the history of Orgash."
Zarachs Banner
Hirins Hourglass
Ereons Quill
Catalyst
Catalyst Slot
Locked Catalyst Slot
Hive
Blood Honey
Blood Mead
Unlocks building this room in the tower.\n\nA garden where plants can be harvested on a weekly basis. More plants can be planted to increase the yields.
The Circle
A warg rider from Toraq comes to you with freshly discovered locations across the Misty Coast where the Westguard soldiers are stashing stolen resources.

One of Toraq's warg riders finds you at your tower, clutching a rough parchment map of the Misty Coast.\n\n"Toraq told me that you might help us reclaim the resources the Storme clan and their fanatics stole from us," she says. "This map marks just a few of the stashes we know of, but do not have the strength to reclaim yet. Toraq wanted me to remind you that you may keep anything of magical value, should you wish. That is your reward for your aid."
Thank you. Where will I find these resources?
Let me take a look.
Stolen Resources

The Purity seems to have taken a lot of interest in the Stoneheavers' magical mysteries, which make up the majority of this cache. There is, however, some food and some forge supplies. Plenty that is usable, if you wish to take it.
Take only the magical supplies. Send the rest to Toraq.
Toraq surely won't miss this cache.

You take the time to sort through everything, looking for what magical objects might bring value to you. Everything else is shipped off to the orcish city. You know that Toraq and the Stoneheavers will appreciate what you have done for them.
Taking the entire cache for yourself means Toraq and the Stoneheavers will never know it was liberated. Nevertheless, you pack everything into a cart that can be wheeled back to your territory.
Quite the treasure tove.

With the Purity protecting this stash dealt with, you begin rummaging through what they have stolen. There seems to have been keen interest in anything to do with orc magic, but also some food and crafting ores. Not a bad haul, all in all.

Connach has requested your help with a mage not far from the city. The city council explains their dilemma.

"Some years ago a mage took up residence nearby. We did not think much of it and he has been helpful many times. A few weeks back though, he started to experiment with spiders, since Southwatch is overrun with them. 
Something must have gone wrong. He has not left his abode since and strange mutations have been sighted all over Southwatch."
I will have a look at this.

With the soldiers guarding this particular cache now slain, you take some time to take stock of what you have found. There is only a small supply of magical materials present, but much ore. The Westguard must have confiscated it before it could be turned into weapons to be used against them.

There is not much of immediate interest to you in this collection the Westguard has confiscated. Some ore clearly meant for the crafting of weapons and some food that is still fresh. You find only a small collection of magical items you might be able to make use off.

First thing in the morning you are told a rider is already waiting to see you. It is an orc of the Stoneheaver clan. Toraq must have sent him from Orgash.\n\n"Toraq told us you wish to help in our quest to retake our home," he says. "We have found camps belonging to the invaders that we alone cannot destroy. If you wish to help, now is the time."
Where are these outposts?
Another one of Toraq's riders comes to your tower with news of camps across the Misty Coast belonging to the invading Westguard forces, or - worse still - the New Purity.

Sticky webs have covered the ground around the hut and the building itself completely. Clusters of spider eggs are stuck to the walls and nearby trees. From within the abode you can hear whimpers and groans but also the chittering of many legged creatures.
Slice up those eggs!
I will dissolve the webs on the ground.
Let's throw a stone and see if something comes out.

You walk around with your troops, making sure they do not miss any eggs. A few of them do show strange markings and colorations, hinting at mutations. \n\nAs you take care of a small spider shooting icy cold webs, you begin to hear a loud clicking. The parents have been alerted by the sounds of their dying brood.
You clear the way to the hut with a few drops here and there that quickly disintegrate the webs and soon stand before the door. From within you can still hear the strange noises.
Be at the ready. There is no saying what awaits us.
As the rock hits the web you can watch the strings vibrate. Mere moments later the space before the hut is a flurry of legs. Spiders have emerged from holes, trees and the house even.
Bait them with meat, then we attack!

Some of the spiders decompose in an instant, leaving nothing but dust behind while others lay on their back now, legs curled inwards.\n\nYou finally step up to the door where the strange noises still emit.
Ready yourselves for whatever is to come.
Artifacts
Glyphs
Usable Items
City of the Orcs

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.13b9f8df-9a42-4f75-af63-16321fd4a1ed
column2: The moment you stepped into this city, which you don't remember seeing on any maps, you could tell it was not like the cities of the Highmark. At first, from the rubble that lies strewn about, you think that it has been destroyed, but you soon realize it is construction work.\n\nThere are orcs all about, clearing pathways and marking roads, using the rubble to build houses and what looks like a tavern. You have never heard of orcs... laying down roots like this.

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.c8f83c90-8822-4603-ae80-4862138c37b0
column2: Perhaps I should take a look around.

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.ec24c29f-a167-4495-9500-bd5118337210
column2:
With all the orcs preoccupied, you quietly tell a member of your company to collect what has caught your eye. As you suspected, you feel a thrum of magic as it is brought closer to you. How anyone let this be thrown casually away is beyond you.

"Are you a mage then?"

A rough voice behind you makes you spin around. Two orcs, one man and one woman, have clambered down off the wall and now face you, wearing suspicious expressions. When you signal for the artifact to be laid down, the man waves a hand.

"Keep it,” he says. “We have higher priorities right now.”

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.f097ae24-59ad-4718-80a7-bb06a1d00e8c
column2: My thanks. Are you in charge here?

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.c3ce6276-4f59-462d-aa34-f6891650838b
column2: You find yourself in a quiet corner of the city. Here, orcs are working on the outer walls. Or wall, as only a section of it has been built over ten feet. Further along, it looks like the builders are still discussing how best to build a strong foundation.\n\nAnd as you look around, you see a pile of tools and weapons just left on the street. One of the items in the pile stands out to you as more ornate, though no newer, than the rest of it.

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.fb6a6f26-2667-43e5-bbf6-6ce5f7213e6e
column2: Investigate the possible artifact.

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.4b88a139-f752-4f50-8176-6160922f9401
column2: I shall shape the earth to help lay the wall foundation.

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.02e9f1d8-f93f-42d7-ad3e-f8325c9359f6
column2: Who is in charge here?

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.30263cae-e993-443a-8d82-4aaccb63dd14
column2: Then why bring it here? Gruun asks with venom in her voice. Toraq laughs.\n\n"She is not wrong to ask," he says. "The Westguard has looked to push us from our homes for many years. It would not be the first time they have sent some stranger to attempt what they have failed. But if not that, why are you here?"

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.2a479465-29ec-4794-9d4c-ab06aa891dcc
column2: To trade. Hire troops. Provide help, if I can.

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.5796f383-f97c-4e65-bdff-7210dbfbf856
column2: It is a rare thing, I'll give you that. Toraq chuckles. His expression turns stoney as he takes you in properly.\n\n"Dark tidings come from the east," he says. "They say the rivers of the Howling Steppes run red with blood. That it seeps from the Needle's stones. Calamity is coming and we must be ready for it." He raises his arms to indicate the city around him. "This is being ready. But... why are you here?"

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.8d50d365-7d86-4c30-8556-6fba786bb7d8
column2:
We are a young clan, Gruun says with a hint of spite. "Formed to make this marvel around you. You are not expected to have heard of us."

Toraq laughs.

"Trust is not easy for us," he states. "We have been fighting the Westguard to defend this place for ourselves since before the Stoneheavers united. If you are not with them, mage, and not with us, why are you here?"

When you find Toraq and Gruun, they are attempting to set a big, metal gate into a gap in the wall, carrying it precariously between them. When he sees you, Toraq smirks but does not stop his work.\n\n"Word has reached us that you've been continuing to give your aid to the Misty Coast! You have my thanks, but the work is not done. There are... a couple of things you might help us with... if you can spare the time."
What do you need?

Soldiers from the Westguard and their ridiculous allies still roam these lands freely, Gruun says as she bends at the waist and then heaves upwards to shove the gate into position. Both she and Toraq relax then, breathing heavily.\n\n"They have set up camps that must be torn down, and stolen resources meant to help build Orgash," she continues. "Small tasks. Perhaps easy for you?"
Easy enough.

Toraq looks at you for a moment before nodding and looking around at the work going on around him.\n\n"We have riders," he says out of the blue. "When our fighters find these camps or our stolen resources, they will send someone to your tower to inform you. Do not worry about telling us where it is. We will find it. And... well, you are a mage. In thanks for your work, should you come across any magical items or supplies, you are free to keep them. We can make them anew, when the time is right."
That is most generous of you. We will get going.

Gruun laughs loudly as she paints paste across another stone, and Toraq's expression shows toothy amusement. When he realizes you are being serious, he looks a little crestfallen.\n\n"I will believe it when I see it," he says. "Humans of the Storme clan still run rampant across these lands, claiming we pillage and burn and steal when all we do is protect our home and take back what they stole from us. And now they have allies, this so-called New Purity, that hunt our shamans too. While they are here, there is little else we can do that we do not already."
Then perhaps we can help thin their numbers.

Toraq eyes you suspiciously, smirking again. Looking around at his city, he nods and scratches a cheek.\n\n"Very well," he nods. "You are a mage - you must have a tower. I will send riders to find you when we locate their camps or the resources they have stolen from us, that were meant to help build this city. And in thanks, if you find anything of magical value, you may keep it. We have other priorities right now."
We have a deal. All the best with your building.

Stepping inside you are instantly taken aback by what lays before you. An elderly man, almost completely engulfed in webs and with six spiderlegs coming from his back. His eyes are turned upwards so only the white is visible and he groans, twitches and mumbles constantly. \n\nHis hands grip a large glyph that pulses occasionally and with each pulse you can see spider eggs growing on or around the man.
Rip that thing from him!
Kill him before these spiders hatch!
I think I can break this curse.

A shockwave goes through everything as soon as the glyph leaves the mans hands. As if a hot knife was passing though everything, the webs and eggs around begin to crumble while he falls to the ground lifeless, his body was already too weak.

You return the news to Connach. The people react with a mixture of shock and appall, but mostly they are relieved that it is all over now.\n\n"Thank you, master mage. That was quite a remarkable feat."
Let's hope we killed all of those beasts.
Looking around the hut you find notes and records of his doings. Apparently he was trying to find a way to domesticate the spiders but the spell went horribly wrong.
Search the hut, I wanna know what happened.
Let us tell the people of these findings.

With a single blow the man topples over as all life leaves his body. The glyph tumbles to the ground and an eery silence begins to spread. You realize that the eggs all around you have stopped moving.

The man falls to the ground with a shudder. After a moment he opens his eyes and croaks weakly: "Thank you." He cannot bring up the strength to add more but after a while he begins to point towards a floor board. \nHidden underneath you find a true treasure trove for arcanists. The man nods shortly for you to take it all before falling into a deep slumber.

The people in Connach are fearful, for large spiders - some mutated and strange - have cocooned one of their wells right at the outskirts of the city.\n\n"Their webs are everywhere, clogging our water supplies and sewers. A few days more and we might just have no water - and streets full of, well, you know. Can you help us?"
Of course. We will be quick.
The Webbed Well
The Arachnomancer

You can see a white hill, completely covered in webs. The only indication that this is a well is a shingled roof atop that barely raises over the masses of webs and... eggs!\n\nA variety of eggs, some with strange markings, are laid out around the well. A few have aready hatched and are nothing more but empty shells while others have only started to move.
Destroy the eggs!
These webs are a nuisance, burn them.
I will dissolve these abominations.
Hide. We strike as soon as the spiders come out.

You hack and slash at the eggs, not minding the webs you have to pass to do so. Some of the spiders give small hissing and chittering noises as they die and soon you begin to hear loud clicking. The parents have been alerted by the sounds of their dying brood.
It is a meager distraction but enough to give you first strike! Your troops charge into the flurry of battle and are able to deal a significant amout of damage already!

You are about to start drippling acids everywhere, but then you remember - this might soak into the ground, affecting the water of the well! You might need to change your tactics, lest you want to kill the citizens of Connach.
Fine. We kill those eggs then.
Burn the webs.

You begin to clear the well of webs, but your movement through them has alerted the spiders. Some begin to climb out of the well while others come from nearby trees.\n\nYou don't have a lot of time inspecting them, but even a simple farmer could see that those are no normal spiders.

You wait a long while until finally a rabbit gets too close to the webs. It disturbs the sticky strands and spiders charge in from nearby trees and out of the well.\n\nWhile your troops manage to get the first hits in, they are tired and stiff from the long wait before hand. Even the adrenaline of the upcoming fight is not enough to fully awaken their weary bones.

Having finally killed off all the arachnids, you make sure to clear the well of any remaining webs. While doing so you see something shimmering in the webs just above the water.\n\nYou retrieve it and find a glyph in your hands. It seems whoever dropped it into the well is responsible for the recent spider invasion. It's power must have drawn them here to nest.

You return to Connach and the people are both appalled and relieved to hear that their torment is over.
None of them know who could have been responsible for dropping the glyph but they assure you to keep their eyes open.

"Should anyone try something like this again, we will make sure to inform you. Let us hope this was the last time. And thank you, master mage, truly."
Statue of Niethalf
Dragonbone Excavation
Silver Drift Mine
Stormwatch Faste
Tuscari Portal
Mage
Master Mage
Circle Mage
Arch Mage
Grand Mage

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.9e8a7987-d092-403d-aff2-fbc7912d2a4e
column2: I am indeed. Are you the local clan leaders?

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.a6280671-c654-4880-8fc8-e89dea9cfffe
column2: Well met!

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.e37c7638-4483-4a5d-8a21-7882e700899c
column2: I have never heard of the Stoneheavers.

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.e4702118-473b-4998-a89c-0a8c31ac909d
column2: I have never heard of orcs building new cities.

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.0fd36a11-ced1-435c-9bd6-e17c389bfda7
column2: This armed force is meant for different battles.

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.775858d7-43ac-4c35-9905-1b5ac2f1a865
column2:
You bend your will to flattening the earth at the wall's edge. It ripples, then rumbles and the orcs all blanch and cry out as they stumble backwards in surprise, only for everything to die down again, the earth reshaped.

One orc though turns to face you. A moment later he is joined by another - a woman, laying a careful hand on the hilt of her vicious weapon.

"You're a mage then?" the first asks. "Thank you for your help."

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.b3057cea-ebae-4ea0-b956-c11a29ec94bd
column2: Two of the orcs discussing the foundations turn and look at you together. One man and one woman, who puts a careful hand on the hilt of her vicious weapon.

column1: Misty Coast City of the Orcs.faded54f-e78c-4178-8300-05d2e50a82e7
column2:
I am Toraq and this is Gruun, the first orc continues. "We are the leaders of the Stoneheaver clan."

He looks around the half-built city and then back to you, eyeing up the company at your back just like Gruun.

"This is Orgash," he says. "You are welcome here, as long as you come in peace. Else... We don't want to fight you, but we will."
Unexpected Growth

The citizens are all gathered on the main plaza. There, overnight, a large tree has sprung from the ground. It is high enough to overlook most houses – thick, as if it were centuries old.

"Don't try to talk yourself out of this one, elf! We all know it was you!"

"I lived here before you were born - despite the likes of you, mind - and never done harm to anyone!"
Why would someone make a tree grow over night?

The elvish woman nods enthusiastically.

“Why indeed?” she asks pointedly. “What would I gain from growing a tree? Almost through my own home at that!” The man's face turns red as beets. 

"Why, you cheeky...! To scare us! Maybe to threaten us? Who knows?!"
Let me have a look. I am sure I can figure this out.
The earth does look a bit disrupted. Step aside.

Everyone except the bickering parties steps back. You inspect the tree, then the ground beneath it. Both emit a strong magical surge. Unsurprising, giving the tree could not have grown naturally.\n\nYou make the magical aura reveal itself, so it hangs in the air like fog. Everyone follows it to its terminus, a house in the square.
Whoever did this lives there.

The woman’s face remains unchanged as she replies: “I did nothing. I woke up to this, same as the rest of the town.”\n\nThe man, though, twists and turns, as if fighting to keep something inside until he can no longer: “I bought a scroll from a traveling wizard!”
A spell? Elaborate.
Tell me the truth, both of you.
Let me inspect this tree closer.
Did anyone see what happened last night?

“Alright, alright. It seems I can no longer deny it.” Defeated, the old man sighs and rubs his face. He goes into his home and returns after a few minutes with a scroll. “This is what I used. But I only did what I had to! The elf stole my business! She is malicious!”

Murmuring has already spread over the other citizens. Some even chuckle.

“What should we do with him, mage?”

The man gulp as the elf steps forward and looks him up and down.

“All I wish for is that you care for this tree for the rest of your living days.”

She smiles sweetly at him and walks off. The man gives a heavy sigh, many of his peers laughing at his defeated expression.

“I saw something!” A child steps up, no older than four or five summers. “Mr. Oliver was talking to the ground last night! He looked silly!” The child laughs before their parent ushers them back.\n\nNo one else steps forward, other than Mr. Oliver himself. “I saw the elf! She planted a seed in the middle of the night! It was her doing!”
I choose to believe the child. Now tell the truth.
This is ridiculous. Take the elf away already.

The citizens spring into action, dragging the elf towards the garrison.

“You believe this cretin over me?!” she berates you all. “I thought you more circumspect than this!” Meanwhile, the man steps up and bows.

“You honor me, great mage. Thank you for your trust. I bought this from a wandering merchant. May it serve you well.”
Earth Armor
[fluff]Having several units with this ability decreases time required.[/]
[error]You must be on a mineable location to use this skill[/]
[error]You must be on a harvestable location to use this skill[/]
Ethereal
or
Have {Amount} Landmarks within your Domain
Employ {Amount} Apprentices
Continue Planning
Flying Spire
Rip your tower from the ground and levitate it freely through Fiara!

A sudden earthquake. A magical explosion! The very walls of your room shake and your tower is ripped from the ground, climbing higher and higher!

Unable to contain the sheer enormity of the spell, you falter and the tower falls to the ground as fast as it rose.

Another shock wave rumbles around you. As you get your bearings, you see the scenery around the tower lies in ruin.
Oops...
I need to study this!
You have caught a glimpse of what your master's spell may achieve - but it is strenuous. With more focus and preparation, you think you might be able to make it easier.
Hire {Amount} Workers into your employ.
Have {Amount} Hamlets within your Domain.
I am looking forward to it.

You are now able to further furnish your rooms and add new devices and amenities that will surely enhance their effectiveness.\n\nYou are on the path to making your tower a mighty fortress of learning and industry.
Flying Spire
Lift off and fly freely through Fiara while your tower keeps emitting your [mDomain].
Gather magical crystals that store some of the Allfire overflow.
Crystalline Garden
Gathering Boost
Increases the yield from harvesting plants.
Melding Flesh I
Melding Flesh II
Melding Flesh III
Greedy

Greydusk Vale miners have come upon tunnels for old rail tracks. Further investigation has revealed that the Windwall Mountains were once connected to the Snake Pass.\n\n"We wish to reestablish this connection," you are told. "The railroad could lead to long forgotten adamantinum reserves. Animals and landslides have made the way impassable but with your help we should be strong enough to clear it."
Reopening the Tunnels
We shall see what can be done.

A thin and sheer layer of ice has covered the walls and metal rails. Dwarves are building new carts and fitting them, hopeful that they might soon retrieve the valuable ores deep in the mountain.\n\nMany of them wish you good fortune, giving you some tools that might aid you as you prepare to clear their way.
Let's venture inside.

The first obstacle you come to, some twenty minutes later, is that the ground has caved in underneath the rails, leaving a pit large enough for three carts to fall through. The weight of one cart alone would probably be enough to drag the rider down and permanently break the rail.
I can close that up.
We must dig out the walls and fill the pit.
It takes some time to fill in the ravine, which is tiring for all involved. You manage to dig out enough of the walls to add rough support to the rail tracks, but then you must continue.
The ground rumbles, sending up some nervous cries as the very rock of the floor shifts and the pit fills itself in. The extra support will let any cart cross safely.

Another hour into the darkness your way is blocked again.\n\nA stinking, bubbling, tarry substance covers the ground and has eroded parts of the rails. The smell stings in your nose and someone in your ranks heaves. It is acidic, metallic and most likely deadly to mortals.
We will need to return with a solution.
I can neutralize this stinking mass.
We need Mountain Copper to rebuild the tracks.

A little while later, an unfamiliar noise catches your ears. A growling, huffing and scratching is coming from one of the tunnels intersecting that which you are following.\n\nSuddenly, a gigantic creature steps out of the darkness, vaguely troll-like and covered in icicles.

It takes a bit of time but with some experimentation, you find the right solution. You pour your own concoction into the pond, which begins to evaporate with a loud hiss.\n\nWhen the vapors have settled, you can assess the damage to the rails.
Leave this cave now and never return.
The large creature doesn’t have the intelligence to fight your magic, succumbing easily. As commanded, it turns and leaves. Soon, the stomping subsides and you know you are alone again.
That should suffice then.

At long last, the rails come to a stop and the tunnel opens up into a large cavern filled with old carts and mining equipment.\n\nIt takes hours to return to the city, but your long and tedious journey is bountifully rewarded. The dwarves celebrate your success, giving you a few valuable resources for good measure.
Finally this is over.
Flintstone
Charged Crystal
Bonedust
Twitching Eyeball
Translucent Silk
Corrupted Ruby
Fairy Grass
Decayed Brain
Good Luck Charm
Triumph over all Circle Mages
Have {Amount} Apprentices
I sense this resentment has gone on for a while.

The man replies with barely restrained disgust.

“Indeed it has! This elf,” he practically spits out the word, “decided to open another apothecary despite the fact that I have provided this city with herbs and tinctures all my life!”

“I have told you before, Mr. Oliver! Not everyone feels comfortable discussing their ailments with a man!” the elf snaps back.
I think it is only fair she decides your punishment.
You should pay a fine to the lady.
Whatever you wish for. My job here is done.

You peruse the busy market stalls and notice a curiously empty spot in the otherwise crowded square.\n\n“It’s the old dwarven alchemist,” one of the neighboring traders offers as she sees you looking at the empty spot. “Haven’t seen ‘im around for quite a bit.”
Perhaps worth investigating?
Rubble
Missing Alchemist

Your band dutifully follows their directions. You stumble across a small group of soldiers much sooner than you thought you would. They don't seem very soldierly, though. They may wear the Baron's colors, but they stumble about confused, and several of them keep scratching at thier faces, leaving bloody streaks.
They seem disorganized. Attack!
Watch them a little longer.

Among the soldiers, your scouts make out bugs swarming. Insects of all sizes, from tiny specks to the size of a child's head. One of the soldiers suddenly screams and tries to run, but is held back by their comrades.\n\nThen they see you, and become agressive. Somehow, they manage some semblance of a fighting formation.

While your soldiers take care of the last stumbling fighters, one of them breaks away and flees. He moves jerkily, like a child's puppet, but seems to follow a straight line away from the battlefield.
There must be more. Follow him!
The miners are furious, even prepared to fight you to their last breath.
Very good. Now for the final step.
The dwarves have readied themselves for you. Their weapons drawn, they stand at the entrance and await your charge.
I can offer some spirits.
He takes a sip from the bottle and his face lights up.
So, will that suffice?
You try your best but your troupe cannot withstand the undead.
So they continue to wander the land.
Craft
Slot
Troop Quarters
Click to cancel the currently selected skill.

The two orcs give each other a careful look before Toraq turns back to you.\n\nGruun shrugs and with a sigh, Toraq says, "I don't wish to conceal anything from you. We are aware of what you have done across the Misty Coast, and we thank you for it! But. There are are many who are still suspicious of why you help us - a suspicion that will only increase because this is the first time we are meeting. Come. There is someone else I want to introduce you to."

You catch Toraq and Gruun on a break from their labours. As you approach, Gruun is talking in hushed tones while Toraq laughs and plays with a small child orc. When he sees you, he sweeps the giggling child up and passes them back to their parent.\n\n"Great mage!" he says. "Thank you for everything you have done for us so far. It is good to see you again."
And you. Is there anything else I can do?

Perhaps it is time that you met our shaman. Gruun says goodbye to the other orc and their child before turning to you properly. "You have proven yourself good at the type of work she needs. And she wants to meet you."\n\n"Yes," Toraq agrees. "I think it is time. Come! I will take you to her."
Lead the way.
Guerrilla Warfare
Their enemies lying dead before you, you know that Toraq, Gruun and all the orcs of Orgash will be thankful for what you have achieved.
The Misty Coast will be free again.
They best be...
We will get them next time!
This time, the forces from the West Coast are too strong for you...
You have arrived at one of the camps Toraq's rider gave you the location of.
We can take them!

You find your master’s old friend’s hut and are relieved to see him sitting out front, enjoying a pipe. Noting your approach, he gives you a friendly wave that falters when you draw near.\n\n"I see you are in dire need of help. I can heal this unfortunate wretch. The ingredients aren’t cheap but I do owe your late master. I will consider this my repayment."

The hermit stands and extends a hand, dropping golden liquid from a small vial over your grievously wounded ally.\n\nFor a moment, nothing happens. Then, the wounds slowly begin to heal and life returns to their eyes. Mere seconds later, your champion is as good as new.
Of course! Just help us, please.
Most impressive. How much to teach me this spell?

Toraq leads you to a small hut near the edge of the city, where an elderly orc sits on a stool outside and serenely watches the busy building work going on around her. When she sees you, she slowly pushes herself to stand and grins.

"This is our shaman," Toraq tells you.

"And this is the mage of great suspicion," the shaman replies without giving you a chance to.
What do you mean?
Toraq wished for us to meet.

You help our enemy to the north as well as us, the shaman points out. "The only reason for this is that you have your own agenda and care little for ours or for their's. This is understandable but makes you suspicious.\n\nBut," she continues, "These are strange and dark times and we must choose strange deeds to match them. Dark deeds too. This is how we will pass Zarach's greatest test."

You have no reason to help us, yet you do, Toraq says.\n\n"This is right," the shaman confirms. "For the orcs, aid has never been in great supply. The struggle does not allow much for it. So, it is strange when it comes. It leads many to ask the question: What do you want in return for your help?"

We both believe you may help us. Help me.

In my youth, I would have done my work myself, but now my body is failing. My students help in the building of the city.

But before I tell you what it is I need, mage, I have long wished to know from you. Why is it you help us now?
Of course I have my own agenda. I expect payment.
How may I help you pass this test?
I wish to see the Misty Coast thrive.
I seek ways to increase my own might.

“I can give you what you seek.” The shaman gives you an understanding nod.

“To come through this struggle, we must have strength and hope. When we first came to these lands, we built shrines to Zarach that have been captured by our enemies. Free them and these things will be returned to us.

When you have done this, find me in the camp nearby. Then you shall have your power.”

The shaman looks deep into your eyes and nods.

“We will soon turn the tide against our enemy, mage. For this we will need all of Zarach’s strength. When we came to these lands, we built shrines to him that have been taken by our enemies in this struggle. If you can free them, strength and hope will return to our people.

I will soon travel to a nearby camp. Find me there when this is done. In return, I will give you a gift.”
Power of the People

You are invited to Greydusk Vale’s annual mole race.\n\nThe rules are simple. First mole over the line wins, only official racing moles are allowed to participate and they must stay within track limits. A long obstacle course has already been prepared and the event will start soon.
I cannot miss this.
A Race in Good Faith

A large audience has already gathered at the race tracks. Hot mead and foods are being handed out for a few coins and the atmosphere is one of joyous exuberance.\n\nThe moles and their racers are already preparing outside. You can see people betting on competitors, or buying potions and the likes in the hopes of helping them trick their way through the race.
I will bet on a mole.

Three of the moles and riders participating today grab your attention:

The first is a slender animal with a light rider, promising swiftness in the upcoming race.

The second pair is sturdy through and through and look to be able to withstand the harshest conditions.

The last animal seems to be extraordinary smart, doing tricks for its rider in return for treats.
I'll bet on the quickest one.
The sturdy beast will be my choice.
A smart mole is bound to win this.
Since it's a little on the heavy side, the mole you chose has much better grip on the ice but is also slower. It reaches the incline second place.
Your chosen mole churns up the ground in front of it as the rider nods to you with gratitude.\n\n"Thank you for your patronage, mage, I will not disappoint you."

A horn echoes through the mountain and the races commences.\n\nThe moles dash along the extensive track, quickly heading for the first obstacle – a steep incline with ice and sleet covering the ground.
Swift and agile the mole you bet on takes the lead. While the others struggle to climb higher, it has already reached the top .
This won't be a problem for my mole.
Come on! Hurry up there!
I will return with coins.
Good luck.
Move the ground a bit to hamper the other moles.
While it is smart, your chosen mount is neither the fastest nor the most athletic. It reaches the ledge of the hill third place and pushes on.
Faster! Go!
You punch the air as your mole reaches the finish line in first place. The crowd erupts with applause and cheers that last until you claim your prize.
That was quite exhilarating!
You watch with eager anticipation, but your mole can’t quite catch the leader, claiming a close second place. The crowd cheers you regardless as you receive your prize.
I will make sure to come again next year.
With leaping strides, your mole claims a close third place. The crowd applauds and cheers enthusiastically even as you receive your prize.
It could have gone better, but not a bad result.
The last challenge thinned the moles’ ranks, but this one is sure to weed out more. Large icicles hang from a natural overpass, threatening to fall on the moles if they don’t progress carefully.
Hah, this is no challenge for a sturdy mole!
Protect our chosen rider and beast.
Come on! You got this!
Come on now!
Your mole evades the ice falling left and right, but loses some speed and falls to second place.
Your bet races through the trap. Even as the icicles hit it, it absorbs the impact with naught but a few scratches. Mole and rider quickly take first place.
Your mole moves cautiously to avoid the falling ice as well as other moles. It is slowly catching up, now in second place!

As the race continues, the final challenge comes up on the competitors. A maze of heavy, wooden walls block the path and every mole that reaches it slows down.\n\nMany rely on their innate senses, or their riders’ orientation, on which way to take.
I will guide our rider telepathically.
Finally a challenge our mole will excel at.
The final lap, come on!
Your choice may be fast as the wind, but it takes a number of wrong turns, getting stuck in dead ends and forced to retrace its steps so that it loses position.
As others meet dead ends or become lost in the maze’s looping paths, your mole dashes left and right without hesitation, winding through the maze as though it is a straight line.
At first, your mole simply tries to break through the walls, but they have been bolted into the ground and reinforced with metal. Meanwhile, faster or smarter moles have dashed past.
Come on, hurry!
I will do what I can.

The largest local lenya fields have been depleted overnight. The people of Alluvyan turn to you for help, promising valuable ingredients for your craft in return.\n\n"We have gathered everyone who works in the fields, in case you wish to question them. Your help would be greatly appreciated. We are truly at a loss for what has happened."
I will see what I can do.
Growing troubles

You arrive at a small farm by an old shrine. You can feel the magical flow that must have made the lenya thrive and, indeed, there are a few elves praying inside.

The field itself looks like it has been dug up and emptied by a great force. Not a single green leaf remains.

A few farmers are trying to re-till the field so that new plants way sprout again.
Inspecting the field is our first priority.

The farmers gather together with hopeless faces.\n\n"Just last week we took some lenya to heal our sick. Then it was a lush field. We really depended on those plants." Suddenly they move in closer and their tones shift. "Those elves didn’t like us taking it. Maybe it was their doing. An act of revenge, maybe?"

The elves finish praying to the Guardian Elen before turning to you. Despair is clear in their expressions.

"Elen be with you, mage. We did not see or hear anything. One day, this was a beautiful field. The next we arrived to carnage."

After checking the farmers are out of earshot, one whispers: "But these farmers have been using lenya for any and all remedies, even mixing it into their food as if it was an endless resource. I would not be surprised if their greed was behind this."

Exploring the field, there are footprints everywhere. Presumably, they belong to the farmers.

But half buried in the soil, you also see something shimmer. You pick it up and uncover a glass bottle, empty and uncorked.
