Stormwatch Faste

You can scarcely believe your eyes, looking upon Stormwatch Faste. The once proud home of the Stormes is now overrun with banners and shields shining with the New Purity's silver dagger atop a blazing golden sun.\n\nThis is a dangerous place for any mage to find themselves. Perhaps the high generals of the Westguard in Bastion can tell you more about how the Purity claimed this place.
Turn back for now, we will come back later.

Westguard soldiers can be seen camped around Stormwatch Faste in every direction you look. Smoke rises from the city gates and many of the Purity banners you saw before are tattered or smoking to embers.

You need not wait long before Reinald finds you, trotting up on a horse.

"I'm glad you could join us," he says. "The assault faltered inside the walls. The Purity was far more prepared than we hoped for."
What is the situation?

On your way through this village you spot a wanted poster nailed roughly into a wooden beam supporting a large roof. \n\nIt is a crude picture of an old man with wild eyes in a pointy hat and flowing robes, and a haggard, old woman similarly dressed but all in black. Below the drawing, it quite clearly says: 'Magic is not for us. It is only for Aonir.'

There is a small crowd in this market square, huddled around a poster that has been pinned up over night.\n\nOn it, you see a crude picture of a crowd of people hustling and bustling about, with a person in the middle of them clutching at a hooded cloak that hides their eyes but not their smirking mouth. Underneath is written, 'Mages could be anywhere. Keep an eye out.'
Weak Purity of Light propaganda...

As you ready to leave this village after a short rest, you notice a small poster has been set up on the roof of a nearby well.\n\nIt is a crude drawing of a frog holding an emptied alchemist's beaker, a drop of liquid falling towards a sparkling puddle on the floor. The frog looks shocked and the text reads: 'This could be you. Don't use magic.'
Granite Dwarf Report

You make the effort to stop by a nearby watch tower to inform the Westguard's standing army of the granite dwarves you found. The guard captain you speak to is wildly frustrated by the news.

"As if orcs and trolls weren't bad enough, now the Granite Dwarves think they can take advantage of how thin we're stretched too," she complains. "Unbelievable. My commander is going to love this!"

Amid her protestations, she writes a quick note and attaches it to a carrier pigeon, then counts out a small bounty in exchange for your information.
Glad to have been of service.

You are called to your company exploring the Westguard, where scouts have seen activity nearby. When you see it for yourself, you discover it is a company of dwarves working to excavate an entrance in the side of a hill.\n\nThere are enough of them to put up a fight if they are charged, which means they must have found some useful resources.
We best report it to the army.
It's not worth our getting involved here.
Let's go down to meet them.

Indeed, the dwarves leave their miners to do their work the moment they see you, their warriors bunching up to protect their prize at all cost.\n\n"These resources are ours by birthright, for we are the children of Niethalf!" their leader shouts to you. "Stay back, or we will destroy you!"
This is Westguard, not Norgate. You are stealing.
You will try. Charge!
Return to Norgate at once. This is ours now.
Let me help you shift the earth.

The treasures of the earth are Niethalf's gifts to his children no matter where they lie! the leader argues. "We care not for borders and politics. This is ours by right and you will respect it, or you will fall!"
You will return to Norgate now!
We best report this to the army.
Alright, alright! I do not wish for violence.
So be it! Fight!

Before the dwarves can argue, you cast your spell to shape the earth, so that the hill seems to knit itself apart before the dwarves' very eyes. The miners are astounded, even horrified. But when all as settled again, the leader turns to you.\n\n"Well. That certainly makes our work easier. As thanks you may take something from this place. Not much, mind! Niethalf is generous, not stupid!"
Very well.

A magical fear leaps into the dwarves eyes as you speak. A few flinch, a couple shift their gaze to the flute on your belt as if they have heard a sound no one else has.

"Aye. I suppose it is time we headed home." The excavation leader nervously grips his axe. "Come on, lads! We'll reclaim Niethalf's gifts further north!"

You're left with the small hilltop to yourself, now with a crack running through it that one person would barely fit through.
The Granite Dwarves manage to drive you back while their miners quickly continue their work. There's no real chance they will still be at it by the time you get here again.
I should inform the army anyway, just in case.
They win. This time.
The miners see their brethren being killed, take up their pickaxes and flee, leaving the mound partially excavated.
Let's see what they'd found.

Half of your company to fit into the cavern the hill covers comfortably - it is no sprawling mine or great hidden place.\n\nThe back wall does glimmer in the torch light though, with traces of veins of uncommon metals glinting at you. If you take the time to dig them out, there is a small but quality amount of good resource to be gained, you think.

It is not a big space or a sprawling mine that the hill top opens up into. There is perhaps room for half of your company to fit comfortably.\n\nThe back wall shines in torch light with veins of common and uncommon metals. Truth be told, the Granite Dwarves have travelled far for... not a large reward but that doesn't seem to bother them. And they are true to their word, passing a little of Niethalf's gift over to you when it has been dug out of the wall.
Well... better than nothing, I suppose.
Get started. Send the resources to my tower.
Dwarven Ruins
An excellent find!
This will come in very useful!

It is no great tomb or sprawling mine you find yourself in but what looks very much like a hidden cache. As the very earth had been closed up around it to make it look natural, you would say it was magically hidden.\n\nThis explains the sacks of pre-distilled Allfire crytals you find stashed about the place, no doubt hidden by some hedge mage in case of an emergency.

Hidden beneath the hillside, you find a small, stone chamber. It is largely unremarkable, except for the intricate drawings that seem to indicate beings working with a great orb of blues, greens, yellows and whites.\n\nThe place must have something to do with the Shapers! You could uncover all manner of knowledge from studying the drawings. One of your scouts finds an artifact of great power too! The dwarves had no idea what they had stumbled upon.

You are passing through a village when you cross paths with a busy but low-ranking army officer handing out posters to anyone who will take one.

"Thieves! Thieves from Norgate!" he shouts. "A handsome reward will be paid to the one who finds these dwarven thieves!"

Curious, you take a leaflet. It details a daring raid on a Westguard armory, from which some Granite Dwarves stole some ores waiting to be turned into arms and armor.
It doesn't hurt to keep an eye out, I suppose.

Your scouts report that these must be the thieves responsible for the heist on the Westguard armory – they are traveling with many crates of refined but unused ores. Your scouts also report, strangely, that they are carrying a supply of magical materials too, wandering from place to place to keep the army off their trail but not making ready to leave the Westguard.
That's... odd. Perhaps we should talk to them.
I must think. Back off for now.
Strike now while they are unaware.
You manage to find the dwarvern thieves again, still moving from place to place to try to stay under the Westguard's watchful gaze.\n\nWhy are they not just heading north back to Norgate?
I would like to try to talk to them.
I'm still unsure. Back off for now.
It does not matter. Strike now!
I wonder what they are up to.

As the fight falls steadily against you, you hear the dwarves shouting among themselves.

"This isn't worth it! We should just take the supplies and leave!" one of them shouts.

"I agree!" another returns. "It was a good plan, but we can't hope to stay hidden now. Finish the fight and pack up! We're going home!"

You find everything the Granite Dwarves took near the battlefield. The magical supplies are all yours for the taking, at least as far as the original bounty is concerned, but you are asked too what should happen to the ores that were stolen.
I want information. Why are you doing this?

The moment the dwarves know you are coming, they run for the supplies. They scramble to get everything up and away, the soldiers among them forming a wall between you and their prize.\n\nIt is only when you raise your hands and tell them that you have no intention of harming them do they slow. Even then, they are still suspicious.
Granite Thieves
I'll do what I can to protect us.
A few moments of more intense study reveals a magic around the place that is indeed but a masterfully crafted illusion. There is no sense in wasting your time going any further.
I won't turn you over. Let's make a trade.

A couple of the Granite Dwarves relax a little, then begin to laugh. One spits on the ground and shakes his head.\n\n"We're not going to tell you that when we don't know who you are! Unless... you want to pay a fair price for it?"
Will this do?
I suppose that's fair.

The dwarven leader catches the coin purse deftly and smirks, jabbing a thumb at the supplies.\n\n"All those posters saying we stole this from the armory..." He shakes his head. "Nah. We stole all this from Bastion. From the keep of Lord Commander Reinald Storme himself. We're waiting around to see whether he'll purchase our silence. Those mountains to the north of the Westguard are awfully enticing."
...Interesting. And good to know.
Blackmail? Not on my watch.
Oh, that's all this is about? Fine.
The dwarves consider you for a long moment of tense silence before their leader shrugs.\n\n"Is there anything else?" he asks impatiently. "We need to be on our way before nightfall."
Are you willing to trade some of what you have?
At the very first hint of a threat, the dwarves raise their weapons again. The leader grins as he pulls his axe free.\n\n"And what exactly are you going to do about it?"
Silence you permanently. Attack!
No. We'll be on our way.
...Fine. Stand down.

As you all fall back from the dwarves, they continue packing everything up and start on their way again. Before you are too far away you hear the leader shout about laying low for a while, there not being any rush.\n\nIt's unlikely you will find them again.
I do hope Reinald knows how to handle this.
At least they are no real threat.
Your company follows your command without question, grabbing the crates of ores as well before they head back towards your tower.

Despite being outmatched, the Granite Dwarves fight a good, skilled fight and manage to eek out a victory.

While the last of your soldiers are killed, the leader starts giving orders for the supplies they have stolen to be heaved away.

"Lay low for a while, lads!" he shouts. "We're in no rush to finish this."
I doubt we'll ever find them again.

By readying themselves to run as soon as the talking or fighting was done, the Granite Dwarves have made it easier for you to sort through everything they stole.\n\nThe magical items are yours for the taking. Reinald won't miss them, and clearly wouldn't want any of this to come to light anyway. The question is what to do with the ores meant for the weapon smithy.
Take just the magical supplies. We'll return the rest.
Take it all. They'll never know.

The leader takes a long look at the supplies being lifted up out of the small pit they had been hidden in, scratching his beard in thought.\n\n"Aye," he says after a moment. "We took much. For the right price you can have a small amount of it. We'll still be able to do what we're here to do."
I'll take those potions.
I'll take those glyph ores.
I'll take the captured souls.
Hmm. Actually, this isn't worth the cost.
A pleasure doing business with you.

The leader whistles to his colleagues to stop what they're doing and pull what you've asked for out first, making the exchange quickly and easily.\n\n"Now, if you don't mind, we're going to be on our way," he tells you. "Don't expect to see us again - we'll do a much better job at hiding this time."

The guards at this watch tower are surprised to see your troops rolling carts of ores up to their door. You explain how you found the ores in the possession of granite dwarves and they are grateful to have them returned, offering you a bounty for your work.
I am glad to have helped.
They said that Lord Reinald is a mage.

The guard captain laughs at the very suggestion of it.\n\n"How awkward would that be?" he asks. "His magic-hating brother rules these lands. I expect he would have to be very careful to hide it! No one is that careful."
... Certainly.
Of course. It is just speculation.
Added promotion: [unitpromotion]{what}[/]
Deals [malus]5[/] [dmg_death][mDeath][/] damage at the start of the units turn.
Unit loses [malus]-1[/] [mFocus] at the start of their turn.\n
Will revive [turns]{UnitModifiers.SelfRevive.AmountOfTurns}[/][mTurns] after dying
This unit [malus]cannot[/] use abilities that cost [mFocus].
Unit loses all Actions at the start of its next turn.

You are checking in on a company in the Westguard, just breaking camp for the day, when around you the wildlife suddenly stirs. A number of horrific roars go up and your troops are startled.\n\nTrolls! They must have come down from the mountains and somehow gone unnoticed by the army!
Hurry! Run!
Without enough time to prepare themselves, your company is slain by the brutal monsters. They will eat well tonight.
Grim. Very grim.
Avoiding brutal stomps and powerful backhands from the enormous beasts, your company is triumphant against the trolls.
Well fought, one and all!
Have the bodies taken to a watch tower for report.
Trolls in the Westguard

The watch tower's guard captain doesn't seem awfully surprised that you are delivering a number of troll corpses to her, venting as she hands you your reward.\n\n"We've heard rumors that some have made it past the border line," she says. "As if Granite Dwarves and orcs weren't enough... we need more support and we need it quickly, else the Westguard will be fraught with danger."
We'll stay on the look out then.
Revive a random unit each round.
Revive a random unit as a [unit][mUnit] {what}[/] each round.
All skills cost no [mFocus].
Graduate Mage
Let me buy some of the fruits of your labor.
The stone-faced dward shrugs "Doubt you can afford much, but we can't carry it all anyway, so here you go.
Better than nothing.
You know what, I think I will take it all.
Offer to help them with your magic.

You show them how your control of the earth can ease everyone's work and allow you to harvest the sky iron safely instead of risking the crumbling walls and falling ceilings.\n\nThe grateful men are happy to share their prize and sing your praises.
Peaceful and profitable.

You are accompanying some of your troops through the Westguard when scouts return to the party with news that a group of Westguard soldiers are fighting trolls nearby.\n\n"There are too many trolls for the army to deal with them effectively," the scout tells you. "Your orders?"
Leave them be. This isn’t our concern.
We should help them! Call the attack!
I will confuse the trolls before we strike.

As your troops move into position to attack, you bend your will to the befuddlement and vexation of the trolls. You see them becoming riled up, focusing less on the Westguard soldiers and simply crashing around, wandering what is going on.
Ah! They are still too strong. Fall back.

With the monsters dead the wounded captain comes to you, looking at the state of your soldiers as well.\n\n"The Westguard thanks you for your service," she says. "Being in the field, we don't have access to the bounties we'd usually give for such acts. Instead, perhaps we may do some training for you? Not that you cannot hold your own. We know out here better than most - every little helps."
Thank you.

The trolls don't differentiate between your troops and those of the Westguard as they stampede through everything that stands in their way.\n\nBoth companies are utterly destroyed, leaving the Westguard just that little less protected for the time being.
That did not go according to plan.

With a rasping laugh the voice replies: "I have been watching your progress and I sense the fire of your ambition. You are not the first to perish in that fire. Stay away from your master's path or you may find yourself sharing his fate."
Wait, what do you know of his end?
Only that it was painful...\n\nAnd with that the orcish mage and his beasts vanish into the forest again.
Did he kill my master?

You are awash in the glow of the Allfire’s power, flowing all around you through the crystal chamber.\n\nWith a blinding and distracting flash, a fiery circle appears not far away and an army marches from it. The Circle have sent their minions to stop you.
Let them try!
A voice like a giant wolf echoes in the tower.\n\n"You have proven to be braver and hardier than I thought. I admire your tenacity. I will tell the Circle you are a worthy opponent."
So...this was a test?

Of sorts. I wanted to see if you had what it takes to become one of us. You do, mageling. You have proven your power in besting my servants and taking one of my towers. The battlefield is yours and you can claim your prize.
Thank you, I guess?
The Lenya Harvest
The Last Resort
Prowling Wildlife
The Magic of Southwatch
Foreboding Danger
A kingdom for a mount
Bringing home the miners
Howling in the Night
Spring Cleaning
Ghostly Problems
For the Banner
The Seal to Approve
Taxing Endeavors
The Ruined Tower
Village Gossip
A Test Of Courage
Water Under the Bridge
The Charmers in Our Midst
An Unusual Prize
Exceptional Tastes
Revenge Upstream
Gone Too Far
Undermining Threats
Killing Southwatch Demons
Until We Mead Again
New Threats Arise
The Conclave
Mining Your Own Business
A Brother's Cry For Help
The Griffon Trainer
The Griffon Trainer
Lost and found
All {who} units in [mDomain] gain:
own
enemy
A howling in the night lets you rise from your slumber. Against the blood red moon, you see shapes of large beasts approaching from afar.\n\nA dark, rasping voice says "Let the hunt begin!".
This sounds like Gor's doing.
What do you know of his fate?

The bizarre corpse continues in a screeching strained voice: "He met the end of all living things, lost in oblivion. Do not forget this lesson lest you suffer it."\n\nWith a twist of the masked figures' hand the life vanishes from the animated corpse and it clutters to the ground like a puppet with its strings cut. Without another glance at you or the sack of bones on the ground, the masked figure steps into a dark mist and vanishes.
This one is a little scary.

One of the mangled corpses stands up and gurgles: "You think you bested me? This is merely one of the many places I reside. You have managed to decimate my horde...I will simply make more of them to fill my ranks."

The dead raises a rotten arm, pointing at you: "The others in the Circle fear you, and rightly so. I will let them know of the power you displayed. But do not for a minute think, you can truly face me and survive."

With an inhuman sigh the corpse crumbles on itself and Hokan's presence has left.
One day we shall meet eye to eye, necromancer. Then we will see...
Wait
Set this stack to wait until next turn.
Sleep
Set this stack to sleep until you give it a new command.
Collect and Research {Amount} Spells
[malus]Conflicted[/]

She stifles a small giggle. "Oh, you will find me much, much more amenable than the others, I assure you. I must say, I am impressed how far you have already come on your own, but I'm sure you could use a friend to help you navigate the challenges before you? Who knows, if we get to know each other really well, maybe I can teach you a thing or two. Just having met me must be so much of an inspiration already."\n\n
It certainly is most...enticing.
I can't say I am impressed.
I thank you for your gracious offer.

Her eyes seem to glow a little brighter and she offers a radiant smile. "I like an assertive partner, but let's not get ahead of ourselves, dear. In time we shall see how you can win my affection, which I can assure you is much sought after."\n\n"For now, behave yourself and don't get in my way and I am sure we will get...closer in time."
I will look forward to it.

Her eyes sparkle with anger, but she still smiles at you. "You certainly can start with learning some manners. You don't have many friends amongst the Circle and you would do well not to risk alienating me. I will let you know what you can do to make it up to me."
Let's see what the future brings.
I have no intention to grovel.
My sincerest apology, I spoke foolishly, Lady Ianna.

She giggles and you swear you hear the sound of small bells ringing. "Well, showing a little courtesy to a lady never goes amiss. At least you know how to behave. I am sure you and I will see more of each other in the future."
That would be most pleasing.
And with these words her image vanishes and all that is left is the scented air of a summer rain and flowers.
That was not what I expected.

Her smile fades and she looks at you with disdain. "So you would reject my friendship? I have killed men for less!" she shouts, then gathers herself.\n\n"But you are young and obviously foolish, so I will let this one slide. Think about what you are missing out on and perhaps next time we meet, you will change your tune."

Shortly after Ianna's image vanishes, a giant wolf appears at the foot of your tower, bearing Gor's sign, dropping a message on a piece of hide.\n\n"I never liked that conceited woman. Good to see you stand against her. You have gained my respect."
The Circle certainly lacks unity.

Ianna has not been gone more than a minute when the face of Undergast appears in your mirror. "I see you have rebuffed that woman's advances. I congratulate you on your sound judgement. She is far too frivolous in her affections and I can only warn you to not trust her."
I see, thank you.
What are you implying?
She beams at you, eyes sparkling: "Keep this up and it's going to become very interesting around here. Some fresh blood can really liven things up."
Right...?
I am sure I can make it up to you...later?
I don't want your help.
So sure of yourself? I must say, I have a weak spot for people without false modesty. Very well, I shall speak on your behalf.
Boring, but I will take it as a gesture of your adolation. At least you tried.
And she is gone again...
How quaint. But I will take it as a symbol of your adolation. At least you tried.
And she is gone again...
And she is gone again...
