Staggered
We are not quite ready yet.
Off we go then.

He strokes his red beard in thought for a moment. "Scratches. And some kind of... shriek? Growl? It's hard to describe. I can guide you down to where we first started hearing it, but then you're on your own. Please kill any vermin you find, so I can send in my miners with a clean conscience."
Cross first and reinforce the bridge.

He takes the offered drink and hands out bowls to everyone.

"What a wonderful trade! This is fine stuff! It reminds me of the bottle my brothers brought me, from the cave not far from here! But this is even better!"

He soon falls asleep, bottle and stuffed animal hugged tightly to his body.
Maybe we should go looking for this cave.
Now, kill him!
The shaggy pony and its dwarven rider appear in front of your tower once more.\n\n"You can send me away again but I will simply return. Spare us both the effort and hear me out!" Kelgrun shouts.
I said go away and I mean it.
Very well. What is it?

That is most unfortunate. I am sure the king will be sad to hear of your lack of interest in aiding the Highmark,” the mouth says curtly. “Should you change your mind, go to our fair city’s dwarven gate. Farewell.\n\nWith that, it disappears.
Pompous ass. I will not be made a tool of.

Indeed. For peace in the Highmark! I am sure the king will value your services.

The dwarves have barricaded themselves in but perhaps you can find a way to approach them. Best of luck.

With that, the mouth vanishes.
Off to Sevenkeeps then.
Every [bonus]{when}[/] round(s) [statuseffect]{what}[/] will be applied to all valid units.
Multiple boosts do not stack.

As you enter Uram Gor’s old city hall, a group of heavily armored dwarves blocks your path. Their armor is nicked and dented and they look exhausted. One of them mutters: “They don’t look like demons, at least.”

Ignoring that, another aims a crossbow at you and steps forward as more dwarves come into the entry hall behind them.

“Stop right there, strangers! What brings you to this realm? We have claimed it by authority of the King of Underhall!”
Krogar says you need our help?
Lay down your weapons. We mean no harm.
We have come to trade.
Is that so? the dwarf snorts derisively. "Well, as you can see our shop is closed at present. With the undead and demons roaming our streets, we have no time to indulge in trading."
Well then, I will offer what aid I can.
That's what that cursed ghost said before it sucked the life our of my brother, Drar! May Niethalf keep your soul.”\n\nHe refocuses his crossbow and says: “Walk away now and I won't shoot you.
I assure you we can be trusted.

The dwarf eyes your banner.\n\n"Hmm, maybe, maybe not. If you want to earn our trust - we have had a hard time drawing water since the undead took back the well. If you rid us of the damned creatures, it would go a long way."
We shall try.
Consider it done.

With the ghosts around the well gone, a small contingent of dwarven engineers gets to work on it and others carry their dead away to bury.

The dwarf from the city hall approaches you with a respectful nod.

“You’ve done a proper job here, I’ll admit. I didn’t trust you at first, but you’ve proven yourself. Our expedition could use your help.”

The dwarf's eyes light up.

"We can use stout warriors indeed. If you are offering aid, we would gladly accept! Our expedition here has met some setbacks. 

At present, we have had a hard time drawing water - the undead have taken back the well. If you rid us of the damned creatures, it would go a long way."

The dwarves look at you expectantly.
We will give our best.
We shall see.
Do the monsters in the city recognize this claim?
I will not be insulted in my own hall. Get out! the dwarf growls. "Walk away, before I lose my patience!"
Make me, dwarf.
The dwarves make short work of your company.
Maybe not the best approach.
You slaughter the guards and sack the place.\n\nYou are gone before their reinforcements arrive but are still close enough to hear angry horns blow out across the city.
A lucrative endeavor. Now best be off.
The Outpost
Free the Well

The well the dwarf spoke of sits on a patch of grass in a park, shaded by an old tree. The lush green looks very out of place and has a disconcerting, sweet smell to it.\n\nThe place is riddled with dwarven corpses. You can make out translucent shapes floating about, circling the well as if in some macabre procession. The sickly sweet air seems to thicken around them and a wailing noise comes from the well.
Try to speak to them.
Those here who are dead, I greet you.
I will ward a path to the well.
Though only temporarily, you manage to hold the ghosts back, allowing you to reach the well and investigate the strange wailing.
Depart ghosts! Give me access to this well!
The undead look at all of you, then wordlessly part to create a corridor to the well - the source of the strange keening noises.
Investigate the noise.
Look inside the well.

Deep down in the well you see a white figure with green, flowing hair that seems to float on the water. A dwarven woman. Her cries and wails echo up the well’s walls.\n\nThe keening seems to draw you closer and the ghosts are surrounding you too.
Your soul is mine now!
I banish you from this realm!
The ghostly wails only seem to get louder as she slowly rises up from the bottom of the well, her black eyes fixed upon you.\n\nA fight seems inevitable now.

With a terrible cry and a shrieked curse, the ghostly figure is banished from the well, her cries lingering in all your ears.\n\nThough the rest of the ghosts silently disperse, your company is harrowed by the call and it weighs on their minds heavily as you leave.
At least we have freed the well.

As fast as you can, you cast the necessary enchantments to catch her soul and bind it to your service.\n\nWith a shriek of protest, she is ripped from the well. The undead around you suddenly hesitate, then slowly disperse without so much as a whisper.
You have met your match, banshee.
Help with what exactly?

The dwarf hesitates a moment before saying: “You see, we’re here to open a path to the Fireforge for the King of Underhall. But so far, we’ve not found the keys. My expedition has lost many good dwarves to creatures roaming the city. We were barely able to establish our base camp.\n\nBetween the undead and the demons, we can’t search for the key’s location. Every step forward is met with two steps back. My men are exhausted. But… we cannot return empty handed. We’ll die here, if we can’t succeed.”
You are definitely in need of help.

“Aye,” he replies. “It pains me, but I can’t let my pride get in the way of duty. We’re just studying now the old dwarven writings collected in the city hall. Hopefully that reveals the Fireforge secrets. But until we can make use of it, perhaps you can help us clear the ruins, so our excavators can dig through them?\n\nJust come to the old hall and they’ll tell you what needs doing. And thank you, again, for your help. It won’t go unrewarded.”
Thank you for your generosity.
Is that really the full measure of your gratitude?
The dwarf grumbles: “Of course, of course. I meant to give you this as well. But I must be off. We shall meet in the hall.”
Until then.
“What? You’re insulting my gifts? I’m grateful, not stupid.” His beard bristles. “You’ll get more when you’ve earned it. Come to the hall and we’ll talk.”\n\nWith that, he stomps off again.
Dwarves. So easily offended.

Corrosion

Tar Bomb

Removes [skill]Guard[/] Stance from each {targettype} unit in {aoe} around a position in {range}.
By tormenting a soul before the act of necromancy, its powers can be greatly increased. Accidentally, doing the same to ones slaves has a similar affect.
You dispel the unholy magic surrounding the dead necromancer and continue towards the stone.
The goblins stop their screaming just long enough to stare at you, then fall over one another trying to flee the camp.
Don't let them go.
Let them flee.
Uram Gor

According to the latest reports, tensions are rising in Estwal. It has become a contested strip of land, by the orcs of the Gate of Swords and the dwarves of Underhall.\n\nThe Middle Mountains have always seen conflict of some kind but now both parties are after the same thing it seems – reclaiming the Fireforge.
I should look into this conflict.

You flip through a few books in your master’s library.\n\n‘Built into the volcano in the Middle Mountains, the Fireforge is known both for its dangers and the great output of glorious weapons and artifacts. Demons are a constant threat - the magic that weaves through the Fireforge is old and draws many close. Only the mightiest dwarven smiths are able to breathe life into the ores and metals that make up the inventory...’
Rivalry - Dwarves
Rivalry - Orcs
Fireforge? Where have I heard that before?

The smell of smoke and the occasional dwarven shout draws you close to a fortified camp. They are constructing weapons of siege, preparing moles for battle and sharpening their blades.

They barely acknowledge your arrival, utterly focused on their preparations. Whatever they are setting out to face, it will be a mighty battle. But a dark haired man steps up to you, scratching his bearded cheek.

“You lost, mage?”
What are you preparing against, pray tell?

“We’re readying an attack against these rotten orcs! They’re trying to claim our birthright for themselves! Thinking they can simply take the Fireforge without repercussions… But we will not let them put so much as a foot into Uram Gor!”

His speech gets louder and louder and when it ends, dwarves all around erupt with battle cries and cheers.

“Will you join us? A few extra hands would not go amiss in the task.”
A horn blows at your approach and the camp bustles with movement. Dwarves ready their weapons with much shouting. The first crossbows fire with a hiss.

More cheers sound. From somewhere, you even see a helmet fly into the air.\n\n“That is ground of you,” their leader says. “We are planning to encircle them. Here. Take our earthshaper into your ranks. We’ll attack at sundown. Make sure to be ready and in position at their camp by then.”
With pleasure.
When you arrive, the orcs are already riled up, pounding their fists against their chests and chanting many a battle song.

Growling wargs prowl the grounds of the orc camp. Most are already wearing harnesses as their masters busy themselves with preparing war paints and donning armor. One of the wargs must have smelled you, for it turns in your direction with a deep, throaty growl.

“Who goes there? Show yourself, coward!”

A female orc steps up, her right arm mangled with battle scars.
At ease. I only want to know why you’re here.

Nazgri’s expression turns from disbelief to amusement and she begins to laugh.

“I did not realize how bloodthirsty the likes of you could truly be. So be it then. Join us – at a cost. I do not trust you. If you would take one of mine into your ranks, we may keep an eye on you.

We meet at the dwarven camp at sundown. Be there. And do not think of running. My wargs have your scent and I promise they are much faster.”
We will not disappoint you.
The heavy cart is quickly taken and pulled away by a few dwarves.\n\n"Oh, bless you! That is great news indeed!" After giving a few commands, Krogar raises a questioning eyebrow. "Anything else?"

When the fighting ends, the ground is painted red with the blood of orcs.\n\nGoing through their camp, you realize they were woefully unprepared for their journey. By the state of their camp and the rather unscathed orcs, you judge them to be younglings trying to prove themselves to their clan, or perhaps simply finding their way in the world.
The dwarves fight hard but they did not expect to defend against a strategist such as you. Now, they lie slain and your troops can empty their pockets with ease.

Orc banners flutter and crack in the wind. Before long, you hear dwarven warning cries ring out across the camp and a deep horn reverberates from the mountains.\n\nNazgri, the chieftain of the small orc tribe, has led her group around the camp. They are chanting battle cries too, their clubs pummeling the wooden palisade.

Hemrig, the leader of the dwarven outpost, has already led his soldiers around the camp.\n\nThe dwarves are well camouflaged in their furs but the orcs are clearly suspecting an attack. Within the hour, guards find scouts and fighting breaks out, drums beating the orcs into a battle frenzy.

Enemies are melding with one of your Allfire nodes!
{what} is being destroyed.
{what} is being pillaged.
{what} is being captured.
{what} is being melded.
Careful. You wouldn’t want to offend a mage, would you?
The dwarf considers this for a moment, then nods solemnly. "Course not. Pardon my language. Hemrig is my name. At your service."
That's better. What are you doing here?

The orcs celebrate their victory with singing and drum beats. Some cut the dwarves’ throats and collect the blood in a large bowl in a sacrifice to Zarach, the renegade Guardian.\n\n“Good fight! Now we can build our outpost and from there march on the Fireforge!” With a click of her tongue, Nazgri tosses a leather-wrapped package to you. “Your reward. Come back if you ever feel like you need more of us in your ranks. This time, for coins though.”

The old city hall is guarded by a group of dwarves sporting heavy crossbows. As you approach, a grizzled veteran in a large, horned helmet, one of the horns snapped, steps forward.

“You’re here to help? Grand!

We received a bunch of new recruits from Estwal. They’re manning one of the new watchtowers but the lackbeards are scared to patrol the streets ‘cause of the skelly riders.

I have no time to drill them proper so I need your help.”
Do you expect me to do the training for you?

As you approach the dwarven hold’s main hall, a group of burned and singed warriors trudge into it as well.

Their commander, wisps of smoke still rising from his beard, loudly complains to some of the craftsmen waiting in the hall:

“There is no way we’re getting to those damned demons! We couldn’t even get close before our beards started burning! And then they belched up those bloody fireballs! Keep your rewards! It’s not worth it!”
Rewards?
You have this all wrong. The forge is mine.
We will stand with you!
Let me think about this. We'll return.

She draws her eyebrows up as she lets out a somewhat grim smirk.

“Why would I tell you anything, mage? I have no reason to fear you - nor do you carry anything of value to me.”

The orcs are slowly gathering, all looking at you darkly and holding their weapons cautiously ready.
We could help you. If our interest align.
I can give you a reason to fear me, if you wish.

She raises a fist to stop those around her shouting profanities at you.

“I am Nazgri, the leader of this war band. We want to build a base, here in Estwal, so that one day we may claim the Fireforge of Uram Gor.

But the dwarves here still do not understand their danger. If they will not stand down, we will teach them to. So, what? Will you join us?”

Her face has grown more sinister, almost challenging you to say no.

The dwarves erupt into cheers when the fighting ends. Hemrig approaches you with a heavy burlap sack, dropping it at your feet.\n\n“This was a monumental success! That’ll show the orcs not to screw with us!” He wipes at his forehead and grins. “And the Fireforge is safe again. Thank you! Don’t forget to take this with you!”
This concludes our agreement then. Good luck.
Drink Potion of Firebreathing
The villagers nod their thanks. "May the gods bless you on this journey. And may they give you the strength to do right by us."

The ground beneath your troops suddenly sinks and the stench of decay wafts up from under a thick layer of ash.\n\nThat is when you realize you are not walking on solid ground at all, but the decaying remains of something very large.
Clear the ash away!

The trolls celebrate your collective victory by drumming their chests with their bare fists and crying out in loud, guttural howls.

“At last! Regan Gor is freed! You have given us our homes! May Mugwa smile upon you forever. It was an honor to fight by your side.”

Not long later, the trolls leave to reclaim their homesteads from the last undead in the region.
Hokan's Soulforge

The forge is built like a fortress and more well fortified than most in Fiara. The moment you step up to the towering stone structure, soldiers start preparing to fire crossbows on the parapets.

The guards at the gate approach too, weapons at the ready.

“Not a step closer, mage! Unless you want to turn your troops into pin cushions.”
The large creatures burst forth from hiding, charging the soldiers racing from the forge. The poor souls never know what hit them, flying off in every direction before your company even catches up.

You dispatch the gate guards, breaking through their ranks like a battering ram.\n\nThough your troops have already fought hard and without pause, more soldiers are already descending on them from inside the forge.

You crest a hill and see orcs trying to hunt a family of bears. As you watch, one of the orcs grabs a cub by its hind legs. When it cries for help, the mother turns and thrashes at the orc, pushing it back into the snow.
Kill the bears!

The dark ruin now lies empty and silent. Berenil's ghost is no longer imprisoned here.

As you approach, the shrieking fury of Berenil's ghost pushes you back. "You freed him, you fool! Now he is liberated while we remain imprisoned forever. You have heaped more misery on us!"\n\nHer wailing causes a searing pain in your banner's mind.
Rest in peace, Berenil.
Harvesting plants yields many useful ingredients, not just for alchemists.
Don't know what to do next? Look for a [adventure_main][ifame:c] Main Adventure[/] to tackle or consult your Grimoire for more goals.
Mining ore veins will grant you precious metals and potentially gems.
Circle mages don't like it when you trespass into their [mDomain].
Take a Sip
Drunk
Restore up to {MoraleChangeValue} [mWillpower] of target unit.
What a spectacle. Let's watch.
Trekking through Estwal you hear heavy footfalls and shouts, both muffled by the snow. The wind carries away all words, but it certainly sounds like both humanoid and bestial cries.
Up this incline we’ll have a better view.
Blood in the snow... Follow the trail!
Over there! A camp!
Ignoring the noise, you investigate the camp to find a couple of thin blankets, some strewn rations and bones.
Take it all before we leave.
Maybe they need help. Go! Towards the noise!
As you leave the small encampment behind, you see orcs hunting a family of bears further up the mountains. It must have been their sleeping stead.
Hurry! Before they see us.
The animals are heartier than you expected. It is no wonder the orcs were having so much trouble.
You corner the bears and kill them one by one.\n\nWhen the fighting is done, you find the orcs watching you warily.
Why were you hunting those bears?
The orcs are already in the midst of battle and, no matter how hard you try, they will not be stopped.
This did not work out how I thought it would...

The mother seems to understand that you are defending her cubs. When the threat at hand is dealt with, she nudges at you and turns to leave.\n\nThe largest of the cubs doesn’t follow its pack when they run off through the snow. It seems your deeds have won you a new companion.
Onwards then. Come with us.

“We came with a war band to establish an outpost here.” The orcs shuffle and shiver in the cold.\n\n“But we were separated. We need these pelts. Leave them to us and we’ll give you some of the rare treasures we’ve found on our travels.”

You watch the fight with great interest.\n\nFor a few moments, the bears hold the upper hand, but one of the orc manages to drive a sharpened stick through the mother’s heart. From then on, it is quickly resolved, though the orcs pay a heavy price for their victory.
Now! Kill the orcs!
Now! Kill the bears!

The large bear fights ferociously, even bravely, to protect her cubs and the orcs are slain one after the other. Still aggravated and incredibly hurt, the bear sniffs the air and urges her cubs onwards.
There is nothing more to see. Let's go.
Best hurry, otherwise we’ll be next.
You stop when the snow is drenched red from the onslaught. Orc skins and bear hides plaster the frozen grounds alike.
That concludes this fight. We leave.

“The pelts,” one of them answers. They look at your soldiers, carefully weighing their options.\n\n“We need them. We’ve been separated from the war band - this is about survival. Leave the pelts to us and we’ll give you the rest. There are some rare things we found.”
Time for us to leave.

Your troops are turning to leave when one of the orcs calls after you: “The pelts! Leave them to us!”

It is neither a question, nor a threat. Merely an inquiry.

“We will pay you for them.”

The relief of the orcs is almost palpable. They take the pelts with great care and toss you a bundle in return.

"You are a good chieftain. Zarach will watch over you."

With that they leave.
Curious group. Time to leave.
What are you doing here in Estwal?
The orcs think for a moment, discussing it among themselves before replying: “You fight well. We will stand with you.”
It is settled then. Let's leave.
Fine. You can have them.
Instead how about you join me?
No way. We are leaving.
Look out! Danger could be close by.

When the ash is cleared, you see the mangled, bloodied and completely gutted corpse of a troll. From the marks on the body and the brutality with which it has been killed, you suspect the work of demons.\n\nMassacred in such cruel manner, there is little to be gained from the corpse: A few pieces of meat and a handful of brittle bones.
Fresh ash is ever falling from Regan Gor, covering any tracks and making it near impossible to discern the direction of the possible danger.
I want to know what died here. Clear the ash.
I can track it magically.

A little further down the path you see a dark shape. Right before your eyes, a demon is stalking the mountain range.\n\nIn it’s wake, you see the glimmer of something brightly visible against the dark ground.
Souls! Let's gather them.
Uncover what it killed. I want to have a look at that.
We're leaving, but be careful.
Fairy Wings
Once a week, visiting units will be able to <nobr>[statuseffect][ifly:c] Fly[/]</nobr> for a short time.
As the ground shifts under them, the other moles slip and slide, losing ground. Your mole finds its way through the small earthquake, bounding into the lead at the top of the hill.
Your mole rushes under the pass with no care. As icicles fall onto it, they shatter against the magical shield you subtly put up. As other moles slow behind it, your pick dashes into first place.
You split your focus masterfully to share the path forward with your mole and rider. As others hesitate or back track to find the right path through, they surge forwards like it is nothing.
Temporarily grants: [unitpromotion]{what}[/]

column1: #Restore Focus Life And Post Combat Revive Skill.Tooltip.Name.Loca
column2: Use Scroll of Restoration
Scroll of Restoration
For a while now, you have heard noises of battle reverberating through the region.\n\nAll of a sudden, those same noises are now approaching you, getting louder with each passing moment.
Quick, hide in that alcove!
Prepare to face whatever this is!

Trolls and undead come into view, clutching at each other in a desperate and vicious fight. You hear their grunting and gnashing of teeth.\n\nThe trolls are undoubtedly the stronger fighters but are greatly outnumbered. It seems only a matter of time until they are defeated.

A group of trolls stumble towards you, surrounded by the undead. They are entwined in a ferocious fight. As you ordered your troops to stand ready, they are easily spotted.

“Help! Please!” A troll calls out to you, desperation thick in his voice.

One of the undead rears up, cackling dryling and shouting: “Stay out of this, mage! This does not concern you!” before sinking its claws into the troll’s flesh.
Support the trolls!
Charge! Help those undead!
Hold posiiton! Do not interfere!

The undead seem to relish tearing through the trolls and their imminent success. With that done, they turn on you.\n\n“What will it be now?” a voice cries out from the group. “Do you wish to fight as well?”
Indeed we do. Charge!
Not at all. We will go.
Another cackle echoes from an undead maw. You quickly order the retreat, making certain that the monsters cannot fall on you from behind.

You watch with growing horror as the undead tear through the trolls, ripping them into tiny pieces to drench the earth beneath them with blood and guts.\n\nTheir hunger for violence satiated, they leave without looking back.
That was quite a close call.

You stand with the undead, drawing one group of trolls away from them to make their fight a true bloodbath that they relish.\n\nWhen the fighting is over, they give you a final glance before going on their way. From their behavior, it seems you are not dangerous enough for them to consider committing to another engagement.
Weakened though they are, the trolls find enough strength to tear your troops apart, finally falling to the undead shortly afterwards.
What a gruesome battle.
The undead are such a force that neither you nor the trolls can stand against them. Within moments, the battle is decided against you.
I regret interfering.

You direct some of the undead away from the trolls, making both groups much easier to deal with. With a combined effort, the fight goes in your favor.\n\nOnce it is over, the trolls collapse, slowly catching their breaths and tending to their wounds.
That is at least something. We better leave.
What was all this about?
Where did they come from?

It takes a while for them to formulate an answer, as exhausted as they are.\n\n“They come from the forge, where Hokan creates his wandering nightmares. Hollow Ones, he calls them. They’re spreading all across the mountains – our homes.”
We freed the forge already.
Hokan the Circle mage?

Lore asks you to join him for the last steps of his project. You watch as he measures out the exact amount of powder, slowly sifts it into a rounded shell and corks it closed.\n\n"What I'm holding now is only a thumb's worth. It is revolutionary! For mining, clearing paths and tunneling!"
Show me.
Throw Potion of Fear
Potion of Fear
Are they related perhaps?
Good to know, thanks.
What an odd mirage.
Under Construction

The trolls nod.\n\n“We plan to attack the forge and reclaim our homes,” one tells you. “If you wish to stand with us, meet us there. There are others that would join too, if asked. If you find them, spread the word. Tell them Mugwa has sent you.”
Great relief washes over the trolls.\n\n"Then you are a true friend to the trolls. We collected weapons and the likes to use in the battle. You can have this. Mugwa watch over you, mage."
We already secured more help. See you at the forge.
We will keep our eyes open and meet you there.
Thank you. That is much appreciated.
We didn't do it for you but... okay.
Mugwa's Support
Scroll of Restoration

The deep chanting that reverberates across the mountains draws you to a large encampment.

Trolls have gathered here, around a carved stone idol. They are praying before it, rocking from side to side. You can’t quite make out what they are saying.

The camp itself is in shambles, as though taken apart by a great storm and thrown back down to earth haphazardly.
Move closer. Quietly.
“Give us a sign, Mugwa. Provide, Mugwa. We trust in you, Mugwa.”\n\nThese sentences are repeated over and over, voices rising and falling in a lulling rhythm.
What are you praying for?
Let's kill them now. It will be easy.
The trolls fall like flies and the battle is quick. Looking through their camp, you find little of value or interest.
At least they have been dealt with now.
When the fighting is through, you are approached by a troll. It seems they had taken post on a nearby plateau, overlooking your actions eagerly.\n\n"A wonderful fight," they tell you.
Indeed it was.
Greetings! Pray tell, what are you doing?

The sudden silence that surrounds you as they stop chanting one by one is almost deafening.

Out of it, one troll shouts: “Mugwa has spoken! Welcome, strangers. It is good you have finally come!”

With that, the trolls all around begin to move, preparing meals, clearing away rubble and rebuilding their homes.
You were expecting us?

We have prayed to Mugwa for a sign. For help. And now here you are.

It is clear the trolls do not see you as a threat, but rather a friend. 

"Our very existence is in danger. Undead have come and destroyed most of our homes. We have lost many and now we do not have the strength to defend ourselves. Help us. Kill the undead and you have our loyalty."

The troll gestures towards a crudely carved stone statue, decorated with whatever the trolls have been able to find – all ranging from hair to coins and bones.\n\n“Mugwa watches over all trolls. Our Guardian. If we are in need, Mugwa provides.”
And what did Mugwa tell you?
“Mugwa has sent you, yes. But you have not proven yourself to Mugwa yet.”
Then let’s see how your false god protects you. Charge them!
I see. Then I will do so now.
It seems this was the wrong choice...
The trolls beat you down without a struggle, tearing through your units in but a few moments.
Who is Mugwa?
You have already said I was sent by Mugwa...
I will see what I can do.

On your way towards the undead, you pass a tiny shrine that could have been created by either trolls or humans.

It is nothing more than three statues no larger than a hand in the deep crack of a boulder. You recognize them as Aonir, Zarach and the false god Mugwa. All shown different signs of wear, which leads you to believe they must have been created years apart.

Praying to one of them could strengthen your troops, but time is pressing. You can already hear the wheezing breaths of the undead. They are closing in with each second.
We will pray to Aonir for guidance.
We will pray to Zarach for guidance.
We will pray to Mugwa for guidance.
It seems neither your strength nor any blessing from any god is enough to help you in this fight.
When our strength returns, we will crush these undead.
They are still too strong! Retreat!
Mugwa did right in choosing you. The troll takes a knee before you. "You have earned our loyalty and trust."
Finally, I have waited for this moment.
Some trolls who were keeping an eye on the situation come to congratulate you.\n\n“You fight bravely,” they say. “We found these while you battled. They shall be yours.”
Thank you. That will come in handy.
We don't need the Guardians’ blessings to fight. Onwards.
Your units have barely stepped away from the shrine when they are surprised by the undead. They must have closed in while you were busy examining the statues.

The trolls join you in prayer, giving you all a sense of unity and security. It does not seem to matter that Mugwa may only ever have been the troll’s fervent dream: the act of communion is what gives you strength.\n\nBut a sudden groaning and clicking makes everyone turn. The undead have cornered you. There is no way to flee now.

During your prayer, you feel rays of light warming your body and soothing your mind. It encompasses not just you, but your troops as well.\n\nBut as you turn to look upon the glow, you see the wall of undead that has closed the distance. Growling and wheezing, they are upon you.

You feel a bubbling sensation that almost burns under your skin. A cold rage spreads through you and your troops, leaving you all lusting for a fight.\n\nLuckily, the first of the undead are already upon you. The stink of rot follows their every step and your heightened senses catch it a hundredfold.
Having seen your fight, the trolls nod their approval.\n\n“Your people trust you. You lead them well into victory.”
Indeed I do.
Unstable
Philo and Mathu'Gar are struggling for control
Unstable
It is unsure if Philo can contain Mathu'Gar

From this vantage point, you can see trolls carrying heavy stones.

One of their kin lies gutted on the ground and the trolls carefully stack stone after stone up to bury them. They exchange no words but the very air seems to thrum with their anger.

You remember the other tribe you met in Regan Gor. They asked you to find more like-minded trolls to move against Hokan’s forge. Maybe these trolls would be willing to join the cause.
What happened to your friend?
They are weak. We can kill them in one blow!
A surge of energy flows back towards you and, for a moment, your magic grows. The stones marking the grave crack under the pressure but do not break. Aside from that, nothing bad seems to happen.
They must have built the grave on a holy sight.

The trolls stop looking for stones and gather round. They are frighteningly large, but your troops stand beside you without batting an eye.\n\nWith a rumbling voice, one of the trolls replies: “My wife. She was killed by roaming monsters. Why do you care, puny one?”
Grave Stones
In the aftermath of the fight, you feel a vibration in the earth, right where the dead troll has been buried. \n\nA slight hum and shifting in the air tells you there is magic here to be tapped into.
I shall do so.

Furious, the trolls look at you.

"Who are you to claim such things? You are no friend nor kin of this tribe!"

Most are now grabbing for clubs and other weapons, or even the spare stones they already have in hand.
Mugwa sends me.
We met your friends not long ago. They sent us!
We come with a message. The tribes are to gather.
A toast to her, then. To ease the pain.
A sharp, rumbling laugh erupts from their leader.\n\n“You try to deceive us! You think us dumb? You will learn what it means to enrage us!”
Yngrid's Axe
Strong Mind

column1: #Restore Focus Life And Post Combat Revive Skill.Tooltip.Description.Loca
column2: Restore {heal} and refill [mFocus] of an {targettype} unit in {range}.

Mugwa? What is the meaning of this? The trolls look taken aback.

You explain the situation, about other trolls seeking help in attacking the Soulforge and how that could resolve the undead problem.

"So, Mugwa has sent you to help us. Then we will follow the call. For Mugwa!"
To the forge!

The trolls are perplexed by your words and it takes a little coaxing for them to grab the bottles.

For a while you exchange stories. They tell you of how hard life has become with all the undead around and how they have had to split up their resources.

“We hid much across Regan Gor. We can never stay too long in one play now. They always come and plunder and kill.”
Then it is time to fight them! Storm the Soulforge!
With a sudden fervor the trolls agree: “We will meet you there and fight! If you still need resources, make sure to collect whatever you need!”
We will see you there then.

A trader from the Windwall Mountains has come to your tower reporting dangerous demons spreading through the region.\n\n“I even saw a carcass, no older than two days! Those blasted creatures are coming from Regan Gor. If they continue to spread like this, they might just overrun our cities!”
Those are bad tidings.
Bad tidings indeed. I don't know what they want but I can tell you, the noises I heard were unsettling. As if they were fighting something. Or someone.
I will send scouts to Regan Gor.
I don't see how this is any of my concern.

The dwarf gives you a disapproving look.\n\n“We cannot trade metals and ores if the roads are clustered with demons and the undead! If you aren’t willing to help, so be it. But don’t complain to me when you can’t get your hands on ores anymore.”
Thank you for the warning.
Quick, hide! In case they come towards us.

Trolls’ battle cries and deep, guttural growls abruptly start ringing through Regan Gor.\n\nThe fight seems close and could pose a danger to your troops if you don’t get a grip on the situation quickly.
Killshot
Refills all actions on kill
First move one [point_death]Soul[/] from your inventory into the soul slot.

Next add [item]Items[/] from your inventory containing [point_death]<sprite name="elementalpoint">Death[/] essence into the ingredient slots to negate any [point_life]<sprite name="elementalpoint">Life[/] essence remaining in your recipe.
I... I want to follow the tracks first.

Monstrous beasts fight their way through the gap into the chamber, screaming and screeching so loudly that you flinch! They carry something with them, or rather seem to be fighting over it as they escape their confines.
The creatures that now guard the Shaper Ruins chamber have settled down after their initial outburst, lying quiet with whatever it is they were fighting over lying between them.
Liquid Courage
This unit is [bonus]immune[/] to [statuseffect]Mindcontrol[/].

What? No! the dwarf lets out a bellowing laugh. "That would takes ages and we need them to be out on the streets patrolling now! I need you to scrounge up some liquid courage for them. A dozen or so bottles of Finon Beer, or a large keg, should suffice.

There’s an inn close by, infested with demons, that might still hold some of the good stuff. Though, honestly, I don’t care where you get it from as long as you take it to the watch tower!

Will you do that for us? You’ll be paid for your troubles, of course."
Leave it with me.

A group of young dwarves are milling about in front of the tower, sweating in the heat of the city. As they see you, they perk up.

“We were promised something to drink! The bloody heat is making us all parched. How is a dwarf supposed to survive here?

Are you bringing the drinks?”
I am afraid not.

As you approach the watchtower, a group of dwarves surrounds you. They have put down their armor and large stains of sweat mar their shirts.\n\n“No drinks?” they lament. “We were promised something to drink.”
Actually, I have something better.
I am sorry, I can't help you. I will return.

You put the large keg down at their feet and they look at you in astonishment.\n\nThey drink the Finon Beer it produces like it is water in a desert, greedily gulping down the first round and helping themselves to a second.

Aye! a dwarf shouts with a reddened face. "A drink or two more in our bellies will get the old courage rolling all right. Get your tankards, lads! Tonight, we drink!"\n\n"Here! Take these as recompense. We meant to trade them for drinks, but we won't get a better deal than this."
I’m not sure this is what their superiors intended.

The dwarves in the watchtower almost fall over one another to get to the bottles of Finon Beer you set down, quickly smashing the lids and pouring the contents into cups. Cheers go up from the group as they drink it down in big, greedy gulps.\n\nThey don’t stop either, quickly going for a second round.
Dwarf Recruits
The crumbling walls of the old inn house a host of demons, dancing and cantering about. They are so intent on their revelry that they barely notice you approach.
Black Inn
Let me try something first.
Bring down the walls around them.
The walls and roof crack and fall inwards, burying the demons beneath them. Many are crushed by the old stone but those left charge at you, shrieking angrily.

Philo walks into the darkened inn and his form seems to blend seamlessly into the dancing shadows of the demons inside.

You hear a great screeching and shrieks that makes your company cower. When it is over, Philo emerges again with a band of very angry, quite wounded, demons behind him.

"We had an argument." Philo states. "They lost. Now they want revenge."
With the demons slain, you find an entry to the inn’s cellars half buried beneath the rubble. Inside, you find strong caskets lining the walls, all bearing the seal of the dwarven brew masters.
Let's get this to the recruits in the watchtower.
First put one [point_elemental]Ore[/] from your inventory into the ore slot.
Next add [item]Items[/] from your inventory containing [point_elemental]<sprite name="elementalpoint">Elemental[/] into the ingredient slots until you reach the first [tutorial]Threshold[/].
Once you reach the first [tutorial]Threshold[/] you will be able to [item]Craft[/] your first recipe.
Once you have no [point_life]<sprite name="elementalpoint">Life[/] left you will be able to [item]Craft[/] your first recipe.
Add [item]Items[/] from your inventory containing [point_life]<sprite name="elementalpoint">Life[/] into the ingredient slots until you reach the first [tutorial]Threshold[/].
Once you reach the first [tutorial]Threshold[/] you will be able to [item]Craft[/] your first recipe.
[tutorial]Catalyst[/] are rare [item]Items[/] that can greatly boost your alchemical formula or change the rules of creation.\n\nAdding a [tutorial]Catalyst[/] is optional.
No enchantments are active for this battle.
The Tower Expansion

Carefully, you peek into the room. Philo is unconscious on the floor but breathing shallowly. Everywhere you look is black soot and the whole room stinks of sulfur. \n\nCrestfallen, you see the empty soulstone lying on the floor and the occasional flickers of black running over Philo's body. Your experiment has failed.
This must require far more energy. Or perhaps ancient energy...

Hours later, when the boy finally wakes, he looks down at his hands and his eyebrows knit together. 

"It is strange... I can still feel the demon. But... the feeling is muted. Like his energy is right there at my fingertips, but his consious somehow retracted?"

Philo concentrates, reaching out across the room away from you. A dark bolt, shaped like a dagger, shoots forth.

"I-I can control it. I can control it!"
It matters not to me. Now be gone.
Thank you for the warning.

Founded by both humans and elves, Alluvyan is renowned for its elegant elvish architecture and lush gardens. \n\nThe city’s gatherers roam the countryside looking for medicinal and magical ingredients and traveling elves often stay here and bring rare plants from Finon Mir.
I might want to go for a visit.

The dwarven settlement in the Coldmark is a bulwark against those that covet the ore-rich mines of the Windwall Mountains, as well as raiding orcs and trolls. \n\nIts citizens are a hardy breed and renowned mountaineers. Coldmark City is one of the few places other than the capital of Windholme that will trade with outsiders at all.
Worth a visit!

The easternmost city of the Highmark, Audale has long been plagued by incursions.\n\n Protecting the fertile plains of Goldenfields to the west, the city itself is always looking for able warriors to help in its defense. It also offers goods from the surrounding villages and craftspeople of Gillyshire.

The only known orc settlement in the west of Fiara, Orgash’s inhabitants survive a remote and harsh environment.

Despite constant threats from human troops from the north and monsters in the south, Orgash still stands undefeated. 

As the settlement is still being built, the orcs may trade with the occasional peddler for much needed supplies and weapons.
Remarkable.

Sevenkeeps is the capital of the Kingdom of the Highmark and the seat of its king.\n\n The seven towers that protect it are a symbol of safe haven for elves and dwarves, who even retain seats on its council. Famous for its great library and prolific alchemists, Sevenkeeps has long been a power for peace and stability across all Fiara.

Silver Drift Hollow is the mining capital of the Windwall Mountains. 

Ores sparkle in almost every cave and the ground is rich with minerals, giving everything the silver sheen that earned the settlement its name. 

It is mostly inhabited by miners and smiths, but traders come from far and wide to buy ores, armor and weapons.
We should go see it!

The remote town of Connach makes its trade from the trees and animals of the great, surrounding forests. \n\nTheir hounds are much sought after by nobles throughout the Highmark and the town is celebrated for its hunters and trackers.
Let's visit.

Once a proud dwarven city controlling access to the legendary Fireforge, Uram Gor is now abandoned to hordes of undead. 

It is said that greedy humans stole the diamond eyes of a statue of Aonir that watches over the place, bringing a curse down upon it.

Recently, the dwarves have begun excursions into the ruin to establish a base from which to access the Fireforge once again.
Interesting.

Bastion was built and named as a symbol to the Highmark’s strength in protecting it’s northern and western fronts. \n\nIt remains a mighty city, in all regards showcasing the determination of the people who call the Westguard their home. It may not be as big as Sevenkeeps, but it is a masterclass in engineering and architecture.

The dwarven city of Windholme is ancient and formidable, built to form stone tiers of hundreds of battlements, towers, steps, stairways and bridges. Thanks to its solid construction, it has never fallen. \n\nThe city’s houses often have five floors that can all be accessed by several levels and footbridges. It is a true marvel of dwarven masonry.
Scout out those noises but be careful.

As you feared, the battle moves towards you.

The noises you could not identify before are being made by demons – large, fiery fiends with sharp claws and teeth that tear through the trolls’ ranks.

The trolls are retreating but the ground is perilous to navigate, even without having to defend against an enemy at the same time. It looks dire for the trolls, their numbers dwindling with every fresh attack from their opponents.
Stay hidden!

Your troops move carefully towards the noise, evading lava puddles and lose gravel where they can.

Nonetheless, a troll spots you and calls out in fear: “Help! Kill them!”

The demons retort in a throaty language you don’t understand. Then, one of them turns towards you and grins.

“Forget those weaklings. Help us and gain our support!”
I will not risk my soldiers!

The trolls collapse where they stand, slowly caring for their wounds.\n\nWhen one of them finally finds his words, he says: “You have done us a great favor. There is no way to repay this debt than to serve you now. Will you accept?”
Of course! I would be glad to have you.

“You fought well for a measly mortal,” one of the demons calls out. “Let’s see what you are truly capable of!”\n\nWithout further warning, the demons take up fighting stances again, this time turning on you.
They betrayed us! Run!

The demons celebrate their victory with harrowing screams.

As if from nowhere, a horned beast joins them and addresses them in the common speech: “The general calls! We are needed elsewhere. Follow! Regan Gor will soon be ours!”

The others follow suit without question, vanishing behind a ledge.
They are trying to gain control of the Windwall Mountains!

A horned beast steps out from behind a ledge, looking about at his dead brethren. He kicks one to the side, turning them over to take note of every wound you gave them.\n\n“You are formidable,” he says after a while. “I dare say you put our general to shame. I will join you. One of your standing will find good use for one like me, I am sure.”
You will work off your blood debt then.
Fight at the trolls' side!
Fight at the demons' side!
Those vile creatures.
As if I would let you live.
Your general?

The large creature gives an almost comical shrug.\n\n“Don’t worry about them. Judging by your skills, they will mean nothing to you. Besides – they still reside in our realm, managing the prince’s army.”
There is a prince as well?

The beast's eyes turn to slits.\n\n"I will not answer any more questions, mage. Do not concern yourself with matters that are beyond your realm and understanding. Do you wish for a strong warrior or not?"
Or course. Welcome to my ranks.
I will never accept the likes of you!
You do not give the beast enough time to react, striking it down with a bolt of pure magic.
Finally this is dealt with.

The Soulforge, designed and built by the Circle mage Hokan Ashir himself, holds many secrets. No one is allowed entry – there is a mass of soldiers defending it at any given time against any that might attempt a strike.

But the magic you feel all around you brings with it an urge to claim it for yourself. What wonderful things you would be able to do with such a forge.

Amid the soldiers, you see masses of undead wandering the perimeter too. Should you decide to fight your way in, you will have to be prepared to face foes across multiple waves. It will not be easy.
A few more steps and it could be mine.
Free the western citadel from the <nobr>New Purity's</nobr> grasp
Stop the plague threatening fields of gold.
Help a young settlement in the Misty Coast.
Defend against the spider incursion in the southern woods.
Relieve a besieged city in the east.
Earn the trust of the northern dwarven kingdom.
Cleanse the mines of <nobr>Silver Drift Hollow</nobr>.
Ease tensions in the old forest, once inhabited by elves.

When he finds the bowl of paint empty, the apprentice draws a knife. So then, it is not paint at all. He draws the blade along his forearm to continue the glyph. Only a couple of details later, it is done.\n\nWith a rumble and a roar, the ground opens up and creatures clamber forth. Lesser demons! The man lets his arms fall. Even from afar you can see he is exhausted. And when the portal closes, he curses.

The apprentice flinches. He slowly turns and, seeing your robes and banner, immediately relaxes.

“I am doing as I am ordered, stranger,” he tells you. “Assembling an army to storm Hokan’s forge. The streams of undead coming from there must be stopped. Hokan is brewing up something dangerous, I just know it.”

He tilts his head in a challenge.

“I do not wish to fight you. So, if you do not intend to help, then stay out of this.”
Help you? How and why would we do that?

You claim victory over the demonic army.\n\nThe apprentice, weakened as he is by the ritual he performed, lies on the battlefield. A sword or claw must have caught him, as his belly has been torn open.
Search him.
We are ready for this challenge.
Let’s prepare further before trying anything.

It is a perilous situation. There are enough soldiers here to defend the Soulforge for many battles. They won’t be dealt with in only one fight.

Retreating a few steps, you try to assess the situation anew.

Maybe you can find help before trying to storm the forge on your own. Hokan’s undead are sure to have increased unrest for the locals – the trolls and demons of Regan Gor.

Demons swarm the forge’s entrance, pushing back as many opponents as they can. Slashing and biting at with horrifying grins and many an insult, they insulate your company from much of the enemy force.
Trolls! Charge them!
Demons! Charge them!

While you focus on the gate guards, the trolls pick off any reinforcements that might attempt to come to their rescue.\n\nThe fight is quickly over, but already you hear more troops pouring forth from inside the forge.

While you take on the gate guards, the demons charge in and destroy any that try to fall back, as well as several squads of reinforcements. The apprentice shouts commands to aid you in any way possible and the demons deliver.\n\nSoon enough the fight is won, but from within the forge a new wave of troops already comes marching towards you.
Signal the second group of trolls to ready!
Signal the second group of demons to ready!
We have to face them inside! Charge!
Now! Call for the trolls help!
Unit Power
The power of this unit. Used to compare units to each other.
Flee, soldiers! There are too many.

Your spell will hold long enough to keep the civilians safe until the bugs lose interest, you think. At the very least, the large creatures are more interested in tearing the building itself apart for now, giving you plenty of time to run.\n\nThe infestation that Goldenfields has been dealing with for months now has not quite been resolved, it seems.
That alchemist messed up.
No need! Go home.
Now! Call for the demons help!

The last battle finally won, the forge falls silent, much of your energy already spent just to get here.\n\nYou stroll through the empty halls to find masses of chain mail shirts, plate armor, scale armor among many a broken piece. It is a true treasure trove to anyone interested in the art of the smithing.
Hokan will not take this lightly. We best prepare.

Your victory is accompanied by the demons’ other-worldly cries.

The apprentice rushes straight past you into the large halls. You quickly hear a metallic ‘clank’ followed by much cursing and the long hiss of steam escaping a high-pressure chamber.

Returning to you, the apprentice calls the demons off as he shakes his head. Slowly, your reinforcements turn to leave.

“You managed a great deed today,” the apprentice tells you. “I will make sure my master knows.”

With that, he vanishes.

When they have retreated, you hear a slow clap emerge from somewhere in the darkness. Out of the shadows steps the translucent figure of Hokan Ashir.

“What a display of power,” he mocks. “I would have enjoyed it, had you attacked any other mage than me.”

His visage turns frosty, then the illusion vanishes with a loud bang.

A translucent figure suddenly steps from the shadows, glowering at you.\n\n“Trespass and slaughter my guards,” it spits. Hokan Ashir’s voice becomes progressively louder until it booms from every possible direction. “How dare you? How dare you steal from me? How dare you stand against me?! You have opposed me for the final time, mage. Now you will pay!”
Getting more Apprentices

With a growing tower your [hero]<nobr>[iapprentice:c] Apprentice</nobr>[/] cap increases.

You should divert some scouting towards finding one of the rare <nobr>[tutorial]Arcane Academies[/]</nobr> spread throughout the lands.

Only there you will be able to choose another pupil.
Finite Resources

Most resource-providing locations are [tutorial]finite[/] and deplete over time when inside your domain.\n\nMake sure to always scout ahead in time for another good spot to spread out to or achieve control over some rarer [tutorial]non-depletable[/] locations!
City Screen
Each city provides unique services and rewards, available once you reach a high enough [tutorial][ifaction:c] Reputation[/] with it.
Navigate through the different vendors of this city by using the bookmarks on the left.
Select objects by left-clicking [mMouseLeft], confirm actions by right-clicking [mMouseRight].
Most locations that provide income inside your [mDomain] will deplete after a while.
No Valid Target Available
A Demons Call
What in the Guardians’ names are you doing here?

With his mouth agape, the apprentice takes the offered souls.

"You... You have such things at hand? Peculiar."

He shakes himself and starts his ritual anew. Mumbling, muttering and chanting, he draws glyphs on the ground and adds the souls at the right time to infuse the magic. The earth tears itself apart to let an army frightening creatures forth.

"Hahaha it is done!” the apprentice yells. “This army shall march with us and fight along our side! Onwards! Let us take over the forge!"

The apprentice’s mouth works for a few moments, as if his words are stuck between his teeth.

“I… You mean… You did? This is… wonderful news! Wonderful indeed! My master will be happy to hear it!”

Without another word, he shouts an order to the demons and they venture off into the ash.
A strange bird, that one.
The demons fight fiercely until the opportunity arises for the apprentice to order a retreat. Then, they vanish, leaving your dead on the ground for the vultures to feast on.
The Guardians curse you!
We will meet you there.

There are plenty of undead stalking Regan Gor. Killing them will provide you with such souls. I will cast a spell on you to assure that you are able to catch every soul.\n\nHe waits for a nod of approval before weaving a spell around you. It is a very basic form of a soul catcher but it should suffice.
Then we better get started.

Daylight fades and you are about to give up the search, as a glint of blue light amidst the rubble catches your eye. Directing your men towards it, you finally have found what drew you here: The crystal shards.\n\nTired, but triumphant your band carries home the treasure.
Bring them to my tower!
Demonic Armor
Siphon Strength
Can apply [statuseffect]{what}[/] to the user if this attack kills off the enemy.
Applies [statuseffect]{what}[/] to the user if this attack kills off the enemy.
Give Siphon Strength
Available Rooms
Only usable as [unit]Mathu'Gar[/].

The never-ending chant of a man guides you to a clearing.\n\nHe kneels there, on the ground in apprentice’s robes, drawing a glyph with dark, glistening paint. He dips his fingers into the liquid to add a couple more strokes.
If we keep watching I might be able to identify it.
It is a glyph of calling. But calling who?
He is a threat! Kill him and his devils!
This unit is a Demon and has:
Ending your turn

You just ended your turn. Any unit with actions left will enter the [tutorial]Guard Stance[/]. Guarding increases a unit's defenses, makes it control all the hexes around it (instead of just in front of it), and makes it immune to [tutorial]Flanking[/].\n\nUnits also replenish their [tutorial]3 Actions[/] at the end of their turn.
Retaliations

This unit just [tutorial]Retaliated[/] because it was attacked in melee combat.\n\nEach retaliation uses up an [actioncost][iaction:c] action[/], so if a unit retaliates three times it can not further retaliate and won't have any actions left on its own turn.
Use a unit's action bar at the bottom to navigate through its abilities.
Auto Select Unit
Auto select unit during battle on start turn.
We too hunt the Red Shaman! A giant orc in full iron plate mail steps forward. "Hail! I am Therik of the Iron Storm!"
Why do you seek him?
Killing the orcs might not have been politically smart, but it certainly proves to be rewarding.
I bring only news of your end!

Therik collapses to his knees before you, holding himself up by his weapon as he breathes hard and spits blood from his mouth.

"You..." he growls. "You will bring doom upon us all! The... The Red Shaman... cannot..."

His eyes roll up and he hits the dirt with a dull, dead thud.
I care nothing for your doom.
It is all just lies and fever dreams.

The orcs easily overpower you, sending their animals chasing after the survivors and swinging their weapons in triumph.\n\n"Let this be a warning, mage! Don't cross forces you are too weak to handle!"

He grins triumphantly.\n\n"Imagine this! Your army and mine, combined. Marching towards Hokan's Soulforge and finally putting his undead minions to rest for good. We would be unstoppable. The only thing I need is three lost souls. Of a medium quality."
Alright, we are leaving.

You can only do a couple of steps when he calls out: "Help me and I will make you the new owner of the Soulforge."\n\nHe gulps and continues, his voice growing more certain: "If you bring me three lost souls, of a medium quality, I will provide you with another army to stand by your side. Demons. As many as you could wish for to storm the forge."

With the apprentice gone, you hear a voice on the wind.

“Your accomplishment pleases me.”

With a cackle, it is gone again. There is no mistaking Uram the Red, Circle mage.
It seems the man was his apprentice.
You have yourself a deal. Here you are.
Sounds promising. Where do I get such souls?
I don't do dealings with strangers. Good day.
We have already freed the forge.

“I must destroy the mechanism that is creating more of Hokan’s troops. The rest, you can have. Equipment and building alike, I have no further use for either.

And taking into consideration that the forge belongs to Hokan Ashir, I am sure a mage such as yourself will find plenty of use for it.

Do we have a deal?”
And what do I gain from that?
Forging Pacts - Soulhunt
As the apprentice promised, the soul slips from the undead body and you are able to catch it easily.

Your approach does not go unnoticed. The apprentice raises her closed fist and the undead come to stand by her side, weapons at the ready. \n\n"One more step and I will order them to attack!" she warns you.
The undead fall to your troops’ skilled fighting and the magic around you seems to suck the soul from one of them at the last moment.
We must bring them to the apprentice.
You count through your captured souls, just to be sure. Yes. You have found enough.
Leave them for the vultures.

He does not carry any possessions other than a piece of parchment showing the same glyphs he drew on the ground. Without knowing the spell’s words, you will not be able to use it.\n\nHowever, in the parchment’s bottom corner you see a sigil that is vaguely familiar. Uram the Red has marked this page.
So Uram sent him. Interesting.
Choose Your Apprentice
Or

Dying Breath
Let's go there!
We must visit!
We will surprise them with sacred water.
You expertly fling the bottle and it crashes on a sharp boulder right above the undead. The shower of glistening liquid makes them squeal and writhe in pain.
That is one down.
Have you got the souls? The apprentice looks nervous.
I do. Here you are.
I will return once I do.
I do. But I decided to keep them.

That is all we need.

The apprentice starts his ritual anew. He adds the souls to the blood glyphs he is drawing into the earth. With a tearing sound and small earthquake, it bursts open. An army of demons springs forth, this time far more fearsome than before.

"It is done! Now we have the power to take the forge!"
We'll meet you there!
The apprentice's magic is at least effective.
The forge is ours! Huzzah!
The undead have cornered a mountain bear. They are too focused on their current prey to notice your approach.
I can weaken them before the fight.
You concentrate your magic into a searing bolt and let it fly. A dark cloud spreads over the undead and tendrils of pure magic lash out at them. Their cries are like music to your ears.
A croaking groan and hissing reaches your ears.\n\nYou are about to warn your troops to be quiet when the first wretch suddenly appears before your very eyes.
After taming the Primal Elements of Eo, Aonir sent the Guardians to protect his work. To this day they guide and watch over his creation.
The Circle of Mages was established by all nations on Eo to prevent the abuse of magic. Their seat is in the far away city of Mulandir.
The Shaikan are descended from an evil alchemist who mixed his blood with that of a dragon.\nOne of each generation always carries the alchemist's soul and they are thus universally mistrusted.
During the War of the Six Races, the Hybernian Empire fell into ruin and split into the Highmark, Nortander and Empyria.
The Circle discovered the Allfire on the southern continent of Xu in the Citadel of the Shapers.\nIt changed all their members forever.
The Shapers were an ancient race who learned to harness the Allfire and were ultimately corrupted by its power.\nTheir ruins dot the land to this day but cannot be accessed by normal means.
The souls of the dead are taken by the Guardian Hirin to the Mor Duine – the River of Souls. Thus, one can revive lost ones for a while before their souls are gone.
Humans, elves and dwarves are descendants of the Shapers, carrying some of their power inside them. This is why magical talent is widespread among the people.
Orcs settled in the Howling Steppes after the War of the Six Races. Nominally united under the Iron Lord, they remain a quarreling people.
The War of Six Races pitted humans, dwarves and elves against orcs, trolls and dark elves and was ultimately decided by intervention from the Guardians.
Zarach and Nor are renegade Guardians revered by the dark races.

You have tracked down a group of undead you intend to rob of their souls

Their twisted bodies move slowly over a natural bridge between two narrow rivers of lava. The gravel beneath them is giving a little but they press on without flinching.

Soon, they will have reached the other side, venturing further towards the Highmark.
I will dissolve the bridge under their feet.
The gravel sinks into the boiling river, taking the undead with it. The river is not wide enough to burn immediately but one succumbs to the flames and perishes.

You have stalked this group for a few minutes, trying to find a good point to intercept them. Just this moment, a large vulture crosses the sky above and makes one of them turn their heads.\n\nWith a gurgled warning call, your troops are sighted.
You keep the earthshaper. I have no need of them.
We don't need a babysitter. We will be there.
Go with your family. They need you more than I do.
I've changed my mind. Find your people.

You are about to give the command to attack when a human woman steps through the undead ranks to lead them.\n\nShe is wearing apprentice’s robes, the color of which you are certain are those of Hokan Ashir, the Circle mage.
Onwards! We march closer.
Watch them! I want to know what they are doing.

The apprentice has led the undead to harvest black ash. They are working under her command while she perches on a nearby boulder.\n\nAfter a while, her eyes shut and she seems to doze off. A loud splash from a nearby busting lava bubble awakens her with a jerk. As she flinches, so do the undead.
I have seen enough. Attack!
She controls them. If I kill her, they will falter.

With a rustle of air and fabric, the Circle mage Hokan manifests before you, obviously steaming with anger.

“Are we really here again so quickly,” he growls. “Listen, novice! You may be able to destroy my tower and steal my forge, the others might even warm to you, but I will not forget this insolence!

I will return one day, when you least expect it, and fight you with all my unleashed power. Then you will wish that I had killed you instead.”
Fine talk for someone I have now beaten twice.

Elynn sneaks closer, her dark clothes blending perfectly with her surroundings. Just as she had assessed, the undead crumble when the apprentice falls. As you begin extracting a soul from the mass of undead, she gives you a conflicted look.\n\n"Hokan is a monster and whatever he is doing must be stopped. But it's hard to accept what it takes sometimes."
You did well. You kept us all safe.

When there are no enemies left standing, you move towards one of the undead and begin to extract the soul. A fluttering feeling, like a bird's heart, accompanies the process that brings it into your hands.
I'll take control over them now.

As your invisible tendrils of magic spread out, the apprentice begins to look around for the source. She spots you but you have already started to wrestle control from her.\n\nA battle of wits ensues, with neither of you wanting to let go. You are able to take over a few of the undead, who begin to scrap with those still under her control.
You return to where you found the undead working. The apprentice has made sure some of them stand guard, so you are spotted right away.\n\n"Oh? Have you returned to dance some more?"
The extent of your [tutorial]Domain[/].
How many [tutorial]Apprentices[/] you currently have and the maximum you could keep under your tutelage.
The number of [tutorial]Rooms[/] unlocked in your tower.

Drill Instructor
Focus Channel

Crystal Growth
Sniper Tower
I found the Ether Distillate! Here!

Orim, the alchemist, tries to move the distraught Gurim out of the way.

Meticulously, he mixes liquids and powders, crushing the ether distillate into the tincture before cooking it all together and letting it cool down. Gurim just keeps pacing the entire time.

When the concoction is finally done, Orim tips the liquid over the crystal.

Thank you! Thank you, mage! The dwarf stumbles to his feet to shake your hand.\n\n"I will wait for you at the laboratory of the alchemist, Orim! I will... I will find some way to get my brother there safely! Please hurry, mage! Please!"
We shall meet you there.

She nods, glancing at the apprentice.

"I know. But at what cost?"

Elynn spontaneously gives the apprentice a burial, not so much as cleaning her blades before honoring her enemy in death.

"Go with grace to the River of Oblivion," she says with a grim look at the grave. "Be free of your master now."
Not if we strike first!
That's one more soul. We better keep going.
Greeting! How much for one of your undead?

The woman turns to you and gawks in disbelief.\n\n"You want to buy one of my units?" Her eyes travel from you to your banner and recognition flashes over her face. "Why, pray tell, would you want that?"
I just need the soul. How about it?
You know, never mind. I'll just take what I need.
Never mind. We need to go.
The woman smirks.\n\n"Of course you do. Be gone. And should you come back, I will make sure to greet you... properly."
Damn it. There won't be any sneaking around now...

She gives the offered coin pouch a look of distrust before grabbing it. Once she has assured herself it will not explode or vanish, she begins to smirk.

"Wrong move, mage."

She gives a signal with her hand and the undead rush towards you.
She betrayed us! Attack!
We can bring snow from outside to cool the path.
I can cool the room down enough to cross.
We'll just have to jump the magma.

You return to the mine where workers huddle outside, still worried for their trapped colleagues.\n\nThe magma chamber has not cooled in your absence, still heating the air to the point of physical discomfort.

You slowly make your way back to the cave in, trying not to let the constant grinding sound bore too deep into your mind to drive you mad.\n\nOnce again, you are faced with the dilemma of how to cross the ravine with only flimsy ropes to support you.
We have to try and cross.
We best return another time.
Let me make some safety adjustments.

You use all the wisdom of your long-practiced craft to reinforce the gap with pullies and mechanics scrapped together from what supplies you have and what you can find around you.\n\nThe effort is worth it, however, as it allows the rest of your company to get across the gap without injury.
There is a shut down mechanism. Give me a moment.

You return to the source of the grinding, the golems milling about deep in one of Silver Drift Hollow's many mines.\n\nThey seem to be patrolling the immediate area, perhaps some ancient defence that has been all but forgotten by the people of the settlement.
Let's move on.

Finally, mercifully, the boring noise stops as the last golem crashes to the floor and the light of its magical energy dies.\n\nYou swear you can still hear it drilling somewhere deep in your mind, but shake your head and look towards the end of the deep tunnels.
DEMONS LOOKING FOR MATHU GAR
WHY
WHO
OUR GENERAL MATHU GAR VANISHED\nIF YOU FIND HIM COME FIND US AND YOU WILL BE REWARDED
OK
Because
Mkay
You return to the spider-infested mine. The webs begin just that little bit closer to the entrance this time, as though the spiders are preparing to expand an empire towards the surface world.
Another mine cleared.
Roll it out the way, however exhausting that may be.

It proves exhausting indeed, most of your troupe expanding a lot of energy to shove the boulder far enough down the tunnel that it can be cleared out of the way.

Behind it though is a wondrous sight. The walls and ceiling of the cavern twinkle with crystals of blue and green, some breaking the light into rainbows.

Amid all the beauty you see long abandoned mining equipment and no further tunnels. You have finally reached the end.
Fire Lane
Ignore them. Not our problem.

Aye, one of the artisans replies to you.

“Some demons have sprung up from the lava around the Fireforge, pushing our expeditions back. I have no idea why they’ve appeared now but they’re wreaking havoc. We can’t send our craftsmen and excavators out with them about.

We’ve offered our most valuable glyphs as a reward for anyone able to rid us of them. So far, no luck.”
Count me in!
Not my business.
Fire Lane
Spreading fire and destruction wherever they tread, the demons show no reaction to your approaching banner. Thick clouds of smoke and ash billow around them.
I am an ally of the Circle mage, Uram.
Find out why they are here.

The demons stop their wanton destruction and stare at you with fiery eyes, processing the inquiry.\n\n“The tunnel diggers disturbed our homes and try to tame our heat!” one of the large horned beasts proclaims. “We will punish them and drive them away again. We will not stop until they are gone!”
Return to your realm. I will make them stop.
Can I pay you to leave this place?
The demon looks at you, eyes narrowed.\n\n"Go then, but if you fail we will return twice-fold!"
You have successfully put an end to the demons’ rampage.
Time to collect my reward.
You have my word, demon.
Try to negotiate with them.

The demon laughs, flames shooting from their mouth.\n\n"What would you have to offer to one such as me, mortal? I command flame and stone! My hordes can best the greatest of foes! What could interest me?"
Raw power?

Hmm,” the demon muses. “With this much power I could wage war on the other demon lords. Hmm.

Agreed, mageling. I will return to my realm and conquer new lands there!

With that, the demons vanish.
These souls as your price!
“Ah! Exquisite!” The demon’s eyes light up. “Such anger and pain. This will suffice. We shall feast well this day.”\n\nWith that, the demons vanish.
Then I have no option but to fight.
Fiery Lanes

You enter the hall of dwarven craftsmen and explain your promise to the demons to make the dwarves stop their expeditions into the lava fields.

The dwarves vehemently refuse, accusing you of being in league with the demons.

“You know how much it cost to establish our trade here? You expect us to just throw that all away?”
If it is gold you seek, I can pay.
Convince them it is their best chance.
It is in your best interest to take this deal.
I shall return with a recompense.

It takes considerable patience and convincing, but eventually they come around to the idea.\n\nTheir guild master addresses you: “With the way to the Fireforge now free, we don’t even need to dig around here anymore. We will make far better things there than we can even find here. If you guarantee the demons are gone, we agree to your deal.”
Then it is settled.

The dwarf snorts derisively.

“That doesn’t even cover a tenth of the cost. But… ugh, the main thing is to get to the Fireforge, I suppose. If the demons are truly gone, we will make a fortune from our crafts there, then this paltry sum won’t matter. Fine. I suppose.”

He snatches the purse, pocketing it and muttering: “For our troubles.”
You are welcome.

“Then it is time!” The assembled dwarves cheer loudly and begin to pack up their tools to make for the Fireforege.\n\n“You are invited to come and share in its bounty,” they tell you. “After all, it is you we should thank that we are able to access it. You are welcome any time.”
My thanks!
